{"plaguenum_articles": "583", "plague": [{"archive_id": "8211886", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR: (IT) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8211886", "date": "2020-09-26 15:47:01", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CHINA (04): (YUNNAN) BUBONIC, RODENTS\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 25 Sep 2020 22:58 CST\nSource: China News [in Chinese, translated DG, abridged, edited]\nhttp://www.chinanews.com/sh/2020/09-25/9300302.shtml\n\n\nOn 25 Sep 2020, the Plague Command Post of Yunnan's Menghai County reported an outbreak of plague among rodents in a remote village of Xiding Township, and following a proactive search, a suspected case of bubonic plague was found in a 3-year-old child who is now undergoing treatment. Local government activated a Level IV public health emergency response.\n\nAccording to reports, a village that is a 3-hour drive from the Menghai County seat recently found 3 rodents dead of unknown cause. The township government immediately reported to the county disease prevention and control center. The provincial level disease prevention and treatment institute and the state level disease control center's on-site epidemiological survey and lab results led to preliminary conclusions on 21 Sep 2020 that rodent plague had occurred in Xiding.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n\n[The specific rodent involved is not stated.\n\nPlague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_. Plague appears to be more prevalent this year (2020) in Mongolia. It is not clear that person-to-person spread has occurred.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a \"bubo.\" Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nYunnan Province, China: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/351]\nSee Also\nPlague - Mongolia (07): (DZ) bubonic 20200904.7747118\nPlague - USA (01): (NM) cat", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8189569", "date": "2020-09-26 15:47:01", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CHINA (04): (YUNNAN) BUBONIC, RODENTS\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 25 Sep 2020 22:58 CST\nSource: China News [in Chinese, translated DG, abridged, edited]\nhttp://www.chinanews.com/sh/2020/09-25/9300302.shtml\n\n\nOn 25 Sep 2020, the Plague Command Post of Yunnan's Menghai County reported an outbreak of plague among rodents in a remote village of Xiding Township, and following a proactive search, a suspected case of bubonic plague was found in a 3-year-old child who is now undergoing treatment. Local government activated a Level IV public health emergency response.\n\nAccording to reports, a village that is a 3-hour drive from the Menghai County seat recently found 3 rodents dead of unknown cause. The township government immediately reported to the county disease prevention and control center. The provincial level disease prevention and treatment institute and the state level disease control center's on-site epidemiological survey and lab results led to preliminary conclusions on 21 Sep 2020 that rodent plague had occurred in Xiding.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n\n[The specific rodent involved is not stated.\n\nPlague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_. Plague appears to be more prevalent this year (2020) in Mongolia. It is not clear that person-to-person spread has occurred.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a \"bubo.\" Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nYunnan Province, China: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/351]\nSee Also\nPlague - Mongolia (07): (DZ) bubonic 20200904.7747118\nPlague - Local government activated a Level IV public health emergency response.\n\nAccording to reports, a village that is a 3-hour drive from the Menghai County seat recently found 3 rodents dead of unknown cause. The township government immediately reported to the county disease prevention and control center. The provincial level disease prevention and treatment institute and the state level disease control center's on-site epidemiological survey and lab results led to preliminary conclusions on 21 Sep 2020 that rodent plague had occurred in Xiding.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n\n[The specific rodent involved is not stated.\n\nPlague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_. Plague appears to be more prevalent this year (2020) in Mongolia. It is not clear that person-to-person spread has occurred.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a \"bubo.\" Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nYunnan Province, China: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/351]\nSee Also\nPlague - Mongolia (07): (DZ) bubonic 20200904.7747118\nPlague - Local government activated a Level IV public health emergency response.\n\nAccording to reports, a village that is a 3-hour drive from the Menghai County seat recently found 3 rodents dead of unknown cause. The township government immediately reported to the county disease prevention and control center. The provincial level disease prevention and treatment institute and the state level disease control center's on-site epidemiological survey and lab results led to preliminary conclusions on 21 Sep 2020 that rodent plague had occurred in Xiding.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n\n[The specific rodent involved is not stated.\n\nPlague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_. Congo DR (10): (IT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7882267", "date": "2020-09-26 15:47:01", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CHINA (04): (YUNNAN) BUBONIC, RODENTS\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 25 Sep 2020 22:58 CST\nSource: China News [in Chinese, translated DG, abridged, edited]\nhttp://www.chinanews.com/sh/2020/09-25/9300302.shtml\n\n\nOn 25 Sep 2020, the Plague Command Post of Yunnan's Menghai County reported an outbreak of plague among rodents in a remote village of Xiding Township, and following a proactive search, a suspected case of bubonic plague was found in a 3-year-old child who is now undergoing treatment. Local government activated a Level IV public health emergency response.\n\nAccording to reports, a village that is a 3-hour drive from the Menghai County seat recently found 3 rodents dead of unknown cause. The township government immediately reported to the county disease prevention and control center. The provincial level disease prevention and treatment institute and the state level disease control center's on-site epidemiological survey and lab results led to preliminary conclusions on 21 Sep 2020 that rodent plague had occurred in Xiding.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n\n[The specific rodent involved is not stated.\n\nPlague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_. Plague appears to be more prevalent this year (2020) in Mongolia. It is not clear that person-to-person spread has occurred.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a \"bubo.\" Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nYunnan Province, China: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/351]\nSee Also\nPlague - Mongolia (07): (DZ) bubonic 20200904.7747118\nPlague - Mongolia (08): (HD) bubonic, marmot exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7820677", "date": "2020-09-26 15:47:01", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CHINA (04): (YUNNAN) BUBONIC, RODENTS\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 25 Sep 2020 22:58 CST\nSource: China News [in Chinese, translated DG, abridged, edited]\nhttp://www.chinanews.com/sh/2020/09-25/9300302.shtml\n\n\nOn 25 Sep 2020, the Plague Command Post of Yunnan's Menghai County reported an outbreak of plague among rodents in a remote village of Xiding Township, and following a proactive search, a suspected case of bubonic plague was found in a 3-year-old child who is now undergoing treatment. Local government activated a Level IV public health emergency response.\n\nAccording to reports, a village that is a 3-hour drive from the Menghai County seat recently found 3 rodents dead of unknown cause. The township government immediately reported to the county disease prevention and control center. The provincial level disease prevention and treatment institute and the state level disease control center's on-site epidemiological survey and lab results led to preliminary conclusions on 21 Sep 2020 that rodent plague had occurred in Xiding.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n\n[The specific rodent involved is not stated.\n\nPlague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_. Plague appears to be more prevalent this year (2020) in Mongolia. It is not clear that person-to-person spread has occurred.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a \"bubo.\" Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nYunnan Province, China: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/351]\nSee Also\nPlague - Mongolia (07): (DZ) bubonic 20200904.7747118\nPlague - China (04): (YN) bubonic, rodents", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7814905", "date": "2020-09-26 15:47:01", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CHINA (04): (YUNNAN) BUBONIC, RODENTS\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 25 Sep 2020 22:58 CST\nSource: China News [in Chinese, translated DG, abridged, edited]\nhttp://www.chinanews.com/sh/2020/09-25/9300302.shtml\n\n\nOn 25 Sep 2020, the Plague Command Post of Yunnan's Menghai County reported an outbreak of plague among rodents in a remote village of Xiding Township, and following a proactive search, a suspected case of bubonic plague was found in a 3-year-old child who is now undergoing treatment. Local government activated a Level IV public health emergency response.\n\nAccording to reports, a village that is a 3-hour drive from the Menghai County seat recently found 3 rodents dead of unknown cause. The township government immediately reported to the county disease prevention and control center. The provincial level disease prevention and treatment institute and the state level disease control center's on-site epidemiological survey and lab results led to preliminary conclusions on 21 Sep 2020 that rodent plague had occurred in Xiding.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n\n[The specific rodent involved is not stated.\n\nPlague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_. Plague appears to be more prevalent this year (2020) in Mongolia. It is not clear that person-to-person spread has occurred.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a \"bubo.\" Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nYunnan Province, China: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/351]\nSee Also\nPlague - Mongolia (07): (DZ) bubonic 20200904.7747118\nPlague - USA (06): (CO) human, cat exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7772408", "date": "2020-08-12 13:07:32", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - RUSSIA: (TUVA) GROUND SQUIRREL, ALERT\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 11 Aug 2020 10:20 PM MSK\nSource: UrduPoint News/Sputnik [edited]\nhttps://www.urdupoint.com/en/world/russian-watchdog-registers-plague-outbreaks-a-998939.html\n\n\nPlague was detected in ground squirrels in the Russian southeastern Republic of Tuva last month [July 2020], the country's consumer rights and human welfare watchdog [Rospotrebnadzor] said on Tuesday [11 Aug 2020], adding that the entire population engaged in livestock breeding in the area was subject to vaccination.\n\n\"There is an epizootic activity of Tuva mountain natural plague foci recorded almost every year since 1964. In July 2020, local epizootics in the habitat of long-tailed ground squirrels were registered on the territory of Mongun-Tayginskiy and Ovyursky [districts] of the Republic of Tuva. An active epizootic process was registered at one of the sites,\" Rospotrebnadzor said.\n\nThe watchdog added that as many as 4810 people had been vaccinated in the republic's affected areas.\n\n\"Field deratization has been carried out on 3.9 hectares [9.6 acres] of land. Medical institutions' epidemic readiness has been checked and training sessions to identify patients with plague have been carried out. Health education is also underway,\" Rospotrebnadzor noted.\n\nIn early July [2020], the republic's Agriculture Ministry called on the residents to observe preventive measures in connection with the bubonic plague outbreak in Mongolia. Since 2016, Russia has registered no cases of plague in humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-SoAs from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed-SoAs@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. Humans are at risk of becoming infected if they are exposed to rodent fleas.\n\nIn the natural foci of Tuva, the vector is the flea _Citellophilus tesquorum altaicus_ and the mammal host is the long-tailed ground squirrel (_Urocitellus undulatus_). For a picture see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long-tailed_ground_squirrel#/media/File:Spermophilus_undulatus1.jpg. - Mod.PMB\n\nMaps of Russia: https://www.usrbc.org/site/resources/russianmap and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/409]\nSee Also\nPlague - In July 2020, local epizootics in the habitat of long-tailed ground squirrels were registered on the territory of Mongun-Tayginskiy and Ovyursky [districts] of the Republic of Tuva. Health education is also underway,\" Rospotrebnadzor noted.\n\nIn early July [2020], the republic's Agriculture Ministry called on the residents to observe preventive measures in connection with the bubonic plague outbreak in Mongolia. In July 2020, local epizootics in the habitat of long-tailed ground squirrels were registered on the territory of Mongun-Tayginskiy and Ovyursky [districts] of the Republic of Tuva. An active epizootic process was registered at one of the sites,\" Rospotrebnadzor said.\n\nThe watchdog added that as many as 4810 people had been vaccinated in the republic's affected areas.\n\n\"Field deratization has been carried out on 3.9 hectares [9.6 acres] of land. Medical institutions' epidemic readiness has been checked and training sessions to identify patients with plague have been carried out. Health education is also underway,\" Rospotrebnadzor noted.\n\nIn early July [2020], the republic's Agriculture Ministry called on the residents to observe preventive measures in connection with the bubonic plague outbreak in Mongolia. Since 2016, Russia has registered no cases of plague in humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-SoAs from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed-SoAs@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. USA: (ID) ground squirrel, alert 20150529.3394344\n2014\n----\nPlague, animal - USA (05): (CA) squirrel 20140804.2656788\n.................................................sb/pmb/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-07-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2020-03-16 00:00:00", "1964-03-16 00:00:00", "2020-07-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ovyursky", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7691613", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (05): (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7691613", "date": "2020-08-12 13:07:32", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - RUSSIA: (TUVA) GROUND SQUIRREL, ALERT\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 11 Aug 2020 10:20 PM MSK\nSource: UrduPoint News/Sputnik [edited]\nhttps://www.urdupoint.com/en/world/russian-watchdog-registers-plague-outbreaks-a-998939.html\n\n\nPlague was detected in ground squirrels in the Russian southeastern Republic of Tuva last month [July 2020], the country's consumer rights and human welfare watchdog [Rospotrebnadzor] said on Tuesday [11 Aug 2020], adding that the entire population engaged in livestock breeding in the area was subject to vaccination.\n\n\"There is an epizootic activity of Tuva mountain natural plague foci recorded almost every year since 1964. In July 2020, local epizootics in the habitat of long-tailed ground squirrels were registered on the territory of Mongun-Tayginskiy and Ovyursky [districts] of the Republic of Tuva. An active epizootic process was registered at one of the sites,\" Rospotrebnadzor said.\n\nThe watchdog added that as many as 4810 people had been vaccinated in the republic's affected areas.\n\n\"Field deratization has been carried out on 3.9 hectares [9.6 acres] of land. Medical institutions' epidemic readiness has been checked and training sessions to identify patients with plague have been carried out. Health education is also underway,\" Rospotrebnadzor noted.\n\nIn early July [2020], the republic's Agriculture Ministry called on the residents to observe preventive measures in connection with the bubonic plague outbreak in Mongolia. Since 2016, Russia has registered no cases of plague in humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-SoAs from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed-SoAs@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. Humans are at risk of becoming infected if they are exposed to rodent fleas.\n\nIn the natural foci of Tuva, the vector is the flea _Citellophilus tesquorum altaicus_ and the mammal host is the long-tailed ground squirrel (_Urocitellus undulatus_). For a picture see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long-tailed_ground_squirrel#/media/File:Spermophilus_undulatus1.jpg. - Mod.PMB\n\nMaps of Russia: https://www.usrbc.org/site/resources/russianmap and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/409]\nSee Also\nPlague - In July 2020, local epizootics in the habitat of long-tailed ground squirrels were registered on the territory of Mongun-Tayginskiy and Ovyursky [districts] of the Republic of Tuva. Health education is also underway,\" Rospotrebnadzor noted.\n\nIn early July [2020], the republic's Agriculture Ministry called on the residents to observe preventive measures in connection with the bubonic plague outbreak in Mongolia. Russia: (TU) ground squirrel, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7670859", "date": "2020-08-12 13:07:32", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - RUSSIA: (TUVA) GROUND SQUIRREL, ALERT\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 11 Aug 2020 10:20 PM MSK\nSource: UrduPoint News/Sputnik [edited]\nhttps://www.urdupoint.com/en/world/russian-watchdog-registers-plague-outbreaks-a-998939.html\n\n\nPlague was detected in ground squirrels in the Russian southeastern Republic of Tuva last month [July 2020], the country's consumer rights and human welfare watchdog [Rospotrebnadzor] said on Tuesday [11 Aug 2020], adding that the entire population engaged in livestock breeding in the area was subject to vaccination.\n\n\"There is an epizootic activity of Tuva mountain natural plague foci recorded almost every year since 1964. In July 2020, local epizootics in the habitat of long-tailed ground squirrels were registered on the territory of Mongun-Tayginskiy and Ovyursky [districts] of the Republic of Tuva. An active epizootic process was registered at one of the sites,\" Rospotrebnadzor said.\n\nThe watchdog added that as many as 4810 people had been vaccinated in the republic's affected areas.\n\n\"Field deratization has been carried out on 3.9 hectares [9.6 acres] of land. Medical institutions' epidemic readiness has been checked and training sessions to identify patients with plague have been carried out. Health education is also underway,\" Rospotrebnadzor noted.\n\nIn early July [2020], the republic's Agriculture Ministry called on the residents to observe preventive measures in connection with the bubonic plague outbreak in Mongolia. Since 2016, Russia has registered no cases of plague in humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-SoAs from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed-SoAs@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. Humans are at risk of becoming infected if they are exposed to rodent fleas.\n\nIn the natural foci of Tuva, the vector is the flea _Citellophilus tesquorum altaicus_ and the mammal host is the long-tailed ground squirrel (_Urocitellus undulatus_). For a picture see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long-tailed_ground_squirrel#/media/File:Spermophilus_undulatus1.jpg. - Mod.PMB\n\nMaps of Russia: https://www.usrbc.org/site/resources/russianmap and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/409]\nSee Also\nPlague - USA: (ID) ground squirrel, alert 20150529.3394344\n2014\n----\nPlague, animal - USA (05): (CA) squirrel 20140804.2656788\n.................................................sb/pmb/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-07-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2020-03-16 00:00:00", "1964-03-16 00:00:00", "2020-07-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ovyursky", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7660510", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - China (03): (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7660510", "date": "2020-07-09 16:30:03", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MONGOLIA (03): MARMOT MEAT CONSUMPTION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 7 Jul 2020\nSource: CNN WORLD [edited]\nhttps://edition.cnn.com/2020/07/07/asia/russia-marmot-hunting-plague-scli-intl/index.html\n\n\nRussian authorities have warned people near the country's border with Mongolia not to hunt or eat marmots after an outbreak of bubonic plague.\n\nTwo cases of the plague were recorded in the Khovd province in western Mongolia, reported Russian state media agency TASS on [Tue 7 Jul 2020].\n\nOfficials from the Republican Ministry of Agriculture and Food told citizens in the border area not to hunt marmots or eat marmot meat, and take preventive measures against insect bites.\n\nMarmots are large ground squirrels, a type of rodent, that have historically been linked to plague outbreaks in the region. Rodents are the main [reservoir] of plague transmission from animals to humans, and the disease can also be passed on through flea bites. Bubonic plague, which is one of plague's 3 forms, causes painful, swollen lymph nodes, as well as fever, chills, and coughing.\n\nPlague killed an estimated 50 million people in Europe during the Black Death pandemic in the Middle Ages, but modern antibiotics can prevent complications and death if administered quickly enough.\n\nMongolia quarantined its region near the Russian border last week [1 Jul 2020] after lab tests showed 2 cases of bubonic plague linked to the consumption of marmot meat, the country's health officials said.\n\nMongolia's National Center for Zoonotic Diseases said last week it had identified and tested 146 people who had come into contact with the 2 infected people. The center also identified 504 people of secondary contact in the Khovd province.\n\nThe Russian Embassy in Mongolia said \"there are no grounds for serious concern\" as the Mongolian authorities have imposed travel restrictions and isolated infected individuals, according to Russian state-run news agency RIA Novosti.\n\nThe embassy also cited Sergei Diorditsu, a World Health Organization (WHO) representative in Mongolia, who reportedly said the province sees seasonal outbreaks of the plague, according to RIA Novosti. \"There are natural foci of plague in Mongolia and the disease is spread by tarbagans [Mongolian marmots],\" said the embassy. \"The problem is that local residents who, despite all prohibitions and recommendations of local authorities, continue to hunt them and eat them, as this is a local delicacy.\"\n\nAuthorities in the Chinese region of Inner Mongolia have also confirmed a case of the plague. The case in the city of Bayannur, northwest of Beijing, was confirmed [Tue 7 Jul 2020], according to state-run Xinhua news agency.\n\nIn 2019 a couple in Mongolia died after eating a raw marmot kidney, triggering a quarantine that left several tourists stranded in the region.\n\nAnywhere from 1000 to 2000 people get the plague every year, according to the WHO, but that estimate does not account for unreported cases.\n\n[Byline: Jack Guy and Mary Ilyushina]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Siberian marmot (_Marmota sibirica_) is a commonly hunted wildlife species in Mongolia, for their meat and skin.\n\nPlague, caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic in wild rodent populations (mainly marmots) over large rural areas of Mongolia. Natural plague foci have occurred over 28.3% of Mongolia, and 47.1% of these foci are highly active. Highly active plague foci exist mainly in the western part of Mongolia. A total of 27% of all plague cultures were isolated from ectoparasites of 12 species of endemic mammals and 1 species of bird.\n\nMost plague cultures isolated from ectoparasites of mammals were from fleas (91.5%). The majority of cultures isolated from fleas were from marmot fleas (64.5% of all fleas). The marmot flea (_Oropsylla silantiewi_) is considered the primary vector of plague. [Portions of this comment were extracted from https://doi.org/10.1089/vbz.2009.0047]. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nMongolia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1]\nSee Also\nPlague - Mongolia (02): (HD) bubonic, marmot exposure 20200702.7533218\nPlague - Rodents are the main [reservoir] of plague transmission from animals to humans, and the disease can also be passed on through flea bites. Bubonic plague, which is one of plague's 3 forms, causes painful, swollen lymph nodes, as well as fever, chills, and coughing.\n\nPlague killed an estimated 50 million people in Europe during the Black Death pandemic in the Middle Ages, but modern antibiotics can prevent complications and death if administered quickly enough.\n\nMongolia quarantined its region near the Russian border last week [1 Jul 2020] after lab tests showed 2 cases of bubonic plague linked to the consumption of marmot meat, the country's health officials said.\n\nMongolia's National Center for Zoonotic Diseases said last week it had identified and tested 146 people who had come into contact with the 2 infected people. The center also identified 504 people of secondary contact in the Khovd province.\n\nThe Russian Embassy in Mongolia said \"there are no grounds for serious concern\" as the Mongolian authorities have imposed travel restrictions and isolated infected individuals, according to Russian state-run news agency RIA Novosti.\n\nThe embassy also cited Sergei Diorditsu, a World Health Organization (WHO) representative in Mongolia, who reportedly said the province sees seasonal outbreaks of the plague, according to RIA Novosti. \"There are natural foci of plague in Mongolia and the disease is spread by tarbagans [Mongolian marmots],\" said the embassy. \"The problem is that local residents who, despite all prohibitions and recommendations of local authorities, continue to hunt them and eat them, as this is a local delicacy.\"\n\nAuthorities in the Chinese region of Inner Mongolia have also confirmed a case of the plague. Mongolia & China: background (02) 20000920.1620\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia & China: Background 20000802.1290\nPlague, bubonic, marmots - Mongolia: RFI 20000801.1274\n.................................................sb/pmb/ao/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bayannur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Background", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Khovd", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7606707", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR (07): (IT) clusters, fatal, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7606707", "date": "2020-07-09 16:30:03", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MONGOLIA (03): MARMOT MEAT CONSUMPTION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 7 Jul 2020\nSource: CNN WORLD [edited]\nhttps://edition.cnn.com/2020/07/07/asia/russia-marmot-hunting-plague-scli-intl/index.html\n\n\nRussian authorities have warned people near the country's border with Mongolia not to hunt or eat marmots after an outbreak of bubonic plague.\n\nTwo cases of the plague were recorded in the Khovd province in western Mongolia, reported Russian state media agency TASS on [Tue 7 Jul 2020].\n\nOfficials from the Republican Ministry of Agriculture and Food told citizens in the border area not to hunt marmots or eat marmot meat, and take preventive measures against insect bites.\n\nMarmots are large ground squirrels, a type of rodent, that have historically been linked to plague outbreaks in the region. Rodents are the main [reservoir] of plague transmission from animals to humans, and the disease can also be passed on through flea bites. Bubonic plague, which is one of plague's 3 forms, causes painful, swollen lymph nodes, as well as fever, chills, and coughing.\n\nPlague killed an estimated 50 million people in Europe during the Black Death pandemic in the Middle Ages, but modern antibiotics can prevent complications and death if administered quickly enough.\n\nMongolia quarantined its region near the Russian border last week [1 Jul 2020] after lab tests showed 2 cases of bubonic plague linked to the consumption of marmot meat, the country's health officials said.\n\nMongolia's National Center for Zoonotic Diseases said last week it had identified and tested 146 people who had come into contact with the 2 infected people. The center also identified 504 people of secondary contact in the Khovd province.\n\nThe Russian Embassy in Mongolia said \"there are no grounds for serious concern\" as the Mongolian authorities have imposed travel restrictions and isolated infected individuals, according to Russian state-run news agency RIA Novosti.\n\nThe embassy also cited Sergei Diorditsu, a World Health Organization (WHO) representative in Mongolia, who reportedly said the province sees seasonal outbreaks of the plague, according to RIA Novosti. \"There are natural foci of plague in Mongolia and the disease is spread by tarbagans [Mongolian marmots],\" said the embassy. \"The problem is that local residents who, despite all prohibitions and recommendations of local authorities, continue to hunt them and eat them, as this is a local delicacy.\"\n\nAuthorities in the Chinese region of Inner Mongolia have also confirmed a case of the plague. The case in the city of Bayannur, northwest of Beijing, was confirmed [Tue 7 Jul 2020], according to state-run Xinhua news agency.\n\nIn 2019 a couple in Mongolia died after eating a raw marmot kidney, triggering a quarantine that left several tourists stranded in the region.\n\nAnywhere from 1000 to 2000 people get the plague every year, according to the WHO, but that estimate does not account for unreported cases.\n\n[Byline: Jack Guy and Mary Ilyushina]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Siberian marmot (_Marmota sibirica_) is a commonly hunted wildlife species in Mongolia, for their meat and skin.\n\nPlague, caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic in wild rodent populations (mainly marmots) over large rural areas of Mongolia. Natural plague foci have occurred over 28.3% of Mongolia, and 47.1% of these foci are highly active. Highly active plague foci exist mainly in the western part of Mongolia. A total of 27% of all plague cultures were isolated from ectoparasites of 12 species of endemic mammals and 1 species of bird.\n\nMost plague cultures isolated from ectoparasites of mammals were from fleas (91.5%). The majority of cultures isolated from fleas were from marmot fleas (64.5% of all fleas). The marmot flea (_Oropsylla silantiewi_) is considered the primary vector of plague. [Portions of this comment were extracted from https://doi.org/10.1089/vbz.2009.0047]. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nMongolia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1]\nSee Also\nPlague - Mongolia (02): (HD) bubonic, marmot exposure 20200702.7533218\nPlague - Mongolia 20020919.5361\n2001\n----\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia (Central): correction 20010904.2115\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia (Central) 20010808.1871\n2000\n----\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia & China: background (03) 20000924.1645\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia & China: background (02) 20000920.1620\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia & China: Background 20000802.1290\nPlague, bubonic, marmots - Mongolia: RFI 20000801.1274\n.................................................sb/pmb/ao/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bayannur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Background", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Khovd", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7591590", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Rodents are the main [reservoir] of plague transmission from animals to humans, and the disease can also be passed on through flea bites. Bubonic plague, which is one of plague's 3 forms, causes painful, swollen lymph nodes, as well as fever, chills, and coughing.\n\nPlague killed an estimated 50 million people in Europe during the Black Death pandemic in the Middle Ages, but modern antibiotics can prevent complications and death if administered quickly enough.\n\nMongolia quarantined its region near the Russian border last week [1 Jul 2020] after lab tests showed 2 cases of bubonic plague linked to the consumption of marmot meat, the country's health officials said.\n\nMongolia's National Center for Zoonotic Diseases said last week it had identified and tested 146 people who had come into contact with the 2 infected people. The case in the city of Bayannur, northwest of Beijing, was confirmed [Tue 7 Jul 2020], according to state-run Xinhua news agency.\n\nIn 2019 a couple in Mongolia died after eating a raw marmot kidney, triggering a quarantine that left several tourists stranded in the region.\n\nAnywhere from 1000 to 2000 people get the plague every year, according to the WHO, but that estimate does not account for unreported cases.\n\n[Byline: Jack Guy and Mary Ilyushina]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Siberian marmot (_Marmota sibirica_) is a commonly hunted wildlife species in Mongolia, for their meat and skin.\n\nPlague, caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic in wild rodent populations (mainly marmots) over large rural areas of Mongolia. Rodents are the main [reservoir] of plague transmission from animals to humans, and the disease can also be passed on through flea bites. Bubonic plague, which is one of plague's 3 forms, causes painful, swollen lymph nodes, as well as fever, chills, and coughing.\n\nPlague killed an estimated 50 million people in Europe during the Black Death pandemic in the Middle Ages, but modern antibiotics can prevent complications and death if administered quickly enough.\n\nMongolia quarantined its region near the Russian border last week [1 Jul 2020] after lab tests showed 2 cases of bubonic plague linked to the consumption of marmot meat, the country's health officials said.\n\nMongolia's National Center for Zoonotic Diseases said last week it had identified and tested 146 people who had come into contact with the 2 infected people. The center also identified 504 people of secondary contact in the Khovd province.\n\nThe Russian Embassy in Mongolia said \"there are no grounds for serious concern\" as the Mongolian authorities have imposed travel restrictions and isolated infected individuals, according to Russian state-run news agency RIA Novosti.\n\nThe embassy also cited Sergei Diorditsu, a World Health Organization (WHO) representative in Mongolia, who reportedly said the province sees seasonal outbreaks of the plague, according to RIA Novosti. \"There are natural foci of plague in Mongolia and the disease is spread by tarbagans [Mongolian marmots],\" said the embassy. \"The problem is that local residents who, despite all prohibitions and recommendations of local authorities, continue to hunt them and eat them, as this is a local delicacy.\"\n\nAuthorities in the Chinese region of Inner Mongolia have also confirmed a case of the plague. Mongolia (03): marmot meat consumption", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7557341", "date": "2020-07-09 16:30:03", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MONGOLIA (03): MARMOT MEAT CONSUMPTION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 7 Jul 2020\nSource: CNN WORLD [edited]\nhttps://edition.cnn.com/2020/07/07/asia/russia-marmot-hunting-plague-scli-intl/index.html\n\n\nRussian authorities have warned people near the country's border with Mongolia not to hunt or eat marmots after an outbreak of bubonic plague.\n\nTwo cases of the plague were recorded in the Khovd province in western Mongolia, reported Russian state media agency TASS on [Tue 7 Jul 2020].\n\nOfficials from the Republican Ministry of Agriculture and Food told citizens in the border area not to hunt marmots or eat marmot meat, and take preventive measures against insect bites.\n\nMarmots are large ground squirrels, a type of rodent, that have historically been linked to plague outbreaks in the region. Rodents are the main [reservoir] of plague transmission from animals to humans, and the disease can also be passed on through flea bites. Bubonic plague, which is one of plague's 3 forms, causes painful, swollen lymph nodes, as well as fever, chills, and coughing.\n\nPlague killed an estimated 50 million people in Europe during the Black Death pandemic in the Middle Ages, but modern antibiotics can prevent complications and death if administered quickly enough.\n\nMongolia quarantined its region near the Russian border last week [1 Jul 2020] after lab tests showed 2 cases of bubonic plague linked to the consumption of marmot meat, the country's health officials said.\n\nMongolia's National Center for Zoonotic Diseases said last week it had identified and tested 146 people who had come into contact with the 2 infected people. The center also identified 504 people of secondary contact in the Khovd province.\n\nThe Russian Embassy in Mongolia said \"there are no grounds for serious concern\" as the Mongolian authorities have imposed travel restrictions and isolated infected individuals, according to Russian state-run news agency RIA Novosti.\n\nThe embassy also cited Sergei Diorditsu, a World Health Organization (WHO) representative in Mongolia, who reportedly said the province sees seasonal outbreaks of the plague, according to RIA Novosti. \"There are natural foci of plague in Mongolia and the disease is spread by tarbagans [Mongolian marmots],\" said the embassy. \"The problem is that local residents who, despite all prohibitions and recommendations of local authorities, continue to hunt them and eat them, as this is a local delicacy.\"\n\nAuthorities in the Chinese region of Inner Mongolia have also confirmed a case of the plague. The case in the city of Bayannur, northwest of Beijing, was confirmed [Tue 7 Jul 2020], according to state-run Xinhua news agency.\n\nIn 2019 a couple in Mongolia died after eating a raw marmot kidney, triggering a quarantine that left several tourists stranded in the region.\n\nAnywhere from 1000 to 2000 people get the plague every year, according to the WHO, but that estimate does not account for unreported cases.\n\n[Byline: Jack Guy and Mary Ilyushina]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Siberian marmot (_Marmota sibirica_) is a commonly hunted wildlife species in Mongolia, for their meat and skin.\n\nPlague, caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic in wild rodent populations (mainly marmots) over large rural areas of Mongolia. Natural plague foci have occurred over 28.3% of Mongolia, and 47.1% of these foci are highly active. Highly active plague foci exist mainly in the western part of Mongolia. A total of 27% of all plague cultures were isolated from ectoparasites of 12 species of endemic mammals and 1 species of bird.\n\nMost plague cultures isolated from ectoparasites of mammals were from fleas (91.5%). The majority of cultures isolated from fleas were from marmot fleas (64.5% of all fleas). The marmot flea (_Oropsylla silantiewi_) is considered the primary vector of plague. [Portions of this comment were extracted from https://doi.org/10.1089/vbz.2009.0047]. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nMongolia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1]\nSee Also\nPlague - Mongolia (02): (HD) bubonic, marmot exposure 20200702.7533218\nPlague - Mongolia: (HD) bubonic, marmot exposure 20200701.7529689\n2019\n----\nPlague - Mongolia (03): (BO) bubonic, marmot, fatal, quarantine 20190506.6456511\nPlague - Mongolia (02): (BO) bubonic, marmot, fatal, quarantine 20190503.6454287\nPlague - Mongolia: (BO) bubonic, susp, fatal, quarantine 20190502.6452212\n2009\n----\nPlague, human - Mongolia: (BO), RFI 20090612.2177\n2007\n----\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia (Gobisumber) 20070924.3163\nPlague, human, fatal - Mongolia 20020919.5361\n2001\n----\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia (Central): correction 20010904.2115\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia (Central) 20010808.1871\n2000\n----\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia & China: background (03) 20000924.1645\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia & China: background (02) 20000920.1620\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia & China: Background 20000802.1290\nPlague, bubonic, marmots - Mongolia: RFI 20000801.1274\n.................................................sb/pmb/ao/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bayannur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Background", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Khovd", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7546991", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR (06): (IT) bubonic, clusters, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7546991", "date": "2020-04-14 18:27:28", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA: (WYOMING) COUGAR\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 9 Apr 2020\nSource: Belleville News Democrat [edited]\nhttps://www.bnd.com/news/nation-world/national/article241909026.html\n\n\nIn Yellowstone, cougars are facing an epidemic of their own: Bubonic plague.\n\nThe flea-borne disease, most famous for killing half of Europe during the medieval ages, is showing up in the cougar population inhabiting the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem [GYE], according to a recent study.\n\nFindings suggest it could be widespread. Of the 28 big cats researchers tested, 12 were infected or had been infected, according to the study published in Environmental Conservation.\n\n\"This suggests that: (bubonic plague) may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed,\" it said, also adding that plague may be a \"significant\" cause of death for the animals.\n\nResearchers carried out the study over the course of 9 years, following the discovery of 2 dead cougars, a mother and her cub, in Wyoming, the Smithsonian Magazine said.\n\nThe deaths weren't in and of themselves surprising, lead researcher Mark Elbroch told Livescience.\n\nIt was the winter, and so starvation was the presumed culprit, but when the true cause of death was discovered, it \"was a shocker,\" he told the outlet.\n\nResearchers said it's very unlikely the average person would ever catch plague from a mountain lion, but given that the disease is capable of animal-to-human transmission, they recommended warnings for some.\n\n\"We would also emphasize that hunters and others handling pumas in this region should be made aware of the possibility of exposure,\" the study said.\n\nCougar behavior makes them a poor means of transferring diseases to people, but as Elbroch's team points out, their high rate of infection means the Yellowstone ecosystem itself could be a hotbed of plague.\n\nA Boy Scout came down with plague in 2008 following a camping trip in Yellowstone National Park, the Jackson Hole News & Guide reported.\n\n\"Plague is very much a part of the landscape in the western U.S., and wild animals are frequently exposed to it,\" a USDA researcher Sarah Bevins told National Geographic. \"Human plague infections are still relatively rare ... but untreated plague infections are still just as deadly as they were 500 years ago.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels, chipmunks and prairie dogs are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nCarnivores (like cougars) may be infected through fleabite or ingestion of infected rodents. Studies of black bears (another carnivore) in California found plague antibody prevalence from 15% to 36%.\n\nThe study referred to can be accessed at https://doi.org/10.1017/S0376892920000065. The abstract reads: \"We tested for plague (_Yersinia pestis_) in a puma population in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem (GYE) over 9 years, overlapping a case when a boy in the area became infected with plague. Antibodies to _Y. pestis_ were detected in 8 of 17 (47%) pumas tested by complementenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, and the organism itself was detected in 4 of 11 (36%) pumas tested after necropsy. Neither puma sex nor age was significantly associated with _Y. pestis_ exposure or mortality, although our sample size was small. The overall prevalence of exposure we recorded was similar to that found along the western slope of Colorado, which is adjacent to the Four Corners region, a known plague hotspot in the USA. This suggests that: (1) _Y. pestis_ may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed; (2) plague is a significant source of mortality for local pumas (6.6% of sub-adult and adult mortality); and (3) pumas may be a useful sentinel for potential risk of plague exposure to humans throughout the West. We would also emphasize that hunters and others handling pumas in this region should be made aware of the possibility of exposure.\" - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nWyoming, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nPlague - Of the 28 big cats researchers tested, 12 were infected or had been infected, according to the study published in Environmental Conservation.\n\n\"This suggests that: (bubonic plague) may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed,\" it said, also adding that plague may be a \"significant\" cause of death for the animals.\n\nResearchers carried out the study over the course of 9 years, following the discovery of 2 dead cougars, a mother and her cub, in Wyoming, the Smithsonian Magazine said.\n\nThe deaths weren't in and of themselves surprising, lead researcher Mark Elbroch told Livescience.\n\nIt was the winter, and so starvation was the presumed culprit, but when the true cause of death was discovered, it \"was a shocker,\" he told the outlet.\n\nResearchers said it's very unlikely the average person would ever catch plague from a mountain lion, but given that the disease is capable of animal-to-human transmission, they recommended warnings for some.\n\n\"We would also emphasize that hunters and others handling pumas in this region should be made aware of the possibility of exposure,\" the study said.\n\nCougar behavior makes them a poor means of transferring diseases to people, but as Elbroch's team points out, their high rate of infection means the Yellowstone ecosystem itself could be a hotbed of plague.\n\nA Boy Scout came down with plague in 2008 following a camping trip in Yellowstone National Park, the Jackson Hole News & Guide reported.\n\n\"Plague is very much a part of the landscape in the western U.S., and wild animals are frequently exposed to it,\" a USDA researcher Sarah Bevins told National Geographic. \"Human plague infections are still relatively rare ... but untreated plague infections are still just as deadly as they were 500 years ago.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels, chipmunks and prairie dogs are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nCarnivores (like cougars) may be infected through fleabite or ingestion of infected rodents. Studies of black bears (another carnivore) in California found plague antibody prevalence from 15% to 36%.\n\nThe study referred to can be accessed at https://doi.org/10.1017/S0376892920000065. The abstract reads: \"We tested for plague (_Yersinia pestis_) in a puma population in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem (GYE) over 9 years, overlapping a case when a boy in the area became infected with plague. Antibodies to _Y. pestis_ were detected in 8 of 17 (47%) pumas tested by complementenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, and the organism itself was detected in 4 of 11 (36%) pumas tested after necropsy. Neither puma sex nor age was significantly associated with _Y. pestis_ exposure or mortality, although our sample size was small. The overall prevalence of exposure we recorded was similar to that found along the western slope of Colorado, which is adjacent to the Four Corners region, a known plague hotspot in the USA. This suggests that: (1) _Y. pestis_ may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed; (2) plague is a significant source of mortality for local pumas (6.6% of sub-adult and adult mortality); and (3) pumas may be a useful sentinel for potential risk of plague exposure to humans throughout the West. We would also emphasize that hunters and others handling pumas in this region should be made aware of the possibility of exposure.\" - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nWyoming, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nPlague - Mongolia (02): (HD) bubonic, marmot exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7533218", "date": "2020-04-14 18:27:28", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA: (WYOMING) COUGAR\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 9 Apr 2020\nSource: Belleville News Democrat [edited]\nhttps://www.bnd.com/news/nation-world/national/article241909026.html\n\n\nIn Yellowstone, cougars are facing an epidemic of their own: Bubonic plague.\n\nThe flea-borne disease, most famous for killing half of Europe during the medieval ages, is showing up in the cougar population inhabiting the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem [GYE], according to a recent study.\n\nFindings suggest it could be widespread. Of the 28 big cats researchers tested, 12 were infected or had been infected, according to the study published in Environmental Conservation.\n\n\"This suggests that: (bubonic plague) may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed,\" it said, also adding that plague may be a \"significant\" cause of death for the animals.\n\nResearchers carried out the study over the course of 9 years, following the discovery of 2 dead cougars, a mother and her cub, in Wyoming, the Smithsonian Magazine said.\n\nThe deaths weren't in and of themselves surprising, lead researcher Mark Elbroch told Livescience.\n\nIt was the winter, and so starvation was the presumed culprit, but when the true cause of death was discovered, it \"was a shocker,\" he told the outlet.\n\nResearchers said it's very unlikely the average person would ever catch plague from a mountain lion, but given that the disease is capable of animal-to-human transmission, they recommended warnings for some.\n\n\"We would also emphasize that hunters and others handling pumas in this region should be made aware of the possibility of exposure,\" the study said.\n\nCougar behavior makes them a poor means of transferring diseases to people, but as Elbroch's team points out, their high rate of infection means the Yellowstone ecosystem itself could be a hotbed of plague.\n\nA Boy Scout came down with plague in 2008 following a camping trip in Yellowstone National Park, the Jackson Hole News & Guide reported.\n\n\"Plague is very much a part of the landscape in the western U.S., and wild animals are frequently exposed to it,\" a USDA researcher Sarah Bevins told National Geographic. \"Human plague infections are still relatively rare ... but untreated plague infections are still just as deadly as they were 500 years ago.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels, chipmunks and prairie dogs are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nCarnivores (like cougars) may be infected through fleabite or ingestion of infected rodents. Studies of black bears (another carnivore) in California found plague antibody prevalence from 15% to 36%.\n\nThe study referred to can be accessed at https://doi.org/10.1017/S0376892920000065. The abstract reads: \"We tested for plague (_Yersinia pestis_) in a puma population in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem (GYE) over 9 years, overlapping a case when a boy in the area became infected with plague. Antibodies to _Y. pestis_ were detected in 8 of 17 (47%) pumas tested by complementenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, and the organism itself was detected in 4 of 11 (36%) pumas tested after necropsy. Neither puma sex nor age was significantly associated with _Y. pestis_ exposure or mortality, although our sample size was small. The overall prevalence of exposure we recorded was similar to that found along the western slope of Colorado, which is adjacent to the Four Corners region, a known plague hotspot in the USA. This suggests that: (1) _Y. pestis_ may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed; (2) plague is a significant source of mortality for local pumas (6.6% of sub-adult and adult mortality); and (3) pumas may be a useful sentinel for potential risk of plague exposure to humans throughout the West. We would also emphasize that hunters and others handling pumas in this region should be made aware of the possibility of exposure.\" - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nWyoming, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nPlague - USA: (NM) zoo 20140729.2643587\nPlague - USA (02): (CO) pneumonic 20140710.2600593\nPlague - USA: (NM) pneumonic 20140425.2430602\nand other items in the archives\n.................................................sb/pmb/msp/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-04-11 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Livescience", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yellowstone", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "National Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7529689", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Mongolia: (HD) bubonic, marmot exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7529689", "date": "2020-04-14 18:27:28", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA: (WYOMING) COUGAR\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 9 Apr 2020\nSource: Belleville News Democrat [edited]\nhttps://www.bnd.com/news/nation-world/national/article241909026.html\n\n\nIn Yellowstone, cougars are facing an epidemic of their own: Bubonic plague.\n\nThe flea-borne disease, most famous for killing half of Europe during the medieval ages, is showing up in the cougar population inhabiting the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem [GYE], according to a recent study.\n\nFindings suggest it could be widespread. Of the 28 big cats researchers tested, 12 were infected or had been infected, according to the study published in Environmental Conservation.\n\n\"This suggests that: (bubonic plague) may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed,\" it said, also adding that plague may be a \"significant\" cause of death for the animals.\n\nResearchers carried out the study over the course of 9 years, following the discovery of 2 dead cougars, a mother and her cub, in Wyoming, the Smithsonian Magazine said.\n\nThe deaths weren't in and of themselves surprising, lead researcher Mark Elbroch told Livescience.\n\nIt was the winter, and so starvation was the presumed culprit, but when the true cause of death was discovered, it \"was a shocker,\" he told the outlet.\n\nResearchers said it's very unlikely the average person would ever catch plague from a mountain lion, but given that the disease is capable of animal-to-human transmission, they recommended warnings for some.\n\n\"We would also emphasize that hunters and others handling pumas in this region should be made aware of the possibility of exposure,\" the study said.\n\nCougar behavior makes them a poor means of transferring diseases to people, but as Elbroch's team points out, their high rate of infection means the Yellowstone ecosystem itself could be a hotbed of plague.\n\nA Boy Scout came down with plague in 2008 following a camping trip in Yellowstone National Park, the Jackson Hole News & Guide reported.\n\n\"Plague is very much a part of the landscape in the western U.S., and wild animals are frequently exposed to it,\" a USDA researcher Sarah Bevins told National Geographic. \"Human plague infections are still relatively rare ... but untreated plague infections are still just as deadly as they were 500 years ago.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels, chipmunks and prairie dogs are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nCarnivores (like cougars) may be infected through fleabite or ingestion of infected rodents. Studies of black bears (another carnivore) in California found plague antibody prevalence from 15% to 36%.\n\nThe study referred to can be accessed at https://doi.org/10.1017/S0376892920000065. The abstract reads: \"We tested for plague (_Yersinia pestis_) in a puma population in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem (GYE) over 9 years, overlapping a case when a boy in the area became infected with plague. Antibodies to _Y. pestis_ were detected in 8 of 17 (47%) pumas tested by complementenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, and the organism itself was detected in 4 of 11 (36%) pumas tested after necropsy. Neither puma sex nor age was significantly associated with _Y. pestis_ exposure or mortality, although our sample size was small. The overall prevalence of exposure we recorded was similar to that found along the western slope of Colorado, which is adjacent to the Four Corners region, a known plague hotspot in the USA. This suggests that: (1) _Y. pestis_ may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed; (2) plague is a significant source of mortality for local pumas (6.6% of sub-adult and adult mortality); and (3) pumas may be a useful sentinel for potential risk of plague exposure to humans throughout the West. We would also emphasize that hunters and others handling pumas in this region should be made aware of the possibility of exposure.\" - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nWyoming, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nPlague - Congo DR (05): (IT) bubonic, septicemic, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7513771", "date": "2020-04-14 18:27:28", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA: (WYOMING) COUGAR\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 9 Apr 2020\nSource: Belleville News Democrat [edited]\nhttps://www.bnd.com/news/nation-world/national/article241909026.html\n\n\nIn Yellowstone, cougars are facing an epidemic of their own: Bubonic plague.\n\nThe flea-borne disease, most famous for killing half of Europe during the medieval ages, is showing up in the cougar population inhabiting the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem [GYE], according to a recent study.\n\nFindings suggest it could be widespread. Of the 28 big cats researchers tested, 12 were infected or had been infected, according to the study published in Environmental Conservation.\n\n\"This suggests that: (bubonic plague) may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed,\" it said, also adding that plague may be a \"significant\" cause of death for the animals.\n\nResearchers carried out the study over the course of 9 years, following the discovery of 2 dead cougars, a mother and her cub, in Wyoming, the Smithsonian Magazine said.\n\nThe deaths weren't in and of themselves surprising, lead researcher Mark Elbroch told Livescience.\n\nIt was the winter, and so starvation was the presumed culprit, but when the true cause of death was discovered, it \"was a shocker,\" he told the outlet.\n\nResearchers said it's very unlikely the average person would ever catch plague from a mountain lion, but given that the disease is capable of animal-to-human transmission, they recommended warnings for some.\n\n\"We would also emphasize that hunters and others handling pumas in this region should be made aware of the possibility of exposure,\" the study said.\n\nCougar behavior makes them a poor means of transferring diseases to people, but as Elbroch's team points out, their high rate of infection means the Yellowstone ecosystem itself could be a hotbed of plague.\n\nA Boy Scout came down with plague in 2008 following a camping trip in Yellowstone National Park, the Jackson Hole News & Guide reported.\n\n\"Plague is very much a part of the landscape in the western U.S., and wild animals are frequently exposed to it,\" a USDA researcher Sarah Bevins told National Geographic. \"Human plague infections are still relatively rare ... but untreated plague infections are still just as deadly as they were 500 years ago.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels, chipmunks and prairie dogs are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nCarnivores (like cougars) may be infected through fleabite or ingestion of infected rodents. Studies of black bears (another carnivore) in California found plague antibody prevalence from 15% to 36%.\n\nThe study referred to can be accessed at https://doi.org/10.1017/S0376892920000065. The abstract reads: \"We tested for plague (_Yersinia pestis_) in a puma population in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem (GYE) over 9 years, overlapping a case when a boy in the area became infected with plague. Antibodies to _Y. pestis_ were detected in 8 of 17 (47%) pumas tested by complementenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, and the organism itself was detected in 4 of 11 (36%) pumas tested after necropsy. Neither puma sex nor age was significantly associated with _Y. pestis_ exposure or mortality, although our sample size was small. The overall prevalence of exposure we recorded was similar to that found along the western slope of Colorado, which is adjacent to the Four Corners region, a known plague hotspot in the USA. This suggests that: (1) _Y. pestis_ may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed; (2) plague is a significant source of mortality for local pumas (6.6% of sub-adult and adult mortality); and (3) pumas may be a useful sentinel for potential risk of plague exposure to humans throughout the West. We would also emphasize that hunters and others handling pumas in this region should be made aware of the possibility of exposure.\" - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nWyoming, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nPlague - USA: (NM) zoo 20140729.2643587\nPlague - USA (02): (CO) pneumonic 20140710.2600593\nPlague - USA: (NM) pneumonic 20140425.2430602\nand other items in the archives\n.................................................sb/pmb/msp/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-04-11 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Livescience", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yellowstone", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "National Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7480784", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR (04): (IT) bubonic, septicemic, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7480784", "date": "2020-04-14 18:27:28", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA: (WYOMING) COUGAR\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 9 Apr 2020\nSource: Belleville News Democrat [edited]\nhttps://www.bnd.com/news/nation-world/national/article241909026.html\n\n\nIn Yellowstone, cougars are facing an epidemic of their own: Bubonic plague.\n\nThe flea-borne disease, most famous for killing half of Europe during the medieval ages, is showing up in the cougar population inhabiting the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem [GYE], according to a recent study.\n\nFindings suggest it could be widespread. Of the 28 big cats researchers tested, 12 were infected or had been infected, according to the study published in Environmental Conservation.\n\n\"This suggests that: (bubonic plague) may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed,\" it said, also adding that plague may be a \"significant\" cause of death for the animals.\n\nResearchers carried out the study over the course of 9 years, following the discovery of 2 dead cougars, a mother and her cub, in Wyoming, the Smithsonian Magazine said.\n\nThe deaths weren't in and of themselves surprising, lead researcher Mark Elbroch told Livescience.\n\nIt was the winter, and so starvation was the presumed culprit, but when the true cause of death was discovered, it \"was a shocker,\" he told the outlet.\n\nResearchers said it's very unlikely the average person would ever catch plague from a mountain lion, but given that the disease is capable of animal-to-human transmission, they recommended warnings for some.\n\n\"We would also emphasize that hunters and others handling pumas in this region should be made aware of the possibility of exposure,\" the study said.\n\nCougar behavior makes them a poor means of transferring diseases to people, but as Elbroch's team points out, their high rate of infection means the Yellowstone ecosystem itself could be a hotbed of plague.\n\nA Boy Scout came down with plague in 2008 following a camping trip in Yellowstone National Park, the Jackson Hole News & Guide reported.\n\n\"Plague is very much a part of the landscape in the western U.S., and wild animals are frequently exposed to it,\" a USDA researcher Sarah Bevins told National Geographic. \"Human plague infections are still relatively rare ... but untreated plague infections are still just as deadly as they were 500 years ago.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels, chipmunks and prairie dogs are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nCarnivores (like cougars) may be infected through fleabite or ingestion of infected rodents. Studies of black bears (another carnivore) in California found plague antibody prevalence from 15% to 36%.\n\nThe study referred to can be accessed at https://doi.org/10.1017/S0376892920000065. The abstract reads: \"We tested for plague (_Yersinia pestis_) in a puma population in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem (GYE) over 9 years, overlapping a case when a boy in the area became infected with plague. Antibodies to _Y. pestis_ were detected in 8 of 17 (47%) pumas tested by complementenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, and the organism itself was detected in 4 of 11 (36%) pumas tested after necropsy. Neither puma sex nor age was significantly associated with _Y. pestis_ exposure or mortality, although our sample size was small. The overall prevalence of exposure we recorded was similar to that found along the western slope of Colorado, which is adjacent to the Four Corners region, a known plague hotspot in the USA. This suggests that: (1) _Y. pestis_ may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed; (2) plague is a significant source of mortality for local pumas (6.6% of sub-adult and adult mortality); and (3) pumas may be a useful sentinel for potential risk of plague exposure to humans throughout the West. We would also emphasize that hunters and others handling pumas in this region should be made aware of the possibility of exposure.\" - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nWyoming, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nPlague -
