Congo DR (03): bubonic, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7343777", "date": "2020-04-14 18:27:28", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA: (WYOMING) COUGAR\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 9 Apr 2020\nSource: Belleville News Democrat [edited]\nhttps://www.bnd.com/news/nation-world/national/article241909026.html\n\n\nIn Yellowstone, cougars are facing an epidemic of their own: Bubonic plague.\n\nThe flea-borne disease, most famous for killing half of Europe during the medieval ages, is showing up in the cougar population inhabiting the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem [GYE], according to a recent study.\n\nFindings suggest it could be widespread. Of the 28 big cats researchers tested, 12 were infected or had been infected, according to the study published in Environmental Conservation.\n\n\"This suggests that: (bubonic plague) may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed,\" it said, also adding that plague may be a \"significant\" cause of death for the animals.\n\nResearchers carried out the study over the course of 9 years, following the discovery of 2 dead cougars, a mother and her cub, in Wyoming, the Smithsonian Magazine said.\n\nThe deaths weren't in and of themselves surprising, lead researcher Mark Elbroch told Livescience.\n\nIt was the winter, and so starvation was the presumed culprit, but when the true cause of death was discovered, it \"was a shocker,\" he told the outlet.\n\nResearchers said it's very unlikely the average person would ever catch plague from a mountain lion, but given that the disease is capable of animal-to-human transmission, they recommended warnings for some.\n\n\"We would also emphasize that hunters and others handling pumas in this region should be made aware of the possibility of exposure,\" the study said.\n\nCougar behavior makes them a poor means of transferring diseases to people, but as Elbroch's team points out, their high rate of infection means the Yellowstone ecosystem itself could be a hotbed of plague.\n\nA Boy Scout came down with plague in 2008 following a camping trip in Yellowstone National Park, the Jackson Hole News & Guide reported.\n\n\"Plague is very much a part of the landscape in the western U.S., and wild animals are frequently exposed to it,\" a USDA researcher Sarah Bevins told National Geographic. \"Human plague infections are still relatively rare ... but untreated plague infections are still just as deadly as they were 500 years ago.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels, chipmunks and prairie dogs are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nCarnivores (like cougars) may be infected through fleabite or ingestion of infected rodents. Studies of black bears (another carnivore) in California found plague antibody prevalence from 15% to 36%.\n\nThe study referred to can be accessed at https://doi.org/10.1017/S0376892920000065. The abstract reads: \"We tested for plague (_Yersinia pestis_) in a puma population in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem (GYE) over 9 years, overlapping a case when a boy in the area became infected with plague. Antibodies to _Y. pestis_ were detected in 8 of 17 (47%) pumas tested by complementenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, and the organism itself was detected in 4 of 11 (36%) pumas tested after necropsy. Neither puma sex nor age was significantly associated with _Y. pestis_ exposure or mortality, although our sample size was small. The overall prevalence of exposure we recorded was similar to that found along the western slope of Colorado, which is adjacent to the Four Corners region, a known plague hotspot in the USA. This suggests that: (1) _Y. pestis_ may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed; (2) plague is a significant source of mortality for local pumas (6.6% of sub-adult and adult mortality); and (3) pumas may be a useful sentinel for potential risk of plague exposure to humans throughout the West. We would also emphasize that hunters and others handling pumas in this region should be made aware of the possibility of exposure.\" - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nWyoming, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nPlague - USA: (WY) cougar", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7224404", "date": "2020-04-14 18:27:28", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA: (WYOMING) COUGAR\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 9 Apr 2020\nSource: Belleville News Democrat [edited]\nhttps://www.bnd.com/news/nation-world/national/article241909026.html\n\n\nIn Yellowstone, cougars are facing an epidemic of their own: Bubonic plague.\n\nThe flea-borne disease, most famous for killing half of Europe during the medieval ages, is showing up in the cougar population inhabiting the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem [GYE], according to a recent study.\n\nFindings suggest it could be widespread. Of the 28 big cats researchers tested, 12 were infected or had been infected, according to the study published in Environmental Conservation.\n\n\"This suggests that: (bubonic plague) may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed,\" it said, also adding that plague may be a \"significant\" cause of death for the animals.\n\nResearchers carried out the study over the course of 9 years, following the discovery of 2 dead cougars, a mother and her cub, in Wyoming, the Smithsonian Magazine said.\n\nThe deaths weren't in and of themselves surprising, lead researcher Mark Elbroch told Livescience.\n\nIt was the winter, and so starvation was the presumed culprit, but when the true cause of death was discovered, it \"was a shocker,\" he told the outlet.\n\nResearchers said it's very unlikely the average person would ever catch plague from a mountain lion, but given that the disease is capable of animal-to-human transmission, they recommended warnings for some.\n\n\"We would also emphasize that hunters and others handling pumas in this region should be made aware of the possibility of exposure,\" the study said.\n\nCougar behavior makes them a poor means of transferring diseases to people, but as Elbroch's team points out, their high rate of infection means the Yellowstone ecosystem itself could be a hotbed of plague.\n\nA Boy Scout came down with plague in 2008 following a camping trip in Yellowstone National Park, the Jackson Hole News & Guide reported.\n\n\"Plague is very much a part of the landscape in the western U.S., and wild animals are frequently exposed to it,\" a USDA researcher Sarah Bevins told National Geographic. \"Human plague infections are still relatively rare ... but untreated plague infections are still just as deadly as they were 500 years ago.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels, chipmunks and prairie dogs are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nCarnivores (like cougars) may be infected through fleabite or ingestion of infected rodents. Studies of black bears (another carnivore) in California found plague antibody prevalence from 15% to 36%.\n\nThe study referred to can be accessed at https://doi.org/10.1017/S0376892920000065. The abstract reads: \"We tested for plague (_Yersinia pestis_) in a puma population in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem (GYE) over 9 years, overlapping a case when a boy in the area became infected with plague. Antibodies to _Y. pestis_ were detected in 8 of 17 (47%) pumas tested by complementenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, and the organism itself was detected in 4 of 11 (36%) pumas tested after necropsy. Neither puma sex nor age was significantly associated with _Y. pestis_ exposure or mortality, although our sample size was small. The overall prevalence of exposure we recorded was similar to that found along the western slope of Colorado, which is adjacent to the Four Corners region, a known plague hotspot in the USA. This suggests that: (1) _Y. pestis_ may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed; (2) plague is a significant source of mortality for local pumas (6.6% of sub-adult and adult mortality); and (3) pumas may be a useful sentinel for potential risk of plague exposure to humans throughout the West. We would also emphasize that hunters and others handling pumas in this region should be made aware of the possibility of exposure.\" - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nWyoming, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nPlague - USA (06): comment 20140807.2666637\nPlague, animal - USA (05): (CA) squirrel 20140804.2656788\nPlague - USA (04): (NM) 20140803.2656232\nPlague - USA (03): (CO) cluster from canine exposure 20140719.2621418\nPlague, animal - USA: (NM) zoo 20140729.2643587\nPlague - USA (02): (CO) pneumonic 20140710.2600593\nPlague - USA: (NM) pneumonic 20140425.2430602\nand other items in the archives\n.................................................sb/pmb/msp/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-04-11 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Livescience", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yellowstone", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "National Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7137313", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Uganda: (ZO) ex Congo DR, 2019", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7137313", "date": "2019-11-13 15:34:05", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CHINA: (INNER MONGOLIA) PNEUMONIC\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 13 Nov 2019 11:27 GMT\nSource: The Guardian [edited]\nhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/nov/13/two-people-diagnosed-with-pneumonic-plague-in-china\n\n\nTwo people in China have been diagnosed with plague, the latest cases of a disease more commonly associated with historical catastrophe.\n\nPlague is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ and can arise in 3 forms -- a lung infection, known as pneumonic plague; a blood infection, known as septicemic plague; and a form that affects the lymph nodes, called bubonic plague. This infection was behind several pandemics including the Black Death of the late middle ages, which is estimated to have killed up to 60% of the European population.\n\nThe 2 new cases being treated at a hospital in Beijing are of the pneumonic form, which is even more serious than bubonic plague. According to the CDC, plague typically spreads to humans who have handled an infected animal or who have been bitten by a flea hosted by an infected animal. However, in the case of pneumonic plague, it can be spread when an infected person coughs. Pneumonic plague is highly contagious and is fatal if not treated quickly with [antimicrobials].\n\nThe WHO said it understood that close contacts were being screened and managed. \"The [Chinese] National Health Commission are implementing efforts to contain and treat the identified cases and increasing surveillance,\" said Fabio Scano, of WHO China.\n\nIt is not the 1st time in recent history that China has dealt with cases of plague. In 2014 the city of Yumen was sealed off and 151 people were placed in quarantine after a man died from the disease.\n\nAccording to the CDC, plague -- largely of the bubonic form -- continues to crop up in rural areas of the USA, including northern Arizona, southern Colorado, and southern Oregon. In 2014 there were 16 cases and 4 deaths in the USA, including that of a man from Utah thought to have come into contact with an infected flea or dead animal.\n\nRecent epidemics have been reported in Africa, Asia, and South America, predominately in rural regions. The WHO reported 3248 cases and 584 deaths from plague worldwide between 2010 and 2015.\n\nIn 2017 Madagascar had an outbreak of plague, with 2348 cases and 202 deaths, of which 1791 cases were pneumonic plague.\n\nThis year, 2019, in Mongolia a couple died from plague apparently after eating raw marmot kidney, triggering a 6-day quarantine in the region.\n\n[Byline: Nicola Davis]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 12 Nov 2019\nSource: Xinhua [edited]\nhttp://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2019-11/12/c_138549881.htm\n\n\nTwo people have been diagnosed with pneumonic plague in Beijing, local health authorities confirmed Tuesday [12 Nov 2019].\n\nAccording to the government website of Chaoyang District in Beijing, 2 patients from north China's Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region were diagnosed with pneumonic plague, which doctors in Beijing confirmed Tuesday [12 Nov 2019].\n\nAt present, the 2 patients have received proper treatment in a relevant medical institution of Chaoyang District, and relevant disease prevention and control measures have been taken.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed 13 Nov 2019\nSource: Slate.com [edited]\nhttps://slate.com/news-and-politics/2019/11/pneumonic-plague-black-death-china-sparks-fears-outbreak.html\n\n\nThe Chinese government announced Tuesday [12 Nov 2019] that 2 people in Beijing have been diagnosed with pneumonic plague, a deadly pandemic, once known as the Black Death, that killed tens of millions of people across Europe in the Middle Ages. The 2 patients were 1st treated in Inner Mongolia, a sparsely populated area in northern China, but after persistent respiratory problems and high fever, 2 symptoms of the plague, they were taken to a hospital in Beijing's Chaoyang District. A local news outlet said police quarantined the patients' room on Monday night [11 Nov 2019], but a now-deleted social media post by a doctor at the hospital indicated the pair 1st sought treatment as long back as 10 days ago [3 Nov 2019].\n\nThe timeline of the diagnosis is significant for multiple reasons in assessing the pandemic risk of the highly infectious illness, which can be transmitted by humans. First, although the pneumonic plague is universally fatal when left untreated, if diagnosed and treated with antibiotics within 24 hours of showing symptoms, the recovery rate is high, according to the World Health Organization. That would make the timing of the initial hospital visit and when the patients showed symptoms particularly important, as well as whom they may have come into contact with in the meantime.\n\n\"On Tuesday [12 Nov 2019], Chinese censors instructed online news aggregators in China to 'block and control' online discussion related to news about the plague,\" according to a directive seen and reported on by The New York Times. \"Skeptical Chinese internet users have charged the government with being slow to disclose news about the disease, which is transmitted between humans and kills even faster than the more-common bubonic form. China has a history of covering up and being slow to announce infectious outbreaks, prompting many people to call for transparency this time.\"\n\n[Byline: Elliot Hannon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The cases occurred in Inner Mongolia and were transferred to Beijing for therapy. Based on the 3rd post stating that the illness or illnesses began 10 days before and that without therapy plague pneumonia has a rapid progression to death, it is likely that the cases began with bubonic plague and spread to the lungs in at least one case.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a \"bubo\". Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this case, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of \"primary\" plague pneumonia. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nBeijing, China: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/353\nInner Mongolia Autonomous Region, China: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/356]\nSee Also\nPlague - Congo DR (03): (IT) Guinea pig, comments 20191018.6734330\nPlague - Congo DR (02): (IT) fatal 20191016.6731137\nPlague - Congo DR: (IT) fatal, human, rodent 20191006.6710185\nPlague - Madagascar (02): (AV) bubonic 20190814.6622982\nPlague - Mongolia (03): (BO) bubonic, marmot, fatal, quarantine 20190506.6456511\nPlague - Mongolia (02): (BO) bubonic, marmot, fatal, quarantine 20190503.6454287\nPlague - Mongolia: (BO) bubonic, susp., fatal, quarantine 20190502.6452212\nPlague - Uganda: Congo DR border, pneumonic, fatal 20190312.6363171\n2018\n----\nPlague - Madagascar (06) 20181002.6065963\nPlague - Madagascar (05) 20180924.6048975\nPlague - Madagascar (04) 20180921.6043410\nPlague - Madagascar (03) 20180919.6039244\nPlague - USA (03): (WY) feline 20180829.5995755\nPlague - Peru: (LB) septicemic, fatal 20180714.5905474\nPlague - USA (02): (ID) 20180614.5856107\nPlague - Madagascar (02): 2017-2018 20180502.5780275\nPlague - Bolivia: (LP) bubonic, fatal 20180417.5752357\nPlague - USA: (NM) canine 20180331.5721677\nPlague - Madagascar: (AV) bubonic 20180122.5572973\n2017\n----\nPlague - Madagascar (37): fatal 20171221.5518585\nPlague - China : (GS) septicemic, fatal 20171215.5506305\n.................................................ll/mj/lxl/ll/rd/lxl", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "1791-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2037-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Inner Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yumen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7028683", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR: (IT) pneumonic, fatal, susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7026580", "date": "2019-11-13 15:34:05", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CHINA: (INNER MONGOLIA) PNEUMONIC\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 13 Nov 2019 11:27 GMT\nSource: The Guardian [edited]\nhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/nov/13/two-people-diagnosed-with-pneumonic-plague-in-china\n\n\nTwo people in China have been diagnosed with plague, the latest cases of a disease more commonly associated with historical catastrophe.\n\nPlague is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ and can arise in 3 forms -- a lung infection, known as pneumonic plague; a blood infection, known as septicemic plague; and a form that affects the lymph nodes, called bubonic plague. This infection was behind several pandemics including the Black Death of the late middle ages, which is estimated to have killed up to 60% of the European population.\n\nThe 2 new cases being treated at a hospital in Beijing are of the pneumonic form, which is even more serious than bubonic plague. According to the CDC, plague typically spreads to humans who have handled an infected animal or who have been bitten by a flea hosted by an infected animal. However, in the case of pneumonic plague, it can be spread when an infected person coughs. Pneumonic plague is highly contagious and is fatal if not treated quickly with [antimicrobials].\n\nThe WHO said it understood that close contacts were being screened and managed. \"The [Chinese] National Health Commission are implementing efforts to contain and treat the identified cases and increasing surveillance,\" said Fabio Scano, of WHO China.\n\nIt is not the 1st time in recent history that China has dealt with cases of plague. In 2014 the city of Yumen was sealed off and 151 people were placed in quarantine after a man died from the disease.\n\nAccording to the CDC, plague -- largely of the bubonic form -- continues to crop up in rural areas of the USA, including northern Arizona, southern Colorado, and southern Oregon. In 2014 there were 16 cases and 4 deaths in the USA, including that of a man from Utah thought to have come into contact with an infected flea or dead animal.\n\nRecent epidemics have been reported in Africa, Asia, and South America, predominately in rural regions. The WHO reported 3248 cases and 584 deaths from plague worldwide between 2010 and 2015.\n\nIn 2017 Madagascar had an outbreak of plague, with 2348 cases and 202 deaths, of which 1791 cases were pneumonic plague.\n\nThis year, 2019, in Mongolia a couple died from plague apparently after eating raw marmot kidney, triggering a 6-day quarantine in the region.\n\n[Byline: Nicola Davis]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 12 Nov 2019\nSource: Xinhua [edited]\nhttp://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2019-11/12/c_138549881.htm\n\n\nTwo people have been diagnosed with pneumonic plague in Beijing, local health authorities confirmed Tuesday [12 Nov 2019].\n\nAccording to the government website of Chaoyang District in Beijing, 2 patients from north China's Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region were diagnosed with pneumonic plague, which doctors in Beijing confirmed Tuesday [12 Nov 2019].\n\nAt present, the 2 patients have received proper treatment in a relevant medical institution of Chaoyang District, and relevant disease prevention and control measures have been taken.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed 13 Nov 2019\nSource: Slate.com [edited]\nhttps://slate.com/news-and-politics/2019/11/pneumonic-plague-black-death-china-sparks-fears-outbreak.html\n\n\nThe Chinese government announced Tuesday [12 Nov 2019] that 2 people in Beijing have been diagnosed with pneumonic plague, a deadly pandemic, once known as the Black Death, that killed tens of millions of people across Europe in the Middle Ages. That would make the timing of the initial hospital visit and when the patients showed symptoms particularly important, as well as whom they may have come into contact with in the meantime.\n\n\"On Tuesday [12 Nov 2019], Chinese censors instructed online news aggregators in China to 'block and control' online discussion related to news about the plague,\" according to a directive seen and reported on by The New York Times. \"Skeptical Chinese internet users have charged the government with being slow to disclose news about the disease, which is transmitted between humans and kills even faster than the more-common bubonic form. China has a history of covering up and being slow to announce infectious outbreaks, prompting many people to call for transparency this time.\"\n\n[Byline: Elliot Hannon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The cases occurred in Inner Mongolia and were transferred to Beijing for therapy. Based on the 3rd post stating that the illness or illnesses began 10 days before and that without therapy plague pneumonia has a rapid progression to death, it is likely that the cases began with bubonic plague and spread to the lungs in at least one case.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a \"bubo\". Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this case, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of \"primary\" plague pneumonia. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nBeijing, China: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/353\nInner Mongolia Autonomous Region, China: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/356]\nSee Also\nPlague - Congo DR (03): (IT) Guinea pig, comments 20191018.6734330\nPlague - Congo DR (02): (IT) fatal 20191016.6731137\nPlague - Congo DR: (IT) fatal, human, rodent 20191006.6710185\nPlague - Madagascar (02): (AV) bubonic 20190814.6622982\nPlague - Mongolia (03): (BO) bubonic, marmot, fatal, quarantine 20190506.6456511\nPlague - Mongolia (02): (BO) bubonic, marmot, fatal, quarantine 20190503.6454287\nPlague - Mongolia: (BO) bubonic, susp., fatal, quarantine 20190502.6452212\nPlague - Uganda: Congo DR border, pneumonic, fatal 20190312.6363171\n2018\n----\nPlague - Madagascar (06) 20181002.6065963\nPlague - Madagascar (05) 20180924.6048975\nPlague - Madagascar (04) 20180921.6043410\nPlague - Madagascar (03) 20180919.6039244\nPlague - USA (03): (WY) feline 20180829.5995755\nPlague - Peru: (LB) septicemic, fatal 20180714.5905474\nPlague - USA (02): (ID) 20180614.5856107\nPlague - Madagascar (02): 2017-2018 20180502.5780275\nPlague - Bolivia: (LP) bubonic, fatal 20180417.5752357\nPlague - USA: (NM) canine 20180331.5721677\nPlague - Madagascar: (AV) bubonic 20180122.5572973\n2017\n----\nPlague - Madagascar (37): fatal 20171221.5518585\nPlague - China : (GS) septicemic, fatal 20171215.5506305\n.................................................ll/mj/lxl/ll/rd/lxl", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "1791-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2037-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Inner Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yumen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6878373", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - China: (Inner Mongolia) 2019", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6878373", "date": "2019-11-13 15:34:05", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CHINA: (INNER MONGOLIA) PNEUMONIC\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 13 Nov 2019 11:27 GMT\nSource: The Guardian [edited]\nhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/nov/13/two-people-diagnosed-with-pneumonic-plague-in-china\n\n\nTwo people in China have been diagnosed with plague, the latest cases of a disease more commonly associated with historical catastrophe.\n\nPlague is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ and can arise in 3 forms -- a lung infection, known as pneumonic plague; a blood infection, known as septicemic plague; and a form that affects the lymph nodes, called bubonic plague. This infection was behind several pandemics including the Black Death of the late middle ages, which is estimated to have killed up to 60% of the European population.\n\nThe 2 new cases being treated at a hospital in Beijing are of the pneumonic form, which is even more serious than bubonic plague. According to the CDC, plague typically spreads to humans who have handled an infected animal or who have been bitten by a flea hosted by an infected animal. However, in the case of pneumonic plague, it can be spread when an infected person coughs. Pneumonic plague is highly contagious and is fatal if not treated quickly with [antimicrobials].\n\nThe WHO said it understood that close contacts were being screened and managed. \"The [Chinese] National Health Commission are implementing efforts to contain and treat the identified cases and increasing surveillance,\" said Fabio Scano, of WHO China.\n\nIt is not the 1st time in recent history that China has dealt with cases of plague. In 2014 the city of Yumen was sealed off and 151 people were placed in quarantine after a man died from the disease.\n\nAccording to the CDC, plague -- largely of the bubonic form -- continues to crop up in rural areas of the USA, including northern Arizona, southern Colorado, and southern Oregon. In 2014 there were 16 cases and 4 deaths in the USA, including that of a man from Utah thought to have come into contact with an infected flea or dead animal.\n\nRecent epidemics have been reported in Africa, Asia, and South America, predominately in rural regions. The WHO reported 3248 cases and 584 deaths from plague worldwide between 2010 and 2015.\n\nIn 2017 Madagascar had an outbreak of plague, with 2348 cases and 202 deaths, of which 1791 cases were pneumonic plague.\n\nThis year, 2019, in Mongolia a couple died from plague apparently after eating raw marmot kidney, triggering a 6-day quarantine in the region.\n\n[Byline: Nicola Davis]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 12 Nov 2019\nSource: Xinhua [edited]\nhttp://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2019-11/12/c_138549881.htm\n\n\nTwo people have been diagnosed with pneumonic plague in Beijing, local health authorities confirmed Tuesday [12 Nov 2019].\n\nAccording to the government website of Chaoyang District in Beijing, 2 patients from north China's Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region were diagnosed with pneumonic plague, which doctors in Beijing confirmed Tuesday [12 Nov 2019].\n\nAt present, the 2 patients have received proper treatment in a relevant medical institution of Chaoyang District, and relevant disease prevention and control measures have been taken.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed 13 Nov 2019\nSource: Slate.com [edited]\nhttps://slate.com/news-and-politics/2019/11/pneumonic-plague-black-death-china-sparks-fears-outbreak.html\n\n\nThe Chinese government announced Tuesday [12 Nov 2019] that 2 people in Beijing have been diagnosed with pneumonic plague, a deadly pandemic, once known as the Black Death, that killed tens of millions of people across Europe in the Middle Ages. The 2 patients were 1st treated in Inner Mongolia, a sparsely populated area in northern China, but after persistent respiratory problems and high fever, 2 symptoms of the plague, they were taken to a hospital in Beijing's Chaoyang District. A local news outlet said police quarantined the patients' room on Monday night [11 Nov 2019], but a now-deleted social media post by a doctor at the hospital indicated the pair 1st sought treatment as long back as 10 days ago [3 Nov 2019].\n\nThe timeline of the diagnosis is significant for multiple reasons in assessing the pandemic risk of the highly infectious illness, which can be transmitted by humans. First, although the pneumonic plague is universally fatal when left untreated, if diagnosed and treated with antibiotics within 24 hours of showing symptoms, the recovery rate is high, according to the World Health Organization. That would make the timing of the initial hospital visit and when the patients showed symptoms particularly important, as well as whom they may have come into contact with in the meantime.\n\n\"On Tuesday [12 Nov 2019], Chinese censors instructed online news aggregators in China to 'block and control' online discussion related to news about the plague,\" according to a directive seen and reported on by The New York Times. \"Skeptical Chinese internet users have charged the government with being slow to disclose news about the disease, which is transmitted between humans and kills even faster than the more-common bubonic form. China has a history of covering up and being slow to announce infectious outbreaks, prompting many people to call for transparency this time.\"\n\n[Byline: Elliot Hannon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The cases occurred in Inner Mongolia and were transferred to Beijing for therapy. Based on the 3rd post stating that the illness or illnesses began 10 days before and that without therapy plague pneumonia has a rapid progression to death, it is likely that the cases began with bubonic plague and spread to the lungs in at least one case.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a \"bubo\". Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this case, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of \"primary\" plague pneumonia. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nBeijing, China: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/353\nInner Mongolia Autonomous Region, China: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/356]\nSee Also\nPlague - China : (GS) septicemic, fatal 20171215.5506305\n.................................................ll/mj/lxl/ll/rd/lxl", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "1791-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2037-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Inner Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yumen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6802547", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - China (03): (NM) bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6802547", "date": "2019-11-13 15:34:05", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CHINA: (INNER MONGOLIA) PNEUMONIC\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 13 Nov 2019 11:27 GMT\nSource: The Guardian [edited]\nhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/nov/13/two-people-diagnosed-with-pneumonic-plague-in-china\n\n\nTwo people in China have been diagnosed with plague, the latest cases of a disease more commonly associated with historical catastrophe.\n\nPlague is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ and can arise in 3 forms -- a lung infection, known as pneumonic plague; a blood infection, known as septicemic plague; and a form that affects the lymph nodes, called bubonic plague. This infection was behind several pandemics including the Black Death of the late middle ages, which is estimated to have killed up to 60% of the European population.\n\nThe 2 new cases being treated at a hospital in Beijing are of the pneumonic form, which is even more serious than bubonic plague. According to the CDC, plague typically spreads to humans who have handled an infected animal or who have been bitten by a flea hosted by an infected animal. However, in the case of pneumonic plague, it can be spread when an infected person coughs. Pneumonic plague is highly contagious and is fatal if not treated quickly with [antimicrobials].\n\nThe WHO said it understood that close contacts were being screened and managed. \"The [Chinese] National Health Commission are implementing efforts to contain and treat the identified cases and increasing surveillance,\" said Fabio Scano, of WHO China.\n\nIt is not the 1st time in recent history that China has dealt with cases of plague. In 2014 the city of Yumen was sealed off and 151 people were placed in quarantine after a man died from the disease.\n\nAccording to the CDC, plague -- largely of the bubonic form -- continues to crop up in rural areas of the USA, including northern Arizona, southern Colorado, and southern Oregon. In 2014 there were 16 cases and 4 deaths in the USA, including that of a man from Utah thought to have come into contact with an infected flea or dead animal.\n\nRecent epidemics have been reported in Africa, Asia, and South America, predominately in rural regions. The WHO reported 3248 cases and 584 deaths from plague worldwide between 2010 and 2015.\n\nIn 2017 Madagascar had an outbreak of plague, with 2348 cases and 202 deaths, of which 1791 cases were pneumonic plague.\n\nThis year, 2019, in Mongolia a couple died from plague apparently after eating raw marmot kidney, triggering a 6-day quarantine in the region.\n\n[Byline: Nicola Davis]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 12 Nov 2019\nSource: Xinhua [edited]\nhttp://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2019-11/12/c_138549881.htm\n\n\nTwo people have been diagnosed with pneumonic plague in Beijing, local health authorities confirmed Tuesday [12 Nov 2019].\n\nAccording to the government website of Chaoyang District in Beijing, 2 patients from north China's Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region were diagnosed with pneumonic plague, which doctors in Beijing confirmed Tuesday [12 Nov 2019].\n\nAt present, the 2 patients have received proper treatment in a relevant medical institution of Chaoyang District, and relevant disease prevention and control measures have been taken.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed 13 Nov 2019\nSource: Slate.com [edited]\nhttps://slate.com/news-and-politics/2019/11/pneumonic-plague-black-death-china-sparks-fears-outbreak.html\n\n\nThe Chinese government announced Tuesday [12 Nov 2019] that 2 people in Beijing have been diagnosed with pneumonic plague, a deadly pandemic, once known as the Black Death, that killed tens of millions of people across Europe in the Middle Ages. The 2 patients were 1st treated in Inner Mongolia, a sparsely populated area in northern China, but after persistent respiratory problems and high fever, 2 symptoms of the plague, they were taken to a hospital in Beijing's Chaoyang District. A local news outlet said police quarantined the patients' room on Monday night [11 Nov 2019], but a now-deleted social media post by a doctor at the hospital indicated the pair 1st sought treatment as long back as 10 days ago [3 Nov 2019].\n\nThe timeline of the diagnosis is significant for multiple reasons in assessing the pandemic risk of the highly infectious illness, which can be transmitted by humans. First, although the pneumonic plague is universally fatal when left untreated, if diagnosed and treated with antibiotics within 24 hours of showing symptoms, the recovery rate is high, according to the World Health Organization. That would make the timing of the initial hospital visit and when the patients showed symptoms particularly important, as well as whom they may have come into contact with in the meantime.\n\n\"On Tuesday [12 Nov 2019], Chinese censors instructed online news aggregators in China to 'block and control' online discussion related to news about the plague,\" according to a directive seen and reported on by The New York Times. \"Skeptical Chinese internet users have charged the government with being slow to disclose news about the disease, which is transmitted between humans and kills even faster than the more-common bubonic form. China has a history of covering up and being slow to announce infectious outbreaks, prompting many people to call for transparency this time.\"\n\n[Byline: Elliot Hannon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The cases occurred in Inner Mongolia and were transferred to Beijing for therapy. Based on the 3rd post stating that the illness or illnesses began 10 days before and that without therapy plague pneumonia has a rapid progression to death, it is likely that the cases began with bubonic plague and spread to the lungs in at least one case.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a \"bubo\". Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this case, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of \"primary\" plague pneumonia. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nBeijing, China: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/353\nInner Mongolia Autonomous Region, China: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/356]\nSee Also\nPlague - China : (GS) septicemic, fatal 20171215.5506305\n.................................................ll/mj/lxl/ll/rd/lxl", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "1791-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2037-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Inner Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yumen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6785027", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - China (02): (NM) bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6785027", "date": "2019-11-13 15:34:05", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CHINA: (INNER MONGOLIA) PNEUMONIC\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 13 Nov 2019 11:27 GMT\nSource: The Guardian [edited]\nhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/nov/13/two-people-diagnosed-with-pneumonic-plague-in-china\n\n\nTwo people in China have been diagnosed with plague, the latest cases of a disease more commonly associated with historical catastrophe.\n\nPlague is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ and can arise in 3 forms -- a lung infection, known as pneumonic plague; a blood infection, known as septicemic plague; and a form that affects the lymph nodes, called bubonic plague. This infection was behind several pandemics including the Black Death of the late middle ages, which is estimated to have killed up to 60% of the European population.\n\nThe 2 new cases being treated at a hospital in Beijing are of the pneumonic form, which is even more serious than bubonic plague. According to the CDC, plague typically spreads to humans who have handled an infected animal or who have been bitten by a flea hosted by an infected animal. However, in the case of pneumonic plague, it can be spread when an infected person coughs. Pneumonic plague is highly contagious and is fatal if not treated quickly with [antimicrobials].\n\nThe WHO said it understood that close contacts were being screened and managed. \"The [Chinese] National Health Commission are implementing efforts to contain and treat the identified cases and increasing surveillance,\" said Fabio Scano, of WHO China.\n\nIt is not the 1st time in recent history that China has dealt with cases of plague. In 2014 the city of Yumen was sealed off and 151 people were placed in quarantine after a man died from the disease.\n\nAccording to the CDC, plague -- largely of the bubonic form -- continues to crop up in rural areas of the USA, including northern Arizona, southern Colorado, and southern Oregon. In 2014 there were 16 cases and 4 deaths in the USA, including that of a man from Utah thought to have come into contact with an infected flea or dead animal.\n\nRecent epidemics have been reported in Africa, Asia, and South America, predominately in rural regions. The WHO reported 3248 cases and 584 deaths from plague worldwide between 2010 and 2015.\n\nIn 2017 Madagascar had an outbreak of plague, with 2348 cases and 202 deaths, of which 1791 cases were pneumonic plague.\n\nThis year, 2019, in Mongolia a couple died from plague apparently after eating raw marmot kidney, triggering a 6-day quarantine in the region.\n\n[Byline: Nicola Davis]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 12 Nov 2019\nSource: Xinhua [edited]\nhttp://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2019-11/12/c_138549881.htm\n\n\nTwo people have been diagnosed with pneumonic plague in Beijing, local health authorities confirmed Tuesday [12 Nov 2019].\n\nAccording to the government website of Chaoyang District in Beijing, 2 patients from north China's Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region were diagnosed with pneumonic plague, which doctors in Beijing confirmed Tuesday [12 Nov 2019].\n\nAt present, the 2 patients have received proper treatment in a relevant medical institution of Chaoyang District, and relevant disease prevention and control measures have been taken.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed 13 Nov 2019\nSource: Slate.com [edited]\nhttps://slate.com/news-and-politics/2019/11/pneumonic-plague-black-death-china-sparks-fears-outbreak.html\n\n\nThe Chinese government announced Tuesday [12 Nov 2019] that 2 people in Beijing have been diagnosed with pneumonic plague, a deadly pandemic, once known as the Black Death, that killed tens of millions of people across Europe in the Middle Ages. China has a history of covering up and being slow to announce infectious outbreaks, prompting many people to call for transparency this time.\"\n\n[Byline: Elliot Hannon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The cases occurred in Inner Mongolia and were transferred to Beijing for therapy. The swollen gland is called a \"bubo\". Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. This infection was behind several pandemics including the Black Death of the late middle ages, which is estimated to have killed up to 60% of the European population.\n\nThe 2 new cases being treated at a hospital in Beijing are of the pneumonic form, which is even more serious than bubonic plague. However, in the case of pneumonic plague, it can be spread when an infected person coughs. China : (GS) septicemic, fatal 20171215.5506305\n.................................................ll/mj/lxl/ll/rd/lxl", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "1791-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2037-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Inner Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yumen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6734330", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR (03): (IT) Guinea pig, comments", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6734330", "date": "2019-05-06 22:24:49", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MONGOLIA (03): (BAYAN-OLGIY) BUBONIC, MARMOT, FATAL, QUARANTINE\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 4 May 2019\nSource: Siberian Times [edited]\nhttps://siberiantimes.com/other/others/news/town-in-mongolia-closed-for-quarantine-after-bubonic-plague-claimed-two-lives/\n\n\nThe Mongolian Ministry of Health confirmed 2 people -- a 38-year-old man and his pregnant wife, 37 -- died from plague after consuming raw meat and internal organs of a marmot. Their deaths left 4 children as orphans aged from 2 to 13. Dramatic pictures have shown at least one aircraft being met by anti-contamination emergency workers in a bid to prevent spread of the disease.\n\nThe local town of Ulgii (or Olgii) on the border with Russia was shut for quarantine by Mongolian health authorities and army. Several dozen tourists from all over the world had to alter their holiday plans and are now waiting to hear when they might be allowed to leave the town.\n\n\"Did you think that the plague was something from the Dark Ages? Us too!! We were just about to leave Ulgii to go deeper into Mongolia, but all exits of the town were shut and we were not allowed to leave. Half of the city is closed due to some plague-contaminated marmots!\" wrote one traveler from Kemerovo [Siberia, Russia] who is marooned on the border with her husband. With a big group of fellow travelers from the US, Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland, South Korea, and Germany, the Russians were besieging the authorities, desperate to leave the town.\n\nThe tragic family that died from plague got infected after eating raw kidneys of a marmot. An old Mongolian tradition says that a raw meat and internal organs of freshly killed marmot strengthens health, local media reported.\n\nThe Mongolian Ministry of Health stressed they did not think that the situation with the plague was critical or anywhere near epidemic. Yet there was no deadline announced for the quarantine which in the worst case scenario can last as long as 21 days.\n\nSanitary and epidemiological services in Russia's Altai and Tuva republics, which neighbour the Bayan-Uglii province of Mongolia, are on high alert since news broke of the plague outbreak.\n\nIn Uglii a total of 158 people who came directly or indirectly into contact with the couple are 'under supervision'.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a \"bubo.\" Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in the report above, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of \"primary\" plague pneumonia. As it is only pneumonic plague that spreads person-to-person and close contact is required, if the tourists were not exposed to the couple, quarantine seems not needed.\n\nPlague is endemic in Mongolia. Marmots such as the Tarvaga, the Tarbagan or Mongolian marmot, _Marmota sibirica_, a large rodent related to the American woodchuck (_M. monax_), are thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in Eastern Asia. The name marmot (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot) comes from French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ \"mountain mouse.\"\n\nMaps of Mongolia: http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/mongolia.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34282. The province of Bayan-Olgiy is in the extreme western part of the country. - Mod.LL\n\nWhile foodborne transmission of _Yersinia pestis_ has been described (e.g, Leslie T, et al. Outbreak of gastroenteritis caused by _Yersinia pestis_ in Afghanistan. Epidemiol Infect. 2011 May; 139(5): 728-35. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20663260), it is far more likely that these bubonic plague cases were acquired via the bites of infected fleas. - Mod.LM]\nSee Also\nPlague - Mongolia (02): (BO) bubonic, marmot, fatal, quarantine 20190503.6454287\nPlague - Mongolia: (BO) bubonic, susp, fatal, quarantine 20190502.6452212\n2009\n----\nPlague, human - Mongolia: (BO), RFI 20090612.2177\n2007\n----\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia (Gobisumber) 20070924.3163\nPlague, human, fatal - Mongolia (Hovsgol) (03) 20070810.2602\nPlague, human, fatal - Mongolia (Hovsgol) (02) 20070809.2589\nPlague, human, fatal - Mongolia (Hovsgol) 20070807.2567\n2003\n----\nPlague - Mongolia 20030908.2255\n2002\n----\nPlague - Mongolia 20020919.5361\n2001\n----\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia (Central): correction 20010904.2115\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia (Central) 20010808.1871\n2000\n----\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia & China: background (03) 20000924.1645\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia & China: background (02) 20000920.1620\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia & China: Background 20000802.1290\nPlague, bubonic, marmots - Mongolia: RFI 20000801.1274\n.................................................ll/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2037-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tarbagan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kemerovo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34282", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Background", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6731137", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR (02): (IT) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6731137", "date": "2019-05-06 22:24:49", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MONGOLIA (03): (BAYAN-OLGIY) BUBONIC, MARMOT, FATAL, QUARANTINE\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 4 May 2019\nSource: Siberian Times [edited]\nhttps://siberiantimes.com/other/others/news/town-in-mongolia-closed-for-quarantine-after-bubonic-plague-claimed-two-lives/\n\n\nThe Mongolian Ministry of Health confirmed 2 people -- a 38-year-old man and his pregnant wife, 37 -- died from plague after consuming raw meat and internal organs of a marmot. Their deaths left 4 children as orphans aged from 2 to 13. Dramatic pictures have shown at least one aircraft being met by anti-contamination emergency workers in a bid to prevent spread of the disease.\n\nThe local town of Ulgii (or Olgii) on the border with Russia was shut for quarantine by Mongolian health authorities and army. Several dozen tourists from all over the world had to alter their holiday plans and are now waiting to hear when they might be allowed to leave the town.\n\n\"Did you think that the plague was something from the Dark Ages? Us too!! We were just about to leave Ulgii to go deeper into Mongolia, but all exits of the town were shut and we were not allowed to leave. Half of the city is closed due to some plague-contaminated marmots!\" wrote one traveler from Kemerovo [Siberia, Russia] who is marooned on the border with her husband. With a big group of fellow travelers from the US, Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland, South Korea, and Germany, the Russians were besieging the authorities, desperate to leave the town.\n\nThe tragic family that died from plague got infected after eating raw kidneys of a marmot. An old Mongolian tradition says that a raw meat and internal organs of freshly killed marmot strengthens health, local media reported.\n\nThe Mongolian Ministry of Health stressed they did not think that the situation with the plague was critical or anywhere near epidemic. Yet there was no deadline announced for the quarantine which in the worst case scenario can last as long as 21 days.\n\nSanitary and epidemiological services in Russia's Altai and Tuva republics, which neighbour the Bayan-Uglii province of Mongolia, are on high alert since news broke of the plague outbreak.\n\nIn Uglii a total of 158 people who came directly or indirectly into contact with the couple are 'under supervision'.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a \"bubo.\" Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in the report above, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of \"primary\" plague pneumonia. As it is only pneumonic plague that spreads person-to-person and close contact is required, if the tourists were not exposed to the couple, quarantine seems not needed.\n\nPlague is endemic in Mongolia. Marmots such as the Tarvaga, the Tarbagan or Mongolian marmot, _Marmota sibirica_, a large rodent related to the American woodchuck (_M. monax_), are thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in Eastern Asia. The name marmot (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot) comes from French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ \"mountain mouse.\"\n\nMaps of Mongolia: http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/mongolia.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34282. The province of Bayan-Olgiy is in the extreme western part of the country. - Mod.LL\n\nWhile foodborne transmission of _Yersinia pestis_ has been described (e.g, Leslie T, et al. Outbreak of gastroenteritis caused by _Yersinia pestis_ in Afghanistan. Epidemiol Infect. 2011 May; 139(5): 728-35. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20663260), it is far more likely that these bubonic plague cases were acquired via the bites of infected fleas. - Mod.LM]\nSee Also\nPlague - A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. The name marmot (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot) comes from French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ \"mountain mouse.\"\n\nMaps of Mongolia: http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/mongolia.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34282. The province of Bayan-Olgiy is in the extreme western part of the country. - Mod.LL\n\nWhile foodborne transmission of _Yersinia pestis_ has been described (e.g, Leslie T, et al. Outbreak of gastroenteritis caused by _Yersinia pestis_ in Afghanistan. Epidemiol Infect. 2011 May; 139(5): 728-35. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20663260), it is far more likely that these bubonic plague cases were acquired via the bites of infected fleas. - Mod.LM]\nSee Also\nPlague - Mongolia (Gobisumber) 20070924.3163\nPlague, human, fatal - Mongolia (Hovsgol) (03) 20070810.2602\nPlague, human, fatal - Mongolia (Hovsgol) (02) 20070809.2589\nPlague, human, fatal - Mongolia (Hovsgol) 20070807.2567\n2003\n----\nPlague - Mongolia: RFI 20000801.1274\n.................................................ll/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2037-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tarbagan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kemerovo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34282", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Background", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6670584", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Crayfish plague - UK: (England) white-clawed crayfish, susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6670584", "date": "2019-05-06 22:24:49", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MONGOLIA (03): (BAYAN-OLGIY) BUBONIC, MARMOT, FATAL, QUARANTINE\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 4 May 2019\nSource: Siberian Times [edited]\nhttps://siberiantimes.com/other/others/news/town-in-mongolia-closed-for-quarantine-after-bubonic-plague-claimed-two-lives/\n\n\nThe Mongolian Ministry of Health confirmed 2 people -- a 38-year-old man and his pregnant wife, 37 -- died from plague after consuming raw meat and internal organs of a marmot. Their deaths left 4 children as orphans aged from 2 to 13. Dramatic pictures have shown at least one aircraft being met by anti-contamination emergency workers in a bid to prevent spread of the disease.\n\nThe local town of Ulgii (or Olgii) on the border with Russia was shut for quarantine by Mongolian health authorities and army. Several dozen tourists from all over the world had to alter their holiday plans and are now waiting to hear when they might be allowed to leave the town.\n\n\"Did you think that the plague was something from the Dark Ages? Us too!! We were just about to leave Ulgii to go deeper into Mongolia, but all exits of the town were shut and we were not allowed to leave. Half of the city is closed due to some plague-contaminated marmots!\" wrote one traveler from Kemerovo [Siberia, Russia] who is marooned on the border with her husband. With a big group of fellow travelers from the US, Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland, South Korea, and Germany, the Russians were besieging the authorities, desperate to leave the town.\n\nThe tragic family that died from plague got infected after eating raw kidneys of a marmot. An old Mongolian tradition says that a raw meat and internal organs of freshly killed marmot strengthens health, local media reported.\n\nThe Mongolian Ministry of Health stressed they did not think that the situation with the plague was critical or anywhere near epidemic. Yet there was no deadline announced for the quarantine which in the worst case scenario can last as long as 21 days.\n\nSanitary and epidemiological services in Russia's Altai and Tuva republics, which neighbour the Bayan-Uglii province of Mongolia, are on high alert since news broke of the plague outbreak.\n\nIn Uglii a total of 158 people who came directly or indirectly into contact with the couple are 'under supervision'.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a \"bubo.\" Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in the report above, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of \"primary\" plague pneumonia. As it is only pneumonic plague that spreads person-to-person and close contact is required, if the tourists were not exposed to the couple, quarantine seems not needed.\n\nPlague is endemic in Mongolia. Marmots such as the Tarvaga, the Tarbagan or Mongolian marmot, _Marmota sibirica_, a large rodent related to the American woodchuck (_M. monax_), are thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in Eastern Asia. The name marmot (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot) comes from French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ \"mountain mouse.\"\n\nMaps of Mongolia: http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/mongolia.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34282. The province of Bayan-Olgiy is in the extreme western part of the country. - Mod.LL\n\nWhile foodborne transmission of _Yersinia pestis_ has been described (e.g, Leslie T, et al. Outbreak of gastroenteritis caused by _Yersinia pestis_ in Afghanistan. Epidemiol Infect. 2011 May; 139(5): 728-35. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20663260), it is far more likely that these bubonic plague cases were acquired via the bites of infected fleas. - Mod.LM]\nSee Also\nPlague - Mongolia & China: background (03) 20000924.1645\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia & China: background (02) 20000920.1620\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia & China: Background 20000802.1290\nPlague, bubonic, marmots - If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in the report above, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of \"primary\" plague pneumonia. As it is only pneumonic plague that spreads person-to-person and close contact is required, if the tourists were not exposed to the couple, quarantine seems not needed.\n\nPlague is endemic in Mongolia. Marmots such as the Tarvaga, the Tarbagan or Mongolian marmot, _Marmota sibirica_, a large rodent related to the American woodchuck (_M. monax_), are thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in Eastern Asia. The name marmot (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot) comes from French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ \"mountain mouse.\"\n\nMaps of Mongolia: http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/mongolia.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34282. The province of Bayan-Olgiy is in the extreme western part of the country. - Mod.LL\n\nWhile foodborne transmission of _Yersinia pestis_ has been described (e.g, Leslie T, et al. Outbreak of gastroenteritis caused by _Yersinia pestis_ in Afghanistan. Epidemiol Infect. 2011 May; 139(5): 728-35. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20663260), it is far more likely that these bubonic plague cases were acquired via the bites of infected fleas. - Mod.LM]\nSee Also\nPlague - Mongolia (02): (BO) bubonic, marmot, fatal, quarantine 20190503.6454287\nPlague - Mongolia: (BO) bubonic, susp, fatal, quarantine 20190502.6452212\n2009\n----\nPlague, human - Mongolia: (BO), RFI 20090612.2177\n2007\n----\nPlague, bubonic -
