Mongolia: RFI 20000801.1274\n.................................................ll/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2037-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tarbagan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kemerovo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34282", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Background", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6454287", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Mongolia (02): (BO) bubonic, marmot, fatal, quarantine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6454287", "date": "2018-10-17 12:04:49", "main_text": "CRAYFISH PLAGUE - UK: (NORTHERN IRELAND) WHITE-CLAWED CRAYFISH, OIE\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 15 Oct 2018\nSource: OIE, WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System), weekly disease information 2018; 31(42) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=28224\n\n\nCrayfish plague (_Aphanomyces astaci_), United Kingdom\n------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 15 Oct 2018 from Dr Christine Middlemiss, Chief Veterinary Officer, DEFRA, Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs, London, United Kingdom\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 31 Aug 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 14 Sep 2018\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: Jun 2018\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Aphanomyces astaci_\nNature of diagnosis: clinical\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Headwater of the River Blackwater, near Aughentaine, Blackwater, Tyrone, Northern Ireland\nDate of start of the outbreak: 31 Aug 2018\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: river system\nWater type: fresh water\nPopulation type: wild\nProduction system: open\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Morbidity / Mortality / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nWhite clawed crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_) / 100 percent / 100 percent / - / 20 / 20 / 0 / 0 /\nAffected population: 20 dead white-clawed crayfish, which were found during routine field surveys, have subsequently tested positive for crayfish plague. The location where the crayfish were found was at the headwater of the River Blackwater, near Aughentaine. This section of the river was enhanced for salmon habitat during the 1990's and 2000's. Surveillance is on-going. No further reports to date.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed in percentages], expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nWhite clawed crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_) / ** / ** / 100 / **\n* Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n** Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nMarine Institute (regional reference laboratory) / White clawed crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_) / polymerase chain reaction / 14 Sep 2018 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\"Crayfish plague is a highly infectious disease of all crayfish of non-North American origin. The aetiological agent is an oomycete fungus, _Aphanomyces astaci_, which is now widespread in Europe as well as in North America.\n\n\"The disease first occurred in Europe in the 3rd quarter of the 19th century in the Franco-German border region. From there, a steady spread of infection occurred, principally in 2 directions, down the Danube into the Balkans and towards the Black Sea, and across the north German plain into Russia and from there south to the Black Sea and north-west to Finland and finally, in 1907, to Sweden. In the 1960s the 1st outbreaks in Spain were reported and in the 1980s further spread of infection to the British Isles, Turkey, Greece, and Norway was reported.\n\n\"The European crayfish species, the noble crayfish _Astacus astacus_ of north-west Europe, the stone crayfish _Austropotamobius pallipes_ of south-west and west Europe, the related _Austropotamobius torrentium_ (mountain streams of south-west Europe), and the slender clawed or Turkish crayfish _Astacus leptodactylus_ of eastern Europe and Asia Minor are all highly susceptible.\" (https://thefishsite.com/disease-guide/crayfish-plague). - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Northern Ireland, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/36315]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nCrayfish plague - Ireland (04): white-clawed crayfish, conf. Surveillance is on-going. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\"Crayfish plague is a highly infectious disease of all crayfish of non-North American origin. The aetiological agent is an oomycete fungus, _Aphanomyces astaci_, which is now widespread in Europe as well as in North America.\n\n\"The disease first occurred in Europe in the 3rd quarter of the 19th century in the Franco-German border region. From there, a steady spread of infection occurred, principally in 2 directions, down the Danube into the Balkans and towards the Black Sea, and across the north German plain into Russia and from there south to the Black Sea and north-west to Finland and finally, in 1907, to Sweden. In the 1960s the 1st outbreaks in Spain were reported and in the 1980s further spread of infection to the British Isles, Turkey, Greece, and Norway was reported.\n\n\"The European crayfish species, the noble crayfish _Astacus astacus_ of north-west Europe, the stone crayfish _Austropotamobius pallipes_ of south-west and west Europe, the related _Austropotamobius torrentium_ (mountain streams of south-west Europe), and the slender clawed or Turkish crayfish _Astacus leptodactylus_ of eastern Europe and Asia Minor are all highly susceptible.\" (https://thefishsite.com/disease-guide/crayfish-plague). - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Northern Ireland, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/36315]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nCrayfish plague - Ireland (04): white-clawed crayfish, conf. Madagascar", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6361715", "date": "2018-10-17 12:04:49", "main_text": "CRAYFISH PLAGUE - UK: (NORTHERN IRELAND) WHITE-CLAWED CRAYFISH, OIE\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 15 Oct 2018\nSource: OIE, WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System), weekly disease information 2018; 31(42) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=28224\n\n\nCrayfish plague (_Aphanomyces astaci_), United Kingdom\n------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 15 Oct 2018 from Dr Christine Middlemiss, Chief Veterinary Officer, DEFRA, Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs, London, United Kingdom\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 31 Aug 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 14 Sep 2018\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: Jun 2018\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Aphanomyces astaci_\nNature of diagnosis: clinical\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Headwater of the River Blackwater, near Aughentaine, Blackwater, Tyrone, Northern Ireland\nDate of start of the outbreak: 31 Aug 2018\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: river system\nWater type: fresh water\nPopulation type: wild\nProduction system: open\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Morbidity / Mortality / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nWhite clawed crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_) / 100 percent / 100 percent / - / 20 / 20 / 0 / 0 /\nAffected population: 20 dead white-clawed crayfish, which were found during routine field surveys, have subsequently tested positive for crayfish plague. The location where the crayfish were found was at the headwater of the River Blackwater, near Aughentaine. This section of the river was enhanced for salmon habitat during the 1990's and 2000's. Surveillance is on-going. No further reports to date.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed in percentages], expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nWhite clawed crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_) / ** / ** / 100 / **\n* Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n** Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nMarine Institute (regional reference laboratory) / White clawed crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_) / polymerase chain reaction / 14 Sep 2018 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\"Crayfish plague is a highly infectious disease of all crayfish of non-North American origin. The location where the crayfish were found was at the headwater of the River Blackwater, near Aughentaine. This section of the river was enhanced for salmon habitat during the 1990's and 2000's. Surveillance is on-going. No further reports to date.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed in percentages], expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nWhite clawed crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_) / ** / ** / 100 / **\n* Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n** Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nMarine Institute (regional reference laboratory) / White clawed crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_) / polymerase chain reaction / 14 Sep 2018 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\"Crayfish plague is a highly infectious disease of all crayfish of non-North American origin. The aetiological agent is an oomycete fungus, _Aphanomyces astaci_, which is now widespread in Europe as well as in North America.\n\n\"The disease first occurred in Europe in the 3rd quarter of the 19th century in the Franco-German border region. From there, a steady spread of infection occurred, principally in 2 directions, down the Danube into the Balkans and towards the Black Sea, and across the north German plain into Russia and from there south to the Black Sea and north-west to Finland and finally, in 1907, to Sweden. In the 1960s the 1st outbreaks in Spain were reported and in the 1980s further spread of infection to the British Isles, Turkey, Greece, and Norway was reported.\n\n\"The European crayfish species, the noble crayfish _Astacus astacus_ of north-west Europe, the stone crayfish _Austropotamobius pallipes_ of south-west and west Europe, the related _Austropotamobius torrentium_ (mountain streams of south-west Europe), and the slender clawed or Turkish crayfish _Astacus leptodactylus_ of eastern Europe and Asia Minor are all highly susceptible.\" (https://thefishsite.com/disease-guide/crayfish-plague). - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Northern Ireland, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/36315]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nCrayfish plague - Ireland (04): white-clawed crayfish, conf. OIE 20170923.5335961\nCrayfish plague - Ireland (03) 20170918.5324118\nCrayfish plague - Ireland (02): white-clawed crayfish, conf, OIE 20170630.5142833\nCrayfish plague - Ireland: white-clawed crayfish 20170523.5056046\n2015\n----\nCrayfish plague - Ireland (02): white-clawed crayfish, conf, OIE 20150902.3617359\nCrayfish plague - Ireland: white-clawed crayfish mortality 20150820.3591203\n2014\n----\nCrayfish plague - UK: (England) white-clawed crayfish 20141001.2821046\nCrayfish plague - Taiwan: redclaw crayfish, OIE 20140219.2287217\n2013\n----\nCrayfish plague - Israel: (HM) OIE 20131216.2118609\nCrayfish plague - Norway: (NT) OIE 20131022.2013248\n2010\n----\nCrayfish plague - Italy: (VN) OIE 20101126.4268\nCrayfish plague - UK: England 20101108.4054\n2008\n----\nCrayfish plague - UK: (England) 20080808.2444\n.................................................crd/mj/ml/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-09-14 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-09-14 00:00:00", "1907-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Finland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Greece", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6094752", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Anthrax and plague: novel dual vaccine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6094752", "date": "2018-06-14 12:37:33", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (02): (IDAHO)\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 12 Jun 2018\nSource: Idaho Central District Health Department [edited]\nhttp://www.cdhd.idaho.gov/pdfs/News/2018/06-12-18-human-plague-case.pdf\n\n\nPlague was confirmed this week in an Elmore county child. The child is recovering after receiving antimicrobial treatment. \"Plague is spread to humans through a bite from an infected flea. People can decrease their risk by treating their pets for fleas and avoiding contact with wildlife,\" said Sarah Correll, DVM, Central District Health Department epidemiologist. \"Wear insect repellant, long pants, and socks when visiting plague affected areas.\"\n\nIt is not known whether the child was exposed to plague in Idaho or during a recent trip to Oregon. Plague has historically been found in wildlife in both states. Since 1990, 8 human cases were confirmed in Oregon and 2 were confirmed in Idaho.\n\nPlague in humans is rare, but occurs naturally in some rodent populations, including ground squirrels in Idaho. Fleas spread the disease between animals. The disease can also be transmitted to humans by direct contact with infected animals or their fleas. Person-to-person transmission is extremely rare and this case was not a risk to others.\n\nSymptoms of plague usually occur within 2 to 6 days of exposure and include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. In most cases, there is also a painful swelling of the lymph node [called a bubo - Mod.LL] in the groin, armpit, or neck. Plague signs in cats and dogs include fever, lethargy and loss of appetite. There may be a swelling in the lymph nodes under the jaw of pets. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment can greatly reduce the risk of death in people and pets.\n\nPlague was identified in 2015 and 2016 in ground squirrels in both Elmore and south Ada counties. However, this season [2018], no ground squirrel die offs or unusual behavior has been reported by state wildlife officials.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in this case are not stated in the report but it is likely to have been bubonic plague. Of late, 2015 was a \"banner year\" for _Y. pestis_ infections in the USA with 15 cases and 4 deaths. In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year (range: 1-17 cases per year) with 0-2 deaths.\n\nThe following was extracted from: Prentice MB, Rahalison L. Plague. Lancet. 2007; 369(9568): 1196-207, with the citations removed:\n\n\"Some plague cases (10-25 per cent) present with primary septicemia (hypotension, shock) without lymph nodes being obviously affected and these patients have higher mortality than those with bubonic plague. The term septicemic plague can be confusing, since most patients with buboes have detectable bacteremia at some stage and can also have high-density bacteremia with systemic signs of sepsis. Debate about whether septicemic plague is always secondary to frank or subclinical bubonic or pneumonic disease continues, but work in mice lends support to the existence of a syndrome of septicemic disease without histological changes in lymph nodes in a few animals infected by flea bites.\"\n\nElmore county, Idaho which was named after the Ida Elmore mines, producer of silver and gold in the 1860s is located south of Boise and in the southwestern part of the state. Its location can be found on a map at: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elmore_County,_Idaho. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Idaho, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3482]\nSee Also\nPlague - USA: (NM) canine 20180331.5721677\n2017\n----\nPlague - USA (14): (CA) bear, exposure 20171213.5501299\nPlague - USA (13): (AZ) bubonic, infected fleas, alert 20170815.5251542\nPlague - USA (12): (NM) bubonic, squirrel, alert 20170811.5244152\nPlague - USA (11): (AZ) bubonic, prairie dog, die-off 20170807.5233248\nPlague - USA (10): (AZ,TX) bubonic, prairie dogs, fleas 20170723.5197563\nPlague - USA (09): (TX) prairie dog, alert 20170704.5150405\nPlague - USA (08): (NM) 20170626.5132081\nPlague - USA (07): (CO) feline 20170615.5108564\nPlague - USA (06): (NM) 20170606.5087671\nPlague - USA (05): (CO) feline, bubonic, alert: corr 20170506.5017288\nPlague - USA (05): (CO) feline, bubonic, alert 20170505.5014699\nPlague - USA (04): (NM) feral cat, alert 20170419.4980169\nPlague - USA (03): (NM) feline, canine 20170412.4965194\nPlague - USA (02): (CO) prairie dog, alert 20170318.4910519\nPlague - Plague has historically been found in wildlife in both states. Since 1990, 8 human cases were confirmed in Oregon and 2 were confirmed in Idaho.\n\nPlague in humans is rare, but occurs naturally in some rodent populations, including ground squirrels in Idaho. Fleas spread the disease between animals. The disease can also be transmitted to humans by direct contact with infected animals or their fleas. Person-to-person transmission is extremely rare and this case was not a risk to others.\n\nSymptoms of plague usually occur within 2 to 6 days of exposure and include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. In most cases, there is also a painful swelling of the lymph node [called a bubo - Mod.LL] in the groin, armpit, or neck. Plague signs in cats and dogs include fever, lethargy and loss of appetite. There may be a swelling in the lymph nodes under the jaw of pets. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment can greatly reduce the risk of death in people and pets.\n\nPlague was identified in 2015 and 2016 in ground squirrels in both Elmore and south Ada counties. However, this season [2018], no ground squirrel die offs or unusual behavior has been reported by state wildlife officials.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in this case are not stated in the report but it is likely to have been bubonic plague. Of late, 2015 was a \"banner year\" for _Y. pestis_ infections in the USA with 15 cases and 4 deaths. In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year (range: 1-17 cases per year) with 0-2 deaths.\n\nThe following was extracted from: Prentice MB, Rahalison L. Plague. Lancet. 2007; 369(9568): 1196-207, with the citations removed:\n\n\"Some plague cases (10-25 per cent) present with primary septicemia (hypotension, shock) without lymph nodes being obviously affected and these patients have higher mortality than those with bubonic plague. The term septicemic plague can be confusing, since most patients with buboes have detectable bacteremia at some stage and can also have high-density bacteremia with systemic signs of sepsis. Debate about whether septicemic plague is always secondary to frank or subclinical bubonic or pneumonic disease continues, but work in mice lends support to the existence of a syndrome of septicemic disease without histological changes in lymph nodes in a few animals infected by flea bites.\"\n\nElmore county, Idaho which was named after the Ida Elmore mines, producer of silver and gold in the 1860s is located south of Boise and in the southwestern part of the state. Its location can be found on a map at: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elmore_County,_Idaho. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Idaho, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3482]\nSee Also\nPlague - Madagascar (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6039244", "date": "2018-06-14 12:37:33", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (02): (IDAHO)\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 12 Jun 2018\nSource: Idaho Central District Health Department [edited]\nhttp://www.cdhd.idaho.gov/pdfs/News/2018/06-12-18-human-plague-case.pdf\n\n\nPlague was confirmed this week in an Elmore county child. The child is recovering after receiving antimicrobial treatment. \"Plague is spread to humans through a bite from an infected flea. People can decrease their risk by treating their pets for fleas and avoiding contact with wildlife,\" said Sarah Correll, DVM, Central District Health Department epidemiologist. \"Wear insect repellant, long pants, and socks when visiting plague affected areas.\"\n\nIt is not known whether the child was exposed to plague in Idaho or during a recent trip to Oregon. Plague has historically been found in wildlife in both states. Since 1990, 8 human cases were confirmed in Oregon and 2 were confirmed in Idaho.\n\nPlague in humans is rare, but occurs naturally in some rodent populations, including ground squirrels in Idaho. Fleas spread the disease between animals. The disease can also be transmitted to humans by direct contact with infected animals or their fleas. Person-to-person transmission is extremely rare and this case was not a risk to others.\n\nSymptoms of plague usually occur within 2 to 6 days of exposure and include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. In most cases, there is also a painful swelling of the lymph node [called a bubo - Mod.LL] in the groin, armpit, or neck. Plague signs in cats and dogs include fever, lethargy and loss of appetite. There may be a swelling in the lymph nodes under the jaw of pets. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment can greatly reduce the risk of death in people and pets.\n\nPlague was identified in 2015 and 2016 in ground squirrels in both Elmore and south Ada counties. However, this season [2018], no ground squirrel die offs or unusual behavior has been reported by state wildlife officials.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in this case are not stated in the report but it is likely to have been bubonic plague. In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year (range: 1-17 cases per year) with 0-2 deaths.\n\nThe following was extracted from: Prentice MB, Rahalison L. Plague. The term septicemic plague can be confusing, since most patients with buboes have detectable bacteremia at some stage and can also have high-density bacteremia with systemic signs of sepsis. Debate about whether septicemic plague is always secondary to frank or subclinical bubonic or pneumonic disease continues, but work in mice lends support to the existence of a syndrome of septicemic disease without histological changes in lymph nodes in a few animals infected by flea bites.\"\n\nElmore county, Idaho which was named after the Ida Elmore mines, producer of silver and gold in the 1860s is located south of Boise and in the southwestern part of the state. USA (02): (ID)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5856107", "date": "2018-06-14 12:37:33", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (02): (IDAHO)\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 12 Jun 2018\nSource: Idaho Central District Health Department [edited]\nhttp://www.cdhd.idaho.gov/pdfs/News/2018/06-12-18-human-plague-case.pdf\n\n\nPlague was confirmed this week in an Elmore county child. The child is recovering after receiving antimicrobial treatment. \"Plague is spread to humans through a bite from an infected flea. People can decrease their risk by treating their pets for fleas and avoiding contact with wildlife,\" said Sarah Correll, DVM, Central District Health Department epidemiologist. \"Wear insect repellant, long pants, and socks when visiting plague affected areas.\"\n\nIt is not known whether the child was exposed to plague in Idaho or during a recent trip to Oregon. Plague has historically been found in wildlife in both states. Since 1990, 8 human cases were confirmed in Oregon and 2 were confirmed in Idaho.\n\nPlague in humans is rare, but occurs naturally in some rodent populations, including ground squirrels in Idaho. Fleas spread the disease between animals. The disease can also be transmitted to humans by direct contact with infected animals or their fleas. Person-to-person transmission is extremely rare and this case was not a risk to others.\n\nSymptoms of plague usually occur within 2 to 6 days of exposure and include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. In most cases, there is also a painful swelling of the lymph node [called a bubo - Mod.LL] in the groin, armpit, or neck. Plague signs in cats and dogs include fever, lethargy and loss of appetite. There may be a swelling in the lymph nodes under the jaw of pets. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment can greatly reduce the risk of death in people and pets.\n\nPlague was identified in 2015 and 2016 in ground squirrels in both Elmore and south Ada counties. However, this season [2018], no ground squirrel die offs or unusual behavior has been reported by state wildlife officials.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in this case are not stated in the report but it is likely to have been bubonic plague. Of late, 2015 was a \"banner year\" for _Y. pestis_ infections in the USA with 15 cases and 4 deaths. In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year (range: 1-17 cases per year) with 0-2 deaths.\n\nThe following was extracted from: Prentice MB, Rahalison L. Plague. Lancet. 2007; 369(9568): 1196-207, with the citations removed:\n\n\"Some plague cases (10-25 per cent) present with primary septicemia (hypotension, shock) without lymph nodes being obviously affected and these patients have higher mortality than those with bubonic plague. The term septicemic plague can be confusing, since most patients with buboes have detectable bacteremia at some stage and can also have high-density bacteremia with systemic signs of sepsis. Debate about whether septicemic plague is always secondary to frank or subclinical bubonic or pneumonic disease continues, but work in mice lends support to the existence of a syndrome of septicemic disease without histological changes in lymph nodes in a few animals infected by flea bites.\"\n\nElmore county, Idaho which was named after the Ida Elmore mines, producer of silver and gold in the 1860s is located south of Boise and in the southwestern part of the state. Its location can be found on a map at: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elmore_County,_Idaho. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Idaho, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3482]\nSee Also\nPlague - USA (03): (ID) ground squirrel, domestic cat, susp 20160604.4265294\n2015\n----\nPlague, animal - USA (08): (ID) vole, susp. 20150617.3443480\nPlague, animal - USA (07): (ID) canine 20150608.3417597\n.................................................jh/ll/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Elmore county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boise", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5780275", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (02): 2017-2018", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5780275", "date": "2017-12-13 17:20:55", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (14): (CALIFORNIA) BEAR, EXPOSURE\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Dec 2016, 7:03 AM\nSource: The Mercury News [edited]\nhttp://www.mercurynews.com/2017/12/08/bears-exposed-to-plague-found-in-northern-california/\n\n\nTwo black bears exposed to the plague were found in Paradise, according to the California Department of Public Health. The department collected blood in September [2017] from 2 bears killed under depredation permits, and the samples tested positive for antibodies to _Yersinia pestis_, the bacterium that causes plague.\n\nThe California Department of Fish and Wildlife issued the depredation permits. Tanya Espinosa, spokesperson for U.S. Department of Agriculture's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said she could not reveal the location the bears were found because they were not on public lands.\n\nThey were removed by Animal and Plant Health Inspection Services because they were damaging private lands and an agricultural resource, Espinosa said.\n\nThe U.S. Department of Agriculture Wildlife Services routinely submits blood samples from bears and other predators it encounters in wildlife management activities. This is, in part, to determine whether they have been exposed to plague in the past.\n\nPlague is a flea-borne disease spread through contact with infected animals, dead or alive, and flea bites. In the 1300s, it killed millions in Europe, and took on the name of the Black Death. Symptoms include fever, nausea, headaches, weakness and swollen, tender lymph nodes. If caught early, it's treatable in the modern age with antibiotics.\n\nPredators like bears often prey on rodents, which are the primary carriers of plague, according to the state Public Health Department. When bears scavenge a plague-infected rodent, they are exposed to plague bacteria and develop antibodies. These bears were infected with the bacterium that causes plague, but unlike humans, bears do not become ill from plague infection, according to the state.\n\nThe public health department can get an indication of plague activity in a geographic area by testing bear blood samples and finding plague antibodies. Positive samples help identify areas where the state department or local agencies can focus rodent surveillance activities to determine the risk to humans and if there is increased plague activity.\n\nPlague routinely occurs in the Sierra Nevada, where the state public health department suspects the bears were most likely exposed, in the mountains east of Paradise. It's hard to pin down exactly where the plague exposure occurred because bears have large home ranges, according to the department.\n\nHistorically, about 12 percent of bear samples have tested positive for plague antibodies, according to California Department of Public Health. Positive bear samples have been found in 32 counties in California.\n\n[Byline: Ashiah Scharaga]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nThe pathogen occurs in California most commonly in chipmunks, ground squirrels, and other rodents, where infection can be subclinical or contribute to mass die-offs. Carnivores (like bears) may be infected through fleabite or ingestion of infected rodents. Studies of black bears in California found plague antibody prevalence from 15 percent to 36 percent. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map: California, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204>]\nSee Also\nPlague - The department collected blood in September [2017] from 2 bears killed under depredation permits, and the samples tested positive for antibodies to _Yersinia pestis_, the bacterium that causes plague.\n\nThe California Department of Fish and Wildlife issued the depredation permits. Tanya Espinosa, spokesperson for U.S. Department of Agriculture's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said she could not reveal the location the bears were found because they were not on public lands.\n\nThey were removed by Animal and Plant Health Inspection Services because they were damaging private lands and an agricultural resource, Espinosa said.\n\nThe U.S. Department of Agriculture Wildlife Services routinely submits blood samples from bears and other predators it encounters in wildlife management activities. This is, in part, to determine whether they have been exposed to plague in the past.\n\nPlague is a flea-borne disease spread through contact with infected animals, dead or alive, and flea bites. In the 1300s, it killed millions in Europe, and took on the name of the Black Death. Symptoms include fever, nausea, headaches, weakness and swollen, tender lymph nodes. If caught early, it's treatable in the modern age with antibiotics.\n\nPredators like bears often prey on rodents, which are the primary carriers of plague, according to the state Public Health Department. When bears scavenge a plague-infected rodent, they are exposed to plague bacteria and develop antibodies. These bears were infected with the bacterium that causes plague, but unlike humans, bears do not become ill from plague infection, according to the state.\n\nThe public health department can get an indication of plague activity in a geographic area by testing bear blood samples and finding plague antibodies. Positive samples help identify areas where the state department or local agencies can focus rodent surveillance activities to determine the risk to humans and if there is increased plague activity.\n\nPlague routinely occurs in the Sierra Nevada, where the state public health department suspects the bears were most likely exposed, in the mountains east of Paradise. It's hard to pin down exactly where the plague exposure occurred because bears have large home ranges, according to the department.\n\nHistorically, about 12 percent of bear samples have tested positive for plague antibodies, according to California Department of Public Health. Positive bear samples have been found in 32 counties in California.\n\n[Byline: Ashiah Scharaga]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. USA: (NM) canine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5721677", "date": "2017-12-13 17:20:55", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (14): (CALIFORNIA) BEAR, EXPOSURE\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Dec 2016, 7:03 AM\nSource: The Mercury News [edited]\nhttp://www.mercurynews.com/2017/12/08/bears-exposed-to-plague-found-in-northern-california/\n\n\nTwo black bears exposed to the plague were found in Paradise, according to the California Department of Public Health. The department collected blood in September [2017] from 2 bears killed under depredation permits, and the samples tested positive for antibodies to _Yersinia pestis_, the bacterium that causes plague.\n\nThe California Department of Fish and Wildlife issued the depredation permits. Tanya Espinosa, spokesperson for U.S. Department of Agriculture's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said she could not reveal the location the bears were found because they were not on public lands.\n\nThey were removed by Animal and Plant Health Inspection Services because they were damaging private lands and an agricultural resource, Espinosa said.\n\nThe U.S. Department of Agriculture Wildlife Services routinely submits blood samples from bears and other predators it encounters in wildlife management activities. This is, in part, to determine whether they have been exposed to plague in the past.\n\nPlague is a flea-borne disease spread through contact with infected animals, dead or alive, and flea bites. In the 1300s, it killed millions in Europe, and took on the name of the Black Death. Symptoms include fever, nausea, headaches, weakness and swollen, tender lymph nodes. If caught early, it's treatable in the modern age with antibiotics.\n\nPredators like bears often prey on rodents, which are the primary carriers of plague, according to the state Public Health Department. When bears scavenge a plague-infected rodent, they are exposed to plague bacteria and develop antibodies. These bears were infected with the bacterium that causes plague, but unlike humans, bears do not become ill from plague infection, according to the state.\n\nThe public health department can get an indication of plague activity in a geographic area by testing bear blood samples and finding plague antibodies. Positive samples help identify areas where the state department or local agencies can focus rodent surveillance activities to determine the risk to humans and if there is increased plague activity.\n\nPlague routinely occurs in the Sierra Nevada, where the state public health department suspects the bears were most likely exposed, in the mountains east of Paradise. It's hard to pin down exactly where the plague exposure occurred because bears have large home ranges, according to the department.\n\nHistorically, about 12 percent of bear samples have tested positive for plague antibodies, according to California Department of Public Health. Positive bear samples have been found in 32 counties in California.\n\n[Byline: Ashiah Scharaga]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nThe pathogen occurs in California most commonly in chipmunks, ground squirrels, and other rodents, where infection can be subclinical or contribute to mass die-offs. Carnivores (like bears) may be infected through fleabite or ingestion of infected rodents. Studies of black bears in California found plague antibody prevalence from 15 percent to 36 percent. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map: California, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204>]\nSee Also\nPlague - The department collected blood in September [2017] from 2 bears killed under depredation permits, and the samples tested positive for antibodies to _Yersinia pestis_, the bacterium that causes plague.\n\nThe California Department of Fish and Wildlife issued the depredation permits. Tanya Espinosa, spokesperson for U.S. Department of Agriculture's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said she could not reveal the location the bears were found because they were not on public lands.\n\nThey were removed by Animal and Plant Health Inspection Services because they were damaging private lands and an agricultural resource, Espinosa said.\n\nThe U.S. Department of Agriculture Wildlife Services routinely submits blood samples from bears and other predators it encounters in wildlife management activities. This is, in part, to determine whether they have been exposed to plague in the past.\n\nPlague is a flea-borne disease spread through contact with infected animals, dead or alive, and flea bites. In the 1300s, it killed millions in Europe, and took on the name of the Black Death. Symptoms include fever, nausea, headaches, weakness and swollen, tender lymph nodes. If caught early, it's treatable in the modern age with antibiotics.\n\nPredators like bears often prey on rodents, which are the primary carriers of plague, according to the state Public Health Department. When bears scavenge a plague-infected rodent, they are exposed to plague bacteria and develop antibodies. These bears were infected with the bacterium that causes plague, but unlike humans, bears do not become ill from plague infection, according to the state.\n\nThe public health department can get an indication of plague activity in a geographic area by testing bear blood samples and finding plague antibodies. Positive samples help identify areas where the state department or local agencies can focus rodent surveillance activities to determine the risk to humans and if there is increased plague activity.\n\nPlague routinely occurs in the Sierra Nevada, where the state public health department suspects the bears were most likely exposed, in the mountains east of Paradise. It's hard to pin down exactly where the plague exposure occurred because bears have large home ranges, according to the department.\n\nHistorically, about 12 percent of bear samples have tested positive for plague antibodies, according to California Department of Public Health. Positive bear samples have been found in 32 counties in California.\n\n[Byline: Ashiah Scharaga]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. USA: (NM) zoo 20140729.2643587\nPlague - USA (02): (CO) pneumonic 20140710.2600593\nPlague - USA: (NM) pneumonic 20140425.2430602\nand other items in the archives\n.................................................sb/pmb/ao/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5506305", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - China : (GS) septicemic, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5506305", "date": "2017-12-13 17:20:55", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (14): (CALIFORNIA) BEAR, EXPOSURE\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Dec 2016, 7:03 AM\nSource: The Mercury News [edited]\nhttp://www.mercurynews.com/2017/12/08/bears-exposed-to-plague-found-in-northern-california/\n\n\nTwo black bears exposed to the plague were found in Paradise, according to the California Department of Public Health. The department collected blood in September [2017] from 2 bears killed under depredation permits, and the samples tested positive for antibodies to _Yersinia pestis_, the bacterium that causes plague.\n\nThe California Department of Fish and Wildlife issued the depredation permits. Tanya Espinosa, spokesperson for U.S. Department of Agriculture's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said she could not reveal the location the bears were found because they were not on public lands.\n\nThey were removed by Animal and Plant Health Inspection Services because they were damaging private lands and an agricultural resource, Espinosa said.\n\nThe U.S. Department of Agriculture Wildlife Services routinely submits blood samples from bears and other predators it encounters in wildlife management activities. This is, in part, to determine whether they have been exposed to plague in the past.\n\nPlague is a flea-borne disease spread through contact with infected animals, dead or alive, and flea bites. In the 1300s, it killed millions in Europe, and took on the name of the Black Death. Symptoms include fever, nausea, headaches, weakness and swollen, tender lymph nodes. If caught early, it's treatable in the modern age with antibiotics.\n\nPredators like bears often prey on rodents, which are the primary carriers of plague, according to the state Public Health Department. When bears scavenge a plague-infected rodent, they are exposed to plague bacteria and develop antibodies. These bears were infected with the bacterium that causes plague, but unlike humans, bears do not become ill from plague infection, according to the state.\n\nThe public health department can get an indication of plague activity in a geographic area by testing bear blood samples and finding plague antibodies. Positive samples help identify areas where the state department or local agencies can focus rodent surveillance activities to determine the risk to humans and if there is increased plague activity.\n\nPlague routinely occurs in the Sierra Nevada, where the state public health department suspects the bears were most likely exposed, in the mountains east of Paradise. It's hard to pin down exactly where the plague exposure occurred because bears have large home ranges, according to the department.\n\nHistorically, about 12 percent of bear samples have tested positive for plague antibodies, according to California Department of Public Health. Positive bear samples have been found in 32 counties in California.\n\n[Byline: Ashiah Scharaga]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nThe pathogen occurs in California most commonly in chipmunks, ground squirrels, and other rodents, where infection can be subclinical or contribute to mass die-offs. Carnivores (like bears) may be infected through fleabite or ingestion of infected rodents. Studies of black bears in California found plague antibody prevalence from 15 percent to 36 percent. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map: California, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204>]\nSee Also\nPlague - USA (14): (CA) bear, exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5501299", "date": "2017-12-13 17:20:55", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (14): (CALIFORNIA) BEAR, EXPOSURE\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Dec 2016, 7:03 AM\nSource: The Mercury News [edited]\nhttp://www.mercurynews.com/2017/12/08/bears-exposed-to-plague-found-in-northern-california/\n\n\nTwo black bears exposed to the plague were found in Paradise, according to the California Department of Public Health. The department collected blood in September [2017] from 2 bears killed under depredation permits, and the samples tested positive for antibodies to _Yersinia pestis_, the bacterium that causes plague.\n\nThe California Department of Fish and Wildlife issued the depredation permits. Tanya Espinosa, spokesperson for U.S. Department of Agriculture's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said she could not reveal the location the bears were found because they were not on public lands.\n\nThey were removed by Animal and Plant Health Inspection Services because they were damaging private lands and an agricultural resource, Espinosa said.\n\nThe U.S. Department of Agriculture Wildlife Services routinely submits blood samples from bears and other predators it encounters in wildlife management activities. This is, in part, to determine whether they have been exposed to plague in the past.\n\nPlague is a flea-borne disease spread through contact with infected animals, dead or alive, and flea bites. In the 1300s, it killed millions in Europe, and took on the name of the Black Death. Symptoms include fever, nausea, headaches, weakness and swollen, tender lymph nodes. If caught early, it's treatable in the modern age with antibiotics.\n\nPredators like bears often prey on rodents, which are the primary carriers of plague, according to the state Public Health Department. When bears scavenge a plague-infected rodent, they are exposed to plague bacteria and develop antibodies. These bears were infected with the bacterium that causes plague, but unlike humans, bears do not become ill from plague infection, according to the state.\n\nThe public health department can get an indication of plague activity in a geographic area by testing bear blood samples and finding plague antibodies. Positive samples help identify areas where the state department or local agencies can focus rodent surveillance activities to determine the risk to humans and if there is increased plague activity.\n\nPlague routinely occurs in the Sierra Nevada, where the state public health department suspects the bears were most likely exposed, in the mountains east of Paradise. It's hard to pin down exactly where the plague exposure occurred because bears have large home ranges, according to the department.\n\nHistorically, about 12 percent of bear samples have tested positive for plague antibodies, according to California Department of Public Health. Positive bear samples have been found in 32 counties in California.\n\n[Byline: Ashiah Scharaga]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nThe pathogen occurs in California most commonly in chipmunks, ground squirrels, and other rodents, where infection can be subclinical or contribute to mass die-offs. Carnivores (like bears) may be infected through fleabite or ingestion of infected rodents. Madagascar (36): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5482572", "date": "2017-11-06 17:59:10", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (30): FATAL\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/plague-outbreak-update-1947-cases-143-deaths-madagascar-69245/\n\n\nPlague outbreak update: 1947 cases, 143 deaths in Madagascar\n------------------------------------------------------------\nIn an update on the plague outbreak in Madagascar, UN officials now put the ever changing case tally in the epidemic that began on [1 Aug 2017] at 1947 confirmed, probable and suspected cases of plague through [3 Nov 2017]. Of these, 1437 (74 percent) were clinically classified as pulmonary plague, 295 (15 percent) were bubonic plague, one was septicemic, and 211 were not yet classified (further classification of cases is in process). The death count has risen to 143.\n\nOfficials have been saying recently that the number of new cases of pulmonary plague is declining across the country. However, while the decline in the incidence is encouraging, more cases of plague are expected to be reported in Madagascar until the typical plague season ends in April 2018.\n\nTo that effect, sustaining ongoing operations during the outbreak and through the plague season is crucial to minimize the current human-to-human transmission of pneumonic plague and the bubonic plague infections. The key control measures that need to continue to the end of April 2018 include active case finding and treatment, comprehensive contact identification, follow-up and antibiotic treatment, rodent and flea control, and safe and dignified burials.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There continues to be substantial variation in the numbers reported in this significant outbreak of plague, making interpretations of control difficult to make. Additionally, it is still difficult to see how the case fatality rate could be as low as it is with over 60 percent of the cases said to be pneumonic plague.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n-------------------------------------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n27 Oct 2017 / 1554 / 113 / 122\n30 Oct 2017 / 1801 / 127 / 82\n1 Nov 2017 / 1836 / 133 / 17\n3 Nov 2017 / 1947 / 143 / 55\n\nFor any budding pathophysiologists interesting in plague virulence, the following is reproduced here:\nFitts EC, Andersson JA, Kirtley ML, et al: New Insights into Autoinducer-2 signaling as a virulence regulator in a mouse model of pneumonic plague. mSphere. 2016;1(6). pii: e00342-16. eCollection 2016 Nov-Dec, available at:\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5156673/\n\nAbstract:\n\"The Enterobacteriaceae family members, including the infamous _Yersinia pestis_, the causative agent of plague, have a highly conserved interbacterial signaling system that is mediated by the autoinducer-2 (AI-2) quorum-sensing molecule. The AI-2 system is implicated in regulating various bacterial virulence genes in diverse environmental niches. Deletion of the gene encoding the synthetic enzyme for the AI-2 substrate, luxS, leads to either no significant change or, paradoxically, an increase in in-vivo bacterial virulence. We showed that deletion of the rbsA and lsrA genes, components of ABC transport systems that interact with AI-2, synergistically disrupted AI-2 signaling patterns and resulted in a more-than-50-fold decrease in _Y. pestis_ strain CO92 virulence in a stringent pneumonic plague mouse model. Deletion of luxS or lsrK (encoding AI-2 kinase) from the ArbsA AlsrA background strain or complementation of the ArbsA AlsrA mutant with the corresponding gene(s) reverted the virulence phenotype to that of the wild-type _Y. pestis_ CO92. Furthermore, the administration of synthetic AI-2 in mice infected with the ArbsA AlsrA AluxS mutant strain attenuated this triple mutant to a virulence phenotype similar to that of the ArbsA AlsrA strain in a pneumonic plague model. Conversely, the administration of AI-2 to mice infected with the ArbsA AlsrA AluxS AlsrK mutant did not rescue animals from lethality, indicating the importance of the AI-2-LsrK axis in regulating bacterial virulence. By performing high-throughput RNA sequencing, the potential role of some AI-2-signaling-regulated genes that modulated bacterial virulence was determined. We anticipate that the characterization of AI-2 signaling in _Y. pestis_ will lead to reexamination of AI-2 systems in other pathogens and that AI-2 signaling may represent a broad-spectrum therapeutic target to combat antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which represent a global crisis of the 21st century.\n\n\"_Yersinia pestis_ is the bacterial agent that causes the highly fatal disease plague. The organism represents a significant concern because of its potential use as a bioterrorism agent, beyond the several thousand naturally occurring human infection cases occurring globally each year. While there has been development of effective antibiotics, the narrow therapeutic window and challenges posed by the existence of antibiotic-resistant strains represent serious concerns. We sought to identify novel virulence factors that could potentially be incorporated into an attenuated vaccine platform or be targeted by novel therapeutics. We show here that a highly conserved quorum-sensing system, autoinducer-2, significantly affected the virulence of _Y. pestis_ in a mouse model of pneumonic plague. We also identified steps in autoinducer-2 signaling which had confounded previous studies and demonstrated the potential for intervention in the virulence mechanism(s) of autoinducer-2. Our findings may have an impact on bacterial pathogenesis research in many other organisms and could result in identifying potential broad-spectrum therapeutic targets to combat antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which represent a global crisis of the 21st century.\" - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]\nSee Also\nPlague - Madagascar (29): fatal 20171104.5422504\nPlague - Madagascar (28): fatal, WHO 20171102.5420572\nPlague - Madagascar (10): fatal 20171004.5361339\nPlague - Madagascar (09): fatal, WHO 20171002.5355599\nPlague - Madagascar (08): fatal 20171001.5353252\nPlague - Madagascar (07): fatal 20170929.5349814\nPlague - Madagascar (06): fatal 20170927.5344842\nPlague - Madagascar (05): fatal 20170922.5334851\nPlague - Madagascar (04): fatal 20170920.5329820\nPlague - Madagascar (03): fatal 20170912.5311663\nPlague - Madagascar (02): 2nd cluster 20170122.4784059\nPlague - Uganda: 2011-2014, ciprofloxacin efficacy 20170217.4846917\nPlague - Madagascar: fatalities 20170110.4754927\n.................................................ll/ao/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1947-03-16 00:00:00", "1947-03-16 00:00:00", "1437-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5481202", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (35): fatal, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5467648", "date": "2017-11-06 17:59:10", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (30): FATAL\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/plague-outbreak-update-1947-cases-143-deaths-madagascar-69245/\n\n\nPlague outbreak update: 1947 cases, 143 deaths in Madagascar\n------------------------------------------------------------\nIn an update on the plague outbreak in Madagascar, UN officials now put the ever changing case tally in the epidemic that began on [1 Aug 2017] at 1947 confirmed, probable and suspected cases of plague through [3 Nov 2017]. Of these, 1437 (74 percent) were clinically classified as pulmonary plague, 295 (15 percent) were bubonic plague, one was septicemic, and 211 were not yet classified (further classification of cases is in process). The death count has risen to 143.\n\nOfficials have been saying recently that the number of new cases of pulmonary plague is declining across the country. However, while the decline in the incidence is encouraging, more cases of plague are expected to be reported in Madagascar until the typical plague season ends in April 2018.\n\nTo that effect, sustaining ongoing operations during the outbreak and through the plague season is crucial to minimize the current human-to-human transmission of pneumonic plague and the bubonic plague infections. The key control measures that need to continue to the end of April 2018 include active case finding and treatment, comprehensive contact identification, follow-up and antibiotic treatment, rodent and flea control, and safe and dignified burials.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There continues to be substantial variation in the numbers reported in this significant outbreak of plague, making interpretations of control difficult to make. Additionally, it is still difficult to see how the case fatality rate could be as low as it is with over 60 percent of the cases said to be pneumonic plague.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n-------------------------------------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n27 Oct 2017 / 1554 / 113 / 122\n30 Oct 2017 / 1801 / 127 / 82\n1 Nov 2017 / 1836 / 133 / 17\n3 Nov 2017 / 1947 / 143 / 55\n\nFor any budding pathophysiologists interesting in plague virulence, the following is reproduced here:\nFitts EC, Andersson JA, Kirtley ML, et al: New Insights into Autoinducer-2 signaling as a virulence regulator in a mouse model of pneumonic plague. mSphere. 2016;1(6). pii: e00342-16. eCollection 2016 Nov-Dec, available at:\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5156673/\n\nAbstract:\n\"The Enterobacteriaceae family members, including the infamous _Yersinia pestis_, the causative agent of plague, have a highly conserved interbacterial signaling system that is mediated by the autoinducer-2 (AI-2) quorum-sensing molecule. The AI-2 system is implicated in regulating various bacterial virulence genes in diverse environmental niches. Deletion of the gene encoding the synthetic enzyme for the AI-2 substrate, luxS, leads to either no significant change or, paradoxically, an increase in in-vivo bacterial virulence. We showed that deletion of the rbsA and lsrA genes, components of ABC transport systems that interact with AI-2, synergistically disrupted AI-2 signaling patterns and resulted in a more-than-50-fold decrease in _Y. pestis_ strain CO92 virulence in a stringent pneumonic plague mouse model. Deletion of luxS or lsrK (encoding AI-2 kinase) from the ArbsA AlsrA background strain or complementation of the ArbsA AlsrA mutant with the corresponding gene(s) reverted the virulence phenotype to that of the wild-type _Y. pestis_ CO92. Furthermore, the administration of synthetic AI-2 in mice infected with the ArbsA AlsrA AluxS mutant strain attenuated this triple mutant to a virulence phenotype similar to that of the ArbsA AlsrA strain in a pneumonic plague model. Conversely, the administration of AI-2 to mice infected with the ArbsA AlsrA AluxS AlsrK mutant did not rescue animals from lethality, indicating the importance of the AI-2-LsrK axis in regulating bacterial virulence. By performing high-throughput RNA sequencing, the potential role of some AI-2-signaling-regulated genes that modulated bacterial virulence was determined. We anticipate that the characterization of AI-2 signaling in _Y. pestis_ will lead to reexamination of AI-2 systems in other pathogens and that AI-2 signaling may represent a broad-spectrum therapeutic target to combat antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which represent a global crisis of the 21st century.\n\n\"_Yersinia pestis_ is the bacterial agent that causes the highly fatal disease plague. The organism represents a significant concern because of its potential use as a bioterrorism agent, beyond the several thousand naturally occurring human infection cases occurring globally each year. While there has been development of effective antibiotics, the narrow therapeutic window and challenges posed by the existence of antibiotic-resistant strains represent serious concerns. We sought to identify novel virulence factors that could potentially be incorporated into an attenuated vaccine platform or be targeted by novel therapeutics. We show here that a highly conserved quorum-sensing system, autoinducer-2, significantly affected the virulence of _Y. pestis_ in a mouse model of pneumonic plague. We also identified steps in autoinducer-2 signaling which had confounded previous studies and demonstrated the potential for intervention in the virulence mechanism(s) of autoinducer-2. Our findings may have an impact on bacterial pathogenesis research in many other organisms and could result in identifying potential broad-spectrum therapeutic targets to combat antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which represent a global crisis of the 21st century.\" - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]\nSee Also\nPlague - Madagascar (29): fatal 20171104.5422504\nPlague - Madagascar (28): fatal, WHO 20171102.5420572\nPlague - Madagascar (34): fatal, decreasing caseload", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5453966", "date": "2017-11-06 17:59:10", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (30): FATAL\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/plague-outbreak-update-1947-cases-143-deaths-madagascar-69245/\n\n\nPlague outbreak update: 1947 cases, 143 deaths in Madagascar\n------------------------------------------------------------\nIn an update on the plague outbreak in Madagascar, UN officials now put the ever changing case tally in the epidemic that began on [1 Aug 2017] at 1947 confirmed, probable and suspected cases of plague through [3 Nov 2017]. Of these, 1437 (74 percent) were clinically classified as pulmonary plague, 295 (15 percent) were bubonic plague, one was septicemic, and 211 were not yet classified (further classification of cases is in process). The death count has risen to 143.\n\nOfficials have been saying recently that the number of new cases of pulmonary plague is declining across the country. However, while the decline in the incidence is encouraging, more cases of plague are expected to be reported in Madagascar until the typical plague season ends in April 2018.\n\nTo that effect, sustaining ongoing operations during the outbreak and through the plague season is crucial to minimize the current human-to-human transmission of pneumonic plague and the bubonic plague infections. The key control measures that need to continue to the end of April 2018 include active case finding and treatment, comprehensive contact identification, follow-up and antibiotic treatment, rodent and flea control, and safe and dignified burials.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There continues to be substantial variation in the numbers reported in this significant outbreak of plague, making interpretations of control difficult to make. We anticipate that the characterization of AI-2 signaling in _Y. pestis_ will lead to reexamination of AI-2 systems in other pathogens and that AI-2 signaling may represent a broad-spectrum therapeutic target to combat antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which represent a global crisis of the 21st century.\n\n\"_Yersinia pestis_ is the bacterial agent that causes the highly fatal disease plague. The organism represents a significant concern because of its potential use as a bioterrorism agent, beyond the several thousand naturally occurring human infection cases occurring globally each year. While there has been development of effective antibiotics, the narrow therapeutic window and challenges posed by the existence of antibiotic-resistant strains represent serious concerns. We sought to identify novel virulence factors that could potentially be incorporated into an attenuated vaccine platform or be targeted by novel therapeutics. We show here that a highly conserved quorum-sensing system, autoinducer-2, significantly affected the virulence of _Y. pestis_ in a mouse model of pneumonic plague. We also identified steps in autoinducer-2 signaling which had confounded previous studies and demonstrated the potential for intervention in the virulence mechanism(s) of autoinducer-2. Our findings may have an impact on bacterial pathogenesis research in many other organisms and could result in identifying potential broad-spectrum therapeutic targets to combat antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which represent a global crisis of the 21st century.\" -
