Madagascar (02): 2nd cluster 20170122.4784059\nPlague - Uganda: 2011-2014, ciprofloxacin efficacy 20170217.4846917\nPlague - Madagascar: fatalities 20170110.4754927\n.................................................ll/ao/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1947-03-16 00:00:00", "1947-03-16 00:00:00", "1437-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5448645", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (32): fatal, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5448645", "date": "2017-11-06 17:59:10", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (30): FATAL\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/plague-outbreak-update-1947-cases-143-deaths-madagascar-69245/\n\n\nPlague outbreak update: 1947 cases, 143 deaths in Madagascar\n------------------------------------------------------------\nIn an update on the plague outbreak in Madagascar, UN officials now put the ever changing case tally in the epidemic that began on [1 Aug 2017] at 1947 confirmed, probable and suspected cases of plague through [3 Nov 2017]. Of these, 1437 (74 percent) were clinically classified as pulmonary plague, 295 (15 percent) were bubonic plague, one was septicemic, and 211 were not yet classified (further classification of cases is in process). The death count has risen to 143.\n\nOfficials have been saying recently that the number of new cases of pulmonary plague is declining across the country. However, while the decline in the incidence is encouraging, more cases of plague are expected to be reported in Madagascar until the typical plague season ends in April 2018.\n\nTo that effect, sustaining ongoing operations during the outbreak and through the plague season is crucial to minimize the current human-to-human transmission of pneumonic plague and the bubonic plague infections. The key control measures that need to continue to the end of April 2018 include active case finding and treatment, comprehensive contact identification, follow-up and antibiotic treatment, rodent and flea control, and safe and dignified burials.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There continues to be substantial variation in the numbers reported in this significant outbreak of plague, making interpretations of control difficult to make. Additionally, it is still difficult to see how the case fatality rate could be as low as it is with over 60 percent of the cases said to be pneumonic plague.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n-------------------------------------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n27 Oct 2017 / 1554 / 113 / 122\n30 Oct 2017 / 1801 / 127 / 82\n1 Nov 2017 / 1836 / 133 / 17\n3 Nov 2017 / 1947 / 143 / 55\n\nFor any budding pathophysiologists interesting in plague virulence, the following is reproduced here:\nFitts EC, Andersson JA, Kirtley ML, et al: New Insights into Autoinducer-2 signaling as a virulence regulator in a mouse model of pneumonic plague. mSphere. 2016;1(6). pii: e00342-16. eCollection 2016 Nov-Dec, available at:\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5156673/\n\nAbstract:\n\"The Enterobacteriaceae family members, including the infamous _Yersinia pestis_, the causative agent of plague, have a highly conserved interbacterial signaling system that is mediated by the autoinducer-2 (AI-2) quorum-sensing molecule. The AI-2 system is implicated in regulating various bacterial virulence genes in diverse environmental niches. Deletion of the gene encoding the synthetic enzyme for the AI-2 substrate, luxS, leads to either no significant change or, paradoxically, an increase in in-vivo bacterial virulence. We showed that deletion of the rbsA and lsrA genes, components of ABC transport systems that interact with AI-2, synergistically disrupted AI-2 signaling patterns and resulted in a more-than-50-fold decrease in _Y. pestis_ strain CO92 virulence in a stringent pneumonic plague mouse model. Deletion of luxS or lsrK (encoding AI-2 kinase) from the ArbsA AlsrA background strain or complementation of the ArbsA AlsrA mutant with the corresponding gene(s) reverted the virulence phenotype to that of the wild-type _Y. pestis_ CO92. Furthermore, the administration of synthetic AI-2 in mice infected with the ArbsA AlsrA AluxS mutant strain attenuated this triple mutant to a virulence phenotype similar to that of the ArbsA AlsrA strain in a pneumonic plague model. Conversely, the administration of AI-2 to mice infected with the ArbsA AlsrA AluxS AlsrK mutant did not rescue animals from lethality, indicating the importance of the AI-2-LsrK axis in regulating bacterial virulence. By performing high-throughput RNA sequencing, the potential role of some AI-2-signaling-regulated genes that modulated bacterial virulence was determined. We anticipate that the characterization of AI-2 signaling in _Y. pestis_ will lead to reexamination of AI-2 systems in other pathogens and that AI-2 signaling may represent a broad-spectrum therapeutic target to combat antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which represent a global crisis of the 21st century.\n\n\"_Yersinia pestis_ is the bacterial agent that causes the highly fatal disease plague. The organism represents a significant concern because of its potential use as a bioterrorism agent, beyond the several thousand naturally occurring human infection cases occurring globally each year. While there has been development of effective antibiotics, the narrow therapeutic window and challenges posed by the existence of antibiotic-resistant strains represent serious concerns. We sought to identify novel virulence factors that could potentially be incorporated into an attenuated vaccine platform or be targeted by novel therapeutics. We show here that a highly conserved quorum-sensing system, autoinducer-2, significantly affected the virulence of _Y. pestis_ in a mouse model of pneumonic plague. We also identified steps in autoinducer-2 signaling which had confounded previous studies and demonstrated the potential for intervention in the virulence mechanism(s) of autoinducer-2. Our findings may have an impact on bacterial pathogenesis research in many other organisms and could result in identifying potential broad-spectrum therapeutic targets to combat antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which represent a global crisis of the 21st century.\" - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]\nSee Also\nPlague - Madagascar (29): fatal 20171104.5422504\nPlague - Madagascar (28): fatal, WHO 20171102.5420572\nPlague - Madagascar (30): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5427532", "date": "2017-11-06 17:59:10", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (30): FATAL\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/plague-outbreak-update-1947-cases-143-deaths-madagascar-69245/\n\n\nPlague outbreak update: 1947 cases, 143 deaths in Madagascar\n------------------------------------------------------------\nIn an update on the plague outbreak in Madagascar, UN officials now put the ever changing case tally in the epidemic that began on [1 Aug 2017] at 1947 confirmed, probable and suspected cases of plague through [3 Nov 2017]. Of these, 1437 (74 percent) were clinically classified as pulmonary plague, 295 (15 percent) were bubonic plague, one was septicemic, and 211 were not yet classified (further classification of cases is in process). The death count has risen to 143.\n\nOfficials have been saying recently that the number of new cases of pulmonary plague is declining across the country. However, while the decline in the incidence is encouraging, more cases of plague are expected to be reported in Madagascar until the typical plague season ends in April 2018.\n\nTo that effect, sustaining ongoing operations during the outbreak and through the plague season is crucial to minimize the current human-to-human transmission of pneumonic plague and the bubonic plague infections. The key control measures that need to continue to the end of April 2018 include active case finding and treatment, comprehensive contact identification, follow-up and antibiotic treatment, rodent and flea control, and safe and dignified burials.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There continues to be substantial variation in the numbers reported in this significant outbreak of plague, making interpretations of control difficult to make. Additionally, it is still difficult to see how the case fatality rate could be as low as it is with over 60 percent of the cases said to be pneumonic plague.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n-------------------------------------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n27 Oct 2017 / 1554 / 113 / 122\n30 Oct 2017 / 1801 / 127 / 82\n1 Nov 2017 / 1836 / 133 / 17\n3 Nov 2017 / 1947 / 143 / 55\n\nFor any budding pathophysiologists interesting in plague virulence, the following is reproduced here:\nFitts EC, Andersson JA, Kirtley ML, et al: New Insights into Autoinducer-2 signaling as a virulence regulator in a mouse model of pneumonic plague. mSphere. 2016;1(6). pii: e00342-16. eCollection 2016 Nov-Dec, available at:\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5156673/\n\nAbstract:\n\"The Enterobacteriaceae family members, including the infamous _Yersinia pestis_, the causative agent of plague, have a highly conserved interbacterial signaling system that is mediated by the autoinducer-2 (AI-2) quorum-sensing molecule. The AI-2 system is implicated in regulating various bacterial virulence genes in diverse environmental niches. By performing high-throughput RNA sequencing, the potential role of some AI-2-signaling-regulated genes that modulated bacterial virulence was determined. We anticipate that the characterization of AI-2 signaling in _Y. pestis_ will lead to reexamination of AI-2 systems in other pathogens and that AI-2 signaling may represent a broad-spectrum therapeutic target to combat antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which represent a global crisis of the 21st century.\n\n\"_Yersinia pestis_ is the bacterial agent that causes the highly fatal disease plague. The organism represents a significant concern because of its potential use as a bioterrorism agent, beyond the several thousand naturally occurring human infection cases occurring globally each year. While there has been development of effective antibiotics, the narrow therapeutic window and challenges posed by the existence of antibiotic-resistant strains represent serious concerns. We sought to identify novel virulence factors that could potentially be incorporated into an attenuated vaccine platform or be targeted by novel therapeutics. We show here that a highly conserved quorum-sensing system, autoinducer-2, significantly affected the virulence of _Y. pestis_ in a mouse model of pneumonic plague. We also identified steps in autoinducer-2 signaling which had confounded previous studies and demonstrated the potential for intervention in the virulence mechanism(s) of autoinducer-2. Our findings may have an impact on bacterial pathogenesis research in many other organisms and could result in identifying potential broad-spectrum therapeutic targets to combat antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which represent a global crisis of the 21st century.\" - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]\nSee Also\nPlague - Madagascar (29): fatal 20171104.5422504\nPlague - Madagascar (28): fatal, WHO 20171102.5420572\nPlague - Madagascar (29): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5422504", "date": "2017-10-20 11:15:02", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (22): FATAL\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 19 Oct 2017 2:50 PM\nSource: Voice of America (VOA) News [edited]\nhttps://www.voanews.com/a/un-says-madagascar-plague-cases-top-1000-mark/4077923.html\n\n\nThe number of cases of plague in Madagascar has doubled during the past 5 days, according to the UN. UN spokesperson Stephane Dujarric said [Thu 19 Oct 2017] as of [Wed 18 Oct 2017], 1032 cases were reported, 67 percent of which are pneumonic, which is more serious than bubonic plague. So far 89 deaths have been recorded, including 13 on [Tue 17 Oct 2017]. Dujarric said the spread was \"highly challenging\" to control.\n\nMedical teams in the country have stepped up efforts to combat the spread of the plague, but experts have said the situation will worsen if not rapidly funded. Only 26 percent of the USD 9.5 million requested has been contributed, Dujarric said.\n\nPneumonic plague is a lung infection, transmitted through flea bites or from person to person through droplets in the air when someone coughs or sneezes. A person can die within 48 hours of the disease's onset if not treated with antibiotics. Symptoms of pneumonic plague include coughing, fever, chest pain and difficulty breathing.\n\nWhile plague is a recurring problem in Madagascar, this particular outbreak has triggered a nationwide panic because it has moved from remote rural areas into the cities, including the capital, Antananarivo.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 19 Oct 2017\nSource: BNGRC (National Office for the Management of Risks and Crises) [in French. trans., edited]edited]\nhttp://www.bngrc-mid.mg/images/document/Peste2017/Bulletin_Flash_19_10_2017_20h00_vff6.pdf\n\n\nCurrently, 39 districts in 17 Regions of Madagascar are affected by the plague epidemic. To date, 911 cases have been reported, of which 612 are pneumonic, 175 are bubonic, and 124 are unspecified. The overall results show 554 people who have already recovered and left the hospital, 262 people undergoing treatment, and 95 deaths.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[These separate reports from the same day show quite different numbers; the VOA report cites UN data with 1032 cases and 89 deaths and the Madagascar generated data cites 911 cases (121 fewer cases) but 95 deaths (6 more deaths). These are different sources of data and, as with the Yemeni cholera epidemic, numbers can vary. Whichever set of numbers is correct is less important than that the outbreak is still growing. It is still early in the plague season but the number of cases has surpassed most recent years.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n-------------------------------------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n- Mod. Madagascar (26): fatal, revised numbers, transportation", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5415688", "date": "2017-10-20 11:15:02", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (22): FATAL\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 19 Oct 2017 2:50 PM\nSource: Voice of America (VOA) News [edited]\nhttps://www.voanews.com/a/un-says-madagascar-plague-cases-top-1000-mark/4077923.html\n\n\nThe number of cases of plague in Madagascar has doubled during the past 5 days, according to the UN. UN spokesperson Stephane Dujarric said [Thu 19 Oct 2017] as of [Wed 18 Oct 2017], 1032 cases were reported, 67 percent of which are pneumonic, which is more serious than bubonic plague. So far 89 deaths have been recorded, including 13 on [Tue 17 Oct 2017]. Dujarric said the spread was \"highly challenging\" to control.\n\nMedical teams in the country have stepped up efforts to combat the spread of the plague, but experts have said the situation will worsen if not rapidly funded. Only 26 percent of the USD 9.5 million requested has been contributed, Dujarric said.\n\nPneumonic plague is a lung infection, transmitted through flea bites or from person to person through droplets in the air when someone coughs or sneezes. A person can die within 48 hours of the disease's onset if not treated with antibiotics. Symptoms of pneumonic plague include coughing, fever, chest pain and difficulty breathing.\n\nWhile plague is a recurring problem in Madagascar, this particular outbreak has triggered a nationwide panic because it has moved from remote rural areas into the cities, including the capital, Antananarivo.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 19 Oct 2017\nSource: BNGRC (National Office for the Management of Risks and Crises) [in French. trans., edited]edited]\nhttp://www.bngrc-mid.mg/images/document/Peste2017/Bulletin_Flash_19_10_2017_20h00_vff6.pdf\n\n\nCurrently, 39 districts in 17 Regions of Madagascar are affected by the plague epidemic. To date, 911 cases have been reported, of which 612 are pneumonic, 175 are bubonic, and 124 are unspecified. The overall results show 554 people who have already recovered and left the hospital, 262 people undergoing treatment, and 95 deaths.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[These separate reports from the same day show quite different numbers; the VOA report cites UN data with 1032 cases and 89 deaths and the Madagascar generated data cites 911 cases (121 fewer cases) but 95 deaths (6 more deaths). These are different sources of data and, as with the Yemeni cholera epidemic, numbers can vary. Whichever set of numbers is correct is less important than that the outbreak is still growing. It is still early in the plague season but the number of cases has surpassed most recent years.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n-------------------------------------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n- Mod. Madagascar (25): fatal, revised numbers, health care transmission", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5405650", "date": "2017-10-20 11:15:02", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (22): FATAL\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 19 Oct 2017 2:50 PM\nSource: Voice of America (VOA) News [edited]\nhttps://www.voanews.com/a/un-says-madagascar-plague-cases-top-1000-mark/4077923.html\n\n\nThe number of cases of plague in Madagascar has doubled during the past 5 days, according to the UN. UN spokesperson Stephane Dujarric said [Thu 19 Oct 2017] as of [Wed 18 Oct 2017], 1032 cases were reported, 67 percent of which are pneumonic, which is more serious than bubonic plague. So far 89 deaths have been recorded, including 13 on [Tue 17 Oct 2017]. Dujarric said the spread was \"highly challenging\" to control.\n\nMedical teams in the country have stepped up efforts to combat the spread of the plague, but experts have said the situation will worsen if not rapidly funded. Only 26 percent of the USD 9.5 million requested has been contributed, Dujarric said.\n\nPneumonic plague is a lung infection, transmitted through flea bites or from person to person through droplets in the air when someone coughs or sneezes. A person can die within 48 hours of the disease's onset if not treated with antibiotics. Symptoms of pneumonic plague include coughing, fever, chest pain and difficulty breathing.\n\nWhile plague is a recurring problem in Madagascar, this particular outbreak has triggered a nationwide panic because it has moved from remote rural areas into the cities, including the capital, Antananarivo.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 19 Oct 2017\nSource: BNGRC (National Office for the Management of Risks and Crises) [in French. trans., edited]edited]\nhttp://www.bngrc-mid.mg/images/document/Peste2017/Bulletin_Flash_19_10_2017_20h00_vff6.pdf\n\n\nCurrently, 39 districts in 17 Regions of Madagascar are affected by the plague epidemic. To date, 911 cases have been reported, of which 612 are pneumonic, 175 are bubonic, and 124 are unspecified. The overall results show 554 people who have already recovered and left the hospital, 262 people undergoing treatment, and 95 deaths.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[These separate reports from the same day show quite different numbers; the VOA report cites UN data with 1032 cases and 89 deaths and the Madagascar generated data cites 911 cases (121 fewer cases) but 95 deaths (6 more deaths). Madagascar: fatalities 20170110.4754927\n.................................................ll/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["cholera", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-22 00:00:00", "1032-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "1032-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5392390", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (22): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5392390", "date": "2017-10-20 11:15:02", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (22): FATAL\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 19 Oct 2017 2:50 PM\nSource: Voice of America (VOA) News [edited]\nhttps://www.voanews.com/a/un-says-madagascar-plague-cases-top-1000-mark/4077923.html\n\n\nThe number of cases of plague in Madagascar has doubled during the past 5 days, according to the UN. UN spokesperson Stephane Dujarric said [Thu 19 Oct 2017] as of [Wed 18 Oct 2017], 1032 cases were reported, 67 percent of which are pneumonic, which is more serious than bubonic plague. So far 89 deaths have been recorded, including 13 on [Tue 17 Oct 2017]. Dujarric said the spread was \"highly challenging\" to control.\n\nMedical teams in the country have stepped up efforts to combat the spread of the plague, but experts have said the situation will worsen if not rapidly funded. Only 26 percent of the USD 9.5 million requested has been contributed, Dujarric said.\n\nPneumonic plague is a lung infection, transmitted through flea bites or from person to person through droplets in the air when someone coughs or sneezes. A person can die within 48 hours of the disease's onset if not treated with antibiotics. Symptoms of pneumonic plague include coughing, fever, chest pain and difficulty breathing.\n\nWhile plague is a recurring problem in Madagascar, this particular outbreak has triggered a nationwide panic because it has moved from remote rural areas into the cities, including the capital, Antananarivo.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 19 Oct 2017\nSource: BNGRC (National Office for the Management of Risks and Crises) [in French. trans., edited]edited]\nhttp://www.bngrc-mid.mg/images/document/Peste2017/Bulletin_Flash_19_10_2017_20h00_vff6.pdf\n\n\nCurrently, 39 districts in 17 Regions of Madagascar are affected by the plague epidemic. To date, 911 cases have been reported, of which 612 are pneumonic, 175 are bubonic, and 124 are unspecified. The overall results show 554 people who have already recovered and left the hospital, 262 people undergoing treatment, and 95 deaths.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[These separate reports from the same day show quite different numbers; the VOA report cites UN data with 1032 cases and 89 deaths and the Madagascar generated data cites 911 cases (121 fewer cases) but 95 deaths (6 more deaths). These are different sources of data and, as with the Yemeni cholera epidemic, numbers can vary. Whichever set of numbers is correct is less important than that the outbreak is still growing. It is still early in the plague season but the number of cases has surpassed most recent years.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n-------------------------------------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n- Mod. LL\n\nMaps of Madagascar can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/madagascar/mar2582r/madagascar_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nPlague - Madagascar (21): fatal, numbers growing, WHO, MOH", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5389292", "date": "2017-10-13 11:56:51", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (18): FATAL\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] New Madagascar Case Numbers\n[2] Antimicrobial Sensitivities of Current _Y. pestis_ Isolates\n\n******\n[1] New Madagascar Case Numbers\nDate: Thu 12 Oct 2017\nSource: Government of Madagascar [machine trans. edited]\nhttp://www.sante.gov.mg/home/uploads/____folderforallfiles/Bulletin%20Flash%20-12-10-2017-20h00%20-%20vf.pdf\n\n\nFor the whole country, 35 districts were affected by the plague epidemic. A total of 561 reported cases of plague were recorded, including 415 pulmonary forms, 145 bubonic forms, and another unspecified case. In general, there are 57 deaths with a national case fatality rate of 10.2% (the ratio of deaths to the total number of cases reported). The following figures show the distribution of case numbers by district (above) and region (below) [The numbers for each district and region can be seen at the original URL. - Mod.LL]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nMelissa Dudley\nSenior Health Intelligence Analyst\n<mlsdudley@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED thanks Melissa Dudley for this posting.\n\nThe rapid rise of cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infection with a predominance of pneumonic plague (415/561 - 74%) is quite worrisome.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths\n---------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57\n\nThe dates above are the day before each report was released. The number of new cases per day, which appears to be increasing, starting on 5 Oct 2017 is:\n\n5 Oct 2017 - 32\n7 Oct 2017 - 43\n8 Oct 2017 - 44\n9 Oct 2017 - 62\n10 Oct 2017 - 51\n11 Oct 2017 - 61\n- Mod.LL\n\n******\n[2] Antimicrobial Sensitivities of Current _Y. pestis_ Isolates\nDate: Fri 13 Oct 2017\nSource: Pasteur Institute Madagascar [machine trans. edited]\nhttp://www.pasteur.mg/synthese-resultats-biologiques-peste-mise-a-jour-6-octobre-2017/\n\n\nMonitoring the susceptibility of strains of _Yersinia pestis_ to different antimicrobials is a priority for the success of the National Program for the Control of Plague. It detects the emergence of strains of reduced susceptibility or resistance to streptomycin and sulfonamides, antimicrobials recommended and used in the National Program, and evaluates other alternatives (tetracycline, ciprofloxacin, and chloramphenicol) for treatment.\n\nSince the beginning of the season, the 11 isolated strains are sensitive to these antimicrobials. They have been isolated from Miarinarivo, Moramanga, Mahajanga, Tsiroanomandidy and Andramasina.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAmanda Walsh\nPublic Health England\n<amanda.walsh@phe.gov.uk>\n\n[ProMED thanks Amanda Walsh for a source to the antimicrobial sensitivity data for strains in the current outbreak, which appear to be fully sensitive. - The number of new cases per day, which appears to be increasing, starting on 5 Oct 2017 is:\n\n5 Oct 2017 - 32\n7 Oct 2017 - 43\n8 Oct 2017 - 44\n9 Oct 2017 - 62\n10 Oct 2017 - 51\n11 Oct 2017 - 61\n- Mod.LL\n\n******\n[2] Antimicrobial Sensitivities of Current _Y. pestis_ Isolates\nDate: Fri 13 Oct 2017\nSource: Pasteur Institute Madagascar [machine trans. edited]\nhttp://www.pasteur.mg/synthese-resultats-biologiques-peste-mise-a-jour-6-octobre-2017/\n\n\nMonitoring the susceptibility of strains of _Yersinia pestis_ to different antimicrobials is a priority for the success of the National Program for the Control of Plague. It detects the emergence of strains of reduced susceptibility or resistance to streptomycin and sulfonamides, antimicrobials recommended and used in the National Program, and evaluates other alternatives (tetracycline, ciprofloxacin, and chloramphenicol) for treatment.\n\nSince the beginning of the season, the 11 isolated strains are sensitive to these antimicrobials. They have been isolated from Miarinarivo, Moramanga, Mahajanga, Tsiroanomandidy and Andramasina.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAmanda Walsh\nPublic Health England\n<amanda.walsh@phe.gov.uk>\n\n[ProMED thanks Amanda Walsh for a source to the antimicrobial sensitivity data for strains in the current outbreak, which appear to be fully sensitive. - Mauritius: ex Madagascar, NOT", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5384887", "date": "2017-10-13 11:56:51", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (18): FATAL\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] New Madagascar Case Numbers\n[2] Antimicrobial Sensitivities of Current _Y. pestis_ Isolates\n\n******\n[1] New Madagascar Case Numbers\nDate: Thu 12 Oct 2017\nSource: Government of Madagascar [machine trans. edited]\nhttp://www.sante.gov.mg/home/uploads/____folderforallfiles/Bulletin%20Flash%20-12-10-2017-20h00%20-%20vf.pdf\n\n\nFor the whole country, 35 districts were affected by the plague epidemic. A total of 561 reported cases of plague were recorded, including 415 pulmonary forms, 145 bubonic forms, and another unspecified case. In general, there are 57 deaths with a national case fatality rate of 10.2% (the ratio of deaths to the total number of cases reported). The following figures show the distribution of case numbers by district (above) and region (below) [The numbers for each district and region can be seen at the original URL. - Mod.LL]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nMelissa Dudley\nSenior Health Intelligence Analyst\n<mlsdudley@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED thanks Melissa Dudley for this posting.\n\nThe rapid rise of cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infection with a predominance of pneumonic plague (415/561 - 74%) is quite worrisome.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths\n---------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57\n\nThe dates above are the day before each report was released. It detects the emergence of strains of reduced susceptibility or resistance to streptomycin and sulfonamides, antimicrobials recommended and used in the National Program, and evaluates other alternatives (tetracycline, ciprofloxacin, and chloramphenicol) for treatment.\n\nSince the beginning of the season, the 11 isolated strains are sensitive to these antimicrobials. A total of 561 reported cases of plague were recorded, including 415 pulmonary forms, 145 bubonic forms, and another unspecified case. In general, there are 57 deaths with a national case fatality rate of 10.2% (the ratio of deaths to the total number of cases reported). The following figures show the distribution of case numbers by district (above) and region (below) [The numbers for each district and region can be seen at the original URL. - Mod.LL]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nMelissa Dudley\nSenior Health Intelligence Analyst\n<mlsdudley@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED thanks Melissa Dudley for this posting.\n\nThe rapid rise of cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infection with a predominance of pneumonic plague (415/561 - 74%) is quite worrisome.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths\n---------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57\n\nThe dates above are the day before each report was released. The number of new cases per day, which appears to be increasing, starting on 5 Oct 2017 is:\n\n5 Oct 2017 - 32\n7 Oct 2017 - 43\n8 Oct 2017 - 44\n9 Oct 2017 - 62\n10 Oct 2017 - 51\n11 Oct 2017 - 61\n- Mod.LL\n\n******\n[2] Antimicrobial Sensitivities of Current _Y. pestis_ Isolates\nDate: Fri 13 Oct 2017\nSource: Pasteur Institute Madagascar [machine trans. edited]\nhttp://www.pasteur.mg/synthese-resultats-biologiques-peste-mise-a-jour-6-octobre-2017/\n\n\nMonitoring the susceptibility of strains of _Yersinia pestis_ to different antimicrobials is a priority for the success of the National Program for the Control of Plague. It detects the emergence of strains of reduced susceptibility or resistance to streptomycin and sulfonamides, antimicrobials recommended and used in the National Program, and evaluates other alternatives (tetracycline, ciprofloxacin, and chloramphenicol) for treatment.\n\nSince the beginning of the season, the 11 isolated strains are sensitive to these antimicrobials. They have been isolated from Miarinarivo, Moramanga, Mahajanga, Tsiroanomandidy and Andramasina.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAmanda Walsh\nPublic Health England\n<amanda.walsh@phe.gov.uk>\n\n[ProMED thanks Amanda Walsh for a source to the antimicrobial sensitivity data for strains in the current outbreak, which appear to be fully sensitive. - Seychelles (03): ex Madagascar, MOH, travel ban", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5376069", "date": "2017-10-08 16:07:43", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (13): FATAL, MORE CASES, EXPORTATIONS\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] More Cases\n[2] Exportations\n\n******\n[1] More Cases\nDate: Sun 8 Oct 2017\nSource: Premium Times [edited]\nhttps://www.premiumtimesng.com/foreign/africa/245444-plague-madagascar-schools-closed-death-toll-rises-42.html\n\n\nSchools in several cities across Madagascar will stay closed this week [week of Sun 8 Oct 2017] due to an outbreak of bubonic plague, with the death toll rising to 42, the Health Ministry said on [Sun 8 Oct 2017]. The government had already prohibited crowds from gathering in order to curb the further spread of the dangerous disease that had sickened 343 people as of [Sun 8 Oct 2017], according to Health Ministry figures. On [Fri 6 Oct 2017], the ministry put the death toll at 36, with 250 sickened.\n\n\"In the heavily populated capital, Antananarivo, 142 people have been infected. Schools in the affected cities of Antananarivo, Toamasina and other regions have been closed for a week,\" the health ministry said. Outbreaks of bubonic plague are common in Madagascar, which lies off Africa's southeastern coast, but the most recent outbreak has included cases of the more serious pneumonic form of plague. About 400 cases of plague are reported in Madagascar every year, most of them bubonic, which is transmitted by fleas. The much rarer pneumonic strain of the disease that is spread person-to-person is fatal unless treated within 24 hours.\n\nThe WHO said it had delivered 1.4 million doses of antimicrobials to Madagascar in view of the plague. With this up to 5000 infected people can be treated and 100 000 can be given a prophylaxis. With early diagnosis, the chances of recovery are good,\" said WHO.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Exportations\nDate: Sat 7 Oct 2017\nSource: UPI [edited]\nhttps://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2017/10/07/WHO-acting-to-contain-Madagascar-plague-outbreak/9891507406347/\n\n\nThe WHO issued a warning about a worrisome outbreak of plague on the African island of Madagascar that has caused 200 infections and 33 deaths since September 2017 [as above, now 343 and 42 - Mod.LL].\n\nThe outbreak of plague is an annual occurrence in Madagascar, which normally reports about 400 cases per year, usually in the remote island highlands. What makes this outbreak different, according to the WHO, is that many of the infected live in more densely populated towns and the capital Antananarivo. Also, the infections reported are pneumatic plague, which is transmitted through the air, making it much more difficult to control.\n\nPneumatic plague is different from bubonic plague, which is the more common form on Madagascar. Bubonic plague is transmitted when an infected individual is bitten by fleas carried by rats. On Madagascar, the outbreaks are more common in rural rice farming areas and are not as easily transmitted. Both versions of the plague were the cause of the Black Death epidemic in the mid-14th century, which wiped out a 3rd of Europe's population.\n\nIn response to the threat, Madagascar's government has closed schools, businesses and outlawed large public gatherings including concerts and sporting events where the disease could be spread to dozens or even hundreds of people at a time.\n\nThe disease is already confirmed to have left the island after several participants in an international basketball tournament displayed symptoms after arriving home. One coach from the Indian Ocean island nation Seychelles died and another from South Africa was diagnosed but survived. Other tournament participants are being monitored for symptoms.\n\nThe outbreak is similar in some respects to the deadly Ebola outbreak that ravaged parts of west Africa in 2014. Similar to Madagascar's outbreak, a single individual infected in an isolated area traveled to a population center, sparking a deadly outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Eric DuVall]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The case count is growing. The date below is generally the day before the date of the report:\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths\n__________________\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42\n\nIt was difficult to see that the fatality in the Seychelles basketball case had presented after returning home and apparently there is a related case in South Africa with a nonfatal outcome. The analogy to the west Africa Ebola outbreak is somewhat fitting as both had a primarily rural infection introduced in an urban setting. Certainly, cases in an urban setting are a major concern locally and with the possibility of air travel spread. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]\nSee Also\nPlague - Madagascar (02) 20150212.3162376\nPlague - Madagascar 20150108.3076901\n.................................................sb/ll/ec/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-09-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5375932", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - The government had already prohibited crowds from gathering in order to curb the further spread of the dangerous disease that had sickened 343 people as of [Sun 8 Oct 2017], according to Health Ministry figures. On [Fri 6 Oct 2017], the ministry put the death toll at 36, with 250 sickened.\n\n\"In the heavily populated capital, Antananarivo, 142 people have been infected. Schools in the affected cities of Antananarivo, Toamasina and other regions have been closed for a week,\" the health ministry said. Outbreaks of bubonic plague are common in Madagascar, which lies off Africa's southeastern coast, but the most recent outbreak has included cases of the more serious pneumonic form of plague. What makes this outbreak different, according to the WHO, is that many of the infected live in more densely populated towns and the capital Antananarivo. Also, the infections reported are pneumatic plague, which is transmitted through the air, making it much more difficult to control.\n\nPneumatic plague is different from bubonic plague, which is the more common form on Madagascar. Bubonic plague is transmitted when an infected individual is bitten by fleas carried by rats. On Madagascar, the outbreaks are more common in rural rice farming areas and are not as easily transmitted. Both versions of the plague were the cause of the Black Death epidemic in the mid-14th century, which wiped out a 3rd of Europe's population.\n\nIn response to the threat, Madagascar's government has closed schools, businesses and outlawed large public gatherings including concerts and sporting events where the disease could be spread to dozens or even hundreds of people at a time.\n\nThe disease is already confirmed to have left the island after several participants in an international basketball tournament displayed symptoms after arriving home. Other tournament participants are being monitored for symptoms.\n\nThe outbreak is similar in some respects to the deadly Ebola outbreak that ravaged parts of west Africa in 2014. Madagascar (02) 20150212.3162376\nPlague - Madagascar 20150108.3076901\n.................................................sb/ll/ec/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-09-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5374264", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (16): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5374264", "date": "2017-10-08 16:07:43", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (13): FATAL, MORE CASES, EXPORTATIONS\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] More Cases\n[2] Exportations\n\n******\n[1] More Cases\nDate: Sun 8 Oct 2017\nSource: Premium Times [edited]\nhttps://www.premiumtimesng.com/foreign/africa/245444-plague-madagascar-schools-closed-death-toll-rises-42.html\n\n\nSchools in several cities across Madagascar will stay closed this week [week of Sun 8 Oct 2017] due to an outbreak of bubonic plague, with the death toll rising to 42, the Health Ministry said on [Sun 8 Oct 2017]. The government had already prohibited crowds from gathering in order to curb the further spread of the dangerous disease that had sickened 343 people as of [Sun 8 Oct 2017], according to Health Ministry figures. On [Fri 6 Oct 2017], the ministry put the death toll at 36, with 250 sickened.\n\n\"In the heavily populated capital, Antananarivo, 142 people have been infected. Schools in the affected cities of Antananarivo, Toamasina and other regions have been closed for a week,\" the health ministry said. Outbreaks of bubonic plague are common in Madagascar, which lies off Africa's southeastern coast, but the most recent outbreak has included cases of the more serious pneumonic form of plague. About 400 cases of plague are reported in Madagascar every year, most of them bubonic, which is transmitted by fleas. The much rarer pneumonic strain of the disease that is spread person-to-person is fatal unless treated within 24 hours.\n\nThe WHO said it had delivered 1.4 million doses of antimicrobials to Madagascar in view of the plague. With this up to 5000 infected people can be treated and 100 000 can be given a prophylaxis. With early diagnosis, the chances of recovery are good,\" said WHO.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Exportations\nDate: Sat 7 Oct 2017\nSource: UPI [edited]\nhttps://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2017/10/07/WHO-acting-to-contain-Madagascar-plague-outbreak/9891507406347/\n\n\nThe WHO issued a warning about a worrisome outbreak of plague on the African island of Madagascar that has caused 200 infections and 33 deaths since September 2017 [as above, now 343 and 42 - Mod.LL].\n\nThe outbreak of plague is an annual occurrence in Madagascar, which normally reports about 400 cases per year, usually in the remote island highlands. What makes this outbreak different, according to the WHO, is that many of the infected live in more densely populated towns and the capital Antananarivo. Also, the infections reported are pneumatic plague, which is transmitted through the air, making it much more difficult to control.\n\nPneumatic plague is different from bubonic plague, which is the more common form on Madagascar. Bubonic plague is transmitted when an infected individual is bitten by fleas carried by rats. On Madagascar, the outbreaks are more common in rural rice farming areas and are not as easily transmitted. Both versions of the plague were the cause of the Black Death epidemic in the mid-14th century, which wiped out a 3rd of Europe's population.\n\nIn response to the threat, Madagascar's government has closed schools, businesses and outlawed large public gatherings including concerts and sporting events where the disease could be spread to dozens or even hundreds of people at a time.\n\nThe disease is already confirmed to have left the island after several participants in an international basketball tournament displayed symptoms after arriving home. One coach from the Indian Ocean island nation Seychelles died and another from South Africa was diagnosed but survived. Other tournament participants are being monitored for symptoms.\n\nThe outbreak is similar in some respects to the deadly Ebola outbreak that ravaged parts of west Africa in 2014. Similar to Madagascar's outbreak, a single individual infected in an isolated area traveled to a population center, sparking a deadly outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Eric DuVall]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The case count is growing. The date below is generally the day before the date of the report:\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths\n__________________\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42\n\nIt was difficult to see that the fatality in the Seychelles basketball case had presented after returning home and apparently there is a related case in South Africa with a nonfatal outcome. The analogy to the west Africa Ebola outbreak is somewhat fitting as both had a primarily rural infection introduced in an urban setting. Certainly, cases in an urban setting are a major concern locally and with the possibility of air travel spread. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]\nSee Also\nPlague - Madagascar (02) 20150212.3162376\nPlague - Madagascar 20150108.3076901\n.................................................sb/ll/ec/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-09-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5373068", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Seychelles (02): poss. local spread, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5373068", "date": "2017-10-08 16:07:43", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (13): FATAL, MORE CASES, EXPORTATIONS\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] More Cases\n[2] Exportations\n\n******\n[1] More Cases\nDate: Sun 8 Oct 2017\nSource: Premium Times [edited]\nhttps://www.premiumtimesng.com/foreign/africa/245444-plague-madagascar-schools-closed-death-toll-rises-42.html\n\n\nSchools in several cities across Madagascar will stay closed this week [week of Sun 8 Oct 2017] due to an outbreak of bubonic plague, with the death toll rising to 42, the Health Ministry said on [Sun 8 Oct 2017]. The government had already prohibited crowds from gathering in order to curb the further spread of the dangerous disease that had sickened 343 people as of [Sun 8 Oct 2017], according to Health Ministry figures. On [Fri 6 Oct 2017], the ministry put the death toll at 36, with 250 sickened.\n\n\"In the heavily populated capital, Antananarivo, 142 people have been infected. Schools in the affected cities of Antananarivo, Toamasina and other regions have been closed for a week,\" the health ministry said. Outbreaks of bubonic plague are common in Madagascar, which lies off Africa's southeastern coast, but the most recent outbreak has included cases of the more serious pneumonic form of plague. About 400 cases of plague are reported in Madagascar every year, most of them bubonic, which is transmitted by fleas. The much rarer pneumonic strain of the disease that is spread person-to-person is fatal unless treated within 24 hours.\n\nThe WHO said it had delivered 1.4 million doses of antimicrobials to Madagascar in view of the plague. With this up to 5000 infected people can be treated and 100 000 can be given a prophylaxis. With early diagnosis, the chances of recovery are good,\" said WHO.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Exportations\nDate: Sat 7 Oct 2017\nSource: UPI [edited]\nhttps://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2017/10/07/WHO-acting-to-contain-Madagascar-plague-outbreak/9891507406347/\n\n\nThe WHO issued a warning about a worrisome outbreak of plague on the African island of Madagascar that has caused 200 infections and 33 deaths since September 2017 [as above, now 343 and 42 - Mod.LL].\n\nThe outbreak of plague is an annual occurrence in Madagascar, which normally reports about 400 cases per year, usually in the remote island highlands. What makes this outbreak different, according to the WHO, is that many of the infected live in more densely populated towns and the capital Antananarivo. Also, the infections reported are pneumatic plague, which is transmitted through the air, making it much more difficult to control.\n\nPneumatic plague is different from bubonic plague, which is the more common form on Madagascar. Bubonic plague is transmitted when an infected individual is bitten by fleas carried by rats. On Madagascar, the outbreaks are more common in rural rice farming areas and are not as easily transmitted. Both versions of the plague were the cause of the Black Death epidemic in the mid-14th century, which wiped out a 3rd of Europe's population.\n\nIn response to the threat, Madagascar's government has closed schools, businesses and outlawed large public gatherings including concerts and sporting events where the disease could be spread to dozens or even hundreds of people at a time.\n\nThe disease is already confirmed to have left the island after several participants in an international basketball tournament displayed symptoms after arriving home. One coach from the Indian Ocean island nation Seychelles died and another from South Africa was diagnosed but survived. Other tournament participants are being monitored for symptoms.\n\nThe outbreak is similar in some respects to the deadly Ebola outbreak that ravaged parts of west Africa in 2014. Similar to Madagascar's outbreak, a single individual infected in an isolated area traveled to a population center, sparking a deadly outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Eric DuVall]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The case count is growing. The analogy to the west Africa Ebola outbreak is somewhat fitting as both had a primarily rural infection introduced in an urban setting. The government had already prohibited crowds from gathering in order to curb the further spread of the dangerous disease that had sickened 343 people as of [Sun 8 Oct 2017], according to Health Ministry figures. On [Fri 6 Oct 2017], the ministry put the death toll at 36, with 250 sickened.\n\n\"In the heavily populated capital, Antananarivo, 142 people have been infected. Schools in the affected cities of Antananarivo, Toamasina and other regions have been closed for a week,\" the health ministry said. Outbreaks of bubonic plague are common in Madagascar, which lies off Africa's southeastern coast, but the most recent outbreak has included cases of the more serious pneumonic form of plague. About 400 cases of plague are reported in Madagascar every year, most of them bubonic, which is transmitted by fleas. The much rarer pneumonic strain of the disease that is spread person-to-person is fatal unless treated within 24 hours.\n\nThe WHO said it had delivered 1.4 million doses of antimicrobials to Madagascar in view of the plague. With this up to 5000 infected people can be treated and 100 000 can be given a prophylaxis. With early diagnosis, the chances of recovery are good,\" said WHO.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Exportations\nDate: Sat 7 Oct 2017\nSource: UPI [edited]\nhttps://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2017/10/07/WHO-acting-to-contain-Madagascar-plague-outbreak/9891507406347/\n\n\nThe WHO issued a warning about a worrisome outbreak of plague on the African island of Madagascar that has caused 200 infections and 33 deaths since September 2017 [as above, now 343 and 42 - Mod.LL].\n\nThe outbreak of plague is an annual occurrence in Madagascar, which normally reports about 400 cases per year, usually in the remote island highlands. What makes this outbreak different, according to the WHO, is that many of the infected live in more densely populated towns and the capital Antananarivo. Also, the infections reported are pneumatic plague, which is transmitted through the air, making it much more difficult to control.\n\nPneumatic plague is different from bubonic plague, which is the more common form on Madagascar. Bubonic plague is transmitted when an infected individual is bitten by fleas carried by rats. On Madagascar, the outbreaks are more common in rural rice farming areas and are not as easily transmitted. Both versions of the plague were the cause of the Black Death epidemic in the mid-14th century, which wiped out a 3rd of Europe's population.\n\nIn response to the threat, Madagascar's government has closed schools, businesses and outlawed large public gatherings including concerts and sporting events where the disease could be spread to dozens or even hundreds of people at a time.\n\nThe disease is already confirmed to have left the island after several participants in an international basketball tournament displayed symptoms after arriving home. One coach from the Indian Ocean island nation Seychelles died and another from South Africa was diagnosed but survived. Other tournament participants are being monitored for symptoms.\n\nThe outbreak is similar in some respects to the deadly Ebola outbreak that ravaged parts of west Africa in 2014. Similar to Madagascar's outbreak, a single individual infected in an isolated area traveled to a population center, sparking a deadly outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Eric DuVall]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The case count is growing. The date below is generally the day before the date of the report:\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths\n__________________\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42\n\nIt was difficult to see that the fatality in the Seychelles basketball case had presented after returning home and apparently there is a related case in South Africa with a nonfatal outcome. The analogy to the west Africa Ebola outbreak is somewhat fitting as both had a primarily rural infection introduced in an urban setting. Certainly, cases in an urban setting are a major concern locally and with the possibility of air travel spread. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]\nSee Also\nPlague - Madagascar (02) 20150212.3162376\nPlague - Madagascar 20150108.3076901\n.................................................sb/ll/ec/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-09-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5367613", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (14): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5367613", "date": "2017-10-08 16:07:43", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (13): FATAL, MORE CASES, EXPORTATIONS\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] More Cases\n[2] Exportations\n\n******\n[1] More Cases\nDate: Sun 8 Oct 2017\nSource: Premium Times [edited]\nhttps://www.premiumtimesng.com/foreign/africa/245444-plague-madagascar-schools-closed-death-toll-rises-42.html\n\n\nSchools in several cities across Madagascar will stay closed this week [week of Sun 8 Oct 2017] due to an outbreak of bubonic plague, with the death toll rising to 42, the Health Ministry said on [Sun 8 Oct 2017]. The government had already prohibited crowds from gathering in order to curb the further spread of the dangerous disease that had sickened 343 people as of [Sun 8 Oct 2017], according to Health Ministry figures. On [Fri 6 Oct 2017], the ministry put the death toll at 36, with 250 sickened.\n\n\"In the heavily populated capital, Antananarivo, 142 people have been infected. Schools in the affected cities of Antananarivo, Toamasina and other regions have been closed for a week,\" the health ministry said. Outbreaks of bubonic plague are common in Madagascar, which lies off Africa's southeastern coast, but the most recent outbreak has included cases of the more serious pneumonic form of plague. About 400 cases of plague are reported in Madagascar every year, most of them bubonic, which is transmitted by fleas. The much rarer pneumonic strain of the disease that is spread person-to-person is fatal unless treated within 24 hours.\n\nThe WHO said it had delivered 1.4 million doses of antimicrobials to Madagascar in view of the plague. With this up to 5000 infected people can be treated and 100 000 can be given a prophylaxis. With early diagnosis, the chances of recovery are good,\" said WHO.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Exportations\nDate: Sat 7 Oct 2017\nSource: UPI [edited]\nhttps://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2017/10/07/WHO-acting-to-contain-Madagascar-plague-outbreak/9891507406347/\n\n\nThe WHO issued a warning about a worrisome outbreak of plague on the African island of Madagascar that has caused 200 infections and 33 deaths since September 2017 [as above, now 343 and 42 - Mod.LL].\n\nThe outbreak of plague is an annual occurrence in Madagascar, which normally reports about 400 cases per year, usually in the remote island highlands. What makes this outbreak different, according to the WHO, is that many of the infected live in more densely populated towns and the capital Antananarivo. Also, the infections reported are pneumatic plague, which is transmitted through the air, making it much more difficult to control.\n\nPneumatic plague is different from bubonic plague, which is the more common form on Madagascar. Bubonic plague is transmitted when an infected individual is bitten by fleas carried by rats. On Madagascar, the outbreaks are more common in rural rice farming areas and are not as easily transmitted. Both versions of the plague were the cause of the Black Death epidemic in the mid-14th century, which wiped out a 3rd of Europe's population.\n\nIn response to the threat, Madagascar's government has closed schools, businesses and outlawed large public gatherings including concerts and sporting events where the disease could be spread to dozens or even hundreds of people at a time.\n\nThe disease is already confirmed to have left the island after several participants in an international basketball tournament displayed symptoms after arriving home. One coach from the Indian Ocean island nation Seychelles died and another from South Africa was diagnosed but survived. Other tournament participants are being monitored for symptoms.\n\nThe outbreak is similar in some respects to the deadly Ebola outbreak that ravaged parts of west Africa in 2014. Similar to Madagascar's outbreak, a single individual infected in an isolated area traveled to a population center, sparking a deadly outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Eric DuVall]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The case count is growing. The date below is generally the day before the date of the report:\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths\n__________________\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42\n\nIt was difficult to see that the fatality in the Seychelles basketball case had presented after returning home and apparently there is a related case in South Africa with a nonfatal outcome. The analogy to the west Africa Ebola outbreak is somewhat fitting as both had a primarily rural infection introduced in an urban setting. Certainly, cases in an urban setting are a major concern locally and with the possibility of air travel spread. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]\nSee Also\nPlague - Madagascar (12): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5366522", "date": "2017-09-25 15:24:27", "main_text": "PLAGUE - IRAQ (02): (BAGHDAD) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 24 Sep 2017\nSource: Alghad Press [in Arabic, trans. Mod.NS, edited]\nhttps://www.alghadpress.com/news/Iraq-News/119679/AlghadPress\n\n\nThe Parliamentary Health and Environment Committee revealed on [Sun 24 Sep 2017] the spread of plague and called for a national campaign against rodents that are causing the disease.\n\nThe deputy head of the Parliamentary Health and Environment Committee, Fares Al-Barefkani, told Alghad Press that \"new cases of plague have been identified, and the causes of the disease are known and are related to the poor municipal, disease control, sewage, and landfill services, in addition to widespread residential slums.\"\n\nAl-Barefkani indicated that \"there are a lot of residential slums that have emerged and are not under the control of Baghdad municipality and lack health services.\" He called for \"a serious national campaign to combat rodents in the residential neighborhoods that cause plague and provide medicines that help to eliminate the disease\" and stressed that \"there is a need to support Baghdad municipality and the health and the environment directorates to educate people on how to combat plague.\"\n\nAl-Barefkani added that \"the Parliamentary Health and Environment Committee does not have accurate data on the number of cases because we are in the process of follow-up in all the governorates.\"\n\nOn Tuesday [12 Sep 2017], the Ministry of Health denied some social media and other media reports about the occurrence of plague cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>via\nvia ProMED-MENA\n<promed-mena@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED would again appreciate more information regarding whether plague cases have occurred in Iraq as it had been previously denied. If plague is present there, a program to eradicate rodents alone will not be effective in preventing human cases as the infected flea vector will seek other blood sources, such as humans.\n\nThis publication regarding the history of _Yersinia pestis_ in Iran also reviews the history of plague in other countries in the Middle East including Iraq:\n\nHashemi Shahraki A, Carniel E, Mostafavi E: Plague in Iran: its history and current status. Epidemiol Health. 2016 Jul 24; 38: e2016033; available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5037359/.\n\n\"Throughout its history, Iraq has experienced multiple epidemics of plague. In 716 and 717 CE, a large outbreak known as al-Ashraf (the Notables) was recorded in Iraq and Syria. In an epidemic of bubonic plague in 1772 and 1773, many victims died in cities such as Basra (with 250 000 deaths) and Mosul. In 1801 CE, a large plague epidemic occurred in Mosul and Baghdad. A plague epidemic occurred again in Baghdad in 1908. From 1923 to 1924, approximately 90 cases of pneumonic plague were reported in Baghdad, and some plague outbreaks were reported in Basra.\" - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/54548.]\nSee Also\nPlague - Iraq: (Baghdad) MOH, denied, RFI 20170913.5313580\n2015\n----\nPlague - Kyrgyzstan: (YK) fatality 20150916.3647353\n2014\n----\nPlague - China (03): (GS) pneumonic, fatality 20141017.2874953\nPlague - Algeria (Oran) 20030622.1537\n.................................................ns/ll/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "1772-03-16 00:00:00", "1773-03-16 00:00:00", "1801-03-16 00:00:00", "1908-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Baghdad", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Basra", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "BAGHDAD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "IRAQ", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Algeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iraq", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Libya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iran", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Syria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "yk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mosul", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5363591", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (11): fatal, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5363591", "date": "2017-09-25 15:24:27", "main_text": "PLAGUE - IRAQ (02): (BAGHDAD) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 24 Sep 2017\nSource: Alghad Press [in Arabic, trans. Mod.NS, edited]\nhttps://www.alghadpress.com/news/Iraq-News/119679/AlghadPress\n\n\nThe Parliamentary Health and Environment Committee revealed on [Sun 24 Sep 2017] the spread of plague and called for a national campaign against rodents that are causing the disease.\n\nThe deputy head of the Parliamentary Health and Environment Committee, Fares Al-Barefkani, told Alghad Press that \"new cases of plague have been identified, and the causes of the disease are known and are related to the poor municipal, disease control, sewage, and landfill services, in addition to widespread residential slums.\"\n\nAl-Barefkani indicated that \"there are a lot of residential slums that have emerged and are not under the control of Baghdad municipality and lack health services.\" He called for \"a serious national campaign to combat rodents in the residential neighborhoods that cause plague and provide medicines that help to eliminate the disease\" and stressed that \"there is a need to support Baghdad municipality and the health and the environment directorates to educate people on how to combat plague.\"\n\nAl-Barefkani added that \"the Parliamentary Health and Environment Committee does not have accurate data on the number of cases because we are in the process of follow-up in all the governorates.\"\n\nOn Tuesday [12 Sep 2017], the Ministry of Health denied some social media and other media reports about the occurrence of plague cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>via\nvia ProMED-MENA\n<promed-mena@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED would again appreciate more information regarding whether plague cases have occurred in Iraq as it had been previously denied. If plague is present there, a program to eradicate rodents alone will not be effective in preventing human cases as the infected flea vector will seek other blood sources, such as humans.\n\nThis publication regarding the history of _Yersinia pestis_ in Iran also reviews the history of plague in other countries in the Middle East including Iraq:\n\nHashemi Shahraki A, Carniel E, Mostafavi E: Plague in Iran: its history and current status. Epidemiol Health. 2016 Jul 24; 38: e2016033; available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5037359/.\n\n\"Throughout its history, Iraq has experienced multiple epidemics of plague. In 716 and 717 CE, a large outbreak known as al-Ashraf (the Notables) was recorded in Iraq and Syria. In an epidemic of bubonic plague in 1772 and 1773, many victims died in cities such as Basra (with 250 000 deaths) and Mosul. In 1801 CE, a large plague epidemic occurred in Mosul and Baghdad. A plague epidemic occurred again in Baghdad in 1908. From 1923 to 1924, approximately 90 cases of pneumonic plague were reported in Baghdad, and some plague outbreaks were reported in Basra.\" - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/54548.]\nSee Also\nPlague - Iraq: (Baghdad) MOH, denied, RFI 20170913.5313580\n2015\n----\nPlague - Kyrgyzstan: (YK) fatality 20150916.3647353\n2014\n----\nPlague - China (03): (GS) pneumonic, fatality 20141017.2874953\nPlague - China: (GS) pneumonic, fatality 20140718.2620341\n2013\n----\nPlague - Kyrgyzstan: (YK) fatal 20130829.1909839\nPlague - Russia: (DA) RFI 20130711.1819290\n2012\n----\nPlague - China: (SC) bubonic, fatal 20120911.1290061\n2011\n----\nPlague, pneumonic, 2009 - Madagascar (10): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5361339", "date": "2017-09-25 15:24:27", "main_text": "PLAGUE - IRAQ (02): (BAGHDAD) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 24 Sep 2017\nSource: Alghad Press [in Arabic, trans. Mod.NS, edited]\nhttps://www.alghadpress.com/news/Iraq-News/119679/AlghadPress\n\n\nThe Parliamentary Health and Environment Committee revealed on [Sun 24 Sep 2017] the spread of plague and called for a national campaign against rodents that are causing the disease.\n\nThe deputy head of the Parliamentary Health and Environment Committee, Fares Al-Barefkani, told Alghad Press that \"new cases of plague have been identified, and the causes of the disease are known and are related to the poor municipal, disease control, sewage, and landfill services, in addition to widespread residential slums.\"\n\nAl-Barefkani indicated that \"there are a lot of residential slums that have emerged and are not under the control of Baghdad municipality and lack health services.\" He called for \"a serious national campaign to combat rodents in the residential neighborhoods that cause plague and provide medicines that help to eliminate the disease\" and stressed that \"there is a need to support Baghdad municipality and the health and the environment directorates to educate people on how to combat plague.\"\n\nAl-Barefkani added that \"the Parliamentary Health and Environment Committee does not have accurate data on the number of cases because we are in the process of follow-up in all the governorates.\"\n\nOn Tuesday [12 Sep 2017], the Ministry of Health denied some social media and other media reports about the occurrence of plague cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>via\nvia ProMED-MENA\n<promed-mena@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED would again appreciate more information regarding whether plague cases have occurred in Iraq as it had been previously denied. If plague is present there, a program to eradicate rodents alone will not be effective in preventing human cases as the infected flea vector will seek other blood sources, such as humans.\n\nThis publication regarding the history of _Yersinia pestis_ in Iran also reviews the history of plague in other countries in the Middle East including Iraq:\n\nHashemi Shahraki A, Carniel E, Mostafavi E: Plague in Iran: its history and current status. Epidemiol Health. 2016 Jul 24; 38: e2016033; available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5037359/.\n\n\"Throughout its history, Iraq has experienced multiple epidemics of plague. In 716 and 717 CE, a large outbreak known as al-Ashraf (the Notables) was recorded in Iraq and Syria. In an epidemic of bubonic plague in 1772 and 1773, many victims died in cities such as Basra (with 250 000 deaths) and Mosul. In 1801 CE, a large plague epidemic occurred in Mosul and Baghdad. A plague epidemic occurred again in Baghdad in 1908. From 1923 to 1924, approximately 90 cases of pneumonic plague were reported in Baghdad, and some plague outbreaks were reported in Basra.\" - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/54548.]\nSee Also\nPlague -
