USA (06): comment 20140807.2666637\nPlague, animal - USA (05): (CA) squirrel 20140804.2656788\nPlague - USA (04): (NM) 20140803.2656232\nPlague - USA (03): (CO) cluster from canine exposure 20140719.2621418\nPlague, animal - USA: (NM) zoo 20140729.2643587\nPlague - USA (02): (CO) pneumonic 20140710.2600593\nPlague - USA: (NM) pneumonic 20140425.2430602\nand other items in the archives\n.................................................sb/tg/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ada County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Elmore County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Background", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4267825", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, animal - USA (04): (CO) feral cat, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4267825", "date": "2016-01-08 16:12:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR\n*******************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Jan 2016\nSource: The Hamilton Spectator [edited]\nhttp://www.thespec.com/news-story/6222323-bubonic-plague-outbreak-kills-63-in-madagascar/\n\n\nThe latest outbreak of bubonic plague on the Indian Ocean island of Madagascar has killed 63 people since August 2015, the Health Ministry said. At least 174 cases of the disease have been detected, Maherisoa Ratsitorahina, head of disease surveillance at the ministry, said in a statement Thursday [7 Jan 2016] in the capital, Antananarivo. Madagascar notified the WHO of the current outbreak in September 2015.\n\nAt least 79 people died after an outbreak in 2014 that continued into early 2015, when at least 335 cases were reported, according to the WHO. The bacterial disease is spread to people who have been bitten by infected rodent fleas, the WHO says.\n\nEfforts to curb the spread of the disease are being impeded by a build-up of garbage in Antananarivo amid a dispute between the municipality and the national government over who is responsible for waste management in the city.\n\n[Byline: Fanja Razafimahatratra]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages. Care must be taken in any rodent eradication program to ensure that a flea-killing compound is part of the plan. Just as in a natural rodent die-off from _Y. pestis_, the fleas will seek alternate hosts, that is, humans.\n\nThe following paragraph is from 1998 (Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4; http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm).\n\n\"Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported, and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo, more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.\"\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy, producing the purpura seen in the \"black plague\" and also spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med 1997; 337(10): 677-81; http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear whether this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]\nSee Also\n2015\n----\nPlague - Madagascar (05): (IT) fatal 20151118.3801914\nPlague - Madagascar (04): (AO) pneumonic, fatal, WHO 20150908.3631683\nPlague - Madagascar (03): (AO) pneumonic, fatal 20150827.3603984\nPlague - Madagascar (02) 20150212.3162376\nPlague - Madagascar 20150108.3076901\n2014\n----\nPlague - Madagascar (04) 20141212.3027826\nPlague - Madagascar (03) 20141125.2988538\nPlague - Madagascar (02) 20141122.2981993\nPlague - Madagascar 20140222.2290976\n2013\n----\nPlague - Madagascar (02): fatalities 20121224.1467364\nPlague - Madagascar: fatalities 20121119.1415379\n2011\n----\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (05): (AV) 20111014.3088\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (04) 20110401.1006\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (03) 20110318.0858\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (02): (AS) Institut Pasteur report 20110221.0563\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar: (Antsiranana) RFI 20110220.0555\n.................................................sb/ll/je/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-01-07 00:00:00", "2015-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2016-01-07 00:00:00", "2015-09-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SF", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4265294", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - The bacterial disease is spread to people who have been bitten by infected rodent fleas, the WHO says.\n\nEfforts to curb the spread of the disease are being impeded by a build-up of garbage in Antananarivo amid a dispute between the municipality and the national government over who is responsible for waste management in the city.\n\n[Byline: Fanja Razafimahatratra]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. Madagascar (02): fatalities 20121224.1467364\nPlague - Madagascar: fatalities 20121119.1415379\n2011\n----\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (05): (AV) 20111014.3088\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (04) 20110401.1006\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (03) 20110318.0858\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (02): (AS) Institut Pasteur report 20110221.0563\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar: (Antsiranana) RFI 20110220.0555\n.................................................sb/ll/je/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-01-07 00:00:00", "2015-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2016-01-07 00:00:00", "2015-09-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SF", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4178118", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (02): (WY) feline", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4178118", "date": "2016-01-08 16:12:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR\n*******************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Jan 2016\nSource: The Hamilton Spectator [edited]\nhttp://www.thespec.com/news-story/6222323-bubonic-plague-outbreak-kills-63-in-madagascar/\n\n\nThe latest outbreak of bubonic plague on the Indian Ocean island of Madagascar has killed 63 people since August 2015, the Health Ministry said. At least 174 cases of the disease have been detected, Maherisoa Ratsitorahina, head of disease surveillance at the ministry, said in a statement Thursday [7 Jan 2016] in the capital, Antananarivo. Madagascar notified the WHO of the current outbreak in September 2015.\n\nAt least 79 people died after an outbreak in 2014 that continued into early 2015, when at least 335 cases were reported, according to the WHO. The bacterial disease is spread to people who have been bitten by infected rodent fleas, the WHO says.\n\nEfforts to curb the spread of the disease are being impeded by a build-up of garbage in Antananarivo amid a dispute between the municipality and the national government over who is responsible for waste management in the city.\n\n[Byline: Fanja Razafimahatratra]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages. Care must be taken in any rodent eradication program to ensure that a flea-killing compound is part of the plan. Just as in a natural rodent die-off from _Y. pestis_, the fleas will seek alternate hosts, that is, humans.\n\nThe following paragraph is from 1998 (Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4; http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm).\n\n\"Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported, and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo, more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.\"\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy, producing the purpura seen in the \"black plague\" and also spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med 1997; 337(10): 677-81; http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear whether this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]\nSee Also\n2015\n----\nPlague - Madagascar (03) 20110318.0858\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (02): (AS) Institut Pasteur report 20110221.0563\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar: (Antsiranana) RFI 20110220.0555\n.................................................sb/ll/je/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-01-07 00:00:00", "2015-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2016-01-07 00:00:00", "2015-09-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SF", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4052792", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Plague: worldwide, 2010-2015", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4052792", "date": "2016-01-08 16:12:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - The bacterial disease is spread to people who have been bitten by infected rodent fleas, the WHO says.\n\nEfforts to curb the spread of the disease are being impeded by a build-up of garbage in Antananarivo amid a dispute between the municipality and the national government over who is responsible for waste management in the city.\n\n[Byline: Fanja Razafimahatratra]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. At least 174 cases of the disease have been detected, Maherisoa Ratsitorahina, head of disease surveillance at the ministry, said in a statement Thursday [7 Jan 2016] in the capital, Antananarivo. Madagascar notified the WHO of the current outbreak in September 2015.\n\nAt least 79 people died after an outbreak in 2014 that continued into early 2015, when at least 335 cases were reported, according to the WHO. The bacterial disease is spread to people who have been bitten by infected rodent fleas, the WHO says.\n\nEfforts to curb the spread of the disease are being impeded by a build-up of garbage in Antananarivo amid a dispute between the municipality and the national government over who is responsible for waste management in the city.\n\n[Byline: Fanja Razafimahatratra]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages. Care must be taken in any rodent eradication program to ensure that a flea-killing compound is part of the plan. In the capital city of Antananarivo, more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.\"\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy, producing the purpura seen in the \"black plague\" and also spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. Madagascar (03) 20110318.0858\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (02): (AS) Institut Pasteur report 20110221.0563\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar: (Antsiranana) RFI 20110220.0555\n.................................................sb/ll/je/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-01-07 00:00:00", "2015-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2016-01-07 00:00:00", "2015-09-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SF", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3801914", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (05): (IT) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3801914", "date": "2015-09-07 19:00:04", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (14): (CALIFORNIA), SQUIRREL\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 5 Sep 2015\nSource: Kolo TV [edited]\nhttp://www.kolotv.com/news/headlines/Plague-Found-in-South-Lake-Tahoe-Picnic-Area-324558161.html\n\n\nEl Dorado County, California health officials announced Friday [4 Sep 2015] that a ground squirrel in South Lake Tahoe has tested positive for plague. The dead animal was found at the Kiva picnic area on 17 Aug [2015]. So far, health officials are not aware of any human contact with the infected squirrel.\n\n\"It's something that we don't see in large pandemics in the modern era of antibiotics,\" explained Dr Randall Todd of the Washoe County Health District. \"But we do still worry about it a little bit in the western and southwestern states because it lives endemically in some of the rodent populations.\" Doctor Todd referred to a map from the CDC, which shows where human cases of plague have been reported between 1970 and 2012. Several were right here in northern Nevada.\n\nThe disease is carried by fleas, and spread by rodents, and other small animals like rabbits and prairie dogs. Dr. Todd said that if one of these animals allows you to get close, that's unusual behavior. They may be sick. He said don't touch it, and don't let your dogs get close either.\n\n\"If you have pets like dogs or cats that are allowed to roam free where they might be exposed to fleas, then you would probably want to take some steps to do flea prevention on your pets, and you probably would not want them to sleep on or in your bed,\" he says. According to information from the CDC, human infection is rare. Fewer than 20 cases have been reported per year over the past 15 years, but it can be fatal.\n\nIf you are exposed, you may have a fever, headache, and painful swollen lymph nodes. Seek medical attention right away.\n\nTo reduce your chances of catching the disease, El Dorado County health officials say don't feed squirrels or other wild rodents. Never touch sick, injured, or dead rodents. Eliminate nesting places for rodents around homes, sheds and garages.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204.]\nSee Also\nPlague, animal - The dead animal was found at the Kiva picnic area on 17 Aug [2015]. So far, health officials are not aware of any human contact with the infected squirrel.\n\n\"It's something that we don't see in large pandemics in the modern era of antibiotics,\" explained Dr Randall Todd of the Washoe County Health District. \"But we do still worry about it a little bit in the western and southwestern states because it lives endemically in some of the rodent populations.\" Doctor Todd referred to a map from the CDC, which shows where human cases of plague have been reported between 1970 and 2012. Several were right here in northern Nevada.\n\nThe disease is carried by fleas, and spread by rodents, and other small animals like rabbits and prairie dogs. Dr. Todd said that if one of these animals allows you to get close, that's unusual behavior. They may be sick. He said don't touch it, and don't let your dogs get close either.\n\n\"If you have pets like dogs or cats that are allowed to roam free where they might be exposed to fleas, then you would probably want to take some steps to do flea prevention on your pets, and you probably would not want them to sleep on or in your bed,\" he says. Fewer than 20 cases have been reported per year over the past 15 years, but it can be fatal.\n\nIf you are exposed, you may have a fever, headache, and painful swollen lymph nodes. USA (16): (NM) septicemic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3668691", "date": "2015-09-07 19:00:04", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (14): (CALIFORNIA), SQUIRREL\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 5 Sep 2015\nSource: Kolo TV [edited]\nhttp://www.kolotv.com/news/headlines/Plague-Found-in-South-Lake-Tahoe-Picnic-Area-324558161.html\n\n\nEl Dorado County, California health officials announced Friday [4 Sep 2015] that a ground squirrel in South Lake Tahoe has tested positive for plague. The dead animal was found at the Kiva picnic area on 17 Aug [2015]. So far, health officials are not aware of any human contact with the infected squirrel.\n\n\"It's something that we don't see in large pandemics in the modern era of antibiotics,\" explained Dr Randall Todd of the Washoe County Health District. \"But we do still worry about it a little bit in the western and southwestern states because it lives endemically in some of the rodent populations.\" Doctor Todd referred to a map from the CDC, which shows where human cases of plague have been reported between 1970 and 2012. Several were right here in northern Nevada.\n\nThe disease is carried by fleas, and spread by rodents, and other small animals like rabbits and prairie dogs. Dr. Todd said that if one of these animals allows you to get close, that's unusual behavior. They may be sick. He said don't touch it, and don't let your dogs get close either.\n\n\"If you have pets like dogs or cats that are allowed to roam free where they might be exposed to fleas, then you would probably want to take some steps to do flea prevention on your pets, and you probably would not want them to sleep on or in your bed,\" he says. According to information from the CDC, human infection is rare. Fewer than 20 cases have been reported per year over the past 15 years, but it can be fatal.\n\nIf you are exposed, you may have a fever, headache, and painful swollen lymph nodes. Seek medical attention right away.\n\nTo reduce your chances of catching the disease, El Dorado County health officials say don't feed squirrels or other wild rodents. Never touch sick, injured, or dead rodents. Eliminate nesting places for rodents around homes, sheds and garages.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204.]\nSee Also\nPlague, animal - USA (02): (CO) pneumonic 20140710.2600593\nPlague - USA: (NM) pneumonic 20140425.2430602\n.................................................sb/pmb/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2015-09-04 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nevada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Dorado County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3647353", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Kyrgyzstan: (YK) fatality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3647353", "date": "2015-09-07 19:00:04", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (14): (CALIFORNIA), SQUIRREL\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 5 Sep 2015\nSource: Kolo TV [edited]\nhttp://www.kolotv.com/news/headlines/Plague-Found-in-South-Lake-Tahoe-Picnic-Area-324558161.html\n\n\nEl Dorado County, California health officials announced Friday [4 Sep 2015] that a ground squirrel in South Lake Tahoe has tested positive for plague. The dead animal was found at the Kiva picnic area on 17 Aug [2015]. So far, health officials are not aware of any human contact with the infected squirrel.\n\n\"It's something that we don't see in large pandemics in the modern era of antibiotics,\" explained Dr Randall Todd of the Washoe County Health District. \"But we do still worry about it a little bit in the western and southwestern states because it lives endemically in some of the rodent populations.\" Doctor Todd referred to a map from the CDC, which shows where human cases of plague have been reported between 1970 and 2012. Several were right here in northern Nevada.\n\nThe disease is carried by fleas, and spread by rodents, and other small animals like rabbits and prairie dogs. Dr. Todd said that if one of these animals allows you to get close, that's unusual behavior. They may be sick. He said don't touch it, and don't let your dogs get close either.\n\n\"If you have pets like dogs or cats that are allowed to roam free where they might be exposed to fleas, then you would probably want to take some steps to do flea prevention on your pets, and you probably would not want them to sleep on or in your bed,\" he says. According to information from the CDC, human infection is rare. Fewer than 20 cases have been reported per year over the past 15 years, but it can be fatal.\n\nIf you are exposed, you may have a fever, headache, and painful swollen lymph nodes. Seek medical attention right away.\n\nTo reduce your chances of catching the disease, El Dorado County health officials say don't feed squirrels or other wild rodents. Never touch sick, injured, or dead rodents. Eliminate nesting places for rodents around homes, sheds and garages.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204.]\nSee Also\nPlague, animal - The dead animal was found at the Kiva picnic area on 17 Aug [2015]. So far, health officials are not aware of any human contact with the infected squirrel.\n\n\"It's something that we don't see in large pandemics in the modern era of antibiotics,\" explained Dr Randall Todd of the Washoe County Health District. \"But we do still worry about it a little bit in the western and southwestern states because it lives endemically in some of the rodent populations.\" Doctor Todd referred to a map from the CDC, which shows where human cases of plague have been reported between 1970 and 2012. Several were right here in northern Nevada.\n\nThe disease is carried by fleas, and spread by rodents, and other small animals like rabbits and prairie dogs. Dr. Todd said that if one of these animals allows you to get close, that's unusual behavior. They may be sick. He said don't touch it, and don't let your dogs get close either.\n\n\"If you have pets like dogs or cats that are allowed to roam free where they might be exposed to fleas, then you would probably want to take some steps to do flea prevention on your pets, and you probably would not want them to sleep on or in your bed,\" he says. According to information from the CDC, human infection is rare. Fewer than 20 cases have been reported per year over the past 15 years, but it can be fatal.\n\nIf you are exposed, you may have a fever, headache, and painful swollen lymph nodes. Seek medical attention right away.\n\nTo reduce your chances of catching the disease, El Dorado County health officials say don't feed squirrels or other wild rodents. Never touch sick, injured, or dead rodents. Eliminate nesting places for rodents around homes, sheds and garages.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. USA (14): (NM) septicemic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3622887", "date": "2015-08-21 16:33:58", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (09): (GEORGIA) ex CALIFORNIA\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 19 Aug 2015\nSource: WXIA-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.11alive.com/story/news/health/2015/08/19/georgia-officials-investigate-case-plague-georgia/31979427/\n\n\nHealth officials are investigating what they are calling the 1st recorded case of human plague in Georgia. An unidentified Georgia resident was infected while hiking in California. The California Department of Public Health said that the \"presumptive positive case\" occurred when the tourist visited in early August 2015.\n\nThe Georgia Public Health Laboratory confirmed later Wednesday, 19 Aug 2015, that the patient did test positive for bubonic plague. The CDC is also conducting tests to confirm the diagnosis. The person was hospitalized in Georgia and released Tuesday night, 18 Aug 2015.\n\nDoctors caution travelers to western states, where plague is naturally occurring, to prevent flea bites and get immediate medical care if they start to feel symptoms.\n\n\"Antimicrobials are effective in treating plague, but without prompt treatment, the disease can cause serious illness or death,\" Patrick O'Neal, M.D., director of health protection for the Georgia Department of Public Health, said in a press release.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the same case initially reported as acquired in California (Plague - USA (08): (CA) 20150819.3589079), but this report confirms that the diagnosis was made in Georgia. As noted, _Yesinia pestis_ is not found in the eastern or Midwestern parts of the USA and if it is diagnosed, the patient either traveled from a endemic area or is the victim of either an intentional or accidental release of the organism. - The California Department of Public Health said that the \"presumptive positive case\" occurred when the tourist visited in early August 2015.\n\nThe Georgia Public Health Laboratory confirmed later Wednesday, 19 Aug 2015, that the patient did test positive for bubonic plague. The CDC is also conducting tests to confirm the diagnosis. The person was hospitalized in Georgia and released Tuesday night, 18 Aug 2015.\n\nDoctors caution travelers to western states, where plague is naturally occurring, to prevent flea bites and get immediate medical care if they start to feel symptoms.\n\n\"Antimicrobials are effective in treating plague, but without prompt treatment, the disease can cause serious illness or death,\" Patrick O'Neal, M.D., director of health protection for the Georgia Department of Public Health, said in a press release.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the same case initially reported as acquired in California (Plague - USA (08): (CA) 20150819.3589079), but this report confirms that the diagnosis was made in Georgia. As noted, _Yesinia pestis_ is not found in the eastern or Midwestern parts of the USA and if it is diagnosed, the patient either traveled from a endemic area or is the victim of either an intentional or accidental release of the organism. - USA: (NM) 20130813.1878261\nPlague, animal - USA: (CA) squirrel, alert 20130518.1720992\n.................................................sb/ll/pg/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-08-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "M.D.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yesinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3591203", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Crayfish plague - Ireland: white-clawed crayfish mortality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3591203", "date": "2015-07-27 20:40:35", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (11): (COLORADO), SQUIRREL\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 24 Jul 2015\nSource: Gould for Golden [edited]\nhttp://gouldforgolden.com/2015/07/24/important-information-tree-squirrels-confirmed-to-have-plague-in-parfet-park-in-golden/\n\n\nJefferson County Public Health (JCPH) received confirmation today [24 Jul 2015] that squirrels located in Parfet Park have tested positive for bubonic plague.\n\nPostings are being placed around the area with information reminding citizens to take simple precautions to avoid exposure. Plague is a highly infectious bacterial disease carried by various types of wild rodents and is transmitted primarily by flea bites. Squirrels, prairie dogs and other mammals, such as rabbits and cats are susceptible to plague because they carry fleas.\n\n\"The risk of residents contracting plague is extremely low,\" said Jefferson County Public Health Director Dr. Mark Johnson. \"We want people to be aware that summer marks the beginning of the plague season, and just a few simple precautions will further reduce that risk.\"\n\nJCPH and the City of Golden Animal Control are working together to investigate the cases and to determine the extent of the die-off in the area.\n\nWhen plague appears in an area, there is usually a die-off of the rodents and rabbits. When the animal dies, the fleas leave to find another host, thus spreading the disease. Most human plague cases result from infected flea bites. Less commonly, people are infected by direct contact (i.e. through a bite) with blood or tissues of infected animals.\n\nThe best way to prevent plague is to control the presence of rodents and fleas in and around the home. In addition, people should avoid contact with any species of wild rodents, especially sick or dead rodents. If a dead rodent is found, do not handle the animal directly, use gloves and place it in a plastic bag. Dogs and cats should be confined so they cannot prey on infected rodents and then bring the disease home with them. Pet owners who live close to rodent populations should use flea control products recommended by their veterinarian. Controlling fleas on pets will prevent the transfer of fleas to humans. If these reasonable precautions are taken, the probability of contracting plague is extremely low.\n\nPlague is easily treated in humans with antibiotics when recognized early. Two to 6 days after being infected with plague, people become ill with the following symptoms: sudden onset of high fever; muscle pain; malaise, or a general feeling of being ill; nausea and vomiting. Anyone experiencing these symptoms should consult a physician immediately.\n\nJefferson County Public Health will continue its plague surveillance of rodent populations in the county. Citizens are requested to report any unusual rodent die-offs to City of Golden Animal Control 303-384-8045.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/awKA. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]\nSee Also\nPlague, animal - USA (13): (CA) squirrel", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3588477", "date": "2015-07-27 20:40:35", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (11): (COLORADO), SQUIRREL\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 24 Jul 2015\nSource: Gould for Golden [edited]\nhttp://gouldforgolden.com/2015/07/24/important-information-tree-squirrels-confirmed-to-have-plague-in-parfet-park-in-golden/\n\n\nJefferson County Public Health (JCPH) received confirmation today [24 Jul 2015] that squirrels located in Parfet Park have tested positive for bubonic plague.\n\nPostings are being placed around the area with information reminding citizens to take simple precautions to avoid exposure. Plague is a highly infectious bacterial disease carried by various types of wild rodents and is transmitted primarily by flea bites. Squirrels, prairie dogs and other mammals, such as rabbits and cats are susceptible to plague because they carry fleas.\n\n\"The risk of residents contracting plague is extremely low,\" said Jefferson County Public Health Director Dr. Mark Johnson. \"We want people to be aware that summer marks the beginning of the plague season, and just a few simple precautions will further reduce that risk.\"\n\nJCPH and the City of Golden Animal Control are working together to investigate the cases and to determine the extent of the die-off in the area.\n\nWhen plague appears in an area, there is usually a die-off of the rodents and rabbits. When the animal dies, the fleas leave to find another host, thus spreading the disease. Most human plague cases result from infected flea bites. Less commonly, people are infected by direct contact (i.e. through a bite) with blood or tissues of infected animals.\n\nThe best way to prevent plague is to control the presence of rodents and fleas in and around the home. In addition, people should avoid contact with any species of wild rodents, especially sick or dead rodents. If a dead rodent is found, do not handle the animal directly, use gloves and place it in a plastic bag. Dogs and cats should be confined so they cannot prey on infected rodents and then bring the disease home with them. Pet owners who live close to rodent populations should use flea control products recommended by their veterinarian. Controlling fleas on pets will prevent the transfer of fleas to humans. If these reasonable precautions are taken, the probability of contracting plague is extremely low.\n\nPlague is easily treated in humans with antibiotics when recognized early. Two to 6 days after being infected with plague, people become ill with the following symptoms: sudden onset of high fever; muscle pain; malaise, or a general feeling of being ill; nausea and vomiting. Anyone experiencing these symptoms should consult a physician immediately.\n\nJefferson County Public Health will continue its plague surveillance of rodent populations in the county. Citizens are requested to report any unusual rodent die-offs to City of Golden Animal Control 303-384-8045.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/awKA. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]\nSee Also\nPlague, animal - Plague is a highly infectious bacterial disease carried by various types of wild rodents and is transmitted primarily by flea bites. Squirrels, prairie dogs and other mammals, such as rabbits and cats are susceptible to plague because they carry fleas.\n\n\"The risk of residents contracting plague is extremely low,\" said Jefferson County Public Health Director Dr. Mark Johnson. \"We want people to be aware that summer marks the beginning of the plague season, and just a few simple precautions will further reduce that risk.\"\n\nJCPH and the City of Golden Animal Control are working together to investigate the cases and to determine the extent of the die-off in the area.\n\nWhen plague appears in an area, there is usually a die-off of the rodents and rabbits. When the animal dies, the fleas leave to find another host, thus spreading the disease. Most human plague cases result from infected flea bites. Less commonly, people are infected by direct contact (i.e. through a bite) with blood or tissues of infected animals.\n\nThe best way to prevent plague is to control the presence of rodents and fleas in and around the home. In addition, people should avoid contact with any species of wild rodents, especially sick or dead rodents. If a dead rodent is found, do not handle the animal directly, use gloves and place it in a plastic bag. Dogs and cats should be confined so they cannot prey on infected rodents and then bring the disease home with them. Pet owners who live close to rodent populations should use flea control products recommended by their veterinarian. Controlling fleas on pets will prevent the transfer of fleas to humans. If these reasonable precautions are taken, the probability of contracting plague is extremely low.\n\nPlague is easily treated in humans with antibiotics when recognized early. Two to 6 days after being infected with plague, people become ill with the following symptoms: sudden onset of high fever; muscle pain; malaise, or a general feeling of being ill; nausea and vomiting. Anyone experiencing these symptoms should consult a physician immediately.\n\nJefferson County Public Health will continue its plague surveillance of rodent populations in the county. Citizens are requested to report any unusual rodent die-offs to City of Golden Animal Control 303-384-8045.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. Plague is a highly infectious bacterial disease carried by various types of wild rodents and is transmitted primarily by flea bites. Squirrels, prairie dogs and other mammals, such as rabbits and cats are susceptible to plague because they carry fleas.\n\n\"The risk of residents contracting plague is extremely low,\" said Jefferson County Public Health Director Dr. Mark Johnson. \"We want people to be aware that summer marks the beginning of the plague season, and just a few simple precautions will further reduce that risk.\"\n\nJCPH and the City of Golden Animal Control are working together to investigate the cases and to determine the extent of the die-off in the area.\n\nWhen plague appears in an area, there is usually a die-off of the rodents and rabbits. When the animal dies, the fleas leave to find another host, thus spreading the disease. Most human plague cases result from infected flea bites. Less commonly, people are infected by direct contact (i.e. through a bite) with blood or tissues of infected animals.\n\nThe best way to prevent plague is to control the presence of rodents and fleas in and around the home. In addition, people should avoid contact with any species of wild rodents, especially sick or dead rodents. If a dead rodent is found, do not handle the animal directly, use gloves and place it in a plastic bag. Dogs and cats should be confined so they cannot prey on infected rodents and then bring the disease home with them. Pet owners who live close to rodent populations should use flea control products recommended by their veterinarian. Controlling fleas on pets will prevent the transfer of fleas to humans. If these reasonable precautions are taken, the probability of contracting plague is extremely low.\n\nPlague is easily treated in humans with antibiotics when recognized early. Two to 6 days after being infected with plague, people become ill with the following symptoms: sudden onset of high fever; muscle pain; malaise, or a general feeling of being ill; nausea and vomiting. Anyone experiencing these symptoms should consult a physician immediately.\n\nJefferson County Public Health will continue its plague surveillance of rodent populations in the county. Squirrels, prairie dogs and other mammals, such as rabbits and cats are susceptible to plague because they carry fleas.\n\n\"The risk of residents contracting plague is extremely low,\" said Jefferson County Public Health Director Dr. Mark Johnson. \"We want people to be aware that summer marks the beginning of the plague season, and just a few simple precautions will further reduce that risk.\"\n\nJCPH and the City of Golden Animal Control are working together to investigate the cases and to determine the extent of the die-off in the area.\n\nWhen plague appears in an area, there is usually a die-off of the rodents and rabbits. When the animal dies, the fleas leave to find another host, thus spreading the disease. Most human plague cases result from infected flea bites. Less commonly, people are infected by direct contact (i.e. through a bite) with blood or tissues of infected animals.\n\nThe best way to prevent plague is to control the presence of rodents and fleas in and around the home. In addition, people should avoid contact with any species of wild rodents, especially sick or dead rodents. If a dead rodent is found, do not handle the animal directly, use gloves and place it in a plastic bag. Dogs and cats should be confined so they cannot prey on infected rodents and then bring the disease home with them. Pet owners who live close to rodent populations should use flea control products recommended by their veterinarian. Controlling fleas on pets will prevent the transfer of fleas to humans. If these reasonable precautions are taken, the probability of contracting plague is extremely low.\n\nPlague is easily treated in humans with antibiotics when recognized early. Two to 6 days after being infected with plague, people become ill with the following symptoms: sudden onset of high fever; muscle pain; malaise, or a general feeling of being ill; nausea and vomiting. USA (12): (CO) feline", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3552460", "date": "2015-07-27 20:40:35", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (11): (COLORADO), SQUIRREL\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 24 Jul 2015\nSource: Gould for Golden [edited]\nhttp://gouldforgolden.com/2015/07/24/important-information-tree-squirrels-confirmed-to-have-plague-in-parfet-park-in-golden/\n\n\nJefferson County Public Health (JCPH) received confirmation today [24 Jul 2015] that squirrels located in Parfet Park have tested positive for bubonic plague.\n\nPostings are being placed around the area with information reminding citizens to take simple precautions to avoid exposure. Plague is a highly infectious bacterial disease carried by various types of wild rodents and is transmitted primarily by flea bites. Squirrels, prairie dogs and other mammals, such as rabbits and cats are susceptible to plague because they carry fleas.\n\n\"The risk of residents contracting plague is extremely low,\" said Jefferson County Public Health Director Dr. Mark Johnson. \"We want people to be aware that summer marks the beginning of the plague season, and just a few simple precautions will further reduce that risk.\"\n\nJCPH and the City of Golden Animal Control are working together to investigate the cases and to determine the extent of the die-off in the area.\n\nWhen plague appears in an area, there is usually a die-off of the rodents and rabbits. When the animal dies, the fleas leave to find another host, thus spreading the disease. Most human plague cases result from infected flea bites. Less commonly, people are infected by direct contact (i.e. through a bite) with blood or tissues of infected animals.\n\nThe best way to prevent plague is to control the presence of rodents and fleas in and around the home. In addition, people should avoid contact with any species of wild rodents, especially sick or dead rodents. If a dead rodent is found, do not handle the animal directly, use gloves and place it in a plastic bag. Dogs and cats should be confined so they cannot prey on infected rodents and then bring the disease home with them. Pet owners who live close to rodent populations should use flea control products recommended by their veterinarian. Controlling fleas on pets will prevent the transfer of fleas to humans. If these reasonable precautions are taken, the probability of contracting plague is extremely low.\n\nPlague is easily treated in humans with antibiotics when recognized early. Two to 6 days after being infected with plague, people become ill with the following symptoms: sudden onset of high fever; muscle pain; malaise, or a general feeling of being ill; nausea and vomiting. Anyone experiencing these symptoms should consult a physician immediately.\n\nJefferson County Public Health will continue its plague surveillance of rodent populations in the county. Citizens are requested to report any unusual rodent die-offs to City of Golden Animal Control 303-384-8045.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/awKA. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]\nSee Also\nPlague, animal - USA: (NM) zoo 20140729.2643587\nPlague - USA (02): (CO) pneumonic 20140710.2600593\nPlague - USA: (NM) pneumonic 20140425.2430602\n.................................................pmb/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Parfet Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the City of Golden Animal Control", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3540232", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (11): (CO) squirrel", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3540232", "date": "2015-07-27 20:40:35", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (11): (COLORADO), SQUIRREL\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 24 Jul 2015\nSource: Gould for Golden [edited]\nhttp://gouldforgolden.com/2015/07/24/important-information-tree-squirrels-confirmed-to-have-plague-in-parfet-park-in-golden/\n\n\nJefferson County Public Health (JCPH) received confirmation today [24 Jul 2015] that squirrels located in Parfet Park have tested positive for bubonic plague.\n\nPostings are being placed around the area with information reminding citizens to take simple precautions to avoid exposure. Plague is a highly infectious bacterial disease carried by various types of wild rodents and is transmitted primarily by flea bites. Squirrels, prairie dogs and other mammals, such as rabbits and cats are susceptible to plague because they carry fleas.\n\n\"The risk of residents contracting plague is extremely low,\" said Jefferson County Public Health Director Dr. Mark Johnson. \"We want people to be aware that summer marks the beginning of the plague season, and just a few simple precautions will further reduce that risk.\"\n\nJCPH and the City of Golden Animal Control are working together to investigate the cases and to determine the extent of the die-off in the area.\n\nWhen plague appears in an area, there is usually a die-off of the rodents and rabbits. When the animal dies, the fleas leave to find another host, thus spreading the disease. Most human plague cases result from infected flea bites. Less commonly, people are infected by direct contact (i.e. through a bite) with blood or tissues of infected animals.\n\nThe best way to prevent plague is to control the presence of rodents and fleas in and around the home. In addition, people should avoid contact with any species of wild rodents, especially sick or dead rodents. If a dead rodent is found, do not handle the animal directly, use gloves and place it in a plastic bag. Dogs and cats should be confined so they cannot prey on infected rodents and then bring the disease home with them. Pet owners who live close to rodent populations should use flea control products recommended by their veterinarian. Controlling fleas on pets will prevent the transfer of fleas to humans. If these reasonable precautions are taken, the probability of contracting plague is extremely low.\n\nPlague is easily treated in humans with antibiotics when recognized early. Two to 6 days after being infected with plague, people become ill with the following symptoms: sudden onset of high fever; muscle pain; malaise, or a general feeling of being ill; nausea and vomiting. Anyone experiencing these symptoms should consult a physician immediately.\n\nJefferson County Public Health will continue its plague surveillance of rodent populations in the county. Citizens are requested to report any unusual rodent die-offs to City of Golden Animal Control 303-384-8045.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/awKA. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]\nSee Also\nPlague, animal - USA (04): (NM) pneumonic, fatality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3537026", "date": "2015-06-01 12:20:58", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (06): (NEBRASKA) PRAIRIE DOG, SPREAD\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 29 May 2015\nSource: Chadrad.com [edited]\nhttp://www.chadrad.com/newsstory.cfm?story=37554\n\n\nThe US Forest Service says that sylvatic plague has been confirmed in black tailed prairie dog colonies on the Oglala National Grassland [NG] north west of Crawford [Nebraska].\n\nActing Pine Ridge district ranger Geri Mason says die-offs of prairie dogs led to the collection of fleas from several prairie dog colonies on the Oglala NG in October and November [2014]. They were tested by the University of South Dakota and results recently came back positive for the bacterium that causes plague.\n\nThe same bacterium that causes bubonic and pneumonic plague in humans causes sylvatic plague in wildlife. Only about 10 to 20 human cases of plague are reported in the United States each year, generally contracted in prairie settings.\n\nMason says it was 1st detected in the Nebraska National Forests and Grasslands in 2004 on both the Buffalo Gap and Fort Pierre National Grasslands in South Dakota, and has since spread to the adjacent Badlands National Park and to the Lower Brule Indian Reservation. The initial outbreak posed a serious threat to the black-footed ferret, which was successfully reintroduced over 20 years ago in the Conata Basin area of the Buffalo Gap NG and has since been introduced in other locations around the region.\n\nThe Forest Service and other agencies began an aggressive campaign of dusting the entrances of prairie dog colonies with a contact insecticide to kill fleas and keep the plague from spreading, but Mason says there are no plans at this time to extend that into the Oglala NG. As for the threat of plague spreading to humans, Mason says prevention is the best remedy. She says to avoid any contact with wild rodents such as prairie dogs, dead or alive, that may have infected fleas, never feed wildlife. She also recommends keeping pets away from prairie dog colonies or dead rodents and to be sure outdoor pets are wearing flea collars to prevent them from bringing in infected fleas.\n\nMore information about the plague can be found at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's website at http://www.cdc.gov.\n\n[byline: Chris Fankhauser]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague was not previously documented in Nebraska, although it was nearby in Wyoming.\n\nPlague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations.\n\nFor a picture of a black tailed prairie dog, go to http://fc07.deviantart.net/fs71/i/2011/220/a/6/black_tailed_prairie_dog_by_dingo84dogs-d45wnep.jpg.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/229. - USA (10): (UT) sylvatic, prairie dog, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3513063", "date": "2015-06-01 12:20:58", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (06): (NEBRASKA) PRAIRIE DOG, SPREAD\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 29 May 2015\nSource: Chadrad.com [edited]\nhttp://www.chadrad.com/newsstory.cfm?story=37554\n\n\nThe US Forest Service says that sylvatic plague has been confirmed in black tailed prairie dog colonies on the Oglala National Grassland [NG] north west of Crawford [Nebraska].\n\nActing Pine Ridge district ranger Geri Mason says die-offs of prairie dogs led to the collection of fleas from several prairie dog colonies on the Oglala NG in October and November [2014]. They were tested by the University of South Dakota and results recently came back positive for the bacterium that causes plague.\n\nThe same bacterium that causes bubonic and pneumonic plague in humans causes sylvatic plague in wildlife. Only about 10 to 20 human cases of plague are reported in the United States each year, generally contracted in prairie settings.\n\nMason says it was 1st detected in the Nebraska National Forests and Grasslands in 2004 on both the Buffalo Gap and Fort Pierre National Grasslands in South Dakota, and has since spread to the adjacent Badlands National Park and to the Lower Brule Indian Reservation. The initial outbreak posed a serious threat to the black-footed ferret, which was successfully reintroduced over 20 years ago in the Conata Basin area of the Buffalo Gap NG and has since been introduced in other locations around the region.\n\nThe Forest Service and other agencies began an aggressive campaign of dusting the entrances of prairie dog colonies with a contact insecticide to kill fleas and keep the plague from spreading, but Mason says there are no plans at this time to extend that into the Oglala NG. As for the threat of plague spreading to humans, Mason says prevention is the best remedy. She says to avoid any contact with wild rodents such as prairie dogs, dead or alive, that may have infected fleas, never feed wildlife. She also recommends keeping pets away from prairie dog colonies or dead rodents and to be sure outdoor pets are wearing flea collars to prevent them from bringing in infected fleas.\n\nMore information about the plague can be found at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's website at http://www.cdc.gov.\n\n[byline: Chris Fankhauser]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague was not previously documented in Nebraska, although it was nearby in Wyoming.\n\nPlague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations.\n\nFor a picture of a black tailed prairie dog, go to http://fc07.deviantart.net/fs71/i/2011/220/a/6/black_tailed_prairie_dog_by_dingo84dogs-d45wnep.jpg.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/229. - USA: (IL), 2009, lab strain, CDC 20110224.0614\n.................................................sb/pmb/je/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2015-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3470704", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (09): (CO) mule deer, prairie dog", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3470704", "date": "2015-06-01 12:20:58", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (06): (NEBRASKA) PRAIRIE DOG, SPREAD\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 29 May 2015\nSource: Chadrad.com [edited]\nhttp://www.chadrad.com/newsstory.cfm?story=37554\n\n\nThe US Forest Service says that sylvatic plague has been confirmed in black tailed prairie dog colonies on the Oglala National Grassland [NG] north west of Crawford [Nebraska].\n\nActing Pine Ridge district ranger Geri Mason says die-offs of prairie dogs led to the collection of fleas from several prairie dog colonies on the Oglala NG in October and November [2014]. They were tested by the University of South Dakota and results recently came back positive for the bacterium that causes plague.\n\nThe same bacterium that causes bubonic and pneumonic plague in humans causes sylvatic plague in wildlife. Only about 10 to 20 human cases of plague are reported in the United States each year, generally contracted in prairie settings.\n\nMason says it was 1st detected in the Nebraska National Forests and Grasslands in 2004 on both the Buffalo Gap and Fort Pierre National Grasslands in South Dakota, and has since spread to the adjacent Badlands National Park and to the Lower Brule Indian Reservation. The initial outbreak posed a serious threat to the black-footed ferret, which was successfully reintroduced over 20 years ago in the Conata Basin area of the Buffalo Gap NG and has since been introduced in other locations around the region.\n\nThe Forest Service and other agencies began an aggressive campaign of dusting the entrances of prairie dog colonies with a contact insecticide to kill fleas and keep the plague from spreading, but Mason says there are no plans at this time to extend that into the Oglala NG. As for the threat of plague spreading to humans, Mason says prevention is the best remedy. She says to avoid any contact with wild rodents such as prairie dogs, dead or alive, that may have infected fleas, never feed wildlife. She also recommends keeping pets away from prairie dog colonies or dead rodents and to be sure outdoor pets are wearing flea collars to prevent them from bringing in infected fleas.\n\nMore information about the plague can be found at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's website at http://www.cdc.gov.\n\n[byline: Chris Fankhauser]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague was not previously documented in Nebraska, although it was nearby in Wyoming.\n\nPlague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations.\n\nFor a picture of a black tailed prairie dog, go to http://fc07.deviantart.net/fs71/i/2011/220/a/6/black_tailed_prairie_dog_by_dingo84dogs-d45wnep.jpg.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/229. - USA: (IL), 2009, lab strain, CDC 20110224.0614\n.................................................sb/pmb/je/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2015-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3417597", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (07): (ID) canine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3417597", "date": "2015-06-01 12:20:58", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (06): (NEBRASKA) PRAIRIE DOG, SPREAD\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 29 May 2015\nSource: Chadrad.com [edited]\nhttp://www.chadrad.com/newsstory.cfm?story=37554\n\n\nThe US Forest Service says that sylvatic plague has been confirmed in black tailed prairie dog colonies on the Oglala National Grassland [NG] north west of Crawford [Nebraska].\n\nActing Pine Ridge district ranger Geri Mason says die-offs of prairie dogs led to the collection of fleas from several prairie dog colonies on the Oglala NG in October and November [2014]. They were tested by the University of South Dakota and results recently came back positive for the bacterium that causes plague.\n\nThe same bacterium that causes bubonic and pneumonic plague in humans causes sylvatic plague in wildlife. Only about 10 to 20 human cases of plague are reported in the United States each year, generally contracted in prairie settings.\n\nMason says it was 1st detected in the Nebraska National Forests and Grasslands in 2004 on both the Buffalo Gap and Fort Pierre National Grasslands in South Dakota, and has since spread to the adjacent Badlands National Park and to the Lower Brule Indian Reservation. The initial outbreak posed a serious threat to the black-footed ferret, which was successfully reintroduced over 20 years ago in the Conata Basin area of the Buffalo Gap NG and has since been introduced in other locations around the region.\n\nThe Forest Service and other agencies began an aggressive campaign of dusting the entrances of prairie dog colonies with a contact insecticide to kill fleas and keep the plague from spreading, but Mason says there are no plans at this time to extend that into the Oglala NG. As for the threat of plague spreading to humans, Mason says prevention is the best remedy. She says to avoid any contact with wild rodents such as prairie dogs, dead or alive, that may have infected fleas, never feed wildlife. She also recommends keeping pets away from prairie dog colonies or dead rodents and to be sure outdoor pets are wearing flea collars to prevent them from bringing in infected fleas.\n\nMore information about the plague can be found at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's website at http://www.cdc.gov.\n\n[byline: Chris Fankhauser]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague was not previously documented in Nebraska, although it was nearby in Wyoming.\n\nPlague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations.\n\nFor a picture of a black tailed prairie dog, go to http://fc07.deviantart.net/fs71/i/2011/220/a/6/black_tailed_prairie_dog_by_dingo84dogs-d45wnep.jpg.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/229. - They were tested by the University of South Dakota and results recently came back positive for the bacterium that causes plague.\n\nThe same bacterium that causes bubonic and pneumonic plague in humans causes sylvatic plague in wildlife. Only about 10 to 20 human cases of plague are reported in the United States each year, generally contracted in prairie settings.\n\nMason says it was 1st detected in the Nebraska National Forests and Grasslands in 2004 on both the Buffalo Gap and Fort Pierre National Grasslands in South Dakota, and has since spread to the adjacent Badlands National Park and to the Lower Brule Indian Reservation. As for the threat of plague spreading to humans, Mason says prevention is the best remedy. She says to avoid any contact with wild rodents such as prairie dogs, dead or alive, that may have infected fleas, never feed wildlife. She also recommends keeping pets away from prairie dog colonies or dead rodents and to be sure outdoor pets are wearing flea collars to prevent them from bringing in infected fleas.\n\nMore information about the plague can be found at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's website at http://www.cdc.gov.\n\n[byline: Chris Fankhauser]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague was not previously documented in Nebraska, although it was nearby in Wyoming.\n\nPlague is primarily a disease of wild rodents.
