USA: (IL), 2009, lab strain, CDC 20110224.0614\n.................................................mpp/ll/je/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the City of Albuquerque Environmental Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Torrance County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2013248", "headline": "PRO/AH> Crayfish plague - Norway: (NT) OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2013248", "date": "2013-08-13 12:05:13", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA: (NEW MEXICO)\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 12 Aug 2013\nFrom: Paul Ettestad <Paul.ettestad@state.nm.us> [edited]\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health confirmed today, 12 Aug 2013, a case of plague in a 15 year old boy from Torrance County who is currently hospitalized in stable condition. This is the 1st human case of plague in New Mexico and in the USA in 2013. An environmental investigation will take place at the boy's home to look for ongoing risk to others in the surrounding area.\n\n\"The Department of Health conducts an investigation when a plague case occurs to ensure the safety of the immediate family, neighbors, and health care providers,\" said Department of Health secretary Retta Ward, MPH. \"We inform neighbors door-to-door about plague found in the area and educate them on reducing their risk. Health care providers and others close to the patient may also have been exposed, and are assessed to determine if they need preventive treatment.\"\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas, but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife, and pets. \"Plague activity in New Mexico is usually highest during the summer months, so it is especially important now to take precautions to avoid rodents and their fleas which can expose you to plague,\" said Dr Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian for the Department of Health. \"Pets that are allowed to roam and hunt can bring infected fleas from dead rodents back into the home, putting you and your children at risk.\"\n\nTo prevent plague, the Department of Health recommends:\n- avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and burrows;\n- keep your pets from roaming and hunting;\n- talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets as not all products are safe for cats, dogs, or your children;\n- clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk, and abandoned vehicles;\n- sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian;\n- see your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever;\n- put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home;\n- don't leave your pet's food and water where mice can get to it.\n\nIn New Mexico, there was 1 human plague case in 2012, 2 human cases of plague in 2011, no cases in 2010, and 6 human cases of plague in 2009, 1 of them fatal.\n\n--\nDr Paul Ettestad\nNew Mexico Department of Health\nUSA\n<Paul.ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Ettestad for this report. The form of _Yersinia pestis_ infection -- bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic -- is not stated in the report but most cases are bubonic. The bubo is an extremely painful lymph node swelling in the area draining from the flea bite that introduced the bacillus.\n\nA county map of the state of New Mexico (http://nmhealth.org/ERD/HealthData/documents/HumanPlagueinNMbyCounty1949-2012.pdf) shows that the concentration of human plague cases in New Mexico (1949-2012) is in the north western part of the state. Most USA cases of human plague infection occur in the Four Corner states -- the south western states of New Mexico, Arizona, Utah, and Colorado -- although California and Oregon have reported cases in recent years. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/2uyq.]\nSee Also\nPlague, animal - USA (04): (CA) squirrel 20130727.1848788\nPlague, animal - USA (03): (NM) canine, alert: 20130627.1794260\nPlague, animal - USA (02): (CA) squirrel, alert 20130619.1781960\nPlague, animal - USA: (CA) squirrel, alert 20130518.1720992\n2012\n---\nPlague - USA (05): (OR), 2nd case 20120916.1296380\nPlague - USA (04): (CO) septicemic 20120828.1269118\nPlague - USA (03): (OR) septicemic, recovery 20120719.1206257\nPlague - USA (02): (OR), septicemic 20120612.1165863\nPlague - USA: (NM) 20120601.1153277\n2011\n---\nPlague - USA (05): (OR), septicemic 20110920.2855\nPlague, animal - USA (04): (NM) canine 20110701.1999\nPlague, animal - USA (03): (CO) 20110612.1792\nPlague, animal - USA (02): (OR) feline 20110610.1773\nPlague - USA (03): (NM) bubonic 20110530.1655\nPlague - USA (02): (NM) bubonic 20110510.1439\nPlague, animal - USA: (NM) canine, feline 20110421.1240\nPlague - USA: (OR), 2010, bubonic, CDC 20110224.0615\nPlague, fatal - USA: (IL), 2009, lab strain, CDC 20110224.061\nPlague - USA: (OR), 2010, bubonic, CDC 20110224.0615\nPlague, fatal - USA: (IL), 2009, lab strain, CDC 20110224.0614\n.................................................ll/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Torrance County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2009541", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar: prison, urban risk, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2009541", "date": "2013-08-13 12:05:13", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA: (NEW MEXICO)\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 12 Aug 2013\nFrom: Paul Ettestad <Paul.ettestad@state.nm.us> [edited]\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health confirmed today, 12 Aug 2013, a case of plague in a 15 year old boy from Torrance County who is currently hospitalized in stable condition. This is the 1st human case of plague in New Mexico and in the USA in 2013. An environmental investigation will take place at the boy's home to look for ongoing risk to others in the surrounding area.\n\n\"The Department of Health conducts an investigation when a plague case occurs to ensure the safety of the immediate family, neighbors, and health care providers,\" said Department of Health secretary Retta Ward, MPH. \"We inform neighbors door-to-door about plague found in the area and educate them on reducing their risk. Health care providers and others close to the patient may also have been exposed, and are assessed to determine if they need preventive treatment.\"\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas, but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife, and pets. \"Plague activity in New Mexico is usually highest during the summer months, so it is especially important now to take precautions to avoid rodents and their fleas which can expose you to plague,\" said Dr Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian for the Department of Health. \"Pets that are allowed to roam and hunt can bring infected fleas from dead rodents back into the home, putting you and your children at risk.\"\n\nTo prevent plague, the Department of Health recommends:\n- avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and burrows;\n- keep your pets from roaming and hunting;\n- talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets as not all products are safe for cats, dogs, or your children;\n- clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk, and abandoned vehicles;\n- sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian;\n- see your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever;\n- put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home;\n- don't leave your pet's food and water where mice can get to it.\n\nIn New Mexico, there was 1 human plague case in 2012, 2 human cases of plague in 2011, no cases in 2010, and 6 human cases of plague in 2009, 1 of them fatal.\n\n--\nDr Paul Ettestad\nNew Mexico Department of Health\nUSA\n<Paul.ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Ettestad for this report. The form of _Yersinia pestis_ infection -- bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic -- is not stated in the report but most cases are bubonic. The bubo is an extremely painful lymph node swelling in the area draining from the flea bite that introduced the bacillus.\n\nA county map of the state of New Mexico (http://nmhealth.org/ERD/HealthData/documents/HumanPlagueinNMbyCounty1949-2012.pdf) shows that the concentration of human plague cases in New Mexico (1949-2012) is in the north western part of the state. Most USA cases of human plague infection occur in the Four Corner states -- the south western states of New Mexico, Arizona, Utah, and Colorado -- although California and Oregon have reported cases in recent years. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/2uyq.]\nSee Also\nPlague, animal - USA (04): (CA) squirrel 20130727.1848788\nPlague, animal - USA (03): (NM) canine, alert: 20130627.1794260\nPlague, animal - USA: (IL), 2009, lab strain, CDC 20110224.0614\n.................................................ll/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Torrance County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1935879", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (02): (NM) bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1935879", "date": "2013-08-13 12:05:13", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA: (NEW MEXICO)\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 12 Aug 2013\nFrom: Paul Ettestad <Paul.ettestad@state.nm.us> [edited]\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health confirmed today, 12 Aug 2013, a case of plague in a 15 year old boy from Torrance County who is currently hospitalized in stable condition. This is the 1st human case of plague in New Mexico and in the USA in 2013. An environmental investigation will take place at the boy's home to look for ongoing risk to others in the surrounding area.\n\n\"The Department of Health conducts an investigation when a plague case occurs to ensure the safety of the immediate family, neighbors, and health care providers,\" said Department of Health secretary Retta Ward, MPH. \"We inform neighbors door-to-door about plague found in the area and educate them on reducing their risk. Health care providers and others close to the patient may also have been exposed, and are assessed to determine if they need preventive treatment.\"\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas, but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife, and pets. \"Plague activity in New Mexico is usually highest during the summer months, so it is especially important now to take precautions to avoid rodents and their fleas which can expose you to plague,\" said Dr Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian for the Department of Health. \"Pets that are allowed to roam and hunt can bring infected fleas from dead rodents back into the home, putting you and your children at risk.\"\n\nTo prevent plague, the Department of Health recommends:\n- avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and burrows;\n- keep your pets from roaming and hunting;\n- talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets as not all products are safe for cats, dogs, or your children;\n- clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk, and abandoned vehicles;\n- sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian;\n- see your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever;\n- put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home;\n- don't leave your pet's food and water where mice can get to it.\n\nIn New Mexico, there was 1 human plague case in 2012, 2 human cases of plague in 2011, no cases in 2010, and 6 human cases of plague in 2009, 1 of them fatal.\n\n--\nDr Paul Ettestad\nNew Mexico Department of Health\nUSA\n<Paul.ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Ettestad for this report. The form of _Yersinia pestis_ infection -- bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic -- is not stated in the report but most cases are bubonic. The bubo is an extremely painful lymph node swelling in the area draining from the flea bite that introduced the bacillus.\n\nA county map of the state of New Mexico (http://nmhealth.org/ERD/HealthData/documents/HumanPlagueinNMbyCounty1949-2012.pdf) shows that the concentration of human plague cases in New Mexico (1949-2012) is in the north western part of the state. Most USA cases of human plague infection occur in the Four Corner states -- the south western states of New Mexico, Arizona, Utah, and Colorado -- although California and Oregon have reported cases in recent years. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/2uyq.]\nSee Also\nPlague, animal - USA (04): (CA) squirrel 20130727.1848788\nPlague, animal - USA (03): (NM) canine, alert: 20130627.1794260\nPlague, animal - USA: (IL), 2009, lab strain, CDC 20110224.0614\n.................................................ll/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Torrance County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1848788", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, animal - USA (04): (CA) squirrel", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1848788", "date": "2012-11-19 11:43:14", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR: FATALITIES\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 15 Nov 2012\nSource: L'Express de Madagascar [in French, trans. Mod.MPP, edited]\nhttp://www.lexpressmada.com/epidemie-madagascar/38515-six-personnes-succombent-de-la-peste.html\n\n\nThe arrival of the rain is not always good news, as rats [and their fleas], the plague vectors, take refuge in habitats, wreaking havoc.\n\nIt is the beginning of the plague season on the Big Island and it is time to start worrying. 6 patients have died of the disease in a month. The Bongolava region has paid the highest price. \"Of the 43 cases identified, 2 people died of bubonic plague on [2 Oct 2012], 2 others died on 5 Nov 2012, and another person died on 9 Nov 2012 person,\" the statistical management of health monitoring and epidemiological surveillance (DVSSE) within the Ministry of Public Health reported yesterday [14 Nov 2012].\n\nHowever, this epidemic does not affect this region alone. Another victim of the plague was also registered in the District of Mandoto in Vakinankaratra, on 9 Oct 2012. The same day, 3 other non-fatal cases were found in the district of Ambalavao in the Haute-Matsiatra region.\n\nThe cause of this deadly epidemic seems always the same. \"The plague victims sometimes live in remote areas and they self-medicate before going to a health center when the disease worsens. However, all health centers are equipped with rapid diagnostic test and medications to treat this disease immediately,\" said Alain Marcel Rahetilahy, head of epidemic and neglected diseases within the Ministry of Health. In contrast, the Regional Director of Public Health for Tsiroanomandidy refused to disclose the circumstances of this deadly epidemic in its domain, without the written permission of the Secretary General of the Ministry of Health.\n\nHowever, Alain Marcel Rahetilahy does not want to dramatize the situation. \"These cases have yet to be confirmed by the Pasteur Institute of Madagascar. And every year, only 30-40 percent of reported cases are confirmed, even if the initial result is positive by a rapid diagnosis test. So the situation is it not very disturbing,\" he reassured.\n\nYet other doctors remain cautious. \"The heat, the rain, and the bushfires that devastated several regions in recent months, forced the rats, propagation vectors of the plague, to flee to the villages. This is why people must remain vigilant,\" warned a doctor who does not wish to reveal his name. And according to the Secretary General of the Ministry of Health, Philemon Tafangy, the number of suspected cases of plague is between 300 and 500 annually.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages. [The following paragraph of this posting is from 1998 (Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4: \"Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had \"virtually disappeared\" on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health-management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.\"\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy producing the purpura seen in the \"Black Plague\" and also spread to the lung causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med 1997; 337(10): 677-80). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear if this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1kSe.]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (05): (AV) 20111014.3088\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (04) 20110401.1006\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (03) 20110318.0858\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (02): (AS) Institut Pasteur report 20110221.0563\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar: (Antsiranana) RFI 20110220.0555\n2010\n----\nPlague - Tanzania: (MY), RFI 20101222.4508\n2009\n----\nPlague - Congo DR: (OR) 20090927.3381\n2008\n----\nPlague, pneumonic, fatal - Congo DR: (Orientale), susp. 20080213.0571\nPlague, fatal - Madagascar (02): (Antananarivo) 20080114.0177\nPlague, fatal - Madagascar: (Antananarivo), RFI 20080111.0141\n2007\n----\nPlague, fatal - Uganda: (Arua, Nebbi), RFI 20071206.3932\nUndiagnosed deaths - Zambia (02): pneumonic plague susp. 20071130.3862\nPlague, bubonic, fatal - Tanzania (Manyara) 20070328.1064\nPlague - Uganda (Masindi) (03): pneumonic 20070309.0835\nPlague - Uganda (Masindi): pneumonic 20070301.0725\nUndiagnosed deaths - Uganda (Masindi): RFI 20070227.0698\n2006\n----\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Orientale) (03): WHO 20061108.3208\nPlague, pneumonic - Uganda (Arua) 20061020.3022\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Orientale): susp., RFI 20061004.2837\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) (05): susp., RFI 20060929.2786\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) 20060614.1650\n.................................................mpp/ll/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Mandoto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1819290", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Russia: (DA) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1819290", "date": "2012-11-19 11:43:14", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR: FATALITIES\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 15 Nov 2012\nSource: L'Express de Madagascar [in French, trans. Mod.MPP, edited]\nhttp://www.lexpressmada.com/epidemie-madagascar/38515-six-personnes-succombent-de-la-peste.html\n\n\nThe arrival of the rain is not always good news, as rats [and their fleas], the plague vectors, take refuge in habitats, wreaking havoc.\n\nIt is the beginning of the plague season on the Big Island and it is time to start worrying. 6 patients have died of the disease in a month. The Bongolava region has paid the highest price. \"Of the 43 cases identified, 2 people died of bubonic plague on [2 Oct 2012], 2 others died on 5 Nov 2012, and another person died on 9 Nov 2012 person,\" the statistical management of health monitoring and epidemiological surveillance (DVSSE) within the Ministry of Public Health reported yesterday [14 Nov 2012].\n\nHowever, this epidemic does not affect this region alone. Another victim of the plague was also registered in the District of Mandoto in Vakinankaratra, on 9 Oct 2012. The same day, 3 other non-fatal cases were found in the district of Ambalavao in the Haute-Matsiatra region.\n\nThe cause of this deadly epidemic seems always the same. \"The plague victims sometimes live in remote areas and they self-medicate before going to a health center when the disease worsens. However, all health centers are equipped with rapid diagnostic test and medications to treat this disease immediately,\" said Alain Marcel Rahetilahy, head of epidemic and neglected diseases within the Ministry of Health. In contrast, the Regional Director of Public Health for Tsiroanomandidy refused to disclose the circumstances of this deadly epidemic in its domain, without the written permission of the Secretary General of the Ministry of Health.\n\nHowever, Alain Marcel Rahetilahy does not want to dramatize the situation. \"These cases have yet to be confirmed by the Pasteur Institute of Madagascar. And every year, only 30-40 percent of reported cases are confirmed, even if the initial result is positive by a rapid diagnosis test. So the situation is it not very disturbing,\" he reassured.\n\nYet other doctors remain cautious. \"The heat, the rain, and the bushfires that devastated several regions in recent months, forced the rats, propagation vectors of the plague, to flee to the villages. This is why people must remain vigilant,\" warned a doctor who does not wish to reveal his name. And according to the Secretary General of the Ministry of Health, Philemon Tafangy, the number of suspected cases of plague is between 300 and 500 annually.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages. [The following paragraph of this posting is from 1998 (Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4: \"Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had \"virtually disappeared\" on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health-management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.\"\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy producing the purpura seen in the \"Black Plague\" and also spread to the lung causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med 1997; 337(10): 677-80). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear if this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1kSe.]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (05): (AV) 20111014.3088\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (04) 20110401.1006\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (03) 20110318.0858\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (02): (AS) Institut Pasteur report 20110221.0563\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar: (Antsiranana) RFI 20110220.0555\n2010\n----\nPlague - Tanzania: (MY), RFI 20101222.4508\n2009\n----\nPlague - Congo DR: (OR) 20090927.3381\n2008\n----\nPlague, pneumonic, fatal - Congo DR: (Orientale), susp. 20080213.0571\nPlague, fatal - Madagascar (02): (Antananarivo) 20080114.0177\nPlague, fatal - Madagascar: (Antananarivo), RFI 20080111.0141\n2007\n----\nPlague, fatal - Uganda: (Arua, Nebbi), RFI 20071206.3932\nUndiagnosed deaths - Zambia (02): pneumonic plague susp. 20071130.3862\nPlague, bubonic, fatal - Tanzania (Manyara) 20070328.1064\nPlague - Uganda (Masindi) (03): pneumonic 20070309.0835\nPlague - Uganda (Masindi): pneumonic 20070301.0725\nUndiagnosed deaths - Uganda (Masindi): RFI 20070227.0698\n2006\n----\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Orientale) (03): WHO 20061108.3208\nPlague, pneumonic - Uganda (Arua) 20061020.3022\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Orientale): susp., RFI 20061004.2837\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) (05): susp., RFI 20060929.2786\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) 20060614.1650\n.................................................mpp/ll/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Mandoto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1794260", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (03): (NM) canine, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1794260", "date": "2012-11-19 11:43:14", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR: FATALITIES\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 15 Nov 2012\nSource: L'Express de Madagascar [in French, trans. Mod.MPP, edited]\nhttp://www.lexpressmada.com/epidemie-madagascar/38515-six-personnes-succombent-de-la-peste.html\n\n\nThe arrival of the rain is not always good news, as rats [and their fleas], the plague vectors, take refuge in habitats, wreaking havoc.\n\nIt is the beginning of the plague season on the Big Island and it is time to start worrying. 6 patients have died of the disease in a month. The Bongolava region has paid the highest price. \"Of the 43 cases identified, 2 people died of bubonic plague on [2 Oct 2012], 2 others died on 5 Nov 2012, and another person died on 9 Nov 2012 person,\" the statistical management of health monitoring and epidemiological surveillance (DVSSE) within the Ministry of Public Health reported yesterday [14 Nov 2012].\n\nHowever, this epidemic does not affect this region alone. Another victim of the plague was also registered in the District of Mandoto in Vakinankaratra, on 9 Oct 2012. The same day, 3 other non-fatal cases were found in the district of Ambalavao in the Haute-Matsiatra region.\n\nThe cause of this deadly epidemic seems always the same. \"The plague victims sometimes live in remote areas and they self-medicate before going to a health center when the disease worsens. However, all health centers are equipped with rapid diagnostic test and medications to treat this disease immediately,\" said Alain Marcel Rahetilahy, head of epidemic and neglected diseases within the Ministry of Health. In contrast, the Regional Director of Public Health for Tsiroanomandidy refused to disclose the circumstances of this deadly epidemic in its domain, without the written permission of the Secretary General of the Ministry of Health.\n\nHowever, Alain Marcel Rahetilahy does not want to dramatize the situation. \"These cases have yet to be confirmed by the Pasteur Institute of Madagascar. And every year, only 30-40 percent of reported cases are confirmed, even if the initial result is positive by a rapid diagnosis test. So the situation is it not very disturbing,\" he reassured.\n\nYet other doctors remain cautious. \"The heat, the rain, and the bushfires that devastated several regions in recent months, forced the rats, propagation vectors of the plague, to flee to the villages. This is why people must remain vigilant,\" warned a doctor who does not wish to reveal his name. And according to the Secretary General of the Ministry of Health, Philemon Tafangy, the number of suspected cases of plague is between 300 and 500 annually.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages. [The following paragraph of this posting is from 1998 (Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4: \"Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had \"virtually disappeared\" on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health-management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.\"\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy producing the purpura seen in the \"Black Plague\" and also spread to the lung causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med 1997; 337(10): 677-80). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear if this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1kSe.]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nPlague, pneumonic - The Bongolava region has paid the highest price. \"Of the 43 cases identified, 2 people died of bubonic plague on [2 Oct 2012], 2 others died on 5 Nov 2012, and another person died on 9 Nov 2012 person,\" the statistical management of health monitoring and epidemiological surveillance (DVSSE) within the Ministry of Public Health reported yesterday [14 Nov 2012].\n\nHowever, this epidemic does not affect this region alone. However, all health centers are equipped with rapid diagnostic test and medications to treat this disease immediately,\" said Alain Marcel Rahetilahy, head of epidemic and neglected diseases within the Ministry of Health. In contrast, the Regional Director of Public Health for Tsiroanomandidy refused to disclose the circumstances of this deadly epidemic in its domain, without the written permission of the Secretary General of the Ministry of Health.\n\nHowever, Alain Marcel Rahetilahy does not want to dramatize the situation. \"These cases have yet to be confirmed by the Pasteur Institute of Madagascar. And every year, only 30-40 percent of reported cases are confirmed, even if the initial result is positive by a rapid diagnosis test. So the situation is it not very disturbing,\" he reassured.\n\nYet other doctors remain cautious. \"The heat, the rain, and the bushfires that devastated several regions in recent months, forced the rats, propagation vectors of the plague, to flee to the villages. This is why people must remain vigilant,\" warned a doctor who does not wish to reveal his name. And according to the Secretary General of the Ministry of Health, Philemon Tafangy, the number of suspected cases of plague is between 300 and 500 annually.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages. [The following paragraph of this posting is from 1998 (Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4: \"Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had \"virtually disappeared\" on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health-management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.\"\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy producing the purpura seen in the \"Black Plague\" and also spread to the lung causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med 1997; 337(10): 677-80). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear if this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1kSe.]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (05): (AV) 20111014.3088\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (04) 20110401.1006\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (03) 20110318.0858\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar (02): (AS) Institut Pasteur report 20110221.0563\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar: (Antsiranana) RFI 20110220.0555\n2010\n----\nPlague - Tanzania: (MY), RFI 20101222.4508\n2009\n----\nPlague - Congo DR: (OR) 20090927.3381\n2008\n----\nPlague, pneumonic, fatal - Congo DR: (Orientale), susp. 20080213.0571\nPlague, fatal - Madagascar (02): (Antananarivo) 20080114.0177\nPlague, fatal - Madagascar: (Antananarivo), RFI 20080111.0141\n2007\n----\nPlague, fatal - Uganda: (Arua, Nebbi), RFI 20071206.3932\nUndiagnosed deaths - Zambia (02): pneumonic plague susp. 20071130.3862\nPlague, bubonic, fatal - Tanzania (Manyara) 20070328.1064\nPlague - Uganda (Masindi) (03): pneumonic 20070309.0835\nPlague - Uganda (Masindi): pneumonic 20070301.0725\nUndiagnosed deaths - Uganda (Masindi): RFI 20070227.0698\n2006\n----\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Orientale) (03): WHO 20061108.3208\nPlague, pneumonic - Uganda (Arua) 20061020.3022\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Orientale): susp., RFI 20061004.2837\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) (05): susp., RFI 20060929.2786\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) 20060614.1650\n.................................................mpp/ll/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Mandoto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1467364", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (02): fatalities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1467364", "date": "2012-11-19 11:43:14", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR: FATALITIES\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 15 Nov 2012\nSource: L'Express de Madagascar [in French, trans. Mod.MPP, edited]\nhttp://www.lexpressmada.com/epidemie-madagascar/38515-six-personnes-succombent-de-la-peste.html\n\n\nThe arrival of the rain is not always good news, as rats [and their fleas], the plague vectors, take refuge in habitats, wreaking havoc.\n\nIt is the beginning of the plague season on the Big Island and it is time to start worrying. 6 patients have died of the disease in a month. The Bongolava region has paid the highest price. \"Of the 43 cases identified, 2 people died of bubonic plague on [2 Oct 2012], 2 others died on 5 Nov 2012, and another person died on 9 Nov 2012 person,\" the statistical management of health monitoring and epidemiological surveillance (DVSSE) within the Ministry of Public Health reported yesterday [14 Nov 2012].\n\nHowever, this epidemic does not affect this region alone. Another victim of the plague was also registered in the District of Mandoto in Vakinankaratra, on 9 Oct 2012. The same day, 3 other non-fatal cases were found in the district of Ambalavao in the Haute-Matsiatra region.\n\nThe cause of this deadly epidemic seems always the same. \"The plague victims sometimes live in remote areas and they self-medicate before going to a health center when the disease worsens. However, all health centers are equipped with rapid diagnostic test and medications to treat this disease immediately,\" said Alain Marcel Rahetilahy, head of epidemic and neglected diseases within the Ministry of Health. In contrast, the Regional Director of Public Health for Tsiroanomandidy refused to disclose the circumstances of this deadly epidemic in its domain, without the written permission of the Secretary General of the Ministry of Health.\n\nHowever, Alain Marcel Rahetilahy does not want to dramatize the situation. \"These cases have yet to be confirmed by the Pasteur Institute of Madagascar. And every year, only 30-40 percent of reported cases are confirmed, even if the initial result is positive by a rapid diagnosis test. So the situation is it not very disturbing,\" he reassured.\n\nYet other doctors remain cautious. \"The heat, the rain, and the bushfires that devastated several regions in recent months, forced the rats, propagation vectors of the plague, to flee to the villages. This is why people must remain vigilant,\" warned a doctor who does not wish to reveal his name. And according to the Secretary General of the Ministry of Health, Philemon Tafangy, the number of suspected cases of plague is between 300 and 500 annually.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages. [The following paragraph of this posting is from 1998 (Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4: \"Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had \"virtually disappeared\" on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health-management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.\"\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy producing the purpura seen in the \"Black Plague\" and also spread to the lung causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med 1997; 337(10): 677-80). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear if this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1kSe.]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nPlague, pneumonic - USA (04): (CA) chipmunk, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1344859", "date": "2012-07-19 11:39:18", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (03): (OREGON), SEPTICEMIC, RECOVERY\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nTue 18 Jul 2012\nSource: The Guardian [edited]\nhttp://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2012/jul/18/oregon-man-case-plague\n\n\nAn Oregon man who contracted a rare case of the plague trying to take a mouse from the jaws of a choking cat is no longer in a critical condition and has talked about his fears of losing all of his fingers as a result of the disease.\n\nThe family of the man, a welder from Prineville in rural Oregon, released pictures showing his hands withered by the cell-killing infection and darkened to the color of charcoal.\n\n\"I don't think I can do my job,\" he told the Associated Press in a phone interview from hospital. I'm going to lose all my fingers on both hands. I don't know about my thumbs. The toes, I might lose all them, too.\"\n\n\"We didn't even know the plague was around anymore,\" said his sister. \"We thought that was an ancient, ancient disease.\"\n\nThe disease, which rampaged through Europe in the Middle Ages and is thought to have wiped out between 1/4th and 1/3rd of the population, is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacterium. It can develop into 3 kinds of plague, including bubonic plague, which swells lymph nodes across the body. The other 2 are septicemic plague, which affects the bloodstream, and pneumonic plague, which affects the lungs.\n\nThe illness began after he saw a stray cat with a dead mouse jammed in the back of his throat. The cat appeared to be choking, so he and a friend attempted to dislodge the mouse. The distressed cat bit his hand. Unable to remove the mouse, the man shot the cat to end his suffering and buried him in the yard. Two days later, he awoke with a fever and chills.\n\nHe spent nearly a month on life support and only recently left the intensive care unit. At one point, doctors thought he was going to die, said his wife.\n\nThe cat's body was dug up, and tests confirmed it had the plague. Other cats and dogs in the area were tested, and none had the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Septicemic plague can cause peripheral gangrene. A photograph of the patient's hand can be found at:\nhttp://www.komonews.com/news/local/Oregon-man-recovering-from-rare-case-of-plague-162820406.html?tab=gallery&c=y&img=0.\n\nNot necessarily relevant for this posting, in an in-press report (Turdjman M, Ibraheem M, Brett M, et al: Misidentification of _Yersinia pestis_ by automated systems, resulting in delayed diagnoses of human plague infections - Oregon and New Mexico. Clin Infect Dis 2012, in press), the authors underscore the importance of clinical diagnosis of plague because automated systems can misidentify it. In theses cases, the Oregon case was initially identified as _Acinetobacter lwoffii_ by one lab, _Pseudomonas luteola_ by a 2nd and _Yersinia pseudotuberculosis_ by a 3rd. In the 2nd case, the lab 1st identified the isolate as _P. luteola_. Misidentification can delay appropriate treatment as well as isolation if needed for pneumonic plague.\n\nOf note, the same publication reports on unpublished data from CDC regarding the number of confirmed cases of human plague in the USA. From 1990 to 2010, 142 confirmed cases occurred, predominantly in Arizona, California, Colorado and New Mexico. Of the 139 cases with clinical data available, 75 percent were bubonic (with a 7 percent mortality); 21 percent were septicemic (with a 24 percent mortality), and 4 percent were pneumonic (with a 50 percent mortality). - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1fWb.]\nSee Also\nPlague - USA (02): (OR), septicemic 20120612.1165863\nPlague - USA: (NM) 20120601.1153277\n2011\n----\nPlague - I'm going to lose all my fingers on both hands. I don't know about my thumbs. The toes, I might lose all them, too.\"\n\n\"We didn't even know the plague was around anymore,\" said his sister. \"We thought that was an ancient, ancient disease.\"\n\nThe disease, which rampaged through Europe in the Middle Ages and is thought to have wiped out between 1/4th and 1/3rd of the population, is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacterium. It can develop into 3 kinds of plague, including bubonic plague, which swells lymph nodes across the body. The other 2 are septicemic plague, which affects the bloodstream, and pneumonic plague, which affects the lungs.\n\nThe illness began after he saw a stray cat with a dead mouse jammed in the back of his throat. The cat appeared to be choking, so he and a friend attempted to dislodge the mouse. The distressed cat bit his hand. Unable to remove the mouse, the man shot the cat to end his suffering and buried him in the yard. Clin Infect Dis 2012, in press), the authors underscore the importance of clinical diagnosis of plague because automated systems can misidentify it. In theses cases, the Oregon case was initially identified as _Acinetobacter lwoffii_ by one lab, _Pseudomonas luteola_ by a 2nd and _Yersinia pseudotuberculosis_ by a 3rd. In the 2nd case, the lab 1st identified the isolate as _P. luteola_. Misidentification can delay appropriate treatment as well as isolation if needed for pneumonic plague.\n\nOf note, the same publication reports on unpublished data from CDC regarding the number of confirmed cases of human plague in the USA. From 1990 to 2010, 142 confirmed cases occurred, predominantly in Arizona, California, Colorado and New Mexico. Of the 139 cases with clinical data available, 75 percent were bubonic (with a 7 percent mortality); 21 percent were septicemic (with a 24 percent mortality), and 4 percent were pneumonic (with a 50 percent mortality). - I'm going to lose all my fingers on both hands. I don't know about my thumbs. The toes, I might lose all them, too.\"\n\n\"We didn't even know the plague was around anymore,\" said his sister. \"We thought that was an ancient, ancient disease.\"\n\nThe disease, which rampaged through Europe in the Middle Ages and is thought to have wiped out between 1/4th and 1/3rd of the population, is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacterium. It can develop into 3 kinds of plague, including bubonic plague, which swells lymph nodes across the body. The other 2 are septicemic plague, which affects the bloodstream, and pneumonic plague, which affects the lungs.\n\nThe illness began after he saw a stray cat with a dead mouse jammed in the back of his throat. The cat appeared to be choking, so he and a friend attempted to dislodge the mouse. The distressed cat bit his hand. Clin Infect Dis 2012, in press), the authors underscore the importance of clinical diagnosis of plague because automated systems can misidentify it. In theses cases, the Oregon case was initially identified as _Acinetobacter lwoffii_ by one lab, _Pseudomonas luteola_ by a 2nd and _Yersinia pseudotuberculosis_ by a 3rd. In the 2nd case, the lab 1st identified the isolate as _P. luteola_. Misidentification can delay appropriate treatment as well as isolation if needed for pneumonic plague.\n\nOf note, the same publication reports on unpublished data from CDC regarding the number of confirmed cases of human plague in the USA. From 1990 to 2010, 142 confirmed cases occurred, predominantly in Arizona, California, Colorado and New Mexico. Of the 139 cases with clinical data available, 75 percent were bubonic (with a 7 percent mortality); 21 percent were septicemic (with a 24 percent mortality), and 4 percent were pneumonic (with a 50 percent mortality). - China: (SC) bubonic, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1290061", "date": "2012-07-19 11:39:18", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (03): (OREGON), SEPTICEMIC, RECOVERY\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nTue 18 Jul 2012\nSource: The Guardian [edited]\nhttp://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2012/jul/18/oregon-man-case-plague\n\n\nAn Oregon man who contracted a rare case of the plague trying to take a mouse from the jaws of a choking cat is no longer in a critical condition and has talked about his fears of losing all of his fingers as a result of the disease.\n\nThe family of the man, a welder from Prineville in rural Oregon, released pictures showing his hands withered by the cell-killing infection and darkened to the color of charcoal.\n\n\"I don't think I can do my job,\" he told the Associated Press in a phone interview from hospital. I'm going to lose all my fingers on both hands. I don't know about my thumbs. The toes, I might lose all them, too.\"\n\n\"We didn't even know the plague was around anymore,\" said his sister. \"We thought that was an ancient, ancient disease.\"\n\nThe disease, which rampaged through Europe in the Middle Ages and is thought to have wiped out between 1/4th and 1/3rd of the population, is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacterium. It can develop into 3 kinds of plague, including bubonic plague, which swells lymph nodes across the body. The other 2 are septicemic plague, which affects the bloodstream, and pneumonic plague, which affects the lungs.\n\nThe illness began after he saw a stray cat with a dead mouse jammed in the back of his throat. The cat appeared to be choking, so he and a friend attempted to dislodge the mouse. The distressed cat bit his hand. Unable to remove the mouse, the man shot the cat to end his suffering and buried him in the yard. Two days later, he awoke with a fever and chills.\n\nHe spent nearly a month on life support and only recently left the intensive care unit. At one point, doctors thought he was going to die, said his wife.\n\nThe cat's body was dug up, and tests confirmed it had the plague. Other cats and dogs in the area were tested, and none had the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Septicemic plague can cause peripheral gangrene. A photograph of the patient's hand can be found at:\nhttp://www.komonews.com/news/local/Oregon-man-recovering-from-rare-case-of-plague-162820406.html?tab=gallery&c=y&img=0.\n\nNot necessarily relevant for this posting, in an in-press report (Turdjman M, Ibraheem M, Brett M, et al: Misidentification of _Yersinia pestis_ by automated systems, resulting in delayed diagnoses of human plague infections - Oregon and New Mexico. Clin Infect Dis 2012, in press), the authors underscore the importance of clinical diagnosis of plague because automated systems can misidentify it. In theses cases, the Oregon case was initially identified as _Acinetobacter lwoffii_ by one lab, _Pseudomonas luteola_ by a 2nd and _Yersinia pseudotuberculosis_ by a 3rd. In the 2nd case, the lab 1st identified the isolate as _P. luteola_. Misidentification can delay appropriate treatment as well as isolation if needed for pneumonic plague.\n\nOf note, the same publication reports on unpublished data from CDC regarding the number of confirmed cases of human plague in the USA. From 1990 to 2010, 142 confirmed cases occurred, predominantly in Arizona, California, Colorado and New Mexico. Of the 139 cases with clinical data available, 75 percent were bubonic (with a 7 percent mortality); 21 percent were septicemic (with a 24 percent mortality), and 4 percent were pneumonic (with a 50 percent mortality). - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1fWb.]\nSee Also\nPlague - USA (02): (OR), septicemic 20120612.1165863\nPlague - USA: (NM) 20120601.1153277\n2011\n----\nPlague - USA (04): (CO) septicemic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1269118", "date": "2012-07-19 11:39:18", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (03): (OREGON), SEPTICEMIC, RECOVERY\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nTue 18 Jul 2012\nSource: The Guardian [edited]\nhttp://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2012/jul/18/oregon-man-case-plague\n\n\nAn Oregon man who contracted a rare case of the plague trying to take a mouse from the jaws of a choking cat is no longer in a critical condition and has talked about his fears of losing all of his fingers as a result of the disease.\n\nThe family of the man, a welder from Prineville in rural Oregon, released pictures showing his hands withered by the cell-killing infection and darkened to the color of charcoal.\n\n\"I don't think I can do my job,\" he told the Associated Press in a phone interview from hospital. I'm going to lose all my fingers on both hands. I don't know about my thumbs. The toes, I might lose all them, too.\"\n\n\"We didn't even know the plague was around anymore,\" said his sister. \"We thought that was an ancient, ancient disease.\"\n\nThe disease, which rampaged through Europe in the Middle Ages and is thought to have wiped out between 1/4th and 1/3rd of the population, is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacterium. It can develop into 3 kinds of plague, including bubonic plague, which swells lymph nodes across the body. The other 2 are septicemic plague, which affects the bloodstream, and pneumonic plague, which affects the lungs.\n\nThe illness began after he saw a stray cat with a dead mouse jammed in the back of his throat. The cat appeared to be choking, so he and a friend attempted to dislodge the mouse. The distressed cat bit his hand. Unable to remove the mouse, the man shot the cat to end his suffering and buried him in the yard. Two days later, he awoke with a fever and chills.\n\nHe spent nearly a month on life support and only recently left the intensive care unit. At one point, doctors thought he was going to die, said his wife.\n\nThe cat's body was dug up, and tests confirmed it had the plague. Other cats and dogs in the area were tested, and none had the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Septicemic plague can cause peripheral gangrene. Clin Infect Dis 2012, in press), the authors underscore the importance of clinical diagnosis of plague because automated systems can misidentify it. In theses cases, the Oregon case was initially identified as _Acinetobacter lwoffii_ by one lab, _Pseudomonas luteola_ by a 2nd and _Yersinia pseudotuberculosis_ by a 3rd. In the 2nd case, the lab 1st identified the isolate as _P. luteola_. Misidentification can delay appropriate treatment as well as isolation if needed for pneumonic plague.\n\nOf note, the same publication reports on unpublished data from CDC regarding the number of confirmed cases of human plague in the USA. From 1990 to 2010, 142 confirmed cases occurred, predominantly in Arizona, California, Colorado and New Mexico. Of the 139 cases with clinical data available, 75 percent were bubonic (with a 7 percent mortality); 21 percent were septicemic (with a 24 percent mortality), and 4 percent were pneumonic (with a 50 percent mortality). - USA (02): (OR), septicemic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1165863", "date": "2011-06-12 19:53:36", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (03): (COLORADO)\n*************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: 3 Jun 2011\nSource: Boulder County [edited]\nhttp://www.bouldercounty.org/apps/newsroom/templates/bc.aspx?articleid=2659&zoneid=1\n\n\nA domestic cat living in the 2500 block of Sixth Street has tested\npositive for plague. Additionally, a dead squirrel [probably a tree\nsquirrel] found at the intersection of Eighth Street and Maxwell\nAvenue has tested positive for plague. As a result, signs listing\nprecautionary measures to avoid plague have been posted in the\nMapleton Hill neighborhood.\n\nThis is the 1st time plague activity has been confirmed in Boulder\nCounty this season [2011].\n\nFor more information about plague, please visit\nhttp://www.BoulderCountyHealth.org or call the Health Alert Hotline\nat 303-441-1460.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 9 Jun 2011\nSource: Boulder Weekly [edited]\nhttp://www.boulderweekly.com/article-5757-plague-passes-with-rabies-on-its-heels.html\n\n\nThe plague outbreak in Boulder's Mapleton Hill area reported last\nweek seems to have run its course, according to county officials. But\n2 confirmed cases of rabies in bats rolled in this week to take its\nplace.\n\nOn 3 Jun 2011, Boulder County Public Health (BCPH) announced that a\ndomestic cat and a dead squirrel tested positive for plague. The cat\nlived in the 2500 block of 6th Street, and the squirrel was found at\n8th Street and Maxwell Avenue. Health officials posted signs around\nthe neighborhood advising residents of the danger and listing\nprecautionary measures to take.\n\nJoe Malinowski, manager of the BCPH Environmental Health Division,\nsaid this week that a 2nd dead squirrel tested positive for plague,\nbut the cat was successfully treated for the disease. There have been\nno other confirmed cases, he said, adding that he knows of no humans\nwho have reported contracting symptoms of the plague, which include\nhigh fever, extreme fatigue and painful, swollen lymph nodes. His\noffice has, however, received a few calls from area residents\nreporting additional dead squirrels. But Malinowski said officials\nwon't test another squirrel unless 2 or more are found in the same\nlocation.\n\nThe same area got hit with a similar plague infestation in 2005, he\nsaid, but usually the disease targets prairie dogs, not squirrels.\nMalinowski added that the plague typically runs its course within a\nfew days. \"It goes through the population pretty quickly,\" he said.\nUsually, prairie dogs return to the empty burrows of a colony that has\nbeen wiped out, and the squirrel population on Mapleton Hill is\nexpected to bounce back as well, he explained.\n\nThis is the 1st confirmed case of plague identified this season\n[2011], but Malinowski said it is common to have outbreaks each year.\n\nResidents were advised to keep cats indoors, since they seem to be\nmore susceptible to plague than dogs.\n\nOfficials suggest protecting pets with flea powder and keeping them\non a leash and out of wild rodent habitats. People entering wild\nrodent habitats should wear insect repellent and tuck their pants into\nsocks to prevent flea bites. Long-handed shovels should be used to\nremove dead rodents, and they should be sealed in garbage bags and\nplaced in garbage cans. Asked what symptoms sick animals exhibit\noutwardly, Malinowski said plague is not like distemper, which can\nleave animals like raccoons acting lethargic and wobbly. \"Typically,\"\nhe said, \"the plague acts so quickly that death comes fast.\"\n\n[Byline: Jefferson Dodge]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[With the widespread hot weather we are getting through the western\nstates, we can confidently expect more of these peri-domestic plague\ncases. - Mod.MHJ]\nSee Also\nPlague, animal - USA (02): (OR) feline 20110610.1773\nPlague, animal - USA: (NM) canine, feline 20110421.1240\n2010\n----\nPlague - USA (02): (CA) rodent 20100819.2878\nPlague, feline - USA (NM): early season cases 20080127.0340\n2007\n----\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (SD) 20070927.3205\nPlague, feline - USA (NM) 20070914.3055\nPlague, wildlife - USA (AZ) 20070812.2625\nPlague, ground squirrels - USA (CA) 20070811.2613\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (CO)(02) 20070729.2434\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (CO) 20070725.2386\nPlague, squirrel - USA (CA) 20070720.2322\nPlague, feline - USA (CO) 20070527.1693\nPlague, squirrel, flea, cat - USA (CO,CA) 20070518.1577\nPlague, squirrels, rabbit - USA (CO) 20070505.1455\nPlague, squirrel - USA (CO)(02) 20070503.1444\nPlague, squirrel - USA (CO) 20070427.1381\n2006\n----\nPlague, cougar - USA (WY) 20061215.3523\nPlague, cats - USA (AZ) 20060630.1806\nPlague, animals - USA (Colorado) (02): prairie dogs 20060627.1785\nPlague, squirrel - USA (CA) 20060528.1499\n.................................................mhj/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "rabies", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-06-03 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mapleton Hill", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boulder", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boulder County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boulder \n County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1153277", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA: (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1153277", "date": "2011-06-12 19:53:36", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (03): (COLORADO)\n*************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: 3 Jun 2011\nSource: Boulder County [edited]\nhttp://www.bouldercounty.org/apps/newsroom/templates/bc.aspx?articleid=2659&zoneid=1\n\n\nA domestic cat living in the 2500 block of Sixth Street has tested\npositive for plague. Additionally, a dead squirrel [probably a tree\nsquirrel] found at the intersection of Eighth Street and Maxwell\nAvenue has tested positive for plague. As a result, signs listing\nprecautionary measures to avoid plague have been posted in the\nMapleton Hill neighborhood.\n\nThis is the 1st time plague activity has been confirmed in Boulder\nCounty this season [2011].\n\nFor more information about plague, please visit\nhttp://www.BoulderCountyHealth.org or call the Health Alert Hotline\nat 303-441-1460.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 9 Jun 2011\nSource: Boulder Weekly [edited]\nhttp://www.boulderweekly.com/article-5757-plague-passes-with-rabies-on-its-heels.html\n\n\nThe plague outbreak in Boulder's Mapleton Hill area reported last\nweek seems to have run its course, according to county officials. But\n2 confirmed cases of rabies in bats rolled in this week to take its\nplace.\n\nOn 3 Jun 2011, Boulder County Public Health (BCPH) announced that a\ndomestic cat and a dead squirrel tested positive for plague. The cat\nlived in the 2500 block of 6th Street, and the squirrel was found at\n8th Street and Maxwell Avenue. Health officials posted signs around\nthe neighborhood advising residents of the danger and listing\nprecautionary measures to take.\n\nJoe Malinowski, manager of the BCPH Environmental Health Division,\nsaid this week that a 2nd dead squirrel tested positive for plague,\nbut the cat was successfully treated for the disease. There have been\nno other confirmed cases, he said, adding that he knows of no humans\nwho have reported contracting symptoms of the plague, which include\nhigh fever, extreme fatigue and painful, swollen lymph nodes. His\noffice has, however, received a few calls from area residents\nreporting additional dead squirrels. But Malinowski said officials\nwon't test another squirrel unless 2 or more are found in the same\nlocation.\n\nThe same area got hit with a similar plague infestation in 2005, he\nsaid, but usually the disease targets prairie dogs, not squirrels.\nMalinowski added that the plague typically runs its course within a\nfew days. \"It goes through the population pretty quickly,\" he said.\nUsually, prairie dogs return to the empty burrows of a colony that has\nbeen wiped out, and the squirrel population on Mapleton Hill is\nexpected to bounce back as well, he explained.\n\nThis is the 1st confirmed case of plague identified this season\n[2011], but Malinowski said it is common to have outbreaks each year.\n\nResidents were advised to keep cats indoors, since they seem to be\nmore susceptible to plague than dogs.\n\nOfficials suggest protecting pets with flea powder and keeping them\non a leash and out of wild rodent habitats. People entering wild\nrodent habitats should wear insect repellent and tuck their pants into\nsocks to prevent flea bites. Long-handed shovels should be used to\nremove dead rodents, and they should be sealed in garbage bags and\nplaced in garbage cans. Asked what symptoms sick animals exhibit\noutwardly, Malinowski said plague is not like distemper, which can\nleave animals like raccoons acting lethargic and wobbly. \"Typically,\"\nhe said, \"the plague acts so quickly that death comes fast.\"\n\n[Byline: Jefferson Dodge]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[With the widespread hot weather we are getting through the western\nstates, we can confidently expect more of these peri-domestic plague\ncases. - There have been\nno other confirmed cases, he said, adding that he knows of no humans\nwho have reported contracting symptoms of the plague, which include\nhigh fever, extreme fatigue and painful, swollen lymph nodes. His\noffice has, however, received a few calls from area residents\nreporting additional dead squirrels. But Malinowski said officials\nwon't test another squirrel unless 2 or more are found in the same\nlocation.\n\nThe same area got hit with a similar plague infestation in 2005, he\nsaid, but usually the disease targets prairie dogs, not squirrels.\nMalinowski added that the plague typically runs its course within a\nfew days. \"It goes through the population pretty quickly,\" he said.\nUsually, prairie dogs return to the empty burrows of a colony that has\nbeen wiped out, and the squirrel population on Mapleton Hill is\nexpected to bounce back as well, he explained.\n\nThis is the 1st confirmed case of plague identified this season\n[2011], but Malinowski said it is common to have outbreaks each year.\n\nResidents were advised to keep cats indoors, since they seem to be\nmore susceptible to plague than dogs.\n\nOfficials suggest protecting pets with flea powder and keeping them\non a leash and out of wild rodent habitats. People entering wild\nrodent habitats should wear insect repellent and tuck their pants into\nsocks to prevent flea bites. Long-handed shovels should be used to\nremove dead rodents, and they should be sealed in garbage bags and\nplaced in garbage cans. Asked what symptoms sick animals exhibit\noutwardly, Malinowski said plague is not like distemper, which can\nleave animals like raccoons acting lethargic and wobbly. \"Typically,\"\nhe said, \"the plague acts so quickly that death comes fast.\"\n\n[Byline: Jefferson Dodge]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[With the widespread hot weather we are getting through the western\nstates, we can confidently expect more of these peri-domestic plague\ncases. - Mod.MHJ]\nSee Also\nPlague, animal - USA (02): (OR) feline 20110610.1773\nPlague, animal - USA: (NM) canine, feline 20110421.1240\n2010\n----\nPlague - USA (02): (CA) rodent 20100819.2878\nPlague, feline - USA (04): (OR), septicemic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=878440", "date": "2011-06-12 19:53:36", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (03): (COLORADO)\n*************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: 3 Jun 2011\nSource: Boulder County [edited]\nhttp://www.bouldercounty.org/apps/newsroom/templates/bc.aspx?articleid=2659&zoneid=1\n\n\nA domestic cat living in the 2500 block of Sixth Street has tested\npositive for plague. Additionally, a dead squirrel [probably a tree\nsquirrel] found at the intersection of Eighth Street and Maxwell\nAvenue has tested positive for plague. As a result, signs listing\nprecautionary measures to avoid plague have been posted in the\nMapleton Hill neighborhood.\n\nThis is the 1st time plague activity has been confirmed in Boulder\nCounty this season [2011].\n\nFor more information about plague, please visit\nhttp://www.BoulderCountyHealth.org or call the Health Alert Hotline\nat 303-441-1460.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 9 Jun 2011\nSource: Boulder Weekly [edited]\nhttp://www.boulderweekly.com/article-5757-plague-passes-with-rabies-on-its-heels.html\n\n\nThe plague outbreak in Boulder's Mapleton Hill area reported last\nweek seems to have run its course, according to county officials. But\n2 confirmed cases of rabies in bats rolled in this week to take its\nplace.\n\nOn 3 Jun 2011, Boulder County Public Health (BCPH) announced that a\ndomestic cat and a dead squirrel tested positive for plague. The cat\nlived in the 2500 block of 6th Street, and the squirrel was found at\n8th Street and Maxwell Avenue. Health officials posted signs around\nthe neighborhood advising residents of the danger and listing\nprecautionary measures to take.\n\nJoe Malinowski, manager of the BCPH Environmental Health Division,\nsaid this week that a 2nd dead squirrel tested positive for plague,\nbut the cat was successfully treated for the disease. There have been\nno other confirmed cases, he said, adding that he knows of no humans\nwho have reported contracting symptoms of the plague, which include\nhigh fever, extreme fatigue and painful, swollen lymph nodes. His\noffice has, however, received a few calls from area residents\nreporting additional dead squirrels. But Malinowski said officials\nwon't test another squirrel unless 2 or more are found in the same\nlocation.\n\nThe same area got hit with a similar plague infestation in 2005, he\nsaid, but usually the disease targets prairie dogs, not squirrels.\nMalinowski added that the plague typically runs its course within a\nfew days. \"It goes through the population pretty quickly,\" he said.\nUsually, prairie dogs return to the empty burrows of a colony that has\nbeen wiped out, and the squirrel population on Mapleton Hill is\nexpected to bounce back as well, he explained.\n\nThis is the 1st confirmed case of plague identified this season\n[2011], but Malinowski said it is common to have outbreaks each year.\n\nResidents were advised to keep cats indoors, since they seem to be\nmore susceptible to plague than dogs.\n\nOfficials suggest protecting pets with flea powder and keeping them\non a leash and out of wild rodent habitats. People entering wild\nrodent habitats should wear insect repellent and tuck their pants into\nsocks to prevent flea bites. Long-handed shovels should be used to\nremove dead rodents, and they should be sealed in garbage bags and\nplaced in garbage cans. Asked what symptoms sick animals exhibit\noutwardly, Malinowski said plague is not like distemper, which can\nleave animals like raccoons acting lethargic and wobbly. \"Typically,\"\nhe said, \"the plague acts so quickly that death comes fast.\"\n\n[Byline: Jefferson Dodge]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[With the widespread hot weather we are getting through the western\nstates, we can confidently expect more of these peri-domestic plague\ncases. -
