USA (AZ) 20060630.1806\nPlague, animals - USA (Colorado) (02): prairie dogs 20060627.1785\nPlague, squirrel - USA (CA) 20060528.1499\n.................................................mhj/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "rabies", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-06-03 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mapleton Hill", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boulder", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boulder County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boulder \n County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "750921", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (02): (OR) feline", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=750921", "date": "2011-02-24 20:00:04", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA: (OREGON), 2010, BUBONIC, CDC\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 24 Feb 2011\nSource: Morbidity Mortality Weekly Report 2011;60:214 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm?s_cid=mm6007a4_e&source=govdelivery>\n\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the\nwestern USA. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected\nflea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals, 2) direct contact\nwith contaminated tissues, or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of\nrespiratory secretions from infected persons or animals. In September\n2010, the Oregon Health Authority reported the 1st 2 cases of human\nplague in Oregon since 1995 and the only 2 USA cases in 2010.\n\nBoth illnesses began on 21 Aug 2010. The patients, aged 17 and 42\nyears, lived in the same household and might have been exposed to\nplague by infected fleas from a dog; that dog was found to be\nseropositive for _Y. pestis_ by the passive\nhemagglutination-inhibition assay (dilution of 1:64). One patient\nacknowledged sleeping in the same bed with the dog during the 2 weeks\nbefore illness onset. Both patients had high fever and multiple\nbilateral inguinal buboes; one patient had hypotension, tachycardia,\nand acute renal failure and was hospitalized. A gram-negative rod with\nbipolar staining was isolated from a specimen of that patient's\nblood.\n\nFour different clinical laboratories attempted to identify the\nisolate. Three different commercial automated systems identified the\norganism as _Acinetobacter lwoffii_, _Pseudomonas luteola_, and\n_Yersinia pseudotuberculosis_, respectively. However, 25 days after\nspecimen collection, the isolate was identified as _Y. pestis_ by\ndirect fluorescent antibody to F1 antigen, polymerase chain reaction,\nand bacteriophage lysis at the Spokane (Washington) Regional Health\nDistrict Laboratory, prompting notification of the Oregon Health\nAuthority. The 2nd patient was identified retrospectively on the basis\nof a single positive serology (passive hemagglutination-inhibition\n[dilution of 1:32]). Plague was not suspected initially. Both patients\nrecovered uneventfully after empiric therapy with doxycycline and\namoxicillin clavulanate potassium, respectively, although the latter\nis not considered effective in treating plague.\n\nAutomated bacterial identification systems can misidentify _Y.\npestis_ (1,2). Automated identification of _Yersinia_ spp. in blood\nshould prompt further clinical evaluation of the patient to determine\nwhether symptoms are compatible with plague. When plague is suspected,\ntreatment should be started immediately, and both the state public\nhealth laboratory and public health authorities should be notified\npromptly.\n\nPlague is a Category A potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections\nare rare but can be life-threatening. The plague case-fatality rate\ndepends on the clinical presentation (i.e., bubonic, septicemic, or\npneumonic) and timing of antibiotic therapy initiation; if untreated,\nthe case-fatality rate is over 50 percent for bubonic plague and\napproaches 100 percent for pneumonic plague (3). Rapid laboratory\nidentification can help guide therapy.\n\nSleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in\nenzootic areas (4). Plague patients with no history of exposure to\nrodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected\nrodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea\ncontrol to dog and cat owners.\n\nReferences\n--------\n1. American Society for Microbiology: Sentinel laboratory guidelines\nfor suspected agent of bioterrorism: Yersinia pestis. Washington, DC:\nAmerican Society for Microbiology; 2009. Available at\n<http://www.asm.org/images/pdf/Clinical/ypestis12-11-09.pdf>. Accessed\n17 Feb 2011.\n2. CDC: Fatal human plague---Arizona and Colorado, 1996. MMWR\n1997;46:617-620.\n3. CDC: Human plague---four states, 2006. MMWR 2006;55:940-943.\n4. Gould LH, Pape J, Ettestad P, Griffith KS, Mead PS: Dog-associated\nrisk factors for human plague. Zoonoses Public Health\n2008;55:448-454.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This CDC report adds additional information regarding the 2 cases of\nbubonic plague in Oregon that occurred in August 2010. Most cases of\n_Y. pestis_ infections in the USA occur in the area of the \"Four\nCorner\" states: Colorado, Arizona, New Mexico and Utah. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, fatal - USA: (IL), 2009, lab strain, CDC 20110224.0614\n2010\n----\nPlague - USA (03): (OR) bubonic 20101004.3597\nPlague - USA (02): (CA) rodent 20100819.2878\nPlague, wildlife - Canada: (SK) prairie dog 20100817.2849\nPlague, feline - USA: (MT) 20100807.2693\nPlague - USA: (CA) ground squirrel 20100708.2275\nPlague, canine - USA: (NM) 20100418.1259\nPlague, cougar - USA (WY) 20100208.0429\n2009\n----\nPlague, feline - USA (CA) 20091205.4150\nPlague, fatal - USA (05): (IL) lab strain susp. RFI 20090921.3320\nPlague, fatal - USA (03): (NM) recovery 20090715.2530\nPlague, tularemia, prairie dogs - USA (SD) 20090712.2494\nPlague, fatal - USA (02): (NM) risk, prevention 20090611.2153\nPlague, fatal - USA: (NM) bubonic 20090605.2080\nPlague, rabbit - USA (NM) 20090415.1435\n2008\n----\nPlague, human, prairie dogs - USA: (AZ) 20081012.3229\nPlague, prairie dogs, ferrets - USA: (SD) (02) 20080722.2213\nPlague, prairie dog, ferrets - USA: (SD) 20080708.2082\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA: (CO), susp., RFI 20080506.1552\nPlague, human, feline - USA (NM): early season cases 20080127.0340\n.................................................ll/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tuberculosis", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-02-24 00:00:00", "2010-09-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-08-21 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-02-17 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-08-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "736097", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic - Libya: (BN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=736097", "date": "2011-02-24 20:00:04", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA: (OREGON), 2010, BUBONIC, CDC\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 24 Feb 2011\nSource: Morbidity Mortality Weekly Report 2011;60:214 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm?s_cid=mm6007a4_e&source=govdelivery>\n\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the\nwestern USA. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected\nflea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals, 2) direct contact\nwith contaminated tissues, or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of\nrespiratory secretions from infected persons or animals. In September\n2010, the Oregon Health Authority reported the 1st 2 cases of human\nplague in Oregon since 1995 and the only 2 USA cases in 2010.\n\nBoth illnesses began on 21 Aug 2010. The patients, aged 17 and 42\nyears, lived in the same household and might have been exposed to\nplague by infected fleas from a dog; that dog was found to be\nseropositive for _Y. pestis_ by the passive\nhemagglutination-inhibition assay (dilution of 1:64). One patient\nacknowledged sleeping in the same bed with the dog during the 2 weeks\nbefore illness onset. Both patients had high fever and multiple\nbilateral inguinal buboes; one patient had hypotension, tachycardia,\nand acute renal failure and was hospitalized. A gram-negative rod with\nbipolar staining was isolated from a specimen of that patient's\nblood.\n\nFour different clinical laboratories attempted to identify the\nisolate. Three different commercial automated systems identified the\norganism as _Acinetobacter lwoffii_, _Pseudomonas luteola_, and\n_Yersinia pseudotuberculosis_, respectively. However, 25 days after\nspecimen collection, the isolate was identified as _Y. pestis_ by\ndirect fluorescent antibody to F1 antigen, polymerase chain reaction,\nand bacteriophage lysis at the Spokane (Washington) Regional Health\nDistrict Laboratory, prompting notification of the Oregon Health\nAuthority. The 2nd patient was identified retrospectively on the basis\nof a single positive serology (passive hemagglutination-inhibition\n[dilution of 1:32]). Plague was not suspected initially. Both patients\nrecovered uneventfully after empiric therapy with doxycycline and\namoxicillin clavulanate potassium, respectively, although the latter\nis not considered effective in treating plague.\n\nAutomated bacterial identification systems can misidentify _Y.\npestis_ (1,2). Automated identification of _Yersinia_ spp. in blood\nshould prompt further clinical evaluation of the patient to determine\nwhether symptoms are compatible with plague. When plague is suspected,\ntreatment should be started immediately, and both the state public\nhealth laboratory and public health authorities should be notified\npromptly.\n\nPlague is a Category A potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections\nare rare but can be life-threatening. The plague case-fatality rate\ndepends on the clinical presentation (i.e., bubonic, septicemic, or\npneumonic) and timing of antibiotic therapy initiation; if untreated,\nthe case-fatality rate is over 50 percent for bubonic plague and\napproaches 100 percent for pneumonic plague (3). Rapid laboratory\nidentification can help guide therapy.\n\nSleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in\nenzootic areas (4). Plague patients with no history of exposure to\nrodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected\nrodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea\ncontrol to dog and cat owners.\n\nReferences\n--------\n1. American Society for Microbiology: Sentinel laboratory guidelines\nfor suspected agent of bioterrorism: Yersinia pestis. Washington, DC:\nAmerican Society for Microbiology; 2009. Available at\n<http://www.asm.org/images/pdf/Clinical/ypestis12-11-09.pdf>. Accessed\n17 Feb 2011.\n2. CDC: Fatal human plague---Arizona and Colorado, 1996. MMWR\n1997;46:617-620.\n3. CDC: Human plague---four states, 2006. MMWR 2006;55:940-943.\n4. Gould LH, Pape J, Ettestad P, Griffith KS, Mead PS: Dog-associated\nrisk factors for human plague. Zoonoses Public Health\n2008;55:448-454.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This CDC report adds additional information regarding the 2 cases of\nbubonic plague in Oregon that occurred in August 2010. USA (02): (NM) bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=717936", "date": "2011-02-24 20:00:04", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA: (OREGON), 2010, BUBONIC, CDC\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 24 Feb 2011\nSource: Morbidity Mortality Weekly Report 2011;60:214 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm?s_cid=mm6007a4_e&source=govdelivery>\n\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the\nwestern USA. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected\nflea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals, 2) direct contact\nwith contaminated tissues, or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of\nrespiratory secretions from infected persons or animals. In September\n2010, the Oregon Health Authority reported the 1st 2 cases of human\nplague in Oregon since 1995 and the only 2 USA cases in 2010.\n\nBoth illnesses began on 21 Aug 2010. The patients, aged 17 and 42\nyears, lived in the same household and might have been exposed to\nplague by infected fleas from a dog; that dog was found to be\nseropositive for _Y. pestis_ by the passive\nhemagglutination-inhibition assay (dilution of 1:64). One patient\nacknowledged sleeping in the same bed with the dog during the 2 weeks\nbefore illness onset. Both patients had high fever and multiple\nbilateral inguinal buboes; one patient had hypotension, tachycardia,\nand acute renal failure and was hospitalized. A gram-negative rod with\nbipolar staining was isolated from a specimen of that patient's\nblood.\n\nFour different clinical laboratories attempted to identify the\nisolate. Three different commercial automated systems identified the\norganism as _Acinetobacter lwoffii_, _Pseudomonas luteola_, and\n_Yersinia pseudotuberculosis_, respectively. However, 25 days after\nspecimen collection, the isolate was identified as _Y. pestis_ by\ndirect fluorescent antibody to F1 antigen, polymerase chain reaction,\nand bacteriophage lysis at the Spokane (Washington) Regional Health\nDistrict Laboratory, prompting notification of the Oregon Health\nAuthority. The 2nd patient was identified retrospectively on the basis\nof a single positive serology (passive hemagglutination-inhibition\n[dilution of 1:32]). Plague was not suspected initially. Both patients\nrecovered uneventfully after empiric therapy with doxycycline and\namoxicillin clavulanate potassium, respectively, although the latter\nis not considered effective in treating plague.\n\nAutomated bacterial identification systems can misidentify _Y.\npestis_ (1,2). Automated identification of _Yersinia_ spp. in blood\nshould prompt further clinical evaluation of the patient to determine\nwhether symptoms are compatible with plague. When plague is suspected,\ntreatment should be started immediately, and both the state public\nhealth laboratory and public health authorities should be notified\npromptly.\n\nPlague is a Category A potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections\nare rare but can be life-threatening. The plague case-fatality rate\ndepends on the clinical presentation (i.e., bubonic, septicemic, or\npneumonic) and timing of antibiotic therapy initiation; if untreated,\nthe case-fatality rate is over 50 percent for bubonic plague and\napproaches 100 percent for pneumonic plague (3). Rapid laboratory\nidentification can help guide therapy.\n\nSleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in\nenzootic areas (4). Plague patients with no history of exposure to\nrodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected\nrodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea\ncontrol to dog and cat owners.\n\nReferences\n--------\n1. American Society for Microbiology: Sentinel laboratory guidelines\nfor suspected agent of bioterrorism: Yersinia pestis. Washington, DC:\nAmerican Society for Microbiology; 2009. Available at\n<http://www.asm.org/images/pdf/Clinical/ypestis12-11-09.pdf>. Accessed\n17 Feb 2011.\n2. CDC: Fatal human plague---Arizona and Colorado, 1996. MMWR\n1997;46:617-620.\n3. CDC: Human plague---four states, 2006. MMWR 2006;55:940-943.\n4. Gould LH, Pape J, Ettestad P, Griffith KS, Mead PS: Dog-associated\nrisk factors for human plague. Zoonoses Public Health\n2008;55:448-454.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This CDC report adds additional information regarding the 2 cases of\nbubonic plague in Oregon that occurred in August 2010. Most cases of\n_Y. pestis_ infections in the USA occur in the area of the \"Four\nCorner\" states: Colorado, Arizona, New Mexico and Utah. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, fatal - USA: (IL), 2009, lab strain, CDC 20110224.0614\n2010\n----\nPlague - USA (03): (OR) bubonic 20101004.3597\nPlague - USA (02): (CA) rodent 20100819.2878\nPlague, wildlife - Canada: (SK) prairie dog 20100817.2849\nPlague, feline - USA: (MT) 20100807.2693\nPlague - USA: (CA) ground squirrel 20100708.2275\nPlague, canine - USA: (NM) 20100418.1259\nPlague, cougar - USA (WY) 20100208.0429\n2009\n----\nPlague, feline - USA (CA) 20091205.4150\nPlague, fatal - USA (05): (IL) lab strain susp. RFI 20090921.3320\nPlague, fatal - USA (03): (NM) recovery 20090715.2530\nPlague, tularemia, prairie dogs - USA (SD) 20090712.2494\nPlague, fatal - USA (02): (NM) risk, prevention 20090611.2153\nPlague, fatal - USA: (NM) bubonic 20090605.2080\nPlague, rabbit - USA (NM) 20090415.1435\n2008\n----\nPlague, human, prairie dogs - USA: (AZ) 20081012.3229\nPlague, prairie dogs, ferrets - USA: (SD) (02) 20080722.2213\nPlague, prairie dog, ferrets - USA: (SD) 20080708.2082\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA: (CO), susp., RFI 20080506.1552\nPlague, human, feline - USA (NM): early season cases 20080127.0340\n.................................................ll/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Details available at:\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Donations.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org (NOT to\nan individual moderator). If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tuberculosis", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-02-24 00:00:00", "2010-09-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-08-21 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-02-17 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-08-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "704026", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, animal - USA: (NM) canine, feline", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=704026", "date": "2011-02-24 20:00:04", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA: (OREGON), 2010, BUBONIC, CDC\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 24 Feb 2011\nSource: Morbidity Mortality Weekly Report 2011;60:214 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm?s_cid=mm6007a4_e&source=govdelivery>\n\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the\nwestern USA. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected\nflea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals, 2) direct contact\nwith contaminated tissues, or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of\nrespiratory secretions from infected persons or animals. In September\n2010, the Oregon Health Authority reported the 1st 2 cases of human\nplague in Oregon since 1995 and the only 2 USA cases in 2010.\n\nBoth illnesses began on 21 Aug 2010. The patients, aged 17 and 42\nyears, lived in the same household and might have been exposed to\nplague by infected fleas from a dog; that dog was found to be\nseropositive for _Y. pestis_ by the passive\nhemagglutination-inhibition assay (dilution of 1:64). One patient\nacknowledged sleeping in the same bed with the dog during the 2 weeks\nbefore illness onset. Both patients had high fever and multiple\nbilateral inguinal buboes; one patient had hypotension, tachycardia,\nand acute renal failure and was hospitalized. A gram-negative rod with\nbipolar staining was isolated from a specimen of that patient's\nblood.\n\nFour different clinical laboratories attempted to identify the\nisolate. Three different commercial automated systems identified the\norganism as _Acinetobacter lwoffii_, _Pseudomonas luteola_, and\n_Yersinia pseudotuberculosis_, respectively. However, 25 days after\nspecimen collection, the isolate was identified as _Y. pestis_ by\ndirect fluorescent antibody to F1 antigen, polymerase chain reaction,\nand bacteriophage lysis at the Spokane (Washington) Regional Health\nDistrict Laboratory, prompting notification of the Oregon Health\nAuthority. The 2nd patient was identified retrospectively on the basis\nof a single positive serology (passive hemagglutination-inhibition\n[dilution of 1:32]). Plague was not suspected initially. Both patients\nrecovered uneventfully after empiric therapy with doxycycline and\namoxicillin clavulanate potassium, respectively, although the latter\nis not considered effective in treating plague.\n\nAutomated bacterial identification systems can misidentify _Y.\npestis_ (1,2). Automated identification of _Yersinia_ spp. in blood\nshould prompt further clinical evaluation of the patient to determine\nwhether symptoms are compatible with plague. When plague is suspected,\ntreatment should be started immediately, and both the state public\nhealth laboratory and public health authorities should be notified\npromptly.\n\nPlague is a Category A potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections\nare rare but can be life-threatening. The plague case-fatality rate\ndepends on the clinical presentation (i.e., bubonic, septicemic, or\npneumonic) and timing of antibiotic therapy initiation; if untreated,\nthe case-fatality rate is over 50 percent for bubonic plague and\napproaches 100 percent for pneumonic plague (3). Rapid laboratory\nidentification can help guide therapy.\n\nSleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in\nenzootic areas (4). Plague patients with no history of exposure to\nrodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected\nrodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea\ncontrol to dog and cat owners.\n\nReferences\n--------\n1. American Society for Microbiology: Sentinel laboratory guidelines\nfor suspected agent of bioterrorism: Yersinia pestis. Washington, DC:\nAmerican Society for Microbiology; 2009. Available at\n<http://www.asm.org/images/pdf/Clinical/ypestis12-11-09.pdf>. Accessed\n17 Feb 2011.\n2. CDC: Fatal human plague---Arizona and Colorado, 1996. MMWR\n1997;46:617-620.\n3. CDC: Human plague---four states, 2006. MMWR 2006;55:940-943.\n4. Gould LH, Pape J, Ettestad P, Griffith KS, Mead PS: Dog-associated\nrisk factors for human plague. Zoonoses Public Health\n2008;55:448-454.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This CDC report adds additional information regarding the 2 cases of\nbubonic plague in Oregon that occurred in August 2010. Most cases of\n_Y. pestis_ infections in the USA occur in the area of the \"Four\nCorner\" states: Colorado, Arizona, New Mexico and Utah. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, fatal - USA: (IL), 2009, lab strain, CDC 20110224.0614\n2010\n----\nPlague - USA (03): (OR) bubonic 20101004.3597\nPlague - USA (02): (CA) rodent 20100819.2878\nPlague, wildlife - Canada: (SK) prairie dog 20100817.2849\nPlague, feline - USA: (MT) 20100807.2693\nPlague - USA: (CA) ground squirrel 20100708.2275\nPlague, canine - USA: (NM) 20100418.1259\nPlague, cougar - USA (WY) 20100208.0429\n2009\n----\nPlague, feline - USA (CA) 20091205.4150\nPlague, fatal - USA (05): (IL) lab strain susp. RFI 20090921.3320\nPlague, fatal - USA (03): (NM) recovery 20090715.2530\nPlague, tularemia, prairie dogs - USA (SD) 20090712.2494\nPlague, fatal - USA (02): (NM) risk, prevention 20090611.2153\nPlague, fatal - USA: (NM) bubonic 20090605.2080\nPlague, rabbit - USA (NM) 20090415.1435\n2008\n----\nPlague, human, prairie dogs - USA: (AZ) 20081012.3229\nPlague, prairie dogs, ferrets - USA: (SD) (02) 20080722.2213\nPlague, prairie dog, ferrets - USA: (SD) 20080708.2082\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA: (CO), susp., RFI 20080506.1552\nPlague, human, feline - USA (NM): early season cases 20080127.0340\n.................................................ll/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Madagascar (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=677787", "date": "2011-02-24 20:00:04", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA: (OREGON), 2010, BUBONIC, CDC\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 24 Feb 2011\nSource: Morbidity Mortality Weekly Report 2011;60:214 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm?s_cid=mm6007a4_e&source=govdelivery>\n\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the\nwestern USA. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected\nflea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals, 2) direct contact\nwith contaminated tissues, or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of\nrespiratory secretions from infected persons or animals. In September\n2010, the Oregon Health Authority reported the 1st 2 cases of human\nplague in Oregon since 1995 and the only 2 USA cases in 2010.\n\nBoth illnesses began on 21 Aug 2010. The patients, aged 17 and 42\nyears, lived in the same household and might have been exposed to\nplague by infected fleas from a dog; that dog was found to be\nseropositive for _Y. pestis_ by the passive\nhemagglutination-inhibition assay (dilution of 1:64). One patient\nacknowledged sleeping in the same bed with the dog during the 2 weeks\nbefore illness onset. Both patients had high fever and multiple\nbilateral inguinal buboes; one patient had hypotension, tachycardia,\nand acute renal failure and was hospitalized. A gram-negative rod with\nbipolar staining was isolated from a specimen of that patient's\nblood.\n\nFour different clinical laboratories attempted to identify the\nisolate. Three different commercial automated systems identified the\norganism as _Acinetobacter lwoffii_, _Pseudomonas luteola_, and\n_Yersinia pseudotuberculosis_, respectively. However, 25 days after\nspecimen collection, the isolate was identified as _Y. pestis_ by\ndirect fluorescent antibody to F1 antigen, polymerase chain reaction,\nand bacteriophage lysis at the Spokane (Washington) Regional Health\nDistrict Laboratory, prompting notification of the Oregon Health\nAuthority. The 2nd patient was identified retrospectively on the basis\nof a single positive serology (passive hemagglutination-inhibition\n[dilution of 1:32]). Plague was not suspected initially. Both patients\nrecovered uneventfully after empiric therapy with doxycycline and\namoxicillin clavulanate potassium, respectively, although the latter\nis not considered effective in treating plague.\n\nAutomated bacterial identification systems can misidentify _Y.\npestis_ (1,2). Automated identification of _Yersinia_ spp. in blood\nshould prompt further clinical evaluation of the patient to determine\nwhether symptoms are compatible with plague. When plague is suspected,\ntreatment should be started immediately, and both the state public\nhealth laboratory and public health authorities should be notified\npromptly.\n\nPlague is a Category A potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections\nare rare but can be life-threatening. The plague case-fatality rate\ndepends on the clinical presentation (i.e., bubonic, septicemic, or\npneumonic) and timing of antibiotic therapy initiation; if untreated,\nthe case-fatality rate is over 50 percent for bubonic plague and\napproaches 100 percent for pneumonic plague (3). Rapid laboratory\nidentification can help guide therapy.\n\nSleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in\nenzootic areas (4). Plague patients with no history of exposure to\nrodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected\nrodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea\ncontrol to dog and cat owners.\n\nReferences\n--------\n1. CDC: Human plague---four states, 2006. MMWR 2006;55:940-943.\n4. Gould LH, Pape J, Ettestad P, Griffith KS, Mead PS: Dog-associated\nrisk factors for human plague. Zoonoses Public Health\n2008;55:448-454.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This CDC report adds additional information regarding the 2 cases of\nbubonic plague in Oregon that occurred in August 2010. Most cases of\n_Y. pestis_ infections in the USA occur in the area of the \"Four\nCorner\" states: Colorado, Arizona, New Mexico and Utah. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, fatal - USA: (IL), 2009, lab strain, CDC 20110224.0614\n2010\n----\nPlague - USA (03): (OR) bubonic 20101004.3597\nPlague - USA (02): (CA) rodent 20100819.2878\nPlague, wildlife - Canada: (SK) prairie dog 20100817.2849\nPlague, feline - USA: (MT) 20100807.2693\nPlague - USA: (CA) ground squirrel 20100708.2275\nPlague, canine - USA: (NM) 20100418.1259\nPlague, cougar - USA (WY) 20100208.0429\n2009\n----\nPlague, feline - USA (CA) 20091205.4150\nPlague, fatal - USA (05): (IL) lab strain susp. RFI 20090921.3320\nPlague, fatal - USA (03): (NM) recovery 20090715.2530\nPlague, tularemia, prairie dogs - USA (SD) 20090712.2494\nPlague, fatal - USA (02): (NM) risk, prevention 20090611.2153\nPlague, fatal - USA: (NM) bubonic 20090605.2080\nPlague, rabbit - USA (NM) 20090415.1435\n2008\n----\nPlague, human, prairie dogs - USA: (AZ) 20081012.3229\nPlague, prairie dogs, ferrets - USA: (SD) (02) 20080722.2213\nPlague, prairie dog, ferrets - USA: (SD) 20080708.2082\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA: (CO), susp., RFI 20080506.1552\nPlague, human, feline - USA (NM): early season cases 20080127.0340\n.................................................ll/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tuberculosis", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-02-24 00:00:00", "2010-09-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-08-21 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-02-17 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-08-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "661812", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA: (OR), 2010, bubonic, CDC", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=661812", "date": "2011-02-24 20:00:04", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA: (OREGON), 2010, BUBONIC, CDC\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 24 Feb 2011\nSource: Morbidity Mortality Weekly Report 2011;60:214 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm?s_cid=mm6007a4_e&source=govdelivery>\n\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the\nwestern USA. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected\nflea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals, 2) direct contact\nwith contaminated tissues, or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of\nrespiratory secretions from infected persons or animals. In September\n2010, the Oregon Health Authority reported the 1st 2 cases of human\nplague in Oregon since 1995 and the only 2 USA cases in 2010.\n\nBoth illnesses began on 21 Aug 2010. The patients, aged 17 and 42\nyears, lived in the same household and might have been exposed to\nplague by infected fleas from a dog; that dog was found to be\nseropositive for _Y. pestis_ by the passive\nhemagglutination-inhibition assay (dilution of 1:64). One patient\nacknowledged sleeping in the same bed with the dog during the 2 weeks\nbefore illness onset. Both patients had high fever and multiple\nbilateral inguinal buboes; one patient had hypotension, tachycardia,\nand acute renal failure and was hospitalized. A gram-negative rod with\nbipolar staining was isolated from a specimen of that patient's\nblood.\n\nFour different clinical laboratories attempted to identify the\nisolate. Three different commercial automated systems identified the\norganism as _Acinetobacter lwoffii_, _Pseudomonas luteola_, and\n_Yersinia pseudotuberculosis_, respectively. However, 25 days after\nspecimen collection, the isolate was identified as _Y. pestis_ by\ndirect fluorescent antibody to F1 antigen, polymerase chain reaction,\nand bacteriophage lysis at the Spokane (Washington) Regional Health\nDistrict Laboratory, prompting notification of the Oregon Health\nAuthority. The 2nd patient was identified retrospectively on the basis\nof a single positive serology (passive hemagglutination-inhibition\n[dilution of 1:32]). Plague was not suspected initially. Both patients\nrecovered uneventfully after empiric therapy with doxycycline and\namoxicillin clavulanate potassium, respectively, although the latter\nis not considered effective in treating plague.\n\nAutomated bacterial identification systems can misidentify _Y.\npestis_ (1,2). Automated identification of _Yersinia_ spp. in blood\nshould prompt further clinical evaluation of the patient to determine\nwhether symptoms are compatible with plague. When plague is suspected,\ntreatment should be started immediately, and both the state public\nhealth laboratory and public health authorities should be notified\npromptly.\n\nPlague is a Category A potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections\nare rare but can be life-threatening. The plague case-fatality rate\ndepends on the clinical presentation (i.e., bubonic, septicemic, or\npneumonic) and timing of antibiotic therapy initiation; if untreated,\nthe case-fatality rate is over 50 percent for bubonic plague and\napproaches 100 percent for pneumonic plague (3). Rapid laboratory\nidentification can help guide therapy.\n\nSleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in\nenzootic areas (4). Plague patients with no history of exposure to\nrodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected\nrodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea\ncontrol to dog and cat owners.\n\nReferences\n--------\n1. American Society for Microbiology: Sentinel laboratory guidelines\nfor suspected agent of bioterrorism: Yersinia pestis. Washington, DC:\nAmerican Society for Microbiology; 2009. Available at\n<http://www.asm.org/images/pdf/Clinical/ypestis12-11-09.pdf>. Accessed\n17 Feb 2011.\n2. CDC: Fatal human plague---Arizona and Colorado, 1996. MMWR\n1997;46:617-620.\n3. CDC: Human plague---four states, 2006. MMWR 2006;55:940-943.\n4. Gould LH, Pape J, Ettestad P, Griffith KS, Mead PS: Dog-associated\nrisk factors for human plague. Zoonoses Public Health\n2008;55:448-454.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This CDC report adds additional information regarding the 2 cases of\nbubonic plague in Oregon that occurred in August 2010. Most cases of\n_Y. pestis_ infections in the USA occur in the area of the \"Four\nCorner\" states: Colorado, Arizona, New Mexico and Utah. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, fatal - USA: (IL), 2009, lab strain, CDC 20110224.0614\n2010\n----\nPlague - USA (03): (OR) bubonic 20101004.3597\nPlague - USA (02): (CA) rodent 20100819.2878\nPlague, wildlife - Canada: (SK) prairie dog 20100817.2849\nPlague, feline - USA: (MT) 20100807.2693\nPlague - USA: (CA) ground squirrel 20100708.2275\nPlague, canine - USA: (NM) 20100418.1259\nPlague, cougar - USA (WY) 20100208.0429\n2009\n----\nPlague, feline - USA (CA) 20091205.4150\nPlague, fatal - USA (05): (IL) lab strain susp. RFI 20090921.3320\nPlague, fatal - USA (03): (NM) recovery 20090715.2530\nPlague, tularemia, prairie dogs - USA (SD) 20090712.2494\nPlague, fatal - USA (02): (NM) risk, prevention 20090611.2153\nPlague, fatal - USA: (NM) bubonic 20090605.2080\nPlague, rabbit - USA (NM) 20090415.1435\n2008\n----\nPlague, human, prairie dogs - USA: (AZ) 20081012.3229\nPlague, prairie dogs, ferrets - USA: (SD) (02) 20080722.2213\nPlague, prairie dog, ferrets - USA: (SD) 20080708.2082\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA: (CO), susp., RFI 20080506.1552\nPlague, human, feline - USA (NM): early season cases 20080127.0340\n.................................................ll/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Details available at:\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Donations.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org (NOT to\nan individual moderator). If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tuberculosis", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-02-24 00:00:00", "2010-09-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-08-21 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-02-17 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-08-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "661759", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Plague, fatal - USA: (IL), 2009, lab strain, CDC", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=661759", "date": "2010-11-08 18:00:04", "main_text": "CRAYFISH PLAGUE - UK: ENGLAND\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 8 Nov 2010\nSource: BristolZooUK [accessed 8 Nov 2010, summarised, edited]\n<http://www.bristolzoo.org.uk/conservationists-highlight-worsening-plight-of-uk-crayfish?theme=orange>\n\n\nBristol conservationists are highlighting the worsening plight of native\ncrayfish as the species is officially upgraded to \"endangered\".\nWhite-clawed crayfish are the UK's only native freshwater crayfish, but\ntheir numbers have suffered extensive decline in recent years. Experts warn\nthe species could become extinct from the UK within the next 30 years; it\nis currently a protected species.\n\nToday, white-clawed crayfish have been upgraded from \"vulnerable\" to\n\"endangered\" on the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN)\nRed List of Threatened Species, following a Sampled Red List Index (SRLI)\nassessment by the Zoological Society of London (ZSL). The ranking gives an\nindication of how likely a species is to become extinct.\n\nEve Leegwater, technical biodiversity officer at the Environment Agency,\nsaid: \"It is important to base conservation efforts on scientific research,\nand the IUCN Red List has become an increasingly important tool to guide\ngovernment and scientific institutes towards the conservation and\nlegislation of species and habitats at risk of extinction.\" She added: \"The\nchange in status of white-clawed crayfish will help stress the need for\nconservation strategies to be implemented to aid this valuable species.\"\n\nUp to 70 per cent of white-clawed crayfish have been lost from the south\nwest, and some parts of the UK have lost their entire populations. This is\npredominantly due to the crayfish plague, a fungus-like disease which is\nharmless to people and most animals but lethal to white-clawed crayfish.\nThe crayfish plague is spread by the invasive American signal crayfish, a\nnon-native species which is taking over UK waterways and wiping out our\nsmaller native species.\n\nThe South West Crayfish Project is currently running the largest strategic\ntranslocation in the UK to date, re-homing at-risk populations of\nwhite-clawed crayfish to new safe sites. In addition, a breeding programme\nfor the crayfish is being developed at Bristol Zoo Gardens, the sister\norganisation to the Bristol Conservation and Science Foundation (BCSF).\n\nMaddy Rees, UK conservation officer for the Bristol Conservation and\nScience Foundation, said: \"The plague can be carried on anything that gets\nwet in infected water, so we are urging people to wash, dry and, if\npossible, disinfect footwear, fishing tackle, nets and other equipment that\ngets damp in our rivers and lakes. Never trap for any species of crayfish\nwithout a trapping licence, as it is illegal, and finally, never move wild\nfish between waterways; always use a reputable stockist.\"\n\nThe survival of white-clawed crayfish will be the focus of a conference\nheld at Bristol Zoo Gardens later this year [2010]. The event, called\n\"Species survival: Securing white-clawed crayfish in a changing\nenvironment\" will take place on 16 and 17 Nov 2010. It will include a range\nof lectures from speakers from across Europe and presentations from experts\nin the field of UK crayfish conservation.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The aetiological agent of crayfish plague is _Aphanomyces astaci_, a\nmember of a group of organisms commonly known as the water moulds. Although\nlong regarded to be fungi, this group, the Oomycetida, are now considered\nprotists and are classified with diatoms and brown algae in a group called\nthe Stramenopiles or Chromista.\n\nThere is evidence that established older _A. astaci_ strains that have been\npresent in Europe for many years are less aggressive than newer strains\nintroduced with crayfish imports from North America since the 1960s. Some\nisolates from warmer waters in Spain have temperature/growth curves with\nhigher optimum temperatures compared with those from northern Europe.\n\nAlthough _A. astaci_ is not an obligate parasite and will grow well under\nlaboratory conditions on artificial media, in the natural environment it\ndoes not survive well for long periods in the absence of a suitable host.\nIt has been shown that _A. astaci_ cysts survive for 2 weeks in distilled\nwater, and that zoospores remained motile for up to 3 days. As _A. astaci_\ncan go through 3 cycles of zoospore emergence, the maximum life span\noutside of a host could be several weeks.\n\n_A. astaci_, both in culture and in infected crayfish, is killed by a short\nexposure to temperatures of 60 C (140 F) or to temperatures of -20 C (-4 F)\nor less for 48 hours or more. Sodium hypochlorite and iodophores are\neffective for disinfection of contaminated equipment. Thorough drying of\nequipment (more than 24 hours) is also effective, as _Aphanomyces_ is not\nresistant to desiccation.\n\nThere is good field and experimental evidence that movements of fish from\nareas in which crayfish plague is active can transmit infection from one\nwatershed to another. _A. astaci_ can also be spread by contaminated\nequipment (nets, boots, clothing, etc).\n\nThe information above is derived from chapter 2.3.7. \"Crayfish Plague\n(_Aphanomyces astaci_)\" in OIE's (World Organisation for Animal Health)\nManual of Diagnostic Tests for Aquatic animals. The chapter includes\nadditional comprehensive information on the agent factors, host factors,\ndisease pattern, diagnosis, control and prevention, etc; see\n<http://oie.int/eng/normes/fmanual/2.2.01_CRAYFISH.pdf>. - Mod.AS\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United Kingdom can be\naccessed at <http://healthmap.org/promed?v=54.5,-2,5>. - Mod.SH]\nSee Also\n2008\n---\nCrayfish plague - UK: (England) 20080808.2444\n2007\n---\nCrayfish plague - UK (England) 20071023.3447\n\n..................sb/arn/msp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nDonate to ProMED-mail. Details available at:\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Donations.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org (NOT to\nan individual moderator). If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chromista", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "658689", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Madagascar (02): (AS) Institut Pasteur report", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=658689", "date": "2010-11-08 18:00:04", "main_text": "CRAYFISH PLAGUE - UK: ENGLAND\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 8 Nov 2010\nSource: BristolZooUK [accessed 8 Nov 2010, summarised, edited]\n<http://www.bristolzoo.org.uk/conservationists-highlight-worsening-plight-of-uk-crayfish?theme=orange>\n\n\nBristol conservationists are highlighting the worsening plight of native\ncrayfish as the species is officially upgraded to \"endangered\".\nWhite-clawed crayfish are the UK's only native freshwater crayfish, but\ntheir numbers have suffered extensive decline in recent years. Experts warn\nthe species could become extinct from the UK within the next 30 years; it\nis currently a protected species.\n\nToday, white-clawed crayfish have been upgraded from \"vulnerable\" to\n\"endangered\" on the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN)\nRed List of Threatened Species, following a Sampled Red List Index (SRLI)\nassessment by the Zoological Society of London (ZSL). The ranking gives an\nindication of how likely a species is to become extinct.\n\nEve Leegwater, technical biodiversity officer at the Environment Agency,\nsaid: \"It is important to base conservation efforts on scientific research,\nand the IUCN Red List has become an increasingly important tool to guide\ngovernment and scientific institutes towards the conservation and\nlegislation of species and habitats at risk of extinction.\" She added: \"The\nchange in status of white-clawed crayfish will help stress the need for\nconservation strategies to be implemented to aid this valuable species.\"\n\nUp to 70 per cent of white-clawed crayfish have been lost from the south\nwest, and some parts of the UK have lost their entire populations. This is\npredominantly due to the crayfish plague, a fungus-like disease which is\nharmless to people and most animals but lethal to white-clawed crayfish.\nThe crayfish plague is spread by the invasive American signal crayfish, a\nnon-native species which is taking over UK waterways and wiping out our\nsmaller native species.\n\nThe South West Crayfish Project is currently running the largest strategic\ntranslocation in the UK to date, re-homing at-risk populations of\nwhite-clawed crayfish to new safe sites. In addition, a breeding programme\nfor the crayfish is being developed at Bristol Zoo Gardens, the sister\norganisation to the Bristol Conservation and Science Foundation (BCSF).\n\nMaddy Rees, UK conservation officer for the Bristol Conservation and\nScience Foundation, said: \"The plague can be carried on anything that gets\nwet in infected water, so we are urging people to wash, dry and, if\npossible, disinfect footwear, fishing tackle, nets and other equipment that\ngets damp in our rivers and lakes. Never trap for any species of crayfish\nwithout a trapping licence, as it is illegal, and finally, never move wild\nfish between waterways; always use a reputable stockist.\"\n\nThe survival of white-clawed crayfish will be the focus of a conference\nheld at Bristol Zoo Gardens later this year [2010]. The event, called\n\"Species survival: Securing white-clawed crayfish in a changing\nenvironment\" will take place on 16 and 17 Nov 2010. It will include a range\nof lectures from speakers from across Europe and presentations from experts\nin the field of UK crayfish conservation.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The aetiological agent of crayfish plague is _Aphanomyces astaci_, a\nmember of a group of organisms commonly known as the water moulds. Although\nlong regarded to be fungi, this group, the Oomycetida, are now considered\nprotists and are classified with diatoms and brown algae in a group called\nthe Stramenopiles or Chromista.\n\nThere is evidence that established older _A. astaci_ strains that have been\npresent in Europe for many years are less aggressive than newer strains\nintroduced with crayfish imports from North America since the 1960s. Some\nisolates from warmer waters in Spain have temperature/growth curves with\nhigher optimum temperatures compared with those from northern Europe.\n\nAlthough _A. astaci_ is not an obligate parasite and will grow well under\nlaboratory conditions on artificial media, in the natural environment it\ndoes not survive well for long periods in the absence of a suitable host.\nIt has been shown that _A. astaci_ cysts survive for 2 weeks in distilled\nwater, and that zoospores remained motile for up to 3 days. As _A. astaci_\ncan go through 3 cycles of zoospore emergence, the maximum life span\noutside of a host could be several weeks.\n\n_A. astaci_, both in culture and in infected crayfish, is killed by a short\nexposure to temperatures of 60 C (140 F) or to temperatures of -20 C (-4 F)\nor less for 48 hours or more. Sodium hypochlorite and iodophores are\neffective for disinfection of contaminated equipment. Thorough drying of\nequipment (more than 24 hours) is also effective, as _Aphanomyces_ is not\nresistant to desiccation.\n\nThere is good field and experimental evidence that movements of fish from\nareas in which crayfish plague is active can transmit infection from one\nwatershed to another. _A. astaci_ can also be spread by contaminated\nequipment (nets, boots, clothing, etc).\n\nThe information above is derived from chapter 2.3.7. \"Crayfish Plague\n(_Aphanomyces astaci_)\" in OIE's (World Organisation for Animal Health)\nManual of Diagnostic Tests for Aquatic animals. The chapter includes\nadditional comprehensive information on the agent factors, host factors,\ndisease pattern, diagnosis, control and prevention, etc; see\n<http://oie.int/eng/normes/fmanual/2.2.01_CRAYFISH.pdf>. - Mod.AS\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United Kingdom can be\naccessed at <http://healthmap.org/promed?v=54.5,-2,5>. - Mod.SH]\nSee Also\n2008\n---\nCrayfish plague - UK: (England) 20080808.2444\n2007\n---\nCrayfish plague - UK (England) 20071023.3447\n\n..................sb/arn/msp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chromista", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "658019", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Madagascar: (Antsiranana) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=658019", "date": "2010-11-08 18:00:04", "main_text": "CRAYFISH PLAGUE - UK: ENGLAND\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 8 Nov 2010\nSource: BristolZooUK [accessed 8 Nov 2010, summarised, edited]\n<http://www.bristolzoo.org.uk/conservationists-highlight-worsening-plight-of-uk-crayfish?theme=orange>\n\n\nBristol conservationists are highlighting the worsening plight of native\ncrayfish as the species is officially upgraded to \"endangered\".\nWhite-clawed crayfish are the UK's only native freshwater crayfish, but\ntheir numbers have suffered extensive decline in recent years. Experts warn\nthe species could become extinct from the UK within the next 30 years; it\nis currently a protected species.\n\nToday, white-clawed crayfish have been upgraded from \"vulnerable\" to\n\"endangered\" on the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN)\nRed List of Threatened Species, following a Sampled Red List Index (SRLI)\nassessment by the Zoological Society of London (ZSL). The ranking gives an\nindication of how likely a species is to become extinct.\n\nEve Leegwater, technical biodiversity officer at the Environment Agency,\nsaid: \"It is important to base conservation efforts on scientific research,\nand the IUCN Red List has become an increasingly important tool to guide\ngovernment and scientific institutes towards the conservation and\nlegislation of species and habitats at risk of extinction.\" She added: \"The\nchange in status of white-clawed crayfish will help stress the need for\nconservation strategies to be implemented to aid this valuable species.\"\n\nUp to 70 per cent of white-clawed crayfish have been lost from the south\nwest, and some parts of the UK have lost their entire populations. This is\npredominantly due to the crayfish plague, a fungus-like disease which is\nharmless to people and most animals but lethal to white-clawed crayfish.\nThe crayfish plague is spread by the invasive American signal crayfish, a\nnon-native species which is taking over UK waterways and wiping out our\nsmaller native species.\n\nThe South West Crayfish Project is currently running the largest strategic\ntranslocation in the UK to date, re-homing at-risk populations of\nwhite-clawed crayfish to new safe sites. In addition, a breeding programme\nfor the crayfish is being developed at Bristol Zoo Gardens, the sister\norganisation to the Bristol Conservation and Science Foundation (BCSF).\n\nMaddy Rees, UK conservation officer for the Bristol Conservation and\nScience Foundation, said: \"The plague can be carried on anything that gets\nwet in infected water, so we are urging people to wash, dry and, if\npossible, disinfect footwear, fishing tackle, nets and other equipment that\ngets damp in our rivers and lakes. Never trap for any species of crayfish\nwithout a trapping licence, as it is illegal, and finally, never move wild\nfish between waterways; always use a reputable stockist.\"\n\nThe survival of white-clawed crayfish will be the focus of a conference\nheld at Bristol Zoo Gardens later this year [2010]. The event, called\n\"Species survival: Securing white-clawed crayfish in a changing\nenvironment\" will take place on 16 and 17 Nov 2010. It will include a range\nof lectures from speakers from across Europe and presentations from experts\nin the field of UK crayfish conservation.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The aetiological agent of crayfish plague is _Aphanomyces astaci_, a\nmember of a group of organisms commonly known as the water moulds. Although\nlong regarded to be fungi, this group, the Oomycetida, are now considered\nprotists and are classified with diatoms and brown algae in a group called\nthe Stramenopiles or Chromista.\n\nThere is evidence that established older _A. astaci_ strains that have been\npresent in Europe for many years are less aggressive than newer strains\nintroduced with crayfish imports from North America since the 1960s. Some\nisolates from warmer waters in Spain have temperature/growth curves with\nhigher optimum temperatures compared with those from northern Europe.\n\nAlthough _A. astaci_ is not an obligate parasite and will grow well under\nlaboratory conditions on artificial media, in the natural environment it\ndoes not survive well for long periods in the absence of a suitable host.\nIt has been shown that _A. astaci_ cysts survive for 2 weeks in distilled\nwater, and that zoospores remained motile for up to 3 days. As _A. astaci_\ncan go through 3 cycles of zoospore emergence, the maximum life span\noutside of a host could be several weeks.\n\n_A. astaci_, both in culture and in infected crayfish, is killed by a short\nexposure to temperatures of 60 C (140 F) or to temperatures of -20 C (-4 F)\nor less for 48 hours or more. Sodium hypochlorite and iodophores are\neffective for disinfection of contaminated equipment. Thorough drying of\nequipment (more than 24 hours) is also effective, as _Aphanomyces_ is not\nresistant to desiccation.\n\nThere is good field and experimental evidence that movements of fish from\nareas in which crayfish plague is active can transmit infection from one\nwatershed to another. _A. astaci_ can also be spread by contaminated\nequipment (nets, boots, clothing, etc).\n\nThe information above is derived from chapter 2.3.7. \"Crayfish Plague\n(_Aphanomyces astaci_)\" in OIE's (World Organisation for Animal Health)\nManual of Diagnostic Tests for Aquatic animals. The chapter includes\nadditional comprehensive information on the agent factors, host factors,\ndisease pattern, diagnosis, control and prevention, etc; see\n<http://oie.int/eng/normes/fmanual/2.2.01_CRAYFISH.pdf>. - Mod.AS\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United Kingdom can be\naccessed at <http://healthmap.org/promed?v=54.5,-2,5>. - Mod.SH]\nSee Also\n2008\n---\nCrayfish plague - UK: (England) 20080808.2444\n2007\n---\nCrayfish plague - UK (England) 20071023.3447\n\n..................sb/arn/msp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chromista", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "623557", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, pneumonic, 2009 - China: (QH) follow up", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=623557", "date": "2010-11-08 18:00:04", "main_text": "CRAYFISH PLAGUE - UK: ENGLAND\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 8 Nov 2010\nSource: BristolZooUK [accessed 8 Nov 2010, summarised, edited]\n<http://www.bristolzoo.org.uk/conservationists-highlight-worsening-plight-of-uk-crayfish?theme=orange>\n\n\nBristol conservationists are highlighting the worsening plight of native\ncrayfish as the species is officially upgraded to \"endangered\".\nWhite-clawed crayfish are the UK's only native freshwater crayfish, but\ntheir numbers have suffered extensive decline in recent years. Experts warn\nthe species could become extinct from the UK within the next 30 years; it\nis currently a protected species.\n\nToday, white-clawed crayfish have been upgraded from \"vulnerable\" to\n\"endangered\" on the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN)\nRed List of Threatened Species, following a Sampled Red List Index (SRLI)\nassessment by the Zoological Society of London (ZSL). The ranking gives an\nindication of how likely a species is to become extinct.\n\nEve Leegwater, technical biodiversity officer at the Environment Agency,\nsaid: \"It is important to base conservation efforts on scientific research,\nand the IUCN Red List has become an increasingly important tool to guide\ngovernment and scientific institutes towards the conservation and\nlegislation of species and habitats at risk of extinction.\" She added: \"The\nchange in status of white-clawed crayfish will help stress the need for\nconservation strategies to be implemented to aid this valuable species.\"\n\nUp to 70 per cent of white-clawed crayfish have been lost from the south\nwest, and some parts of the UK have lost their entire populations. This is\npredominantly due to the crayfish plague, a fungus-like disease which is\nharmless to people and most animals but lethal to white-clawed crayfish.\nThe crayfish plague is spread by the invasive American signal crayfish, a\nnon-native species which is taking over UK waterways and wiping out our\nsmaller native species.\n\nThe South West Crayfish Project is currently running the largest strategic\ntranslocation in the UK to date, re-homing at-risk populations of\nwhite-clawed crayfish to new safe sites. In addition, a breeding programme\nfor the crayfish is being developed at Bristol Zoo Gardens, the sister\norganisation to the Bristol Conservation and Science Foundation (BCSF).\n\nMaddy Rees, UK conservation officer for the Bristol Conservation and\nScience Foundation, said: \"The plague can be carried on anything that gets\nwet in infected water, so we are urging people to wash, dry and, if\npossible, disinfect footwear, fishing tackle, nets and other equipment that\ngets damp in our rivers and lakes. Never trap for any species of crayfish\nwithout a trapping licence, as it is illegal, and finally, never move wild\nfish between waterways; always use a reputable stockist.\"\n\nThe survival of white-clawed crayfish will be the focus of a conference\nheld at Bristol Zoo Gardens later this year [2010]. The event, called\n\"Species survival: Securing white-clawed crayfish in a changing\nenvironment\" will take place on 16 and 17 Nov 2010. It will include a range\nof lectures from speakers from across Europe and presentations from experts\nin the field of UK crayfish conservation.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The aetiological agent of crayfish plague is _Aphanomyces astaci_, a\nmember of a group of organisms commonly known as the water moulds. Although\nlong regarded to be fungi, this group, the Oomycetida, are now considered\nprotists and are classified with diatoms and brown algae in a group called\nthe Stramenopiles or Chromista.\n\nThere is evidence that established older _A. astaci_ strains that have been\npresent in Europe for many years are less aggressive than newer strains\nintroduced with crayfish imports from North America since the 1960s. Some\nisolates from warmer waters in Spain have temperature/growth curves with\nhigher optimum temperatures compared with those from northern Europe.\n\nAlthough _A. astaci_ is not an obligate parasite and will grow well under\nlaboratory conditions on artificial media, in the natural environment it\ndoes not survive well for long periods in the absence of a suitable host.\nIt has been shown that _A. astaci_ cysts survive for 2 weeks in distilled\nwater, and that zoospores remained motile for up to 3 days. As _A. astaci_\ncan go through 3 cycles of zoospore emergence, the maximum life span\noutside of a host could be several weeks.\n\n_A. astaci_, both in culture and in infected crayfish, is killed by a short\nexposure to temperatures of 60 C (140 F) or to temperatures of -20 C (-4 F)\nor less for 48 hours or more. Sodium hypochlorite and iodophores are\neffective for disinfection of contaminated equipment. Thorough drying of\nequipment (more than 24 hours) is also effective, as _Aphanomyces_ is not\nresistant to desiccation.\n\nThere is good field and experimental evidence that movements of fish from\nareas in which crayfish plague is active can transmit infection from one\nwatershed to another. _A. astaci_ can also be spread by contaminated\nequipment (nets, boots, clothing, etc).\n\nThe information above is derived from chapter 2.3.7. \"Crayfish Plague\n(_Aphanomyces astaci_)\" in OIE's (World Organisation for Animal Health)\nManual of Diagnostic Tests for Aquatic animals. The chapter includes\nadditional comprehensive information on the agent factors, host factors,\ndisease pattern, diagnosis, control and prevention, etc; see\n<http://oie.int/eng/normes/fmanual/2.2.01_CRAYFISH.pdf>. - Mod.AS\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United Kingdom can be\naccessed at <http://healthmap.org/promed?v=54.5,-2,5>. - Mod.SH]\nSee Also\n2008\n---\nCrayfish plague - UK: (England) 20080808.2444\n2007\n---\nCrayfish plague - UK (England) 20071023.3447\n\n..................sb/arn/msp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Experts warn\nthe species could become extinct from the UK within the next 30 years; it\nis currently a protected species.\n\nToday, white-clawed crayfish have been upgraded from \"vulnerable\" to\n\"endangered\" on the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN)\nRed List of Threatened Species, following a Sampled Red List Index (SRLI)\nassessment by the Zoological Society of London (ZSL). In addition, a breeding programme\nfor the crayfish is being developed at Bristol Zoo Gardens, the sister\norganisation to the Bristol Conservation and Science Foundation (BCSF).\n\nMaddy Rees, UK conservation officer for the Bristol Conservation and\nScience Foundation, said: \"The plague can be carried on anything that gets\nwet in infected water, so we are urging people to wash, dry and, if\npossible, disinfect footwear, fishing tackle, nets and other equipment that\ngets damp in our rivers and lakes. Never trap for any species of crayfish\nwithout a trapping licence, as it is illegal, and finally, never move wild\nfish between waterways; always use a reputable stockist.\"\n\nThe survival of white-clawed crayfish will be the focus of a conference\nheld at Bristol Zoo Gardens later this year [2010]. The event, called\n\"Species survival: Securing white-clawed crayfish in a changing\nenvironment\" will take place on 16 and 17 Nov 2010. It will include a range\nof lectures from speakers from across Europe and presentations from experts\nin the field of UK crayfish conservation.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The aetiological agent of crayfish plague is _Aphanomyces astaci_, a\nmember of a group of organisms commonly known as the water moulds. Although\nlong regarded to be fungi, this group, the Oomycetida, are now considered\nprotists and are classified with diatoms and brown algae in a group called\nthe Stramenopiles or Chromista.\n\nThere is evidence that established older _A. astaci_ strains that have been\npresent in Europe for many years are less aggressive than newer strains\nintroduced with crayfish imports from North America since the 1960s. Some\nisolates from warmer waters in Spain have temperature/growth curves with\nhigher optimum temperatures compared with those from northern Europe.\n\nAlthough _A. astaci_ is not an obligate parasite and will grow well under\nlaboratory conditions on artificial media, in the natural environment it\ndoes not survive well for long periods in the absence of a suitable host.\nIt has been shown that _A. astaci_ cysts survive for 2 weeks in distilled\nwater, and that zoospores remained motile for up to 3 days. As _A. astaci_\ncan go through 3 cycles of zoospore emergence, the maximum life span\noutside of a host could be several weeks.\n\n_A. astaci_, both in culture and in infected crayfish, is killed by a short\nexposure to temperatures of 60 C (140 F) or to temperatures of -20 C (-4 F)\nor less for 48 hours or more. Sodium hypochlorite and iodophores are\neffective for disinfection of contaminated equipment. Thorough drying of\nequipment (more than 24 hours) is also effective, as _Aphanomyces_ is not\nresistant to desiccation.\n\nThere is good field and experimental evidence that movements of fish from\nareas in which crayfish plague is active can transmit infection from one\nwatershed to another. _A. astaci_ can also be spread by contaminated\nequipment (nets, boots, clothing, etc).\n\nThe information above is derived from chapter 2.3.7. \"Crayfish Plague\n(_Aphanomyces astaci_)\" in OIE's (World Organisation for Animal Health)\nManual of Diagnostic Tests for Aquatic animals.
