Experts warn\nthe species could become extinct from the UK within the next 30 years; it\nis currently a protected species.\n\nToday, white-clawed crayfish have been upgraded from \"vulnerable\" to\n\"endangered\" on the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN)\nRed List of Threatened Species, following a Sampled Red List Index (SRLI)\nassessment by the Zoological Society of London (ZSL). The ranking gives an\nindication of how likely a species is to become extinct.\n\nEve Leegwater, technical biodiversity officer at the Environment Agency,\nsaid: \"It is important to base conservation efforts on scientific research,\nand the IUCN Red List has become an increasingly important tool to guide\ngovernment and scientific institutes towards the conservation and\nlegislation of species and habitats at risk of extinction.\" She added: \"The\nchange in status of white-clawed crayfish will help stress the need for\nconservation strategies to be implemented to aid this valuable species.\"\n\nUp to 70 per cent of white-clawed crayfish have been lost from the south\nwest, and some parts of the UK have lost their entire populations. This is\npredominantly due to the crayfish plague, a fungus-like disease which is\nharmless to people and most animals but lethal to white-clawed crayfish.\nThe crayfish plague is spread by the invasive American signal crayfish, a\nnon-native species which is taking over UK waterways and wiping out our\nsmaller native species.\n\nThe South West Crayfish Project is currently running the largest strategic\ntranslocation in the UK to date, re-homing at-risk populations of\nwhite-clawed crayfish to new safe sites. In addition, a breeding programme\nfor the crayfish is being developed at Bristol Zoo Gardens, the sister\norganisation to the Bristol Conservation and Science Foundation (BCSF).\n\nMaddy Rees, UK conservation officer for the Bristol Conservation and\nScience Foundation, said: \"The plague can be carried on anything that gets\nwet in infected water, so we are urging people to wash, dry and, if\npossible, disinfect footwear, fishing tackle, nets and other equipment that\ngets damp in our rivers and lakes. Never trap for any species of crayfish\nwithout a trapping licence, as it is illegal, and finally, never move wild\nfish between waterways; always use a reputable stockist.\"\n\nThe survival of white-clawed crayfish will be the focus of a conference\nheld at Bristol Zoo Gardens later this year [2010]. The event, called\n\"Species survival: Securing white-clawed crayfish in a changing\nenvironment\" will take place on 16 and 17 Nov 2010. It will include a range\nof lectures from speakers from across Europe and presentations from experts\nin the field of UK crayfish conservation.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The aetiological agent of crayfish plague is _Aphanomyces astaci_, a\nmember of a group of organisms commonly known as the water moulds. Although\nlong regarded to be fungi, this group, the Oomycetida, are now considered\nprotists and are classified with diatoms and brown algae in a group called\nthe Stramenopiles or Chromista.\n\nThere is evidence that established older _A. astaci_ strains that have been\npresent in Europe for many years are less aggressive than newer strains\nintroduced with crayfish imports from North America since the 1960s. Some\nisolates from warmer waters in Spain have temperature/growth curves with\nhigher optimum temperatures compared with those from northern Europe.\n\nAlthough _A. astaci_ is not an obligate parasite and will grow well under\nlaboratory conditions on artificial media, in the natural environment it\ndoes not survive well for long periods in the absence of a suitable host.\nIt has been shown that _A. astaci_ cysts survive for 2 weeks in distilled\nwater, and that zoospores remained motile for up to 3 days. As _A. astaci_\ncan go through 3 cycles of zoospore emergence, the maximum life span\noutside of a host could be several weeks.\n\n_A. astaci_, both in culture and in infected crayfish, is killed by a short\nexposure to temperatures of 60 C (140 F) or to temperatures of -20 C (-4 F)\nor less for 48 hours or more. Sodium hypochlorite and iodophores are\neffective for disinfection of contaminated equipment. Thorough drying of\nequipment (more than 24 hours) is also effective, as _Aphanomyces_ is not\nresistant to desiccation.\n\nThere is good field and experimental evidence that movements of fish from\nareas in which crayfish plague is active can transmit infection from one\nwatershed to another. _A. astaci_ can also be spread by contaminated\nequipment (nets, boots, clothing, etc).\n\nThe information above is derived from chapter 2.3.7. \"Crayfish Plague\n(_Aphanomyces astaci_)\" in OIE's (World Organisation for Animal Health)\nManual of Diagnostic Tests for Aquatic animals. The chapter includes\nadditional comprehensive information on the agent factors, host factors,\ndisease pattern, diagnosis, control and prevention, etc; see\n<http://oie.int/eng/normes/fmanual/2.2.01_CRAYFISH.pdf>. - Mod.AS\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United Kingdom can be\naccessed at <http://healthmap.org/promed?v=54.5,-2,5>. - Mod.SH]\nSee Also\n2008\n---\nCrayfish plague - UK: (England) 20080808.2444\n2007\n---\nCrayfish plague - UK (England) 20071023.3447\n\n..................sb/arn/msp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. Details available at:\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Donations.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org (NOT to\nan individual moderator). If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chromista", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "590449", "headline": "PRO/AH> Crayfish plague - Italy: (VN) OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=590449", "date": "2010-11-08 18:00:04", "main_text": "CRAYFISH PLAGUE - UK: ENGLAND\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 8 Nov 2010\nSource: BristolZooUK [accessed 8 Nov 2010, summarised, edited]\n<http://www.bristolzoo.org.uk/conservationists-highlight-worsening-plight-of-uk-crayfish?theme=orange>\n\n\nBristol conservationists are highlighting the worsening plight of native\ncrayfish as the species is officially upgraded to \"endangered\".\nWhite-clawed crayfish are the UK's only native freshwater crayfish, but\ntheir numbers have suffered extensive decline in recent years. Experts warn\nthe species could become extinct from the UK within the next 30 years; it\nis currently a protected species.\n\nToday, white-clawed crayfish have been upgraded from \"vulnerable\" to\n\"endangered\" on the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN)\nRed List of Threatened Species, following a Sampled Red List Index (SRLI)\nassessment by the Zoological Society of London (ZSL). The ranking gives an\nindication of how likely a species is to become extinct.\n\nEve Leegwater, technical biodiversity officer at the Environment Agency,\nsaid: \"It is important to base conservation efforts on scientific research,\nand the IUCN Red List has become an increasingly important tool to guide\ngovernment and scientific institutes towards the conservation and\nlegislation of species and habitats at risk of extinction.\" She added: \"The\nchange in status of white-clawed crayfish will help stress the need for\nconservation strategies to be implemented to aid this valuable species.\"\n\nUp to 70 per cent of white-clawed crayfish have been lost from the south\nwest, and some parts of the UK have lost their entire populations. This is\npredominantly due to the crayfish plague, a fungus-like disease which is\nharmless to people and most animals but lethal to white-clawed crayfish.\nThe crayfish plague is spread by the invasive American signal crayfish, a\nnon-native species which is taking over UK waterways and wiping out our\nsmaller native species.\n\nThe South West Crayfish Project is currently running the largest strategic\ntranslocation in the UK to date, re-homing at-risk populations of\nwhite-clawed crayfish to new safe sites. In addition, a breeding programme\nfor the crayfish is being developed at Bristol Zoo Gardens, the sister\norganisation to the Bristol Conservation and Science Foundation (BCSF).\n\nMaddy Rees, UK conservation officer for the Bristol Conservation and\nScience Foundation, said: \"The plague can be carried on anything that gets\nwet in infected water, so we are urging people to wash, dry and, if\npossible, disinfect footwear, fishing tackle, nets and other equipment that\ngets damp in our rivers and lakes. Never trap for any species of crayfish\nwithout a trapping licence, as it is illegal, and finally, never move wild\nfish between waterways; always use a reputable stockist.\"\n\nThe survival of white-clawed crayfish will be the focus of a conference\nheld at Bristol Zoo Gardens later this year [2010]. The event, called\n\"Species survival: Securing white-clawed crayfish in a changing\nenvironment\" will take place on 16 and 17 Nov 2010. It will include a range\nof lectures from speakers from across Europe and presentations from experts\nin the field of UK crayfish conservation.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The aetiological agent of crayfish plague is _Aphanomyces astaci_, a\nmember of a group of organisms commonly known as the water moulds. Although\nlong regarded to be fungi, this group, the Oomycetida, are now considered\nprotists and are classified with diatoms and brown algae in a group called\nthe Stramenopiles or Chromista.\n\nThere is evidence that established older _A. astaci_ strains that have been\npresent in Europe for many years are less aggressive than newer strains\nintroduced with crayfish imports from North America since the 1960s. Some\nisolates from warmer waters in Spain have temperature/growth curves with\nhigher optimum temperatures compared with those from northern Europe.\n\nAlthough _A. astaci_ is not an obligate parasite and will grow well under\nlaboratory conditions on artificial media, in the natural environment it\ndoes not survive well for long periods in the absence of a suitable host.\nIt has been shown that _A. astaci_ cysts survive for 2 weeks in distilled\nwater, and that zoospores remained motile for up to 3 days. As _A. astaci_\ncan go through 3 cycles of zoospore emergence, the maximum life span\noutside of a host could be several weeks.\n\n_A. astaci_, both in culture and in infected crayfish, is killed by a short\nexposure to temperatures of 60 C (140 F) or to temperatures of -20 C (-4 F)\nor less for 48 hours or more. Sodium hypochlorite and iodophores are\neffective for disinfection of contaminated equipment. Thorough drying of\nequipment (more than 24 hours) is also effective, as _Aphanomyces_ is not\nresistant to desiccation.\n\nThere is good field and experimental evidence that movements of fish from\nareas in which crayfish plague is active can transmit infection from one\nwatershed to another. _A. astaci_ can also be spread by contaminated\nequipment (nets, boots, clothing, etc).\n\nThe information above is derived from chapter 2.3.7. \"Crayfish Plague\n(_Aphanomyces astaci_)\" in OIE's (World Organisation for Animal Health)\nManual of Diagnostic Tests for Aquatic animals. The chapter includes\nadditional comprehensive information on the agent factors, host factors,\ndisease pattern, diagnosis, control and prevention, etc; see\n<http://oie.int/eng/normes/fmanual/2.2.01_CRAYFISH.pdf>. - Mod.AS\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United Kingdom can be\naccessed at <http://healthmap.org/promed?v=54.5,-2,5>. - Mod.SH]\nSee Also\n2008\n---\nCrayfish plague - UK: (England) 20080808.2444\n2007\n---\nCrayfish plague - UK (England) 20071023.3447\n\n..................sb/arn/msp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chromista", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "573415", "headline": "PRO/AH> Crayfish plague - UK: England", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=573415", "date": "2010-11-08 18:00:04", "main_text": "CRAYFISH PLAGUE - UK: ENGLAND\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 8 Nov 2010\nSource: BristolZooUK [accessed 8 Nov 2010, summarised, edited]\n<http://www.bristolzoo.org.uk/conservationists-highlight-worsening-plight-of-uk-crayfish?theme=orange>\n\n\nBristol conservationists are highlighting the worsening plight of native\ncrayfish as the species is officially upgraded to \"endangered\".\nWhite-clawed crayfish are the UK's only native freshwater crayfish, but\ntheir numbers have suffered extensive decline in recent years. Experts warn\nthe species could become extinct from the UK within the next 30 years; it\nis currently a protected species.\n\nToday, white-clawed crayfish have been upgraded from \"vulnerable\" to\n\"endangered\" on the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN)\nRed List of Threatened Species, following a Sampled Red List Index (SRLI)\nassessment by the Zoological Society of London (ZSL). The ranking gives an\nindication of how likely a species is to become extinct.\n\nEve Leegwater, technical biodiversity officer at the Environment Agency,\nsaid: \"It is important to base conservation efforts on scientific research,\nand the IUCN Red List has become an increasingly important tool to guide\ngovernment and scientific institutes towards the conservation and\nlegislation of species and habitats at risk of extinction.\" She added: \"The\nchange in status of white-clawed crayfish will help stress the need for\nconservation strategies to be implemented to aid this valuable species.\"\n\nUp to 70 per cent of white-clawed crayfish have been lost from the south\nwest, and some parts of the UK have lost their entire populations. This is\npredominantly due to the crayfish plague, a fungus-like disease which is\nharmless to people and most animals but lethal to white-clawed crayfish.\nThe crayfish plague is spread by the invasive American signal crayfish, a\nnon-native species which is taking over UK waterways and wiping out our\nsmaller native species.\n\nThe South West Crayfish Project is currently running the largest strategic\ntranslocation in the UK to date, re-homing at-risk populations of\nwhite-clawed crayfish to new safe sites. In addition, a breeding programme\nfor the crayfish is being developed at Bristol Zoo Gardens, the sister\norganisation to the Bristol Conservation and Science Foundation (BCSF).\n\nMaddy Rees, UK conservation officer for the Bristol Conservation and\nScience Foundation, said: \"The plague can be carried on anything that gets\nwet in infected water, so we are urging people to wash, dry and, if\npossible, disinfect footwear, fishing tackle, nets and other equipment that\ngets damp in our rivers and lakes. Never trap for any species of crayfish\nwithout a trapping licence, as it is illegal, and finally, never move wild\nfish between waterways; always use a reputable stockist.\"\n\nThe survival of white-clawed crayfish will be the focus of a conference\nheld at Bristol Zoo Gardens later this year [2010]. The event, called\n\"Species survival: Securing white-clawed crayfish in a changing\nenvironment\" will take place on 16 and 17 Nov 2010. It will include a range\nof lectures from speakers from across Europe and presentations from experts\nin the field of UK crayfish conservation.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The aetiological agent of crayfish plague is _Aphanomyces astaci_, a\nmember of a group of organisms commonly known as the water moulds. Although\nlong regarded to be fungi, this group, the Oomycetida, are now considered\nprotists and are classified with diatoms and brown algae in a group called\nthe Stramenopiles or Chromista.\n\nThere is evidence that established older _A. astaci_ strains that have been\npresent in Europe for many years are less aggressive than newer strains\nintroduced with crayfish imports from North America since the 1960s. Some\nisolates from warmer waters in Spain have temperature/growth curves with\nhigher optimum temperatures compared with those from northern Europe.\n\nAlthough _A. astaci_ is not an obligate parasite and will grow well under\nlaboratory conditions on artificial media, in the natural environment it\ndoes not survive well for long periods in the absence of a suitable host.\nIt has been shown that _A. astaci_ cysts survive for 2 weeks in distilled\nwater, and that zoospores remained motile for up to 3 days. As _A. astaci_\ncan go through 3 cycles of zoospore emergence, the maximum life span\noutside of a host could be several weeks.\n\n_A. astaci_, both in culture and in infected crayfish, is killed by a short\nexposure to temperatures of 60 C (140 F) or to temperatures of -20 C (-4 F)\nor less for 48 hours or more. Sodium hypochlorite and iodophores are\neffective for disinfection of contaminated equipment. Thorough drying of\nequipment (more than 24 hours) is also effective, as _Aphanomyces_ is not\nresistant to desiccation.\n\nThere is good field and experimental evidence that movements of fish from\nareas in which crayfish plague is active can transmit infection from one\nwatershed to another. _A. astaci_ can also be spread by contaminated\nequipment (nets, boots, clothing, etc).\n\nThe information above is derived from chapter 2.3.7. \"Crayfish Plague\n(_Aphanomyces astaci_)\" in OIE's (World Organisation for Animal Health)\nManual of Diagnostic Tests for Aquatic animals. The chapter includes\nadditional comprehensive information on the agent factors, host factors,\ndisease pattern, diagnosis, control and prevention, etc; see\n<http://oie.int/eng/normes/fmanual/2.2.01_CRAYFISH.pdf>. - Mod.AS\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United Kingdom can be\naccessed at <http://healthmap.org/promed?v=54.5,-2,5>. - Mod.SH]\nSee Also\n2008\n---\nCrayfish plague - UK: (England) 20080808.2444\n2007\n---\nCrayfish plague - UK (England) 20071023.3447\n\n..................sb/arn/msp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chromista", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "543965", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (03): (OR) bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=543965", "date": "2010-08-07 23:00:17", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FELINE - USA: (MONTANA)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 7 Aug 2010\nSource: West Yellowstone News [edited]\n<http://www.westyellowstonenews.com/articles/2010/08/05/news/news6.txt>\n\n\nPlague reported contracted by area cat\n--------------------------------------\nVeterinarians at White and White Veterinary Hospital in Ennis,\nMontana, have diagnosed the 1st case of plague this summer in an\nindoor/outdoor pet cat. Over the years, veterinarians there have\ndiagnosed numerous cases of plague and tularemia, all in domestic\ncats and in the summer months.\n\nCases have ranged from as far north as Norris to this most recent\ncase in the south, residing at Raynold's Pass.\n\nA diagnosis of plague is confirmed either by growing the culprit\nbacteria from a fine needle aspirate or by demonstrating an increase\nin antibodies in the cat from the onset of the disease, compared to a\nconvalescent blood sample taken 3 to 4 weeks later. An independent\nlab in Colorado confirmed the Raynold's Pass cat did have plague. The\ncat has since made a full recovery.\n\nIndoor/outdoor cats in rural areas that hunt rodents are the most\nlikely to encounter the 2 diseases.\n\nSigns [in animals] include swollen lymph nodes, lethargy, anorexia\nand a high fever.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabites and direct contact with infected animals. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of fleas which, when\ninfected, are carriers. These fleas generally do not infest other\nanimals unless their natural hosts are unavailable.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas.\nThey may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially\ncats, serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea\ntreatments and repellents appropriate for pets and available. Some\nproducts may be suitable for dogs but not cats or may be suitable for\nan adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your\nveterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and\npuppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under\nthe jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front\nleg (the armpit if you will), lethargy, anorexia and fever. Please\ntake your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities in\nyour pet. Veterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves\nwhen examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the\nveterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one\npalpating the swelling.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home\nvia a pet vehicle and can also transmit disease to you, the owner or\ncaretaker of the pet. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nPlague - USA: (CA) ground squirrel 20100708.2275\nPlague, canine - USA: (NM) 20100418.1259\nPlague, cougar - USA (WY) 20100208.0429\n2009\n----\nPlague, feline - USA (CA) 20091205.4150\nPlague, fatal - USA (05): (IL) lab strain susp. RFI 20090921.3320\nPlague, fatal - USA (04): (IL) lab strain susp. RFI 20090920.3298\nPlague, fatal - USA (03): (NM) recovery 20090715.2530\nPlague, tularemia, prairie dogs - USA (SD) 20090712.2494\nPlague, fatal - USA (02): (NM) risk, prevention 20090611.2153\nPlague, fatal - USA: (NM) bubonic 20090605.2080\nPlague, rabbit - USA (NM) 20090415.1435\n2008\n----\nPlague, human, prairie dogs - USA: (AZ) 20081012.3229\nPlague, bubonic - USA: (CT ex WY) 20080827.2672\nPlague, wildlife - USA: (CO) rabbit 20080727.2289\nPlague, prairie dogs, ferrets - USA: (SD) (02) 20080722.2213\nPlague, prairie dog, ferrets - USA: (SD) 20080708.2082\nPlague, feline - USA (WY): mountain lion 20080522.1694\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA: (CO), susp., RFI 20080506.1552\nPlague, human, feline - USA (NM): early season cases 20080127.0340\n....................tg/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "White", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "538786", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - China: (Tibet Autonomous Region)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=538786", "date": "2010-08-07 23:00:17", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FELINE - USA: (MONTANA)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 7 Aug 2010\nSource: West Yellowstone News [edited]\n<http://www.westyellowstonenews.com/articles/2010/08/05/news/news6.txt>\n\n\nPlague reported contracted by area cat\n--------------------------------------\nVeterinarians at White and White Veterinary Hospital in Ennis,\nMontana, have diagnosed the 1st case of plague this summer in an\nindoor/outdoor pet cat. A bubo that ruptures may infect the\nveterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one\npalpating the swelling.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home\nvia a pet vehicle and can also transmit disease to you, the owner or\ncaretaker of the pet. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nPlague - USA: (CA) ground squirrel 20100708.2275\nPlague, canine - USA: (NM) 20100418.1259\nPlague, cougar - USA (WY) 20100208.0429\n2009\n----\nPlague, feline - USA (CA) 20091205.4150\nPlague, fatal - USA (05): (IL) lab strain susp. RFI 20090921.3320\nPlague, fatal - USA (04): (IL) lab strain susp. RFI 20090920.3298\nPlague, fatal - USA (03): (NM) recovery 20090715.2530\nPlague, tularemia, prairie dogs - USA (SD) 20090712.2494\nPlague, fatal - USA (02): (NM) risk, prevention 20090611.2153\nPlague, fatal - USA: (NM) bubonic 20090605.2080\nPlague, rabbit - USA (NM) 20090415.1435\n2008\n----\nPlague, human, prairie dogs - USA: (AZ) 20081012.3229\nPlague, bubonic - USA: (CT ex WY) 20080827.2672\nPlague, wildlife - USA: (CO) rabbit 20080727.2289\nPlague, prairie dogs, ferrets - USA: (SD) (02) 20080722.2213\nPlague, prairie dog, ferrets - USA: (SD) 20080708.2082\nPlague, feline - USA (WY): mountain lion 20080522.1694\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA: (CO), susp., RFI 20080506.1552\nPlague, human, feline - USA (NM): early season cases 20080127.0340\n....................tg/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "White", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "507295", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - South America: Bolivia, Peru, PAHO report", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=507295", "date": "2010-08-07 23:00:17", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FELINE - USA: (MONTANA)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 7 Aug 2010\nSource: West Yellowstone News [edited]\n<http://www.westyellowstonenews.com/articles/2010/08/05/news/news6.txt>\n\n\nPlague reported contracted by area cat\n--------------------------------------\nVeterinarians at White and White Veterinary Hospital in Ennis,\nMontana, have diagnosed the 1st case of plague this summer in an\nindoor/outdoor pet cat. Over the years, veterinarians there have\ndiagnosed numerous cases of plague and tularemia, all in domestic\ncats and in the summer months.\n\nCases have ranged from as far north as Norris to this most recent\ncase in the south, residing at Raynold's Pass.\n\nA diagnosis of plague is confirmed either by growing the culprit\nbacteria from a fine needle aspirate or by demonstrating an increase\nin antibodies in the cat from the onset of the disease, compared to a\nconvalescent blood sample taken 3 to 4 weeks later. An independent\nlab in Colorado confirmed the Raynold's Pass cat did have plague. The\ncat has since made a full recovery.\n\nIndoor/outdoor cats in rural areas that hunt rodents are the most\nlikely to encounter the 2 diseases.\n\nSigns [in animals] include swollen lymph nodes, lethargy, anorexia\nand a high fever.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabites and direct contact with infected animals. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of fleas which, when\ninfected, are carriers. These fleas generally do not infest other\nanimals unless their natural hosts are unavailable.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas.\nThey may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially\ncats, serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea\ntreatments and repellents appropriate for pets and available. Some\nproducts may be suitable for dogs but not cats or may be suitable for\nan adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your\nveterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and\npuppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under\nthe jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front\nleg (the armpit if you will), lethargy, anorexia and fever. Please\ntake your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities in\nyour pet. Veterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves\nwhen examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the\nveterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one\npalpating the swelling.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home\nvia a pet vehicle and can also transmit disease to you, the owner or\ncaretaker of the pet. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nPlague - USA: (CA) ground squirrel 20100708.2275\nPlague, canine - USA: (NM) 20100418.1259\nPlague, cougar - USA (WY) 20100208.0429\n2009\n----\nPlague, feline - USA (CA) 20091205.4150\nPlague, fatal - USA (05): (IL) lab strain susp. RFI 20090921.3320\nPlague, fatal - USA (04): (IL) lab strain susp. RFI 20090920.3298\nPlague, fatal - USA (03): (NM) recovery 20090715.2530\nPlague, tularemia, prairie dogs - USA (SD) 20090712.2494\nPlague, fatal - USA (02): (NM) risk, prevention 20090611.2153\nPlague, fatal - USA: (NM) bubonic 20090605.2080\nPlague, rabbit - USA (NM) 20090415.1435\n2008\n----\nPlague, human, prairie dogs - USA: (AZ) 20081012.3229\nPlague, bubonic - USA: (CT ex WY) 20080827.2672\nPlague, wildlife - USA: (CO) rabbit 20080727.2289\nPlague, prairie dogs, ferrets - USA: (SD) (02) 20080722.2213\nPlague, prairie dog, ferrets - USA: (SD) 20080708.2082\nPlague, feline - USA (WY): mountain lion 20080522.1694\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA: (CO), susp., RFI 20080506.1552\nPlague, human, feline - USA (NM): early season cases 20080127.0340\n....................tg/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "White", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "492823", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Peru (04): (LL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=492823", "date": "2010-08-07 23:00:17", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FELINE - USA: (MONTANA)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 7 Aug 2010\nSource: West Yellowstone News [edited]\n<http://www.westyellowstonenews.com/articles/2010/08/05/news/news6.txt>\n\n\nPlague reported contracted by area cat\n--------------------------------------\nVeterinarians at White and White Veterinary Hospital in Ennis,\nMontana, have diagnosed the 1st case of plague this summer in an\nindoor/outdoor pet cat. Over the years, veterinarians there have\ndiagnosed numerous cases of plague and tularemia, all in domestic\ncats and in the summer months.\n\nCases have ranged from as far north as Norris to this most recent\ncase in the south, residing at Raynold's Pass.\n\nA diagnosis of plague is confirmed either by growing the culprit\nbacteria from a fine needle aspirate or by demonstrating an increase\nin antibodies in the cat from the onset of the disease, compared to a\nconvalescent blood sample taken 3 to 4 weeks later. An independent\nlab in Colorado confirmed the Raynold's Pass cat did have plague. The\ncat has since made a full recovery.\n\nIndoor/outdoor cats in rural areas that hunt rodents are the most\nlikely to encounter the 2 diseases.\n\nSigns [in animals] include swollen lymph nodes, lethargy, anorexia\nand a high fever.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabites and direct contact with infected animals. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of fleas which, when\ninfected, are carriers. These fleas generally do not infest other\nanimals unless their natural hosts are unavailable.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas.\nThey may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially\ncats, serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea\ntreatments and repellents appropriate for pets and available. Some\nproducts may be suitable for dogs but not cats or may be suitable for\nan adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your\nveterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and\npuppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under\nthe jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front\nleg (the armpit if you will), lethargy, anorexia and fever. Please\ntake your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities in\nyour pet. Veterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves\nwhen examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the\nveterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one\npalpating the swelling.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home\nvia a pet vehicle and can also transmit disease to you, the owner or\ncaretaker of the pet. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nPlague - USA: (CA) ground squirrel 20100708.2275\nPlague, canine - USA: (NM) 20100418.1259\nPlague, cougar - USA (WY) 20100208.0429\n2009\n----\nPlague, feline - USA (CA) 20091205.4150\nPlague, fatal - USA (05): (IL) lab strain susp. RFI 20090921.3320\nPlague, fatal - USA (04): (IL) lab strain susp. RFI 20090920.3298\nPlague, fatal - USA (03): (NM) recovery 20090715.2530\nPlague, tularemia, prairie dogs - USA (SD) 20090712.2494\nPlague, fatal - USA (02): (NM) risk, prevention 20090611.2153\nPlague, fatal - USA: (NM) bubonic 20090605.2080\nPlague, rabbit - USA (NM) 20090415.1435\n2008\n----\nPlague, human, prairie dogs - USA: (AZ) 20081012.3229\nPlague, bubonic - USA: (CT ex WY) 20080827.2672\nPlague, wildlife - USA: (CO) rabbit 20080727.2289\nPlague, prairie dogs, ferrets - USA: (SD) (02) 20080722.2213\nPlague, prairie dog, ferrets - USA: (SD) 20080708.2082\nPlague, feline - USA (WY): mountain lion 20080522.1694\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA: (CO), susp., RFI 20080506.1552\nPlague, human, feline - USA (NM): early season cases 20080127.0340\n....................tg/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. He was also\nshivering and suffered from fatigue after he ate the animal on Saturday\nmorning, 13 Jun 2010. He was rushed to the People's Hospital in the Aksai\nKazakh autonomous county and died a few hours later. He was diagnosed with\nbubonic plague.\n\nThe man was one of the workers building a road from Dunhuang to\nDangjinshan. He hunted a marmot for food near the construction site. A\nworker with the project's administrative office confirmed the case to the\nGlobal Times but declined to give details.\n\nThe local health authority launched emergency response measures after the\nincident by sending experts to disinfect the construction site. \"As of\nright now, none of those who had close contact with the man shows any\nabnormal symptoms,\" the health authority said in a statement. Health\nofficials have urged herdsmen, tourists, and workers to stay away from\nmarmots and their resting place. They also urged residents to inform\nauthorities if they spot any dead marmots.\n\n[byline: Huang Jingjing]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The usual mode of transmission for bubonic plague is via a flea bite.\nBubonic plague is named for the typical \"bubo\", a very tender _Yersinia\npestis_ infected lymph node. A secondary bacteremia may occur which can\nlead to lethal side effects. If pneumonic plague develops, spread from\nhuman-to-human can occur, which can lead to an outbreak of pneumonic plague.\n\nMarmots such as the tarvaga, the tarbagan, or Mongolian marmot, _Marmota\nsibirica_, a large rodent related to the American woodchuck (_M. monax_),\nare thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in\nEastern Asia. The name marmot (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot>) comes\nfrom French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ (or _mus montanus_)\n\"mountain mouse\". - Mod.LL\n\nA map showing the provinces of China is available at\n<http://travel.nationalgeographic.com/travel/countries/china-map/> and the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of China can be seen at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01x9>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2009\n---\nPlague, pneumonic - China (06): (QH), WHO 20090811.2870\nPlague, pneumonic - China: (QH), RFI 20090801.2702\nPlague, human - Mongolia: (BO), RFI 20090612.2177\n2007\n---\nPlague, bubonic - Peru (02): (LL), bubonic, pneumonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=482788", "date": "2010-06-18 15:00:03", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC, FATAL - CHINA: (GANSU)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 17 Jun 2010\nSource: Global Times [edited]\n<http://china.globaltimes.cn/society/2010-06/542589.html>\n\n\nA construction worker in Gansu Province died soon after he hunted, cooked,\nand ate an infected marmot, the provincial health authority has announced.\n\nThe authority announced on Tuesday, 15 Jun 2010, that the man developed a\nhigh fever and swollen lymph glands under his left armpit. He was also\nshivering and suffered from fatigue after he ate the animal on Saturday\nmorning, 13 Jun 2010. He was rushed to the People's Hospital in the Aksai\nKazakh autonomous county and died a few hours later. He was diagnosed with\nbubonic plague.\n\nThe man was one of the workers building a road from Dunhuang to\nDangjinshan. He hunted a marmot for food near the construction site. A\nworker with the project's administrative office confirmed the case to the\nGlobal Times but declined to give details.\n\nThe local health authority launched emergency response measures after the\nincident by sending experts to disinfect the construction site. \"As of\nright now, none of those who had close contact with the man shows any\nabnormal symptoms,\" the health authority said in a statement. Health\nofficials have urged herdsmen, tourists, and workers to stay away from\nmarmots and their resting place. They also urged residents to inform\nauthorities if they spot any dead marmots.\n\n[byline: Huang Jingjing]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The usual mode of transmission for bubonic plague is via a flea bite.\nBubonic plague is named for the typical \"bubo\", a very tender _Yersinia\npestis_ infected lymph node. A secondary bacteremia may occur which can\nlead to lethal side effects. If pneumonic plague develops, spread from\nhuman-to-human can occur, which can lead to an outbreak of pneumonic plague.\n\nMarmots such as the tarvaga, the tarbagan, or Mongolian marmot, _Marmota\nsibirica_, a large rodent related to the American woodchuck (_M. monax_),\nare thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in\nEastern Asia. The name marmot (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot>) comes\nfrom French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ (or _mus montanus_)\n\"mountain mouse\". - Mod.LL\n\nA map showing the provinces of China is available at\n<http://travel.nationalgeographic.com/travel/countries/china-map/> and the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of China can be seen at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01x9>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2009\n---\nPlague, pneumonic - China (06): (QH), WHO 20090811.2870\nPlague, pneumonic - China: (QH), RFI 20090801.2702\nPlague, human - Mongolia: (BO), RFI 20090612.2177\n2007\n---\nPlague, bubonic - If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. You may also unsubscribe\nat <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\npostmaster@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-06-15 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Gansu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marmota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Qinghai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aksai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkmenistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Astrakhan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tibet", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dangjinshan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Background", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gansu Province", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "469160", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Peru: (TJ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=469160", "date": "2010-06-18 15:00:03", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC, FATAL - CHINA: (GANSU)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 17 Jun 2010\nSource: Global Times [edited]\n<http://china.globaltimes.cn/society/2010-06/542589.html>\n\n\nA construction worker in Gansu Province died soon after he hunted, cooked,\nand ate an infected marmot, the provincial health authority has announced.\n\nThe authority announced on Tuesday, 15 Jun 2010, that the man developed a\nhigh fever and swollen lymph glands under his left armpit. He was also\nshivering and suffered from fatigue after he ate the animal on Saturday\nmorning, 13 Jun 2010. He was rushed to the People's Hospital in the Aksai\nKazakh autonomous county and died a few hours later. He was diagnosed with\nbubonic plague.\n\nThe man was one of the workers building a road from Dunhuang to\nDangjinshan. He hunted a marmot for food near the construction site. A\nworker with the project's administrative office confirmed the case to the\nGlobal Times but declined to give details.\n\nThe local health authority launched emergency response measures after the\nincident by sending experts to disinfect the construction site. \"As of\nright now, none of those who had close contact with the man shows any\nabnormal symptoms,\" the health authority said in a statement. Health\nofficials have urged herdsmen, tourists, and workers to stay away from\nmarmots and their resting place. They also urged residents to inform\nauthorities if they spot any dead marmots.\n\n[byline: Huang Jingjing]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The usual mode of transmission for bubonic plague is via a flea bite.\nBubonic plague is named for the typical \"bubo\", a very tender _Yersinia\npestis_ infected lymph node. A secondary bacteremia may occur which can\nlead to lethal side effects. If pneumonic plague develops, spread from\nhuman-to-human can occur, which can lead to an outbreak of pneumonic plague.\n\nMarmots such as the tarvaga, the tarbagan, or Mongolian marmot, _Marmota\nsibirica_, a large rodent related to the American woodchuck (_M. monax_),\nare thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in\nEastern Asia. The name marmot (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot>) comes\nfrom French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ (or _mus montanus_)\n\"mountain mouse\". - Mod.LL\n\nA map showing the provinces of China is available at\n<http://travel.nationalgeographic.com/travel/countries/china-map/> and the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of China can be seen at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01x9>. - USA: (CA) ground squirrel", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=461609", "date": "2010-06-18 15:00:03", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC, FATAL - CHINA: (GANSU)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 17 Jun 2010\nSource: Global Times [edited]\n<http://china.globaltimes.cn/society/2010-06/542589.html>\n\n\nA construction worker in Gansu Province died soon after he hunted, cooked,\nand ate an infected marmot, the provincial health authority has announced.\n\nThe authority announced on Tuesday, 15 Jun 2010, that the man developed a\nhigh fever and swollen lymph glands under his left armpit. He was also\nshivering and suffered from fatigue after he ate the animal on Saturday\nmorning, 13 Jun 2010. He was rushed to the People's Hospital in the Aksai\nKazakh autonomous county and died a few hours later. He was diagnosed with\nbubonic plague.\n\nThe man was one of the workers building a road from Dunhuang to\nDangjinshan. He hunted a marmot for food near the construction site. A\nworker with the project's administrative office confirmed the case to the\nGlobal Times but declined to give details.\n\nThe local health authority launched emergency response measures after the\nincident by sending experts to disinfect the construction site. \"As of\nright now, none of those who had close contact with the man shows any\nabnormal symptoms,\" the health authority said in a statement. Health\nofficials have urged herdsmen, tourists, and workers to stay away from\nmarmots and their resting place. They also urged residents to inform\nauthorities if they spot any dead marmots.\n\n[byline: Huang Jingjing]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The usual mode of transmission for bubonic plague is via a flea bite.\nBubonic plague is named for the typical \"bubo\", a very tender _Yersinia\npestis_ infected lymph node. A secondary bacteremia may occur which can\nlead to lethal side effects. If pneumonic plague develops, spread from\nhuman-to-human can occur, which can lead to an outbreak of pneumonic plague.\n\nMarmots such as the tarvaga, the tarbagan, or Mongolian marmot, _Marmota\nsibirica_, a large rodent related to the American woodchuck (_M. monax_),\nare thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in\nEastern Asia. The name marmot (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot>) comes\nfrom French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ (or _mus montanus_)\n\"mountain mouse\". - Mod.LL\n\nA map showing the provinces of China is available at\n<http://travel.nationalgeographic.com/travel/countries/china-map/> and the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of China can be seen at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01x9>. - He was also\nshivering and suffered from fatigue after he ate the animal on Saturday\nmorning, 13 Jun 2010. He was rushed to the People's Hospital in the Aksai\nKazakh autonomous county and died a few hours later. He was diagnosed with\nbubonic plague.\n\nThe man was one of the workers building a road from Dunhuang to\nDangjinshan. He hunted a marmot for food near the construction site. A\nworker with the project's administrative office confirmed the case to the\nGlobal Times but declined to give details.\n\nThe local health authority launched emergency response measures after the\nincident by sending experts to disinfect the construction site. \"As of\nright now, none of those who had close contact with the man shows any\nabnormal symptoms,\" the health authority said in a statement. The name marmot (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot>) comes\nfrom French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ (or _mus montanus_)\n\"mountain mouse\". - Mod.LL\n\nA map showing the provinces of China is available at\n<http://travel.nationalgeographic.com/travel/countries/china-map/> and the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of China can be seen at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01x9>. - RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=458779", "date": "2010-06-18 15:00:03", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC, FATAL - CHINA: (GANSU)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 17 Jun 2010\nSource: Global Times [edited]\n<http://china.globaltimes.cn/society/2010-06/542589.html>\n\n\nA construction worker in Gansu Province died soon after he hunted, cooked,\nand ate an infected marmot, the provincial health authority has announced.\n\nThe authority announced on Tuesday, 15 Jun 2010, that the man developed a\nhigh fever and swollen lymph glands under his left armpit. He was also\nshivering and suffered from fatigue after he ate the animal on Saturday\nmorning, 13 Jun 2010. He was rushed to the People's Hospital in the Aksai\nKazakh autonomous county and died a few hours later. He was diagnosed with\nbubonic plague.\n\nThe man was one of the workers building a road from Dunhuang to\nDangjinshan. He hunted a marmot for food near the construction site. A\nworker with the project's administrative office confirmed the case to the\nGlobal Times but declined to give details.\n\nThe local health authority launched emergency response measures after the\nincident by sending experts to disinfect the construction site. \"As of\nright now, none of those who had close contact with the man shows any\nabnormal symptoms,\" the health authority said in a statement. Health\nofficials have urged herdsmen, tourists, and workers to stay away from\nmarmots and their resting place. They also urged residents to inform\nauthorities if they spot any dead marmots.\n\n[byline: Huang Jingjing]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The usual mode of transmission for bubonic plague is via a flea bite.\nBubonic plague is named for the typical \"bubo\", a very tender _Yersinia\npestis_ infected lymph node. A secondary bacteremia may occur which can\nlead to lethal side effects. If pneumonic plague develops, spread from\nhuman-to-human can occur, which can lead to an outbreak of pneumonic plague.\n\nMarmots such as the tarvaga, the tarbagan, or Mongolian marmot, _Marmota\nsibirica_, a large rodent related to the American woodchuck (_M. monax_),\nare thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in\nEastern Asia. The name marmot (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot>) comes\nfrom French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ (or _mus montanus_)\n\"mountain mouse\". - Mod.LL\n\nA map showing the provinces of China is available at\n<http://travel.nationalgeographic.com/travel/countries/china-map/> and the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of China can be seen at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01x9>. - Peru: (LL) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=417411", "date": "2009-08-11 18:00:07", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CHINA (06): (QINGHAI), WHO\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 11 Aug 2009\nSource: WHO Outbreak Reports [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2006_08_11/en/index.html>\n\n\nOn 1 Aug 2009, the Ministry of Health (MoH), China reported a cluster\noutbreak of pulmonary plague cases in the remote town of Ziketan, Qinghai\nprovince. The 1st case was a 32 year old male herdsman, who developed fever\nand hemoptysis on 26 Jul 2009. He was referred to a hospital but died en\nroute, and was buried the following day. On 30 Jul 2009, 11 people who had\nclose contact with the case (mainly relatives who attended the funeral)\ndeveloped fever and cough, and were all hospitalized. On 1 Aug 2009,\nspecimens taken from all these 12 people, including the 1st case, tested\npositive for plague.\n\nOn 2 Aug 2009 both the 64 year old father-in-law of the index case and a 37\nyear old male neighbor of the 1st case (who helped to bury the corpse) also\ndied. Of the remaining 9 cases, one is in critical condition, one had acute\nsymptoms of fever and cough, and 7 are in stable condition.\n\nAs of 6 Aug 2009, the local health authority has isolated 332 close\ncontacts for further medical observation, and implemented traffic control\naround the affected area. Experts on both disease prevention and control\nand clinical management have been dispatched to Qinghai province.\nProtective clothes, X-ray machines and other medical equipment have been\nsent to the affected area. Prevention guidance pamphlets have also been\ndisseminated.\n\nAccording to the epidemiological investigation, the source of this outbreak\nwas a wild marmot, which had contact with the dog of the index case.\nZiketan is in an area of natural plague bacteria circulation amongst\nanimals and at the present time it is the active season for plague\ntransmission amongst animals. No drug resistance of the bacterium has been\nfound so far and the 3 death cases have been attributed largely to delayed\ntreatment.\n\nChina has established a national surveillance network for plague, and has\nprepared necessary supplies in high-risk areas. After this outbreak,\nspecial funds, supplies and experts were quickly dispatched to the affected\narea.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the formal WHO outbreak report regarding the recent cluster of\npneumonic plague in north western China. No further information regarding\nthe patient who was in critical condition in ProMED's 6 Aug 2009 posting is\navailable. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, pneumonic - China (05): (QH) Comment 20090807.2800\nPlague, pneumonic - China (04): (QH) 20090806.2778\nPlague, pneumonic - China (03): (QH) 20090805.2764\nPlague, pneumonic - China (02): (QH) 20090803.2724\nPlague, pneumonic - China: (QH), RFI 20090801.2702\nPlague, human - Mongolia: (BO), RFI 20090612.2177\n2007\n---\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia (Gobisumber) 20070924.3163\nPlague, human, fatal - Mongolia (Hovsgol) (03) 20070810.2602\nPlague, human, fatal - Mongolia (Hovsgol) 20070807.2567\nPlague, rodents - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-08-01 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-08-01 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-08-06 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Qinghai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkmenistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Astrakhan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tibet", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ziketan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Background", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "411655", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, canine - USA: (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=411655", "date": "2009-08-11 18:00:07", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CHINA (06): (QINGHAI), WHO\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 11 Aug 2009\nSource: WHO Outbreak Reports [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2006_08_11/en/index.html>\n\n\nOn 1 Aug 2009, the Ministry of Health (MoH), China reported a cluster\noutbreak of pulmonary plague cases in the remote town of Ziketan, Qinghai\nprovince. The 1st case was a 32 year old male herdsman, who developed fever\nand hemoptysis on 26 Jul 2009. He was referred to a hospital but died en\nroute, and was buried the following day. On 30 Jul 2009, 11 people who had\nclose contact with the case (mainly relatives who attended the funeral)\ndeveloped fever and cough, and were all hospitalized. On 1 Aug 2009,\nspecimens taken from all these 12 people, including the 1st case, tested\npositive for plague.\n\nOn 2 Aug 2009 both the 64 year old father-in-law of the index case and a 37\nyear old male neighbor of the 1st case (who helped to bury the corpse) also\ndied. Of the remaining 9 cases, one is in critical condition, one had acute\nsymptoms of fever and cough, and 7 are in stable condition.\n\nAs of 6 Aug 2009, the local health authority has isolated 332 close\ncontacts for further medical observation, and implemented traffic control\naround the affected area. Experts on both disease prevention and control\nand clinical management have been dispatched to Qinghai province.\nProtective clothes, X-ray machines and other medical equipment have been\nsent to the affected area. Prevention guidance pamphlets have also been\ndisseminated.\n\nAccording to the epidemiological investigation, the source of this outbreak\nwas a wild marmot, which had contact with the dog of the index case.\nZiketan is in an area of natural plague bacteria circulation amongst\nanimals and at the present time it is the active season for plague\ntransmission amongst animals. No drug resistance of the bacterium has been\nfound so far and the 3 death cases have been attributed largely to delayed\ntreatment.\n\nChina has established a national surveillance network for plague, and has\nprepared necessary supplies in high-risk areas. After this outbreak,\nspecial funds, supplies and experts were quickly dispatched to the affected\narea.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the formal WHO outbreak report regarding the recent cluster of\npneumonic plague in north western China. No further information regarding\nthe patient who was in critical condition in ProMED's 6 Aug 2009 posting is\navailable. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, pneumonic - China (05): (QH) Comment 20090807.2800\nPlague, pneumonic - The 1st case was a 32 year old male herdsman, who developed fever\nand hemoptysis on 26 Jul 2009. He was referred to a hospital but died en\nroute, and was buried the following day. On 30 Jul 2009, 11 people who had\nclose contact with the case (mainly relatives who attended the funeral)\ndeveloped fever and cough, and were all hospitalized. On 1 Aug 2009,\nspecimens taken from all these 12 people, including the 1st case, tested\npositive for plague.\n\nOn 2 Aug 2009 both the 64 year old father-in-law of the index case and a 37\nyear old male neighbor of the 1st case (who helped to bury the corpse) also\ndied. Of the remaining 9 cases, one is in critical condition, one had acute\nsymptoms of fever and cough, and 7 are in stable condition.\n\nAs of 6 Aug 2009, the local health authority has isolated 332 close\ncontacts for further medical observation, and implemented traffic control\naround the affected area. Experts on both disease prevention and control\nand clinical management have been dispatched to Qinghai province.\nProtective clothes, X-ray machines and other medical equipment have been\nsent to the affected area. Prevention guidance pamphlets have also been\ndisseminated.\n\nAccording to the epidemiological investigation, the source of this outbreak\nwas a wild marmot, which had contact with the dog of the index case.\nZiketan is in an area of natural plague bacteria circulation amongst\nanimals and at the present time it is the active season for plague\ntransmission amongst animals. No drug resistance of the bacterium has been\nfound so far and the 3 death cases have been attributed largely to delayed\ntreatment.\n\nChina has established a national surveillance network for plague, and has\nprepared necessary supplies in high-risk areas. After this outbreak,\nspecial funds, supplies and experts were quickly dispatched to the affected\narea.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the formal WHO outbreak report regarding the recent cluster of\npneumonic plague in north western China. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-08-01 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-08-01 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-08-06 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Qinghai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkmenistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Astrakhan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tibet", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ziketan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Background", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "296145", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, fatal - USA (05): (IL) lab strain susp. RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=296145", "date": "2009-08-11 18:00:07", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CHINA (06): (QINGHAI), WHO\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 11 Aug 2009\nSource: WHO Outbreak Reports [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2006_08_11/en/index.html>\n\n\nOn 1 Aug 2009, the Ministry of Health (MoH), China reported a cluster\noutbreak of pulmonary plague cases in the remote town of Ziketan, Qinghai\nprovince. The 1st case was a 32 year old male herdsman, who developed fever\nand hemoptysis on 26 Jul 2009. He was referred to a hospital but died en\nroute, and was buried the following day. On 30 Jul 2009, 11 people who had\nclose contact with the case (mainly relatives who attended the funeral)\ndeveloped fever and cough, and were all hospitalized. On 1 Aug 2009,\nspecimens taken from all these 12 people, including the 1st case, tested\npositive for plague.\n\nOn 2 Aug 2009 both the 64 year old father-in-law of the index case and a 37\nyear old male neighbor of the 1st case (who helped to bury the corpse) also\ndied. Of the remaining 9 cases, one is in critical condition, one had acute\nsymptoms of fever and cough, and 7 are in stable condition.\n\nAs of 6 Aug 2009, the local health authority has isolated 332 close\ncontacts for further medical observation, and implemented traffic control\naround the affected area. Experts on both disease prevention and control\nand clinical management have been dispatched to Qinghai province.\nProtective clothes, X-ray machines and other medical equipment have been\nsent to the affected area. Prevention guidance pamphlets have also been\ndisseminated.\n\nAccording to the epidemiological investigation, the source of this outbreak\nwas a wild marmot, which had contact with the dog of the index case.\nZiketan is in an area of natural plague bacteria circulation amongst\nanimals and at the present time it is the active season for plague\ntransmission amongst animals. No drug resistance of the bacterium has been\nfound so far and the 3 death cases have been attributed largely to delayed\ntreatment.\n\nChina has established a national surveillance network for plague, and has\nprepared necessary supplies in high-risk areas. After this outbreak,\nspecial funds, supplies and experts were quickly dispatched to the affected\narea.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the formal WHO outbreak report regarding the recent cluster of\npneumonic plague in north western China. No further information regarding\nthe patient who was in critical condition in ProMED's 6 Aug 2009 posting is\navailable. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, pneumonic - China (05): (QH) Comment 20090807.2800\nPlague, pneumonic - RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=295336", "date": "2009-08-11 18:00:07", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CHINA (06): (QINGHAI), WHO\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 11 Aug 2009\nSource: WHO Outbreak Reports [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2006_08_11/en/index.html>\n\n\nOn 1 Aug 2009, the Ministry of Health (MoH), China reported a cluster\noutbreak of pulmonary plague cases in the remote town of Ziketan, Qinghai\nprovince. The 1st case was a 32 year old male herdsman, who developed fever\nand hemoptysis on 26 Jul 2009. He was referred to a hospital but died en\nroute, and was buried the following day. On 30 Jul 2009, 11 people who had\nclose contact with the case (mainly relatives who attended the funeral)\ndeveloped fever and cough, and were all hospitalized. On 1 Aug 2009,\nspecimens taken from all these 12 people, including the 1st case, tested\npositive for plague.\n\nOn 2 Aug 2009 both the 64 year old father-in-law of the index case and a 37\nyear old male neighbor of the 1st case (who helped to bury the corpse) also\ndied. Of the remaining 9 cases, one is in critical condition, one had acute\nsymptoms of fever and cough, and 7 are in stable condition.\n\nAs of 6 Aug 2009, the local health authority has isolated 332 close\ncontacts for further medical observation, and implemented traffic control\naround the affected area. Experts on both disease prevention and control\nand clinical management have been dispatched to Qinghai province.\nProtective clothes, X-ray machines and other medical equipment have been\nsent to the affected area. Prevention guidance pamphlets have also been\ndisseminated.\n\nAccording to the epidemiological investigation, the source of this outbreak\nwas a wild marmot, which had contact with the dog of the index case.\nZiketan is in an area of natural plague bacteria circulation amongst\nanimals and at the present time it is the active season for plague\ntransmission amongst animals. No drug resistance of the bacterium has been\nfound so far and the 3 death cases have been attributed largely to delayed\ntreatment.\n\nChina has established a national surveillance network for plague, and has\nprepared necessary supplies in high-risk areas. After this outbreak,\nspecial funds, supplies and experts were quickly dispatched to the affected\narea.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the formal WHO outbreak report regarding the recent cluster of\npneumonic plague in north western China. The city [officials] said the girl was likely exposed to the\nplague in the East Mountains, and investigators are gathering more\ninformation on how she was exposed.\n\nOfficials also believe the girl's great-grandfather was also infected\nwith plague, but they're still awaiting final test results.\n\nFamily pets are also prone to the plague and could carry infected\nfleas home to their owners. Dogs may not show symptoms, the city said,\nbut cats may develop swollen lymph nodes in the neck, become\nlethargic, suffer a fever or lose their appetite. Officials suggest\nthat pet owners use flea control on their pets, keep them away from\ndead rodents or rodent burrows, and prevent them from roaming or\nhunting. They should also take sick pets to a veterinarian.\n\nPeople should also avoid sick or dead rodents, keep their distance\nfrom wildlife and prevent rodents from living near their homes by\nremoving trash and weeds and getting wood piles off the ground.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not stated, it is likely that the child had the bubonic form\nof _Yersinia pestis_ infection, the most common manifestation of\nplague in humans.\n\nThe southwestern state of New Mexico can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00Bg>.\nA map of the state of New Mexico showing the location of Bernalillo\nCounty mentioned in the posting can be found at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/new_mexico_map.html>. - The city [officials] said the girl was likely exposed to the\nplague in the East Mountains, and investigators are gathering more\ninformation on how she was exposed.\n\nOfficials also believe the girl's great-grandfather was also infected\nwith plague, but they're still awaiting final test results.\n\nFamily pets are also prone to the plague and could carry infected\nfleas home to their owners. Dogs may not show symptoms, the city said,\nbut cats may develop swollen lymph nodes in the neck, become\nlethargic, suffer a fever or lose their appetite. Officials suggest\nthat pet owners use flea control on their pets, keep them away from\ndead rodents or rodent burrows, and prevent them from roaming or\nhunting. They should also take sick pets to a veterinarian.\n\nPeople should also avoid sick or dead rodents, keep their distance\nfrom wildlife and prevent rodents from living near their homes by\nremoving trash and weeds and getting wood piles off the ground.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not stated, it is likely that the child had the bubonic form\nof _Yersinia pestis_ infection, the most common manifestation of\nplague in humans.\n\nThe southwestern state of New Mexico can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00Bg>.\nA map of the state of New Mexico showing the location of Bernalillo\nCounty mentioned in the posting can be found at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/new_mexico_map.html>. - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo \n County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "250457", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic, pneumonic - Uganda, 2006: (AW, NE)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=250457", "date": "2009-07-15 20:00:06", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (03): (NEW MEXICO) RECOVERY\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 9 Jul 2009\nSource: KRQE.com [edited]\n<http://www.krqe.com/dpp/news/health/health_krqe_albuquerque_bernalillo_county_girl_recovering_from_plague_200907091454>\n\n\nA 16-month-old Bernalillo County girl is recovering from plague, the\ncounty's 1st human case this year [2009] and the state's 5th,\naccording to the Albuquerque Vector-Borne and Zoonotic Disease\nDivision. The city [officials] said the girl was likely exposed to the\nplague in the East Mountains, and investigators are gathering more\ninformation on how she was exposed.\n\nOfficials also believe the girl's great-grandfather was also infected\nwith plague, but they're still awaiting final test results.\n\nFamily pets are also prone to the plague and could carry infected\nfleas home to their owners. Dogs may not show symptoms, the city said,\nbut cats may develop swollen lymph nodes in the neck, become\nlethargic, suffer a fever or lose their appetite. Officials suggest\nthat pet owners use flea control on their pets, keep them away from\ndead rodents or rodent burrows, and prevent them from roaming or\nhunting. They should also take sick pets to a veterinarian.\n\nPeople should also avoid sick or dead rodents, keep their distance\nfrom wildlife and prevent rodents from living near their homes by\nremoving trash and weeds and getting wood piles off the ground.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not stated, it is likely that the child had the bubonic form\nof _Yersinia pestis_ infection, the most common manifestation of\nplague in humans.\n\nThe southwestern state of New Mexico can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00Bg>.\nA map of the state of New Mexico showing the location of Bernalillo\nCounty mentioned in the posting can be found at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/new_mexico_map.html>. -
