The city [officials] said the girl was likely exposed to the\nplague in the East Mountains, and investigators are gathering more\ninformation on how she was exposed.\n\nOfficials also believe the girl's great-grandfather was also infected\nwith plague, but they're still awaiting final test results.\n\nFamily pets are also prone to the plague and could carry infected\nfleas home to their owners. Dogs may not show symptoms, the city said,\nbut cats may develop swollen lymph nodes in the neck, become\nlethargic, suffer a fever or lose their appetite. Officials suggest\nthat pet owners use flea control on their pets, keep them away from\ndead rodents or rodent burrows, and prevent them from roaming or\nhunting. They should also take sick pets to a veterinarian.\n\nPeople should also avoid sick or dead rodents, keep their distance\nfrom wildlife and prevent rodents from living near their homes by\nremoving trash and weeds and getting wood piles off the ground.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not stated, it is likely that the child had the bubonic form\nof _Yersinia pestis_ infection, the most common manifestation of\nplague in humans.\n\nThe southwestern state of New Mexico can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00Bg>.\nA map of the state of New Mexico showing the location of Bernalillo\nCounty mentioned in the posting can be found at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/new_mexico_map.html>. - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo \n County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "241217", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Uganda: (AW, NE), 2008: RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=241217", "date": "2009-06-11 13:00:08", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - USA (02): (NEW MEXICO) RISK, PREVENTION\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 10 Jun 2009\nFrom: Paul Ettestad <Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n\nThe 3rd human case of plague (_Yersinia pestis_) from New Mexico in\n2009 has been confirmed and only 1 week after the 1st 2 cases. All 3\ncases were most likely exposed via fleabite due to their clinical\npresentations of bubonic plague. Though we will never know the exact\nexposure, one of the risk factors in the 1st 2 cases was that the\nfamily dog was allowed to roam and hunt and then sleep in bed with\nthe children. No flea control products were used on the dog.\n\nThis type of risk has been seen in other human cases in past years\nand serves as a reminder to emphasize flea control product use on\npets, even in dry areas. These are not the typical dog and cat fleas,\nbut plague-infected rodent fleas from various animal species (prairie\ndogs, rock squirrels, wood rats, etc) that may be involved in a\nplague outbreak. The rodent fleas will transiently move to other\nanimals (dogs, cats, etc) from their preferred rodent host when it\ndies, and can be brought into the home by pets that are allowed to\nroam and hunt.\n\nNorth-central New Mexico is having a cooler and wetter late spring\nwhich allows infected fleas to survive longer and to move to the\nburrow entrances after their host rodent has died from plague without\nbeing prone to desiccation in the usual hot and dry environment. This\nincreases the risk that people and pets walking near the burrow\nentrances may have infected fleas jump onto them to try and take a blood meal.\n\n--\nPaul Ettestad DVM, MS\nState Public Health Veterinarian\nEpidemiology and Response Division\nNew Mexico Department of Health\nUSA\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Ettestad for his first-hand information and\nthe inclusion of the news release from the State Department of\nHealth, dated 10 Jun 2009:\n\nState confirms 3rd human plague case from Santa Fe County\nAnimal cases also confirmed in Taos and Santa Fe Counties\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe New Mexico Department of Health confirmed today [10 Jun 2009] a\n3rd case of bubonic plague in Santa Fe County so far in 2009. A\n56-year-old man was hospitalized and is back home recovering. The\nDepartment of Health is conducting an environmental investigation at\nthe man's residence to determine if there is any ongoing risk to people.\n\nThe Department also confirmed a plague case in a dog from north of\nthe city of Taos and a cat case from the Arroyo Hondo area southeast\nof the city of Santa Fe. Earlier this month [June 2009] the\nDepartment reported a fatal case in an 8-year-old Santa Fe County boy\nand a case in his 10-year-old sister who recovered. There have been a\ntotal of 3 human cases in New Mexico, all in Santa Fe County, so far in 2009.\n\nTo prevent cases of plague, the Department of Health recommends\n- Avoid sick or dead rodents.\n- Teach children not to play near rodent nests or burrows.\n- Treat pets regularly with an effective flea control product.\n- Clean up areas near the house where rodents could live.\n- Keep pets from roaming and hunting.\n- Sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian.\n\nSymptoms in cats and dogs are similar to humans. Fever, lethargy, not\neating, and swollen lymph nodes (usually in the neck area) are the\nmost common signs.\n\nThere was one human case of plague in 2008 in an Eddy County man.\nThere were 5 human cases of plague in Bernalillo, San Juan, Santa Fe,\nand Torrance counties in 2007 with a fatality. 8 human plague cases\noccurred in New Mexico in 2006 with 3 fatalities.\"\n\nThe southwestern state of New Mexico can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00bF>.\nA map of the state of New Mexico showing the location of Santa Fe and\nthe other counties mentioned in the posting can be found at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/new_mexico_map.html>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, fatal - USA: (NM) bubonic 20090605.2080\nPlague, rabbit - USA (NM) 20090415.1435\n2008\n----\nPlague, human, feline - USA (NM): early season cases 20080127.0340\n2007\n----\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (NM) 20070929.3218\nPlague, feline - USA (NM) 20070914.3055\nPlague, human, septicemic - USA (NM) 20070612.1914\nPlague, human, fatal - USA (NM) 20070608.1875\nPlague, human, secondary pneumonic - USA (NM) 20070607.1846\nPlague, septicemic - USA (NM) 20070504.1447\n2006\n----\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (NM)(02) 20060724.2034\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (NM) 20060717.1960\nPlague, human - USA (NM) 20060601.1526\nPlague, human, fatal - USA (NM) 20060528.1500\n2005\n----\nPlague, human - USA (NM)(02) 20050726.2163\nPlague, human - USA (NM) 20050725.2157\n2004\n----\nPlague, cats - USA (NM) 20040502.1213\n...................................ll/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-06-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "San Juan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eddy County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arroyo Hondo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "239524", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, tularemia, prairie dogs - USA (SD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=239524", "date": "2009-06-11 13:00:08", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - USA (02): (NEW MEXICO) RISK, PREVENTION\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 10 Jun 2009\nFrom: Paul Ettestad <Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n\nThe 3rd human case of plague (_Yersinia pestis_) from New Mexico in\n2009 has been confirmed and only 1 week after the 1st 2 cases. All 3\ncases were most likely exposed via fleabite due to their clinical\npresentations of bubonic plague. Though we will never know the exact\nexposure, one of the risk factors in the 1st 2 cases was that the\nfamily dog was allowed to roam and hunt and then sleep in bed with\nthe children. No flea control products were used on the dog.\n\nThis type of risk has been seen in other human cases in past years\nand serves as a reminder to emphasize flea control product use on\npets, even in dry areas. These are not the typical dog and cat fleas,\nbut plague-infected rodent fleas from various animal species (prairie\ndogs, rock squirrels, wood rats, etc) that may be involved in a\nplague outbreak. The rodent fleas will transiently move to other\nanimals (dogs, cats, etc) from their preferred rodent host when it\ndies, and can be brought into the home by pets that are allowed to\nroam and hunt.\n\nNorth-central New Mexico is having a cooler and wetter late spring\nwhich allows infected fleas to survive longer and to move to the\nburrow entrances after their host rodent has died from plague without\nbeing prone to desiccation in the usual hot and dry environment. This\nincreases the risk that people and pets walking near the burrow\nentrances may have infected fleas jump onto them to try and take a blood meal.\n\n--\nPaul Ettestad DVM, MS\nState Public Health Veterinarian\nEpidemiology and Response Division\nNew Mexico Department of Health\nUSA\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Ettestad for his first-hand information and\nthe inclusion of the news release from the State Department of\nHealth, dated 10 Jun 2009:\n\nState confirms 3rd human plague case from Santa Fe County\nAnimal cases also confirmed in Taos and Santa Fe Counties\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe New Mexico Department of Health confirmed today [10 Jun 2009] a\n3rd case of bubonic plague in Santa Fe County so far in 2009. A\n56-year-old man was hospitalized and is back home recovering. The\nDepartment of Health is conducting an environmental investigation at\nthe man's residence to determine if there is any ongoing risk to people.\n\nThe Department also confirmed a plague case in a dog from north of\nthe city of Taos and a cat case from the Arroyo Hondo area southeast\nof the city of Santa Fe. Earlier this month [June 2009] the\nDepartment reported a fatal case in an 8-year-old Santa Fe County boy\nand a case in his 10-year-old sister who recovered. There have been a\ntotal of 3 human cases in New Mexico, all in Santa Fe County, so far in 2009.\n\nTo prevent cases of plague, the Department of Health recommends\n- Avoid sick or dead rodents.\n- Teach children not to play near rodent nests or burrows.\n- Treat pets regularly with an effective flea control product.\n- Clean up areas near the house where rodents could live.\n- Keep pets from roaming and hunting.\n- Sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian.\n\nSymptoms in cats and dogs are similar to humans. Fever, lethargy, not\neating, and swollen lymph nodes (usually in the neck area) are the\nmost common signs.\n\nThere was one human case of plague in 2008 in an Eddy County man.\nThere were 5 human cases of plague in Bernalillo, San Juan, Santa Fe,\nand Torrance counties in 2007 with a fatality. 8 human plague cases\noccurred in New Mexico in 2006 with 3 fatalities.\"\n\nThe southwestern state of New Mexico can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00bF>.\nA map of the state of New Mexico showing the location of Santa Fe and\nthe other counties mentioned in the posting can be found at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/new_mexico_map.html>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, fatal - USA: (NM) bubonic 20090605.2080\nPlague, rabbit - USA (NM) 20090415.1435\n2008\n----\nPlague, human, feline - USA (NM): early season cases 20080127.0340\n2007\n----\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (NM) 20070929.3218\nPlague, feline - USA (NM) 20070914.3055\nPlague, human, septicemic - USA (NM) 20070612.1914\nPlague, human, fatal - USA (NM) 20070608.1875\nPlague, human, secondary pneumonic - USA (NM) 20070607.1846\nPlague, septicemic - USA (NM) 20070504.1447\n2006\n----\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (NM)(02) 20060724.2034\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (NM) 20060717.1960\nPlague, human - USA (NM) 20060601.1526\nPlague, human, fatal - USA (NM) 20060528.1500\n2005\n----\nPlague, human - USA (NM)(02) 20050726.2163\nPlague, human - USA (NM) 20050725.2157\n2004\n----\nPlague, cats - USA (NM) 20040502.1213\n...................................ll/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-06-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "San Juan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eddy County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arroyo Hondo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "232949", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic - Libya (02): (BN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=232949", "date": "2009-06-11 13:00:08", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - USA (02): (NEW MEXICO) RISK, PREVENTION\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 10 Jun 2009\nFrom: Paul Ettestad <Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n\nThe 3rd human case of plague (_Yersinia pestis_) from New Mexico in\n2009 has been confirmed and only 1 week after the 1st 2 cases. All 3\ncases were most likely exposed via fleabite due to their clinical\npresentations of bubonic plague. Though we will never know the exact\nexposure, one of the risk factors in the 1st 2 cases was that the\nfamily dog was allowed to roam and hunt and then sleep in bed with\nthe children. No flea control products were used on the dog.\n\nThis type of risk has been seen in other human cases in past years\nand serves as a reminder to emphasize flea control product use on\npets, even in dry areas. These are not the typical dog and cat fleas,\nbut plague-infected rodent fleas from various animal species (prairie\ndogs, rock squirrels, wood rats, etc) that may be involved in a\nplague outbreak. The rodent fleas will transiently move to other\nanimals (dogs, cats, etc) from their preferred rodent host when it\ndies, and can be brought into the home by pets that are allowed to\nroam and hunt.\n\nNorth-central New Mexico is having a cooler and wetter late spring\nwhich allows infected fleas to survive longer and to move to the\nburrow entrances after their host rodent has died from plague without\nbeing prone to desiccation in the usual hot and dry environment. This\nincreases the risk that people and pets walking near the burrow\nentrances may have infected fleas jump onto them to try and take a blood meal.\n\n--\nPaul Ettestad DVM, MS\nState Public Health Veterinarian\nEpidemiology and Response Division\nNew Mexico Department of Health\nUSA\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Ettestad for his first-hand information and\nthe inclusion of the news release from the State Department of\nHealth, dated 10 Jun 2009:\n\nState confirms 3rd human plague case from Santa Fe County\nAnimal cases also confirmed in Taos and Santa Fe Counties\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe New Mexico Department of Health confirmed today [10 Jun 2009] a\n3rd case of bubonic plague in Santa Fe County so far in 2009. A\n56-year-old man was hospitalized and is back home recovering. The\nDepartment of Health is conducting an environmental investigation at\nthe man's residence to determine if there is any ongoing risk to people.\n\nThe Department also confirmed a plague case in a dog from north of\nthe city of Taos and a cat case from the Arroyo Hondo area southeast\nof the city of Santa Fe. Earlier this month [June 2009] the\nDepartment reported a fatal case in an 8-year-old Santa Fe County boy\nand a case in his 10-year-old sister who recovered. There have been a\ntotal of 3 human cases in New Mexico, all in Santa Fe County, so far in 2009.\n\nTo prevent cases of plague, the Department of Health recommends\n- Avoid sick or dead rodents.\n- Teach children not to play near rodent nests or burrows.\n- Treat pets regularly with an effective flea control product.\n- Clean up areas near the house where rodents could live.\n- Keep pets from roaming and hunting.\n- Sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian.\n\nSymptoms in cats and dogs are similar to humans. Fever, lethargy, not\neating, and swollen lymph nodes (usually in the neck area) are the\nmost common signs.\n\nThere was one human case of plague in 2008 in an Eddy County man.\nThere were 5 human cases of plague in Bernalillo, San Juan, Santa Fe,\nand Torrance counties in 2007 with a fatality. 8 human plague cases\noccurred in New Mexico in 2006 with 3 fatalities.\"\n\nThe southwestern state of New Mexico can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00bF>.\nA map of the state of New Mexico showing the location of Santa Fe and\nthe other counties mentioned in the posting can be found at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/new_mexico_map.html>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, fatal - USA: (NM) bubonic 20090605.2080\nPlague, rabbit - USA (NM) 20090415.1435\n2008\n----\nPlague, human, feline - USA (NM): early season cases 20080127.0340\n2007\n----\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (NM) 20070929.3218\nPlague, feline - USA (NM) 20070914.3055\nPlague, human, septicemic - USA (NM) 20070612.1914\nPlague, human, fatal - USA (NM) 20070608.1875\nPlague, human, secondary pneumonic - USA (NM) 20070607.1846\nPlague, septicemic - USA (NM) 20070504.1447\n2006\n----\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (NM)(02) 20060724.2034\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (NM) 20060717.1960\nPlague, human - USA (NM) 20060601.1526\nPlague, human, fatal - USA (NM) 20060528.1500\n2005\n----\nPlague, human - USA (NM)(02) 20050726.2163\nPlague, human - USA (NM) 20050725.2157\n2004\n----\nPlague, cats - USA (NM) 20040502.1213\n...................................ll/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. These are not the typical dog and cat fleas,\nbut plague-infected rodent fleas from various animal species (prairie\ndogs, rock squirrels, wood rats, etc) that may be involved in a\nplague outbreak. The rodent fleas will transiently move to other\nanimals (dogs, cats, etc) from their preferred rodent host when it\ndies, and can be brought into the home by pets that are allowed to\nroam and hunt.\n\nNorth-central New Mexico is having a cooler and wetter late spring\nwhich allows infected fleas to survive longer and to move to the\nburrow entrances after their host rodent has died from plague without\nbeing prone to desiccation in the usual hot and dry environment. This\nincreases the risk that people and pets walking near the burrow\nentrances may have infected fleas jump onto them to try and take a blood meal.\n\n--\nPaul Ettestad DVM, MS\nState Public Health Veterinarian\nEpidemiology and Response Division\nNew Mexico Department of Health\nUSA\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Ettestad for his first-hand information and\nthe inclusion of the news release from the State Department of\nHealth, dated 10 Jun 2009:\n\nState confirms 3rd human plague case from Santa Fe County\nAnimal cases also confirmed in Taos and Santa Fe Counties\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe New Mexico Department of Health confirmed today [10 Jun 2009] a\n3rd case of bubonic plague in Santa Fe County so far in 2009. A\n56-year-old man was hospitalized and is back home recovering. The\nDepartment of Health is conducting an environmental investigation at\nthe man's residence to determine if there is any ongoing risk to people.\n\nThe Department also confirmed a plague case in a dog from north of\nthe city of Taos and a cat case from the Arroyo Hondo area southeast\nof the city of Santa Fe. Earlier this month [June 2009] the\nDepartment reported a fatal case in an 8-year-old Santa Fe County boy\nand a case in his 10-year-old sister who recovered. There have been a\ntotal of 3 human cases in New Mexico, all in Santa Fe County, so far in 2009.\n\nTo prevent cases of plague, the Department of Health recommends\n- Avoid sick or dead rodents.\n- Teach children not to play near rodent nests or burrows.\n- Treat pets regularly with an effective flea control product.\n- Clean up areas near the house where rodents could live.\n- Keep pets from roaming and hunting.\n- Sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian.\n\nSymptoms in cats and dogs are similar to humans. Fever, lethargy, not\neating, and swollen lymph nodes (usually in the neck area) are the\nmost common signs.\n\nThere was one human case of plague in 2008 in an Eddy County man.\nThere were 5 human cases of plague in Bernalillo, San Juan, Santa Fe,\nand Torrance counties in 2007 with a fatality. 8 human plague cases\noccurred in New Mexico in 2006 with 3 fatalities.\"\n\nThe southwestern state of New Mexico can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00bF>.\nA map of the state of New Mexico showing the location of Santa Fe and\nthe other counties mentioned in the posting can be found at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/new_mexico_map.html>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, fatal - USA: (NM) bubonic 20090605.2080\nPlague, rabbit - USA (NM) 20090415.1435\n2008\n----\nPlague, human, feline - USA (NM): early season cases 20080127.0340\n2007\n----\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (NM) 20070929.3218\nPlague, feline - USA (NM) 20070914.3055\nPlague, human, septicemic - USA (NM) 20070612.1914\nPlague, human, fatal - USA (NM) 20070608.1875\nPlague, human, secondary pneumonic - USA (NM) 20070607.1846\nPlague, septicemic - USA (NM) 20070504.1447\n2006\n----\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (NM)(02) 20060724.2034\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (NM) 20060717.1960\nPlague, human - USA (NM) 20060601.1526\nPlague, human, fatal - USA (NM) 20060528.1500\n2005\n----\nPlague, human - USA (NM)(02) 20050726.2163\nPlague, human - USA (NM) 20050725.2157\n2004\n----\nPlague, cats - USA (NM) 20040502.1213\n...................................ll/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-06-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "San Juan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eddy County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arroyo Hondo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "216957", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, fatal - USA (02): (NM) risk, prevention", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=216957", "date": "2009-06-11 13:00:08", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - USA (02): (NEW MEXICO) RISK, PREVENTION\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 10 Jun 2009\nFrom: Paul Ettestad <Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n\nThe 3rd human case of plague (_Yersinia pestis_) from New Mexico in\n2009 has been confirmed and only 1 week after the 1st 2 cases. All 3\ncases were most likely exposed via fleabite due to their clinical\npresentations of bubonic plague. Though we will never know the exact\nexposure, one of the risk factors in the 1st 2 cases was that the\nfamily dog was allowed to roam and hunt and then sleep in bed with\nthe children. No flea control products were used on the dog.\n\nThis type of risk has been seen in other human cases in past years\nand serves as a reminder to emphasize flea control product use on\npets, even in dry areas. These are not the typical dog and cat fleas,\nbut plague-infected rodent fleas from various animal species (prairie\ndogs, rock squirrels, wood rats, etc) that may be involved in a\nplague outbreak. The rodent fleas will transiently move to other\nanimals (dogs, cats, etc) from their preferred rodent host when it\ndies, and can be brought into the home by pets that are allowed to\nroam and hunt.\n\nNorth-central New Mexico is having a cooler and wetter late spring\nwhich allows infected fleas to survive longer and to move to the\nburrow entrances after their host rodent has died from plague without\nbeing prone to desiccation in the usual hot and dry environment. This\nincreases the risk that people and pets walking near the burrow\nentrances may have infected fleas jump onto them to try and take a blood meal.\n\n--\nPaul Ettestad DVM, MS\nState Public Health Veterinarian\nEpidemiology and Response Division\nNew Mexico Department of Health\nUSA\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Ettestad for his first-hand information and\nthe inclusion of the news release from the State Department of\nHealth, dated 10 Jun 2009:\n\nState confirms 3rd human plague case from Santa Fe County\nAnimal cases also confirmed in Taos and Santa Fe Counties\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe New Mexico Department of Health confirmed today [10 Jun 2009] a\n3rd case of bubonic plague in Santa Fe County so far in 2009. A\n56-year-old man was hospitalized and is back home recovering. The\nDepartment of Health is conducting an environmental investigation at\nthe man's residence to determine if there is any ongoing risk to people.\n\nThe Department also confirmed a plague case in a dog from north of\nthe city of Taos and a cat case from the Arroyo Hondo area southeast\nof the city of Santa Fe. Earlier this month [June 2009] the\nDepartment reported a fatal case in an 8-year-old Santa Fe County boy\nand a case in his 10-year-old sister who recovered. There have been a\ntotal of 3 human cases in New Mexico, all in Santa Fe County, so far in 2009.\n\nTo prevent cases of plague, the Department of Health recommends\n- Avoid sick or dead rodents.\n- Teach children not to play near rodent nests or burrows.\n- Treat pets regularly with an effective flea control product.\n- Clean up areas near the house where rodents could live.\n- Keep pets from roaming and hunting.\n- Sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian.\n\nSymptoms in cats and dogs are similar to humans. Fever, lethargy, not\neating, and swollen lymph nodes (usually in the neck area) are the\nmost common signs.\n\nThere was one human case of plague in 2008 in an Eddy County man.\nThere were 5 human cases of plague in Bernalillo, San Juan, Santa Fe,\nand Torrance counties in 2007 with a fatality. 8 human plague cases\noccurred in New Mexico in 2006 with 3 fatalities.\"\n\nThe southwestern state of New Mexico can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00bF>.\nA map of the state of New Mexico showing the location of Santa Fe and\nthe other counties mentioned in the posting can be found at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/new_mexico_map.html>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, fatal - USA: (NM) bubonic 20090605.2080\nPlague, rabbit - USA (NM) 20090415.1435\n2008\n----\nPlague, human, feline - USA (NM): early season cases 20080127.0340\n2007\n----\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (NM) 20070929.3218\nPlague, feline - USA (NM) 20070914.3055\nPlague, human, septicemic - USA (NM) 20070612.1914\nPlague, human, fatal - USA (NM) 20070608.1875\nPlague, human, secondary pneumonic - USA (NM) 20070607.1846\nPlague, septicemic - USA (NM) 20070504.1447\n2006\n----\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (NM)(02) 20060724.2034\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (NM) 20060717.1960\nPlague, human - USA (NM) 20060601.1526\nPlague, human, fatal - USA (NM) 20060528.1500\n2005\n----\nPlague, human - USA (NM)(02) 20050726.2163\nPlague, human - USA (NM) 20050725.2157\n2004\n----\nPlague, cats - USA (NM) 20040502.1213\n...................................ll/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The disease, common in north western Uganda and neighboring\nDemocratic Republic of Congo, causes fever, headaches, and fatigue, the\nnewspaper said.\n\n[byline: Fred Ojambo]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Fatalities in plague, infections due to _Yersinia pestis_ are often due to\nspread of the organism outside of the painful bubo into the bloodstream\ncausing septicemic plague and/or spread to the lung causing pneumonic\ndisease. It is this latter form that facilitates person-to-person spread\nvia the respiratory route.\n\nArua and Nebbi are endemic for plague and are located in north western\nUganda as can be seen on a map at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf>. - Mod.LL\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uganda is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?g=443328&g=443360&v=2,31.167,5>. CopyEd.MJ]\nSee Also\nPlague, pneumonic - Madagascar: (Toamasina) 20081026.3383\nPlague, pneumonic, fatal - Congo DR: (Orientale), susp. 20080213.0571\nPlague, fatal - Madagascar (02): (Antananarivo) 20080114.0177\nPlague, fatal - Madagascar: (Antananarivo), RFI 20080111.0141\n2007\n---\nPlague, fatal - Uganda: (Arua, Nebbi), RFI 20071206.3932\nUndiagnosed deaths - Zambia (02): pneumonic plague susp. 20071130.3862\nPlague - Uganda (Masindi) (03): pneumonic 20070309.0835\nPlague - The disease, common in north western Uganda and neighboring\nDemocratic Republic of Congo, causes fever, headaches, and fatigue, the\nnewspaper said.\n\n[byline: Fred Ojambo]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Fatalities in plague, infections due to _Yersinia pestis_ are often due to\nspread of the organism outside of the painful bubo into the bloodstream\ncausing septicemic plague and/or spread to the lung causing pneumonic\ndisease. It is this latter form that facilitates person-to-person spread\nvia the respiratory route.\n\nArua and Nebbi are endemic for plague and are located in north western\nUganda as can be seen on a map at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf>. - Mod.LL\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uganda is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?g=443328&g=443360&v=2,31.167,5>. The disease, common in north western Uganda and neighboring\nDemocratic Republic of Congo, causes fever, headaches, and fatigue, the\nnewspaper said.\n\n[byline: Fred Ojambo]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Fatalities in plague, infections due to _Yersinia pestis_ are often due to\nspread of the organism outside of the painful bubo into the bloodstream\ncausing septicemic plague and/or spread to the lung causing pneumonic\ndisease. It is this latter form that facilitates person-to-person spread\nvia the respiratory route.\n\nArua and Nebbi are endemic for plague and are located in north western\nUganda as can be seen on a map at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf>. - Mod.LL\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uganda is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?g=443328&g=443360&v=2,31.167,5>. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bloomberg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kampala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ugandan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "122266", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Madagascar: (Toamasina)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=122266", "date": "2008-07-27 09:00:28", "main_text": "PLAGUE, WILDLIFE - USA: (COLORADO) RABBIT\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n\nDate: 26 Jul 2008\nSource: The Pueblo Chieftain [edited]\n<http://www.chieftain.com/articles/2008/07/26/news/local/doc488acef1ac429841871677.txt>\n\n\nCrews spray for plague-carrying fleas\n-------------------------------------\nA dead rabbit that tested positive for plague was found near Paradise\nDrive and Platteville Boulevard in Pueblo West, Colorado. Pueblo\nCity-County Health Department crews on Friday [25 Jul 2008] dusted\nprairie dog holes in north Pueblo West to kill fleas that can carry plague.\n\nPlague was confirmed following tests on a dead rabbit found by a\nresident recently in the area of Paradise Drive and Platteville\nBoulevard, according to health department spokeswoman Mary Davis.\n\"All residents in the area have been alerted to that and employees\nare dusting prairie dog holes in that area right now,\" Davis said Friday.\n\nPlague is relatively common in rabbits and rodents. It can infect\nhumans and domestic animals if they are bitten by a flea that has had\ncontact with an infected mouse, rabbit, prairie dog or other wild animal.\n\nThat's why \"everyone should be aware of the risk, no matter where\nthey live,\" Davis said. \"Everyone should always be aware of the\nguidelines for protecting themselves and their pets.\" Pets that spend\ntime outdoors, especially in rural areas, should be treated regularly\nfor fleas and should be kept on a leash in areas where rodents and\nother potential plague carriers are known to live.\n\nHomeowners should clear their properties of plant materials, lumber\nor debris that provide attractive cover for rabbits, mice and rats.\nKnown rodent habitats should be treated with flea powder or other\ninsecticides. When spending time in rural areas likely to harbor\nrabbits, prairie dogs and rodents, wearing insect repellent and long\npants, tucked into socks, can prevent flea bites. Humans should avoid\nall contact with wild animals and rodents that are known to be\npotential carriers of plague, and should never handle a sick or dead animal.\n\nSigns of plague infection include a sudden fever, fatigue and general\nmalaise. The disease is treatable in humans and animals but is more\neasily treated if caught early. For more information, or to report a\ndead or sick animal, call the Environmental Health Division of the\nPueblo City-County Health Department at 583-4323.\n\n[Byline: Loretta Sword]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabite and direct contact with infected animals. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of flea, which, when\ninfected, is a carrier. These fleas generally do not infest other\nanimals unless their natural hosts are unavailable.\n\nRock squirrels (_Spermophilus variegatus_) are closely related to\nCalifornia ground squirrels and are the most significant plague host\nin Colorado. Their principal flea (_Diamanus montanus_) is an\naggressive parasite and will readily bite other animals and people.\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague by infective fleas.\nThey may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially\nwith cats, serve as a direct source of infection.\n\nOften prairie dogs are considered sentinel animals. Cats are also\nvery sensitive. Owners should be alert to any swelling on their\nanimals and if found the pet should be examined by a veterinarian. - Mod.TG\n\nProMED has only ever reported one other rabbit with plague, which was\nlast year, also in Colorado -- see ProMED 2007 archive below. - Mod.JW\n\n[A map of Colorado is available at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/united_states/colorado_90.jpg> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nPlague, prairie dogs, ferrets - USA: (SD)(02) 20080722.2213\nPlague, prairie dog, ferrets - USA: (SD) 20080708.2082\nPlague, feline - USA (WY): mountain lion 20080522.1694\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA: (CO), susp., RFI 20080506.1552\n2007\n----\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (SD) 20070927.3205\nPlague, wildlife - USA (AZ) 20070812.2625\nPlague, ground squirrels - USA (CA) 20070811.2613\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (CO)(02) 20070729.2434\nPlague, squirrel - USA (CA) 20070720.2322\nPlague, squirrel, flea, cat - USA (CO,CA) 20070518.1577\nPlague, squirrels, rabbit - USA (CO) 20070505.1455\nPlague, squirrel - USA (CO)(02) 20070503.1444\n....................tg/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "118781", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic, prairie dogs - USA: (AZ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=118781", "date": "2008-07-27 09:00:28", "main_text": "PLAGUE, WILDLIFE - USA: (COLORADO) RABBIT\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n\nDate: 26 Jul 2008\nSource: The Pueblo Chieftain [edited]\n<http://www.chieftain.com/articles/2008/07/26/news/local/doc488acef1ac429841871677.txt>\n\n\nCrews spray for plague-carrying fleas\n-------------------------------------\nA dead rabbit that tested positive for plague was found near Paradise\nDrive and Platteville Boulevard in Pueblo West, Colorado. Pueblo\nCity-County Health Department crews on Friday [25 Jul 2008] dusted\nprairie dog holes in north Pueblo West to kill fleas that can carry plague.\n\nPlague was confirmed following tests on a dead rabbit found by a\nresident recently in the area of Paradise Drive and Platteville\nBoulevard, according to health department spokeswoman Mary Davis.\n\"All residents in the area have been alerted to that and employees\nare dusting prairie dog holes in that area right now,\" Davis said Friday.\n\nPlague is relatively common in rabbits and rodents. It can infect\nhumans and domestic animals if they are bitten by a flea that has had\ncontact with an infected mouse, rabbit, prairie dog or other wild animal.\n\nThat's why \"everyone should be aware of the risk, no matter where\nthey live,\" Davis said. \"Everyone should always be aware of the\nguidelines for protecting themselves and their pets.\" Pets that spend\ntime outdoors, especially in rural areas, should be treated regularly\nfor fleas and should be kept on a leash in areas where rodents and\nother potential plague carriers are known to live.\n\nHomeowners should clear their properties of plant materials, lumber\nor debris that provide attractive cover for rabbits, mice and rats.\nKnown rodent habitats should be treated with flea powder or other\ninsecticides. When spending time in rural areas likely to harbor\nrabbits, prairie dogs and rodents, wearing insect repellent and long\npants, tucked into socks, can prevent flea bites. Humans should avoid\nall contact with wild animals and rodents that are known to be\npotential carriers of plague, and should never handle a sick or dead animal.\n\nSigns of plague infection include a sudden fever, fatigue and general\nmalaise. The disease is treatable in humans and animals but is more\neasily treated if caught early. For more information, or to report a\ndead or sick animal, call the Environmental Health Division of the\nPueblo City-County Health Department at 583-4323.\n\n[Byline: Loretta Sword]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabite and direct contact with infected animals. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of flea, which, when\ninfected, is a carrier. These fleas generally do not infest other\nanimals unless their natural hosts are unavailable.\n\nRock squirrels (_Spermophilus variegatus_) are closely related to\nCalifornia ground squirrels and are the most significant plague host\nin Colorado. Their principal flea (_Diamanus montanus_) is an\naggressive parasite and will readily bite other animals and people.\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague by infective fleas.\nThey may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially\nwith cats, serve as a direct source of infection.\n\nOften prairie dogs are considered sentinel animals. Cats are also\nvery sensitive. Owners should be alert to any swelling on their\nanimals and if found the pet should be examined by a veterinarian. - Mod.TG\n\nProMED has only ever reported one other rabbit with plague, which was\nlast year, also in Colorado -- see ProMED 2007 archive below. - Mod.JW\n\n[A map of Colorado is available at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/united_states/colorado_90.jpg> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nPlague, prairie dogs, ferrets - USA: (SD)(02) 20080722.2213\nPlague, prairie dog, ferrets - USA: (SD) 20080708.2082\nPlague, feline - USA (WY): mountain lion 20080522.1694\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA: (CO), susp., RFI 20080506.1552\n2007\n----\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (SD) 20070927.3205\nPlague, wildlife - USA (AZ) 20070812.2625\nPlague, ground squirrels - USA (CA) 20070811.2613\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (CO)(02) 20070729.2434\nPlague, squirrel - USA (CA) 20070720.2322\nPlague, squirrel, flea, cat - USA (CO,CA) 20070518.1577\nPlague, squirrels, rabbit - USA (CO) 20070505.1455\nPlague, squirrel - USA (CO)(02) 20070503.1444\n....................tg/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Pueblo\nCity-County Health Department crews on Friday [25 Jul 2008] dusted\nprairie dog holes in north Pueblo West to kill fleas that can carry plague.\n\nPlague was confirmed following tests on a dead rabbit found by a\nresident recently in the area of Paradise Drive and Platteville\nBoulevard, according to health department spokeswoman Mary Davis.\n\"All residents in the area have been alerted to that and employees\nare dusting prairie dog holes in that area right now,\" Davis said Friday.\n\nPlague is relatively common in rabbits and rodents. It can infect\nhumans and domestic animals if they are bitten by a flea that has had\ncontact with an infected mouse, rabbit, prairie dog or other wild animal.\n\nThat's why \"everyone should be aware of the risk, no matter where\nthey live,\" Davis said. \"Everyone should always be aware of the\nguidelines for protecting themselves and their pets.\" Pets that spend\ntime outdoors, especially in rural areas, should be treated regularly\nfor fleas and should be kept on a leash in areas where rodents and\nother potential plague carriers are known to live.\n\nHomeowners should clear their properties of plant materials, lumber\nor debris that provide attractive cover for rabbits, mice and rats.\nKnown rodent habitats should be treated with flea powder or other\ninsecticides. When spending time in rural areas likely to harbor\nrabbits, prairie dogs and rodents, wearing insect repellent and long\npants, tucked into socks, can prevent flea bites. Humans should avoid\nall contact with wild animals and rodents that are known to be\npotential carriers of plague, and should never handle a sick or dead animal.\n\nSigns of plague infection include a sudden fever, fatigue and general\nmalaise. The disease is treatable in humans and animals but is more\neasily treated if caught early. For more information, or to report a\ndead or sick animal, call the Environmental Health Division of the\nPueblo City-County Health Department at 583-4323.\n\n[Byline: Loretta Sword]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabite and direct contact with infected animals. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of flea, which, when\ninfected, is a carrier. These fleas generally do not infest other\nanimals unless their natural hosts are unavailable.\n\nRock squirrels (_Spermophilus variegatus_) are closely related to\nCalifornia ground squirrels and are the most significant plague host\nin Colorado. Their principal flea (_Diamanus montanus_) is an\naggressive parasite and will readily bite other animals and people.\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague by infective fleas.\nThey may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially\nwith cats, serve as a direct source of infection.\n\nOften prairie dogs are considered sentinel animals. Cats are also\nvery sensitive. Owners should be alert to any swelling on their\nanimals and if found the pet should be examined by a veterinarian. - Mod.TG\n\nProMED has only ever reported one other rabbit with plague, which was\nlast year, also in Colorado -- see ProMED 2007 archive below. - Mod.JW\n\n[A map of Colorado is available at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/united_states/colorado_90.jpg> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nPlague, prairie dogs, ferrets - USA: (SD)(02) 20080722.2213\nPlague, prairie dog, ferrets - USA: (SD) 20080708.2082\nPlague, feline - USA (WY): mountain lion 20080522.1694\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA: (CO), susp., RFI 20080506.1552\n2007\n----\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (SD) 20070927.3205\nPlague, wildlife - USA (AZ) 20070812.2625\nPlague, ground squirrels - USA (CA) 20070811.2613\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (CO)(02) 20070729.2434\nPlague, squirrel - USA (CA) 20070720.2322\nPlague, squirrel, flea, cat - USA (CO,CA) 20070518.1577\nPlague, squirrels, rabbit - USA (CO) 20070505.1455\nPlague, squirrel - USA (CO)(02) 20070503.1444\n....................tg/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "101727", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Crayfish plague - UK: (England)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=101727", "date": "2008-07-27 09:00:28", "main_text": "PLAGUE, WILDLIFE - USA: (COLORADO) RABBIT\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n\nDate: 26 Jul 2008\nSource: The Pueblo Chieftain [edited]\n<http://www.chieftain.com/articles/2008/07/26/news/local/doc488acef1ac429841871677.txt>\n\n\nCrews spray for plague-carrying fleas\n-------------------------------------\nA dead rabbit that tested positive for plague was found near Paradise\nDrive and Platteville Boulevard in Pueblo West, Colorado. Pueblo\nCity-County Health Department crews on Friday [25 Jul 2008] dusted\nprairie dog holes in north Pueblo West to kill fleas that can carry plague.\n\nPlague was confirmed following tests on a dead rabbit found by a\nresident recently in the area of Paradise Drive and Platteville\nBoulevard, according to health department spokeswoman Mary Davis.\n\"All residents in the area have been alerted to that and employees\nare dusting prairie dog holes in that area right now,\" Davis said Friday.\n\nPlague is relatively common in rabbits and rodents. It can infect\nhumans and domestic animals if they are bitten by a flea that has had\ncontact with an infected mouse, rabbit, prairie dog or other wild animal.\n\nThat's why \"everyone should be aware of the risk, no matter where\nthey live,\" Davis said. \"Everyone should always be aware of the\nguidelines for protecting themselves and their pets.\" Pets that spend\ntime outdoors, especially in rural areas, should be treated regularly\nfor fleas and should be kept on a leash in areas where rodents and\nother potential plague carriers are known to live.\n\nHomeowners should clear their properties of plant materials, lumber\nor debris that provide attractive cover for rabbits, mice and rats.\nKnown rodent habitats should be treated with flea powder or other\ninsecticides. When spending time in rural areas likely to harbor\nrabbits, prairie dogs and rodents, wearing insect repellent and long\npants, tucked into socks, can prevent flea bites. Humans should avoid\nall contact with wild animals and rodents that are known to be\npotential carriers of plague, and should never handle a sick or dead animal.\n\nSigns of plague infection include a sudden fever, fatigue and general\nmalaise. The disease is treatable in humans and animals but is more\neasily treated if caught early. For more information, or to report a\ndead or sick animal, call the Environmental Health Division of the\nPueblo City-County Health Department at 583-4323.\n\n[Byline: Loretta Sword]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabite and direct contact with infected animals. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of flea, which, when\ninfected, is a carrier. These fleas generally do not infest other\nanimals unless their natural hosts are unavailable.\n\nRock squirrels (_Spermophilus variegatus_) are closely related to\nCalifornia ground squirrels and are the most significant plague host\nin Colorado. Their principal flea (_Diamanus montanus_) is an\naggressive parasite and will readily bite other animals and people.\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague by infective fleas.\nThey may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially\nwith cats, serve as a direct source of infection.\n\nOften prairie dogs are considered sentinel animals. Cats are also\nvery sensitive. Owners should be alert to any swelling on their\nanimals and if found the pet should be examined by a veterinarian. - Mod.TG\n\nProMED has only ever reported one other rabbit with plague, which was\nlast year, also in Colorado -- see ProMED 2007 archive below. - Mod.JW\n\n[A map of Colorado is available at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/united_states/colorado_90.jpg> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nPlague, prairie dogs, ferrets - USA: (SD)(02) 20080722.2213\nPlague, prairie dog, ferrets - USA: (SD) 20080708.2082\nPlague, feline - USA (WY): mountain lion 20080522.1694\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA: (CO), susp., RFI 20080506.1552\n2007\n----\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (SD) 20070927.3205\nPlague, wildlife - USA (AZ) 20070812.2625\nPlague, ground squirrels - USA (CA) 20070811.2613\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (CO)(02) 20070729.2434\nPlague, squirrel - USA (CA) 20070720.2322\nPlague, squirrel, flea, cat - USA (CO,CA) 20070518.1577\nPlague, squirrels, rabbit - USA (CO) 20070505.1455\nPlague, squirrel - USA (CO)(02) 20070503.1444\n....................tg/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "98925", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, wildlife, human exposure -  Russia (Siberia)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=98925", "date": "2008-07-27 09:00:28", "main_text": "PLAGUE, WILDLIFE - USA: (COLORADO) RABBIT\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n\nDate: 26 Jul 2008\nSource: The Pueblo Chieftain [edited]\n<http://www.chieftain.com/articles/2008/07/26/news/local/doc488acef1ac429841871677.txt>\n\n\nCrews spray for plague-carrying fleas\n-------------------------------------\nA dead rabbit that tested positive for plague was found near Paradise\nDrive and Platteville Boulevard in Pueblo West, Colorado. Pueblo\nCity-County Health Department crews on Friday [25 Jul 2008] dusted\nprairie dog holes in north Pueblo West to kill fleas that can carry plague.\n\nPlague was confirmed following tests on a dead rabbit found by a\nresident recently in the area of Paradise Drive and Platteville\nBoulevard, according to health department spokeswoman Mary Davis.\n\"All residents in the area have been alerted to that and employees\nare dusting prairie dog holes in that area right now,\" Davis said Friday.\n\nPlague is relatively common in rabbits and rodents. It can infect\nhumans and domestic animals if they are bitten by a flea that has had\ncontact with an infected mouse, rabbit, prairie dog or other wild animal.\n\nThat's why \"everyone should be aware of the risk, no matter where\nthey live,\" Davis said. \"Everyone should always be aware of the\nguidelines for protecting themselves and their pets.\" Pets that spend\ntime outdoors, especially in rural areas, should be treated regularly\nfor fleas and should be kept on a leash in areas where rodents and\nother potential plague carriers are known to live.\n\nHomeowners should clear their properties of plant materials, lumber\nor debris that provide attractive cover for rabbits, mice and rats.\nKnown rodent habitats should be treated with flea powder or other\ninsecticides. When spending time in rural areas likely to harbor\nrabbits, prairie dogs and rodents, wearing insect repellent and long\npants, tucked into socks, can prevent flea bites. Humans should avoid\nall contact with wild animals and rodents that are known to be\npotential carriers of plague, and should never handle a sick or dead animal.\n\nSigns of plague infection include a sudden fever, fatigue and general\nmalaise. The disease is treatable in humans and animals but is more\neasily treated if caught early. For more information, or to report a\ndead or sick animal, call the Environmental Health Division of the\nPueblo City-County Health Department at 583-4323.\n\n[Byline: Loretta Sword]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabite and direct contact with infected animals. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of flea, which, when\ninfected, is a carrier. These fleas generally do not infest other\nanimals unless their natural hosts are unavailable.\n\nRock squirrels (_Spermophilus variegatus_) are closely related to\nCalifornia ground squirrels and are the most significant plague host\nin Colorado. Their principal flea (_Diamanus montanus_) is an\naggressive parasite and will readily bite other animals and people.\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague by infective fleas.\nThey may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially\nwith cats, serve as a direct source of infection.\n\nOften prairie dogs are considered sentinel animals. Cats are also\nvery sensitive. Owners should be alert to any swelling on their\nanimals and if found the pet should be examined by a veterinarian. - Mod.TG\n\nProMED has only ever reported one other rabbit with plague, which was\nlast year, also in Colorado -- see ProMED 2007 archive below. - Mod.JW\n\n[A map of Colorado is available at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/united_states/colorado_90.jpg> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nPlague, prairie dogs, ferrets - USA: (SD)(02) 20080722.2213\nPlague, prairie dog, ferrets - USA: (SD) 20080708.2082\nPlague, feline - USA (WY): mountain lion 20080522.1694\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA: (CO), susp., RFI 20080506.1552\n2007\n----\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (SD) 20070927.3205\nPlague, wildlife - USA (AZ) 20070812.2625\nPlague, ground squirrels - USA (CA) 20070811.2613\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (CO)(02) 20070729.2434\nPlague, squirrel - USA (CA) 20070720.2322\nPlague, squirrel, flea, cat - USA (CO,CA) 20070518.1577\nPlague, squirrels, rabbit - USA (CO) 20070505.1455\nPlague, squirrel - USA (CO)(02) 20070503.1444\n....................tg/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Pueblo\nCity-County Health Department crews on Friday [25 Jul 2008] dusted\nprairie dog holes in north Pueblo West to kill fleas that can carry plague.\n\nPlague was confirmed following tests on a dead rabbit found by a\nresident recently in the area of Paradise Drive and Platteville\nBoulevard, according to health department spokeswoman Mary Davis.\n\"All residents in the area have been alerted to that and employees\nare dusting prairie dog holes in that area right now,\" Davis said Friday.\n\nPlague is relatively common in rabbits and rodents. It can infect\nhumans and domestic animals if they are bitten by a flea that has had\ncontact with an infected mouse, rabbit, prairie dog or other wild animal.\n\nThat's why \"everyone should be aware of the risk, no matter where\nthey live,\" Davis said. \"Everyone should always be aware of the\nguidelines for protecting themselves and their pets.\" Pets that spend\ntime outdoors, especially in rural areas, should be treated regularly\nfor fleas and should be kept on a leash in areas where rodents and\nother potential plague carriers are known to live.\n\nHomeowners should clear their properties of plant materials, lumber\nor debris that provide attractive cover for rabbits, mice and rats.\nKnown rodent habitats should be treated with flea powder or other\ninsecticides. When spending time in rural areas likely to harbor\nrabbits, prairie dogs and rodents, wearing insect repellent and long\npants, tucked into socks, can prevent flea bites. Humans should avoid\nall contact with wild animals and rodents that are known to be\npotential carriers of plague, and should never handle a sick or dead animal.\n\nSigns of plague infection include a sudden fever, fatigue and general\nmalaise. The disease is treatable in humans and animals but is more\neasily treated if caught early. For more information, or to report a\ndead or sick animal, call the Environmental Health Division of the\nPueblo City-County Health Department at 583-4323.\n\n[Byline: Loretta Sword]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabite and direct contact with infected animals. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of flea, which, when\ninfected, is a carrier. These fleas generally do not infest other\nanimals unless their natural hosts are unavailable.\n\nRock squirrels (_Spermophilus variegatus_) are closely related to\nCalifornia ground squirrels and are the most significant plague host\nin Colorado. Their principal flea (_Diamanus montanus_) is an\naggressive parasite and will readily bite other animals and people.\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague by infective fleas.\nThey may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially\nwith cats, serve as a direct source of infection.\n\nOften prairie dogs are considered sentinel animals. Cats are also\nvery sensitive. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "96991", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, prairie dogs, ferrets - USA: (SD)(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=96991", "date": "2008-01-11 14:00:13", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - MADAGASCAR: (ANTANANARIVO), REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri 11 Jan 2008\nSource: L'Express de Madagascar (transl. - Mod.LM) [edited]\n<http://www.lexpressmada.com/display.php>\n\nThe district of Manjakandriana has been confronted with the bubonic\nplague. With the last information communicated by the service of the\ntransmissible disease, the disease has killed, up to now, 3 people.\nIn addition to a 38-year-old man, an inhabitant of Manankasikely and\ndead on 5 Jan 2008, a 12-year-old is also dead in Ambohitseheno. The 3rd\nvictim lived in the rural district of Ambatolaona, and his death\noccurred in December 2007.\nMoreover, as of 10 Jan 2008, 4 men and a woman are under treatment in\nthe hospital complex of the district.\n\"The rats haven't been beaten down. We have rushed a medical team to\nManjakandriana to address the situation,\" said Dr. Rolland Robinson,\nchief of the service of the Emergenies and Transmissible Diseases within\nthe Ministry of Health, Family Planning and Social Protection.\nIn all the cases, the killing of rats are not done, because \"that\nsupports the profusion of the fleas and, so the recrudescence of the\nmalady,\" said Dr. Robinson. He encourages the cleansing of the places\nand the insecticide use.\n[Byline: Fanja Saholiarisoa]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Dan Silver\n[3 deaths are reported in this press posting but 18 deaths are noted in\nthe web posting below. ProMED would appreciate learning more\ninformation regarding this outbreak.\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial\nresistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al:\nMultidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable\nplasmid. N Engl J Med 1997;337: 677-81). The strain was resistant to\nchloramphenicol, streptomycin and tetracycline but sensitive to\nfluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This\nwas an ominous observation, however, it is not clear if this naturally\noccurring strain has persisted or spread.\nManjakandriana is an administrative region in the central Madagascar\nprovince of Antananarivo. The area can be found on a map of the island\nat:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antananarivo_Province>. - Mod.LL]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 9 Jan 2008\nSource: Les dessous d'information mondiale [edited]\n<http://eldib.wordpress.com/2008/01/10/2175/>\n\nAt least 18 people have died of bubonic plague on the East African\nisland of Madagascar in the past 10 days, and at least 5 patients are\nstill in hospital. Bubonic plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_\nbacillus carried by rat fleas.\nAt the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of\nMadagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages.\n[The following paragraph of this posting is from 1998 (Chanteau S,\nRatsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease\nin Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998;4: 101-104:\n\"Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had \"virtually disappeared\" on\nthe island due to efficient pest-control and good health-management.\nHowever since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic\nplague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each\nyear. In the capital city of Antananarivo more cases are also being\nnotified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has\naccounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.\"\n- Mod.LL]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\n2007\n----\nPlague, fatal - Uganda: (Arua, Nebbi), RFI 20071206.3932\nUndiagnosed deaths - Zambia (02): pneumonic plague susp. 20071130.3862\nPlague - Uganda (Masindi) (03): pneumonic 20070309.0835\nPlague - Uganda (Masindi): pneumonic 20070301.0725\nUndiagnosed deaths - Uganda (Masindi): RFI 20070227.0698\n2006\n----\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Orientale) (03): WHO 20061108.3208\nPlague, pneumonic - Uganda (Arua) 20061020.3022\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Orientale): susp., RFI 20061004.2837\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) (05): susp., RFI 20060929.2786\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) 20060614.1650\n2005\n----\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema) (08): pneumonic plague susp\n20050905.2625\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema): hem fever susp, RFI\n20050805.2274\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (07): (North East) 20050315.0754\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) 20050218.0537\n2004\n----\nPlague - Congo DR (Ituri): susp. 20040730.2083\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20040112.0128\n2003\n----\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) (02): background 20031013.2584\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20031012.2566\nPlague - Uganda (Arua) 20030331.0794\n2002\n----\nPlague - Uganda (Nebbi District): RFI 20021218.6090\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20021130.5938\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi (Nsanje) 20020601.4378\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi, Mozambique 20020510.4160\n1997\n----\nYersinia pestis, antibiotic resistance - Madagascar 19970905.1911\n1996\n----\nPlague - Madagascar 19961023.1790\n1995\n----\nPlague - Madagascar (3) 19951011.0935\nPlague - Madagascar (press report) 19950922.0873\n......................ll/lm/ejp/lm\nThe information transmitted in this electronic communication is intended only\nfor the person or entity to whom it is addressed and may contain confidential\nand/or privileged material.
