Wild carnivores\nin the dog family, such as coyotes and foxes, can develop blood titers\nagainst _Y. pestis_ (1,2) Experimentally, dogs inoculated with _Y. pestis_\ndevelop bacteremia and have had _Y. pestis_ isolated for 10 days from the\noropharynx (1). Subclinically and clinically affected dogs can develop\nantibodies against _Y. pestis_ (1), and people have contracted plague after\nskinning infected coyotes and foxes (1,3).\n\"References:\n1. Poland J, Barnes A. Plague. In: Steele JH, ed. CRC handbook series in\nzoonoses Boca Raton, Fla: CRC Press, 1979.\n2. Rust JH jr, Cavanaugh DC, O'Shita R, et al. The role of domestic animals\nin the epidemiology of plague. I. Experimental infection of dogs and cats.\nJ Infect Dis 1971; 124: 522-6 [although a different reference in the same\njournal actually discusses the serologies: The role of domestic animals in\nthe epidemiology of plague. II. Antibody to _Yersinia pestis_ in sera of\ndogs and cats. Rust JH jr, Miller BE, Bahmanyar M, et al. J Infect Dis\n1971; 124: 527-31. - Mod.LL]\n3. Barnes AM. Surveillance and control of bubonic plague in the United\nStates. Symp Zool Soc London 1982.\"\nPlague is endemic in Mongolia. Marmots such as the Tarvaga, the Tarbagan or\nMongolian Marmot _Marmota sibirica_, a large rodent related to the American\nwoodchuck (_M. monax_), are thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs\nfor _Y. pestis_ in Eastern Asia. The name marmot\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot>) comes from French marmotte, from\nLatin mures monti \"mountain mouse.\"\nA map of the country of Mongolia can be found at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/mongolia.pdf>. The\nprovince of Hovsgol is in the north-central part of the country. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, rodents - Russia (Volgograd, Astrakhan): susp. 20070128.0368\n2005\n---\nPlague - China (Tibet) 20050626.1798\nPlague, camels - Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan: susp. 20050212.0479\n2004\n---\nPlague - Turkmenistan (Dashoguz): susp (02) 20040707.1820\nPlague - Turkmenistan (Dashoguz): susp 20040706.1811\nPlague warning - Russia: RFI 20040427.1178\n2003\n---\nPlague - Mongolia 20030908.2255\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 20030822.2119\nPlague - Kazakhstan (Mangistausk): suspected 20030801.1881\n2002\n---\nPlague - Mongolia 20020919.5361\n2001\n---\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia (Central): correction 20010904.2115\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia (Central) 20010808.1871\n2000\n---\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia & China: background (03) 20000924.1645\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia & China: background (02) 20000920.1620\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia & China: Background 20000802.1290\nPlague, bubonic, marmots - Mongolia: RFI 20000801.1274\n1999\n---\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (05) 19990817.1418\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan 19990802.1322\n1998\n---\nPlague, marmots - Kyrgyzstan (Dzhetyoguz) 19980811.1572\n.................ll/mj/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA (CO)(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=19658", "date": "2007-05-22 22:00:02", "main_text": "PLAGUE, NON-HUMAN PRIMATE - USA (COLORADO)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 21 May 2007\nSource: CBS4denver.com [edited]\n<http://cbs4denver.com/topstories/local_story_141180508.html>\n\nMonkey Tests Positive For Plague At Denver Zoo\n-----------------------------------------------\nTissue samples from a deceased monkey at the Denver Zoo tested\npositive for bubonic plague, zoo officials announced Monday [21 May\n2007]. The zoo learned late Friday [18 May 2007] from the Colorado\nDepartment of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) that the hooded\ncapuchin monkey had the plague.\nThe monkey seemed lethargic last Tuesday [15 May 2007] and was found\ndead Wednesday morning [16 May 2007] by a zookeeper, zoo officials\nsaid. It's unclear if the monkey contracted the disease from infected\nfleas, or if the monkey ingested the remains of an infected squirrel.\nThe zoo suspects it's from ingestion. None of the other monkeys in\nthe troop have displayed signs of illness, but antibiotics have been\nadministered as a precaution.\n\"Denver Zoo remains in regular contact with CDPHE,\" Senior\nVeterinarian Dave Kenny said in a prepared statement. \"And although\nthe risk of contracting plague to people and animals in the area is\nextremely low, we are continuing to emphasize communication with\nvisitors to prevent exposure to squirrels and rabbits.\"\nJohn Pape, an epidemiologist with CDPHE, said the death was\nunfortunate, but not unexpected. \"There are some animal species in\nthe zoo collection, including monkeys, that could be susceptible to\nplague,\" Pape said. \"Infected squirrels and a rabbit have been\nreported in the area and can have contact with the zoo animals.\"\nHooded capuchin monkeys are a small primate native to South America.\n[Byline: Matthew J. Buettner]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n[Please see: <http://www.9news.com/imageenlarge.aspx?storyid=70541>\nfor a photo of a capuchin monkey. Several of the recent postings on\nplague contain more information on the situation in Colorado. Monkeys\ngroom each other so if one has acquired plague from fleas, the\nantibiotic prophylaxis is appropriate. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nPlague, squirrel, flea, cat - USA (CO,CA)20070518.1577\nPlague, squirrels, rabbit - USA (CO)20070505.1455\nPlague, septicemic - USA (NM)20070504.1447\nPlague, squirrel - USA (CO)(02)20070503.1444\nPlague, squirrel - USA (CO)20070427.1381\n....................tg/ejp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The zoo learned late Friday [18 May 2007] from the Colorado\nDepartment of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) that the hooded\ncapuchin monkey had the plague.\nThe monkey seemed lethargic last Tuesday [15 May 2007] and was found\ndead Wednesday morning [16 May 2007] by a zookeeper, zoo officials\nsaid. It's unclear if the monkey contracted the disease from infected\nfleas, or if the monkey ingested the remains of an infected squirrel.\nThe zoo suspects it's from ingestion. None of the other monkeys in\nthe troop have displayed signs of illness, but antibiotics have been\nadministered as a precaution.\n\"Denver Zoo remains in regular contact with CDPHE,\" Senior\nVeterinarian Dave Kenny said in a prepared statement. \"And although\nthe risk of contracting plague to people and animals in the area is\nextremely low, we are continuing to emphasize communication with\nvisitors to prevent exposure to squirrels and rabbits.\"\nJohn Pape, an epidemiologist with CDPHE, said the death was\nunfortunate, but not unexpected. \"There are some animal species in\nthe zoo collection, including monkeys, that could be susceptible to\nplague,\" Pape said. \"Infected squirrels and a rabbit have been\nreported in the area and can have contact with the zoo animals.\"\nHooded capuchin monkeys are a small primate native to South America.\n[Byline: Matthew J. Buettner]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n[Please see: <http://www.9news.com/imageenlarge.aspx?storyid=70541>\nfor a photo of a capuchin monkey. Several of the recent postings on\nplague contain more information on the situation in Colorado. The zoo learned late Friday [18 May 2007] from the Colorado\nDepartment of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) that the hooded\ncapuchin monkey had the plague.\nThe monkey seemed lethargic last Tuesday [15 May 2007] and was found\ndead Wednesday morning [16 May 2007] by a zookeeper, zoo officials\nsaid. It's unclear if the monkey contracted the disease from infected\nfleas, or if the monkey ingested the remains of an infected squirrel.\nThe zoo suspects it's from ingestion. None of the other monkeys in\nthe troop have displayed signs of illness, but antibiotics have been\nadministered as a precaution.\n\"Denver Zoo remains in regular contact with CDPHE,\" Senior\nVeterinarian Dave Kenny said in a prepared statement. \"And although\nthe risk of contracting plague to people and animals in the area is\nextremely low, we are continuing to emphasize communication with\nvisitors to prevent exposure to squirrels and rabbits.\"\nJohn Pape, an epidemiologist with CDPHE, said the death was\nunfortunate, but not unexpected. \"There are some animal species in\nthe zoo collection, including monkeys, that could be susceptible to\nplague,\" Pape said. \"Infected squirrels and a rabbit have been\nreported in the area and can have contact with the zoo animals.\"\nHooded capuchin monkeys are a small primate native to South America.\n[Byline: Matthew J. Buettner]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n[Please see: <http://www.9news.com/imageenlarge.aspx?storyid=70541>\nfor a photo of a capuchin monkey. Several of the recent postings on\nplague contain more information on the situation in Colorado. Monkeys\ngroom each other so if one has acquired plague from fleas, the\nantibiotic prophylaxis is appropriate. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nPlague, squirrel, flea, cat - USA (CO,CA)20070518.1577\nPlague, squirrels, rabbit - USA (CO)20070505.1455\nPlague, septicemic - USA (NM)20070504.1447\nPlague, squirrel - USA (CO)(02)20070503.1444\nPlague, squirrel - USA (CO)20070427.1381\n....................tg/ejp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. None of the other monkeys in\nthe troop have displayed signs of illness, but antibiotics have been\nadministered as a precaution.\n\"Denver Zoo remains in regular contact with CDPHE,\" Senior\nVeterinarian Dave Kenny said in a prepared statement. \"And although\nthe risk of contracting plague to people and animals in the area is\nextremely low, we are continuing to emphasize communication with\nvisitors to prevent exposure to squirrels and rabbits.\"\nJohn Pape, an epidemiologist with CDPHE, said the death was\nunfortunate, but not unexpected. \"There are some animal species in\nthe zoo collection, including monkeys, that could be susceptible to\nplague,\" Pape said. \"Infected squirrels and a rabbit have been\nreported in the area and can have contact with the zoo animals.\"\nHooded capuchin monkeys are a small primate native to South America.\n[Byline: Matthew J. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-05-21 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-05-18 00:00:00", "2007-05-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10412", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, squirrel, flea, cat - USA (CO,CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10412", "date": "2007-03-02 11:00:02", "main_text": "PLAGUE - UGANDA (MASINDI) (O2): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 1 Mar 2007\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: All Africa [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200702280906.html>\n\nAccording to a ministry of health official, the plague that has infected 15\npeople and killed 9 in Masindi (in the north west of Uganda) is in fact, a\nmodified strain of the bubonic plague that killed an estimated 25 million\npeople in just 5 years (1347-1352.)\nThe director general of health services, Sam Zaramba, said the 1st case was\nreported 3 weeks ago but the spread has been contained. There has not been\na new infection reported in the last week. When the 1st deaths occurred in\nMasindi, initial suspicions were that either meningitis or Ebola were the\ncause.\nBlood samples from the deceased were quickly tested [and the results\nconfirmed] that it was bubonic plague that caused the deaths. [The results\nof additional tests performed] in South Africa and in Denmark, further\nconfirmed the suspicions.\nThis is not the 1st time bubonic plague has occurred in Uganda in the\nrecent past. Dr Zaramba said it has occurred on and off in Nebbi [also in\nnorth western Uganda] a number of times over the past 30 years. He further\nsaid that after discovering the occurrence of plague, the 1st priority is\nto contain the spread. Plague originates in rats and spreads to humans\nthrough fleas.\nThe 1st measure taken in Masindi was to stop people from sleeping on the\nfloor. Dr Zaramba said this reduced the prevalence of rats. Smearing floors\nwith cow dung also helps contain the spread of plague as it discourages\nrats from entering domestic environments.\n[byline: Ben Simon]\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nEAI Corporation\n4301 North Fairfax Drive, Suite 200\nArlington, VA 22203\nUSA\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[In yesterday's ProMED-mail posting (Plague - Uganda (Masindi): pneumonic\n20070301.0725), the newswire mentioned that the form of plague in this\ncurrent outbreak was the pneumonic form. In the above newswire describes\nthe plague as bubonic (see yesterday's [1 Mar 2007] moderator comment for a\ndescription of the different forms of plague). In the pneumonic form of\nplague person-to-person transmission occurs at a higher frequency than in\nthe bubonic form as there is respiratory spread from aerosolized droplets.\nThe mortality rate with pneumonic plague is much higher than seen with the\nbubonic form. In the above newswire, the \"observed\" case fatality rate is\n60 per cent, within the range expected with untreated disease. ProMED-mail\nwould appreciate clarification of the epidemiologic picture in this current\noutbreak from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nPlague - Uganda (Masindi): pneumonic 20070301.0725\nUndiagnosed deaths - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Okoro County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Fairfax Drive", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arlington", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10150", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, squirrels, rabbit - USA (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10150", "date": "2007-03-02 11:00:02", "main_text": "PLAGUE - UGANDA (MASINDI) (O2): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 1 Mar 2007\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: All Africa [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200702280906.html>\n\nAccording to a ministry of health official, the plague that has infected 15\npeople and killed 9 in Masindi (in the north west of Uganda) is in fact, a\nmodified strain of the bubonic plague that killed an estimated 25 million\npeople in just 5 years (1347-1352.)\nThe director general of health services, Sam Zaramba, said the 1st case was\nreported 3 weeks ago but the spread has been contained. There has not been\na new infection reported in the last week. When the 1st deaths occurred in\nMasindi, initial suspicions were that either meningitis or Ebola were the\ncause.\nBlood samples from the deceased were quickly tested [and the results\nconfirmed] that it was bubonic plague that caused the deaths. [The results\nof additional tests performed] in South Africa and in Denmark, further\nconfirmed the suspicions.\nThis is not the 1st time bubonic plague has occurred in Uganda in the\nrecent past. Dr Zaramba said it has occurred on and off in Nebbi [also in\nnorth western Uganda] a number of times over the past 30 years. He further\nsaid that after discovering the occurrence of plague, the 1st priority is\nto contain the spread. Plague originates in rats and spreads to humans\nthrough fleas.\nThe 1st measure taken in Masindi was to stop people from sleeping on the\nfloor. Dr Zaramba said this reduced the prevalence of rats. Smearing floors\nwith cow dung also helps contain the spread of plague as it discourages\nrats from entering domestic environments.\n[byline: Ben Simon]\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nEAI Corporation\n4301 North Fairfax Drive, Suite 200\nArlington, VA 22203\nUSA\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[In yesterday's ProMED-mail posting (Plague - Uganda (Masindi): pneumonic\n20070301.0725), the newswire mentioned that the form of plague in this\ncurrent outbreak was the pneumonic form. In the above newswire describes\nthe plague as bubonic (see yesterday's [1 Mar 2007] moderator comment for a\ndescription of the different forms of plague). In the pneumonic form of\nplague person-to-person transmission occurs at a higher frequency than in\nthe bubonic form as there is respiratory spread from aerosolized droplets.\nThe mortality rate with pneumonic plague is much higher than seen with the\nbubonic form. In the above newswire, the \"observed\" case fatality rate is\n60 per cent, within the range expected with untreated disease. ProMED-mail\nwould appreciate clarification of the epidemiologic picture in this current\noutbreak from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nPlague - Uganda (Masindi): pneumonic 20070301.0725\nUndiagnosed deaths - Uganda (Masindi): RFI 20070227.0698\n2006\n---\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Orientale) (03): WHO 20061108.3208\nPlague, pneumonic - Uganda (Arua) 20061020.3022\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Orientale) (02) 20061015.2964\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Orientale): susp., RFI 20061004.2837\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) (05): susp., RFI 20060929.2786\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) (04): background 20060827.2438\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) (03) 20060825.2401\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) (02) 20060627.1787\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) 20060614.1650\n2005\n---\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema) (08): pneumonic plague susp\n20050905.2625\nUndiagnosed deaths - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20040112.0128\n2003\n---\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) (02): background 20031013.2584\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20031012.2566\nPlague - Uganda (Arua) 20030331.0794\n2002\n---\nPlague - He further\nsaid that after discovering the occurrence of plague, the 1st priority is\nto contain the spread. Plague originates in rats and spreads to humans\nthrough fleas.\nThe 1st measure taken in Masindi was to stop people from sleeping on the\nfloor. Dr Zaramba said this reduced the prevalence of rats. Smearing floors\nwith cow dung also helps contain the spread of plague as it discourages\nrats from entering domestic environments.\n[byline: Ben Simon]\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nEAI Corporation\n4301 North Fairfax Drive, Suite 200\nArlington, VA 22203\nUSA\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[In yesterday's ProMED-mail posting (Plague - Uganda (Masindi): pneumonic\n20070301.0725), the newswire mentioned that the form of plague in this\ncurrent outbreak was the pneumonic form. In the above newswire describes\nthe plague as bubonic (see yesterday's [1 Mar 2007] moderator comment for a\ndescription of the different forms of plague). In the pneumonic form of\nplague person-to-person transmission occurs at a higher frequency than in\nthe bubonic form as there is respiratory spread from aerosolized droplets.\nThe mortality rate with pneumonic plague is much higher than seen with the\nbubonic form. In the above newswire, the \"observed\" case fatality rate is\n60 per cent, within the range expected with untreated disease. ProMED-mail\nwould appreciate clarification of the epidemiologic picture in this current\noutbreak from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nPlague - Uganda (Masindi): pneumonic 20070301.0725\nUndiagnosed deaths - Uganda (Masindi): RFI 20070227.0698\n2006\n---\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Orientale) (03): WHO 20061108.3208\nPlague, pneumonic - Uganda (Arua) 20061020.3022\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Orientale) (02) 20061015.2964\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Orientale): susp., RFI 20061004.2837\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) (05): susp., RFI 20060929.2786\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) (04): background 20060827.2438\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) (03) 20060825.2401\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) (02) 20060627.1787\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) 20060614.1650\n2005\n---\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema) (08): pneumonic plague susp\n20050905.2625\nUndiagnosed deaths - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Okoro County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Fairfax Drive", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arlington", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9285", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic, fatal - Tanzania (Manyara)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9285", "date": "2007-03-02 11:00:02", "main_text": "PLAGUE - UGANDA (MASINDI) (O2): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 1 Mar 2007\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: All Africa [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200702280906.html>\n\nAccording to a ministry of health official, the plague that has infected 15\npeople and killed 9 in Masindi (in the north west of Uganda) is in fact, a\nmodified strain of the bubonic plague that killed an estimated 25 million\npeople in just 5 years (1347-1352.)\nThe director general of health services, Sam Zaramba, said the 1st case was\nreported 3 weeks ago but the spread has been contained. There has not been\na new infection reported in the last week. When the 1st deaths occurred in\nMasindi, initial suspicions were that either meningitis or Ebola were the\ncause.\nBlood samples from the deceased were quickly tested [and the results\nconfirmed] that it was bubonic plague that caused the deaths. [The results\nof additional tests performed] in South Africa and in Denmark, further\nconfirmed the suspicions.\nThis is not the 1st time bubonic plague has occurred in Uganda in the\nrecent past. Dr Zaramba said it has occurred on and off in Nebbi [also in\nnorth western Uganda] a number of times over the past 30 years. He further\nsaid that after discovering the occurrence of plague, the 1st priority is\nto contain the spread. Plague originates in rats and spreads to humans\nthrough fleas.\nThe 1st measure taken in Masindi was to stop people from sleeping on the\nfloor. Dr Zaramba said this reduced the prevalence of rats. Smearing floors\nwith cow dung also helps contain the spread of plague as it discourages\nrats from entering domestic environments.\n[byline: Ben Simon]\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nEAI Corporation\n4301 North Fairfax Drive, Suite 200\nArlington, VA 22203\nUSA\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[In yesterday's ProMED-mail posting (Plague - Uganda (Masindi): pneumonic\n20070301.0725), the newswire mentioned that the form of plague in this\ncurrent outbreak was the pneumonic form. In the above newswire describes\nthe plague as bubonic (see yesterday's [1 Mar 2007] moderator comment for a\ndescription of the different forms of plague). In the pneumonic form of\nplague person-to-person transmission occurs at a higher frequency than in\nthe bubonic form as there is respiratory spread from aerosolized droplets.\nThe mortality rate with pneumonic plague is much higher than seen with the\nbubonic form. In the above newswire, the \"observed\" case fatality rate is\n60 per cent, within the range expected with untreated disease. ProMED-mail\nwould appreciate clarification of the epidemiologic picture in this current\noutbreak from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nPlague - Uganda (Masindi): pneumonic 20070301.0725\nUndiagnosed deaths - Uganda (Masindi): RFI 20070227.0698\n2006\n---\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Orientale) (03): WHO 20061108.3208\nPlague, pneumonic - Uganda (Arua) 20061020.3022\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Orientale) (02) 20061015.2964\nPlague, pneumonic - Uganda (Masindi): conf", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8520", "date": "2006-10-04 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR (ORIENTALE): SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 3 Oct 2006\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: UN Integrated Regional Information Networks (IRIN) [edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=55811&SelectRegion=Great_Lakes&SelectCountry=DRC>\n\n[Suspected - Mod.LL] pneumonic plague has, since 16 Aug 2006, claimed 29\nlives and infected another 500 people in the Pawa and Wemba areas of Isiro\nDistrict in northeastern Democratic Republic of Congo, according to the WHO.\nDr. Florent Ekwanzala, an epidemiologist with the WHO, said on Mon 2 Oct\n2006 that a WHO-backed health team comprising a supervisor, laboratory\nnurse and members of an international NGO had collected samples that were\nsent to the National Institute of Bio-Medical Research in Kinshasa to\nconfirm the diagnosis.\nThe WHO team has been informing the local population on how to avoid the\ndisease by taking precautions against flea bites, avoiding the handling of\ncarcasses in plague-endemic areas and contact with infective tissues, or\nbeing exposed to patients with pneumonic plague.\n\"The samples are expected to be compared with those of other lung diseases,\nas it could also turn out to be leptospirosis,\" Ekwanzala said.\nEkwanzala said the same area recently experienced a similar epidemic on a\nsmaller scale, which could have spread from the neighboring region. A few\ncases were recorded in the Reti, Ringa and Zobia zones of the Bas-Uele\nDistrict.\nThere were 19 deaths and 100 suspected cases in June 2006 in the\nneighboring district of Ituri, which, according to the WHO, is the most\nactive breeding ground for human plague in the world, with an average of\n1000 cases per year.\nPlague is endemic in many countries in Africa, in the former Soviet Union,\nthe Americas and Asia. In 2003, 9 countries reported 2118 cases and 182\ndeaths, almost all in Africa.\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D.\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[The relatively low mortality rate reported in the posting suggests\nalternative diagnoses; at least not all the cases are the pneumonic form.\nProMED would like more information about these clusters of possible\npneumonic plague.\nA map of Congo DR showing the northeast Orientale (also written Oriental or\nEastern) province, where Isiro, Ituri and Bas-Uele districts are located,\ncan be found at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/congo_demrep_pol98.jpg>.\nProMED thanks Dr. Joe Dudley for this submission. - Mod.LL] pneumonic plague has, since 16 Aug 2006, claimed 29\nlives and infected another 500 people in the Pawa and Wemba areas of Isiro\nDistrict in northeastern Democratic Republic of Congo, according to the WHO.\nDr. Florent Ekwanzala, an epidemiologist with the WHO, said on Mon 2 Oct\n2006 that a WHO-backed health team comprising a supervisor, laboratory\nnurse and members of an international NGO had collected samples that were\nsent to the National Institute of Bio-Medical Research in Kinshasa to\nconfirm the diagnosis.\nThe WHO team has been informing the local population on how to avoid the\ndisease by taking precautions against flea bites, avoiding the handling of\ncarcasses in plague-endemic areas and contact with infective tissues, or\nbeing exposed to patients with pneumonic plague.\n\"The samples are expected to be compared with those of other lung diseases,\nas it could also turn out to be leptospirosis,\" Ekwanzala said.\nEkwanzala said the same area recently experienced a similar epidemic on a\nsmaller scale, which could have spread from the neighboring region. A few\ncases were recorded in the Reti, Ringa and Zobia zones of the Bas-Uele\nDistrict.\nThere were 19 deaths and 100 suspected cases in June 2006 in the\nneighboring district of Ituri, which, according to the WHO, is the most\nactive breeding ground for human plague in the world, with an average of\n1000 cases per year.\nPlague is endemic in many countries in Africa, in the former Soviet Union,\nthe Americas and Asia. In 2003, 9 countries reported 2118 cases and 182\ndeaths, almost all in Africa.\n--\nJoseph P. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-08-16 00:00:00", "2006-06-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2118-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Qinghai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zobia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ituri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kinshasa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Okoro County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reti", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Isiro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ringa", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4412", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Orientale)(03): WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4412", "date": "2006-10-04 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR (ORIENTALE): SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 3 Oct 2006\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: UN Integrated Regional Information Networks (IRIN) [edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=55811&SelectRegion=Great_Lakes&SelectCountry=DRC>\n\n[Suspected - Mod.LL] pneumonic plague has, since 16 Aug 2006, claimed 29\nlives and infected another 500 people in the Pawa and Wemba areas of Isiro\nDistrict in northeastern Democratic Republic of Congo, according to the WHO.\nDr. Florent Ekwanzala, an epidemiologist with the WHO, said on Mon 2 Oct\n2006 that a WHO-backed health team comprising a supervisor, laboratory\nnurse and members of an international NGO had collected samples that were\nsent to the National Institute of Bio-Medical Research in Kinshasa to\nconfirm the diagnosis.\nThe WHO team has been informing the local population on how to avoid the\ndisease by taking precautions against flea bites, avoiding the handling of\ncarcasses in plague-endemic areas and contact with infective tissues, or\nbeing exposed to patients with pneumonic plague.\n\"The samples are expected to be compared with those of other lung diseases,\nas it could also turn out to be leptospirosis,\" Ekwanzala said.\nEkwanzala said the same area recently experienced a similar epidemic on a\nsmaller scale, which could have spread from the neighboring region. A few\ncases were recorded in the Reti, Ringa and Zobia zones of the Bas-Uele\nDistrict.\nThere were 19 deaths and 100 suspected cases in June 2006 in the\nneighboring district of Ituri, which, according to the WHO, is the most\nactive breeding ground for human plague in the world, with an average of\n1000 cases per year.\nPlague is endemic in many countries in Africa, in the former Soviet Union,\nthe Americas and Asia. In 2003, 9 countries reported 2118 cases and 182\ndeaths, almost all in Africa.\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D.\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[The relatively low mortality rate reported in the posting suggests\nalternative diagnoses; at least not all the cases are the pneumonic form.\nProMED would like more information about these clusters of possible\npneumonic plague.\nA map of Congo DR showing the northeast Orientale (also written Oriental or\nEastern) province, where Isiro, Ituri and Bas-Uele districts are located,\ncan be found at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/congo_demrep_pol98.jpg>.\nProMED thanks Dr. Joe Dudley for this submission. - Mod.LL] pneumonic plague has, since 16 Aug 2006, claimed 29\nlives and infected another 500 people in the Pawa and Wemba areas of Isiro\nDistrict in northeastern Democratic Republic of Congo, according to the WHO.\nDr. Florent Ekwanzala, an epidemiologist with the WHO, said on Mon 2 Oct\n2006 that a WHO-backed health team comprising a supervisor, laboratory\nnurse and members of an international NGO had collected samples that were\nsent to the National Institute of Bio-Medical Research in Kinshasa to\nconfirm the diagnosis.\nThe WHO team has been informing the local population on how to avoid the\ndisease by taking precautions against flea bites, avoiding the handling of\ncarcasses in plague-endemic areas and contact with infective tissues, or\nbeing exposed to patients with pneumonic plague.\n\"The samples are expected to be compared with those of other lung diseases,\nas it could also turn out to be leptospirosis,\" Ekwanzala said.\nEkwanzala said the same area recently experienced a similar epidemic on a\nsmaller scale, which could have spread from the neighboring region. A few\ncases were recorded in the Reti, Ringa and Zobia zones of the Bas-Uele\nDistrict.\nThere were 19 deaths and 100 suspected cases in June 2006 in the\nneighboring district of Ituri, which, according to the WHO, is the most\nactive breeding ground for human plague in the world, with an average of\n1000 cases per year.\nPlague is endemic in many countries in Africa, in the former Soviet Union,\nthe Americas and Asia. In 2003, 9 countries reported 2118 cases and 182\ndeaths, almost all in Africa.\n--\nJoseph P. Congo DR (Ituri) (05) :susp., RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3072", "date": "2006-07-20 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, HUMAN - USA (COLORADO)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed, 19 Jul 2006\nFrom: Mark Liao <markliaohk@gmail.com>\nSource: Durango Herald [edited]\n<http://durangoherald.com/asp-bin/article_generation.asp?article_type=news&article_path=/news/06/news060719_7.htm>\n\nA La Plata County man has tested positive for plague, the 1st\nconfirmed case of human plague since the summer of 2005, when 2 cases\nwere reported in the county, the San Juan Basin Health Department\nsaid Tue, 18 Jul 2006.\nThe man has been treated at a hospital and has been released and is\nrecovering, said Lynn Westberg, director of San Juan Basin Health.\nDuring the past 30 years, there have been 49 reported cases of plague\nin humans in Colorado. Human c s in the USA occurs mostly in rural\nareas, with an average of 10 to 15 cases each year nationwide.\nIn Southwest Colorado, 7 animals -- including squirrels, household\ncats, and prairie dogs -- have tested positive for plague this\nsummer, according to a news release from the health department. \"This\nyear particularly, there seems to be a lot of plague, and it is\nwidespread throughout the county and region,\" Westberg said.\nCats become infected from flea bites or by direct contact with\ninfected rodents. Plague-infected cats will generally have a history\nof roaming freely in rural or semi-rural areas, and their owners\noften report that the felines are known hunters. Infected cats\nfrequently exhibit swelling and sores around the mouth, head and neck\nand appear ill. Pet owners should seek veterinary care for such\nanimals. Because domestic cats can carry infected fleas into the\nhome, it is important to consult a veterinarian for information about\nflea control for pets, health experts say.\n--\nMark Liao\nProgram in Human Biology\nStanford University\nStanford, CA\n<markliaohk@gmail.com>\n[The manifestations of plague in this man were not stated, but it is\nmost likely that this was bubonic plague. A map of Colorado showing\nthe location of La Plata County in southern Colorado, bordering on\nNew Mexico can be found at: <http://pix.epodunk.com/locatorMaps/co/CO_9554.gif>\nProMED thanks Mark Liao for submission of this posting. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (NM) 20060717.1960\nPlague, septicemic - USA (CA) 20060701.1822\nPlague, human - USA (NM) 20060601.1526\nPlague, human, fatal - USA (NM) 20060528.1500\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (CA) 20060419.1148\nPlague, animals - USA (CO): early season cases 20060220.0563\n2005\n----\nPlague, missing laboratory mice - USA (NJ) 20050915.2728\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (CO) 20050819.2440\nPlague, human - USA (NM)(02) 20050726.2163\nPlague, human - USA (NM) 20050725.2157\nPlague, feline - USA (WY): Alert 20050709.1954\nPlague, human - USA (CO) 20050518.1359\nPlague - Brazil (Ceara): RFI 20050428.1180\n.............................ll/pg/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Human c s in the USA occurs mostly in rural\nareas, with an average of 10 to 15 cases each year nationwide.\nIn Southwest Colorado, 7 animals -- including squirrels, household\ncats, and prairie dogs -- have tested positive for plague this\nsummer, according to a news release from the health department. \"This\nyear particularly, there seems to be a lot of plague, and it is\nwidespread throughout the county and region,\" Westberg said.\nCats become infected from flea bites or by direct contact with\ninfected rodents. Infected cats\nfrequently exhibit swelling and sores around the mouth, head and neck\nand appear ill. Pet owners should seek veterinary care for such\nanimals. Human c s in the USA occurs mostly in rural\nareas, with an average of 10 to 15 cases each year nationwide.\nIn Southwest Colorado, 7 animals -- including squirrels, household\ncats, and prairie dogs -- have tested positive for plague this\nsummer, according to a news release from the health department. \"This\nyear particularly, there seems to be a lot of plague, and it is\nwidespread throughout the county and region,\" Westberg said.\nCats become infected from flea bites or by direct contact with\ninfected rodents. Plague-infected cats will generally have a history\nof roaming freely in rural or semi-rural areas, and their owners\noften report that the felines are known hunters. Infected cats\nfrequently exhibit swelling and sores around the mouth, head and neck\nand appear ill. Pet owners should seek veterinary care for such\nanimals. Because domestic cats can carry infected fleas into the\nhome, it is important to consult a veterinarian for information about\nflea control for pets, health experts say.\n--\nMark Liao\nProgram in Human Biology\nStanford University\nStanford, CA\n<markliaohk@gmail.com>\n[The manifestations of plague in this man were not stated, but it is\nmost likely that this was bubonic plague. A map of Colorado showing\nthe location of La Plata County in southern Colorado, bordering on\nNew Mexico can be found at: <http://pix.epodunk.com/locatorMaps/co/CO_9554.gif>\nProMED thanks Mark Liao for submission of this posting. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (NM) 20060717.1960\nPlague, septicemic - USA (CA) 20060701.1822\nPlague, human - USA (NM) 20060601.1526\nPlague, human, fatal - USA (NM) 20060528.1500\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (CA) 20060419.1148\nPlague, animals - USA (CO): early season cases 20060220.0563\n2005\n----\nPlague, missing laboratory mice - USA (NJ) 20050915.2728\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (CO) 20050819.2440\nPlague, human - USA (NM)(02) 20050726.2163\nPlague, human - USA (NM) 20050725.2157\nPlague, feline - USA (WY): Alert 20050709.1954\nPlague, human - USA (CO) 20050518.1359\nPlague - Brazil (Ceara): RFI 20050428.1180\n.............................ll/pg/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Human c s in the USA occurs mostly in rural\nareas, with an average of 10 to 15 cases each year nationwide.\nIn Southwest Colorado, 7 animals -- including squirrels, household\ncats, and prairie dogs -- have tested positive for plague this\nsummer, according to a news release from the health department. \"This\nyear particularly, there seems to be a lot of plague, and it is\nwidespread throughout the county and region,\" Westberg said.\nCats become infected from flea bites or by direct contact with\ninfected rodents. Plague-infected cats will generally have a history\nof roaming freely in rural or semi-rural areas, and their owners\noften report that the felines are known hunters. Infected cats\nfrequently exhibit swelling and sores around the mouth, head and neck\nand appear ill. Pet owners should seek veterinary care for such\nanimals. Because domestic cats can carry infected fleas into the\nhome, it is important to consult a veterinarian for information about\nflea control for pets, health experts say.\n--\nMark Liao\nProgram in Human Biology\nStanford University\nStanford, CA\n<markliaohk@gmail.com>\n[The manifestations of plague in this man were not stated, but it is\nmost likely that this was bubonic plague. A map of Colorado showing\nthe location of La Plata County in southern Colorado, bordering on\nNew Mexico can be found at: <http://pix.epodunk.com/locatorMaps/co/CO_9554.gif>\nProMED thanks Mark Liao for submission of this posting. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (NM) 20060717.1960\nPlague, septicemic - USA (CA) 20060701.1822\nPlague, human - USA (NM) 20060601.1526\nPlague, human, fatal - USA (NM) 20060528.1500\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (CA) 20060419.1148\nPlague, animals - USA (CO): early season cases 20060220.0563\n2005\n----\nPlague, missing laboratory mice - USA (NJ) 20050915.2728\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (CO) 20050819.2440\nPlague, human - USA (NM)(02) 20050726.2163\nPlague, human - USA (NM) 20050725.2157\nPlague, feline - USA (WY): Alert 20050709.1954\nPlague, human - USA (CO) 20050518.1359\nPlague - Brazil (Ceara): RFI 20050428.1180\n.............................ll/pg/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Human c s in the USA occurs mostly in rural\nareas, with an average of 10 to 15 cases each year nationwide.\nIn Southwest Colorado, 7 animals -- including squirrels, household\ncats, and prairie dogs -- have tested positive for plague this\nsummer, according to a news release from the health department. \"This\nyear particularly, there seems to be a lot of plague, and it is\nwidespread throughout the county and region,\" Westberg said.\nCats become infected from flea bites or by direct contact with\ninfected rodents. Plague-infected cats will generally have a history\nof roaming freely in rural or semi-rural areas, and their owners\noften report that the felines are known hunters. Infected cats\nfrequently exhibit swelling and sores around the mouth, head and neck\nand appear ill. Pet owners should seek veterinary care for such\nanimals. Because domestic cats can carry infected fleas into the\nhome, it is important to consult a veterinarian for information about\nflea control for pets, health experts say.\n--\nMark Liao\nProgram in Human Biology\nStanford University\nStanford, CA\n<markliaohk@gmail.com>\n[The manifestations of plague in this man were not stated, but it is\nmost likely that this was bubonic plague. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Ceara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Juan Basin Health", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "La Plata County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Southwest Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1981", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic, human - USA (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1981", "date": "2006-06-14 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR (ITURI)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 14 Jun 2006\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\nSource: WHO Outbreak Reports [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2006_06_14/en/index.html>\n\nAs of 13 Jun 2006, WHO has received reports of 100 deaths of\nsuspected pneumonic plague, including 19 deaths in Ituri district,\nOriental province. Suspected cases of bubonic plague have also been\nreported, but the total number is not known at this time. Preliminary\nresults from rapid diagnostic tests in the area confirm pneumonic\nplague. Additional laboratory analysis, including tests by culture,\nis ongoing on 18 samples.\nIturi is known to be the most active focus of human plague worldwide,\nreporting around 1000 cases a year. The 1st cases in this outbreak\noccurred in a rural area, in the Zone de Sante of Linga, in mid-May 2006.\nA team from Medecins sans Frontieres (Switzerland), WHO and Ministry\nof Health has been in the area to assess the situation and provide\nsupport to the local health authorities. Isolation wards have been\nestablished to treat patients; close contacts are being traced and\nreceiving chemoprophylaxis. However, control measures have been\ndifficult to implement because of security concerns in the area.\nFor more information, see the fact sheet on plague at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs267/en/>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague\npresentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in\ninfectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are\nsecondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague.\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure.\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\nCDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters as being at greatest\nrisk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through\nair ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for\nprophylaxis are tetracyclines, quinolones, or chloramphenicol.\nA map of Congo DR showing Oriental province, where Ituri is located,\ncan be found at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/congo_demrep_pol98.jpg>. - Mod.LL]\n[Of note, this is the same general area where there was a major\noutbreak of pneumonic and bubonic plague in 2005 (see prior\nProMED-mail postings listed below. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema) (08): pneumonic plague susp\n20050905.2625\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema): hem fever susp, RFI 20050805.2274\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (07): (North East) 20050315.0754\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) 20050218.0537\n2004\n----\nPlague, fatal - China (Qinghai) 20041101.2948\nPlague - Congo DR (Ituri): susp. 20040730.2083\nPlague, fatal - Ecuador (Chimborazo) (02) 20040513.1288\nPlague, fatal - Ecuador: RFI 20040510.1264\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20040112.0128\n2003\n----\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) (02): background 20031013.2584\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20031012.2566\nPlague - Algeria (Oran) (04) 20030704.1643\nPlague, bubonic - Algeria (Oran) 20030622.1537\nPlague - Uganda (Arua) 20030331.0794\n2002\n----\nPlague - Uganda (Nebbi District): RFI 20021218.6090\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20021130.5938\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi (Nsanje) 20020601.4378\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi, Mozambique 20020510.4160\nPlague - India (Chandigarh) (04): WHO confirmation 20020220.3592\nPlague, suspected - India (Chandigarh) 20020215.3567\n2001\n----\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20011031.2689\nPlague - Uganda (Okoro County) (02) 20011016.2543\nPlague, suspected - Congo DR 20011011.2484\nPlague - Uganda (Okoro County) 20011009.2459\n........................ll/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Qinghai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Zone de Sante of Linga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Okoro County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ecuador", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ecuador", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1868", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, septicemic - USA (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1868", "date": "2006-06-14 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR (ITURI)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 14 Jun 2006\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\nSource: WHO Outbreak Reports [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2006_06_14/en/index.html>\n\nAs of 13 Jun 2006, WHO has received reports of 100 deaths of\nsuspected pneumonic plague, including 19 deaths in Ituri district,\nOriental province. Suspected cases of bubonic plague have also been\nreported, but the total number is not known at this time. Preliminary\nresults from rapid diagnostic tests in the area confirm pneumonic\nplague. Additional laboratory analysis, including tests by culture,\nis ongoing on 18 samples.\nIturi is known to be the most active focus of human plague worldwide,\nreporting around 1000 cases a year. The 1st cases in this outbreak\noccurred in a rural area, in the Zone de Sante of Linga, in mid-May 2006.\nA team from Medecins sans Frontieres (Switzerland), WHO and Ministry\nof Health has been in the area to assess the situation and provide\nsupport to the local health authorities. Isolation wards have been\nestablished to treat patients; close contacts are being traced and\nreceiving chemoprophylaxis. However, control measures have been\ndifficult to implement because of security concerns in the area.\nFor more information, see the fact sheet on plague at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs267/en/>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague\npresentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in\ninfectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are\nsecondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague.\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure.\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\nCDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters as being at greatest\nrisk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through\nair ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for\nprophylaxis are tetracyclines, quinolones, or chloramphenicol.\nA map of Congo DR showing Oriental province, where Ituri is located,\ncan be found at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/congo_demrep_pol98.jpg>. - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Qinghai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Zone de Sante of Linga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Okoro County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ecuador", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ecuador", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1849", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, cats - USA (AZ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1849", "date": "2006-06-14 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR (ITURI)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 14 Jun 2006\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\nSource: WHO Outbreak Reports [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2006_06_14/en/index.html>\n\nAs of 13 Jun 2006, WHO has received reports of 100 deaths of\nsuspected pneumonic plague, including 19 deaths in Ituri district,\nOriental province. Suspected cases of bubonic plague have also been\nreported, but the total number is not known at this time. Preliminary\nresults from rapid diagnostic tests in the area confirm pneumonic\nplague. Additional laboratory analysis, including tests by culture,\nis ongoing on 18 samples.\nIturi is known to be the most active focus of human plague worldwide,\nreporting around 1000 cases a year. The 1st cases in this outbreak\noccurred in a rural area, in the Zone de Sante of Linga, in mid-May 2006.\nA team from Medecins sans Frontieres (Switzerland), WHO and Ministry\nof Health has been in the area to assess the situation and provide\nsupport to the local health authorities. Isolation wards have been\nestablished to treat patients; close contacts are being traced and\nreceiving chemoprophylaxis. However, control measures have been\ndifficult to implement because of security concerns in the area.\nFor more information, see the fact sheet on plague at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs267/en/>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague\npresentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in\ninfectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are\nsecondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague.\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure.\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\nCDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters as being at greatest\nrisk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through\nair ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for\nprophylaxis are tetracyclines, quinolones, or chloramphenicol.\nA map of Congo DR showing Oriental province, where Ituri is located,\ncan be found at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/congo_demrep_pol98.jpg>. - Mod.LL]\n[Of note, this is the same general area where there was a major\noutbreak of pneumonic and bubonic plague in 2005 (see prior\nProMED-mail postings listed below. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nUndiagnosed deaths - Suspected cases of bubonic plague have also been\nreported, but the total number is not known at this time. Preliminary\nresults from rapid diagnostic tests in the area confirm pneumonic\nplague. Additional laboratory analysis, including tests by culture,\nis ongoing on 18 samples.\nIturi is known to be the most active focus of human plague worldwide,\nreporting around 1000 cases a year. The 1st cases in this outbreak\noccurred in a rural area, in the Zone de Sante of Linga, in mid-May 2006.\nA team from Medecins sans Frontieres (Switzerland), WHO and Ministry\nof Health has been in the area to assess the situation and provide\nsupport to the local health authorities. Isolation wards have been\nestablished to treat patients; close contacts are being traced and\nreceiving chemoprophylaxis. However, control measures have been\ndifficult to implement because of security concerns in the area.\nFor more information, see the fact sheet on plague at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs267/en/>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague\npresentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in\ninfectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are\nsecondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague.\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure.\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\nCDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters as being at greatest\nrisk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through\nair ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for\nprophylaxis are tetracyclines, quinolones, or chloramphenicol.\nA map of Congo DR showing Oriental province, where Ituri is located,\ncan be found at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/congo_demrep_pol98.jpg>. - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Qinghai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Zone de Sante of Linga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Okoro County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ecuador", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ecuador", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209563", "headline": "PRO/ERR> Plague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri): correction", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209563", "date": "2006-06-14 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR (ITURI)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 14 Jun 2006\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\nSource: WHO Outbreak Reports [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2006_06_14/en/index.html>\n\nAs of 13 Jun 2006, WHO has received reports of 100 deaths of\nsuspected pneumonic plague, including 19 deaths in Ituri district,\nOriental province. Suspected cases of bubonic plague have also been\nreported, but the total number is not known at this time. Preliminary\nresults from rapid diagnostic tests in the area confirm pneumonic\nplague. Additional laboratory analysis, including tests by culture,\nis ongoing on 18 samples.\nIturi is known to be the most active focus of human plague worldwide,\nreporting around 1000 cases a year. The 1st cases in this outbreak\noccurred in a rural area, in the Zone de Sante of Linga, in mid-May 2006.\nA team from Medecins sans Frontieres (Switzerland), WHO and Ministry\nof Health has been in the area to assess the situation and provide\nsupport to the local health authorities. Isolation wards have been\nestablished to treat patients; close contacts are being traced and\nreceiving chemoprophylaxis. However, control measures have been\ndifficult to implement because of security concerns in the area.\nFor more information, see the fact sheet on plague at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs267/en/>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague\npresentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in\ninfectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are\nsecondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague.\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure.\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\nCDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters as being at greatest\nrisk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through\nair ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for\nprophylaxis are tetracyclines, quinolones, or chloramphenicol.\nA map of Congo DR showing Oriental province, where Ituri is located,\ncan be found at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/congo_demrep_pol98.jpg>. - Mod.LL]\n[Of note, this is the same general area where there was a major\noutbreak of pneumonic and bubonic plague in 2005 (see prior\nProMED-mail postings listed below. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema) (08): pneumonic plague susp\n20050905.2625\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema): hem fever susp, RFI 20050805.2274\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (07): (North East) 20050315.0754\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) 20050218.0537\n2004\n----\nPlague, fatal - China (Qinghai) 20041101.2948\nPlague - Congo DR (Ituri): susp. 20040730.2083\nPlague, fatal - Ecuador (Chimborazo) (02) 20040513.1288\nPlague, fatal - Ecuador: RFI 20040510.1264\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20040112.0128\n2003\n----\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) (02): background 20031013.2584\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20031012.2566\nPlague - Algeria (Oran) (04) 20030704.1643\nPlague, bubonic - Algeria (Oran) 20030622.1537\nPlague - Uganda (Arua) 20030331.0794\n2002\n----\nPlague - Uganda (Nebbi District): RFI 20021218.6090\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20021130.5938\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi (Nsanje) 20020601.4378\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi, Mozambique 20020510.4160\nPlague - India (Chandigarh) (04): WHO confirmation 20020220.3592\nPlague, suspected - India (Chandigarh) 20020215.3567\n2001\n----\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20011031.2689\nPlague - Uganda (Okoro County) (02) 20011016.2543\nPlague, suspected - Congo DR 20011011.2484\nPlague - Uganda (Okoro County) 20011009.2459\n........................ll/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1601", "date": "2005-09-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED DEATHS - CONGO DR (MANIEMA) (08): PNEUMONIC PLAGUE SUSPECTED\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Clinical Virology\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/jocv>\nDate: Mon 5 Sep 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: IRIN [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/274ed4a3686af8958a66a87dc8a8fa1e.htm>\n\nDRC: epidemic in diamond area identified as pneumonic plague\n------------------------------------------------------------\nAt least 38 people have died, and at least 1300 others are diagnosed with a\ndisease that the UK-based medical NGO Merlin calls a highly contagious form\nof pneumonic plague, which broke out in July 2005 in the remote diamond\nmining area of Libaku ya Suka in the Democratic Republic of Congo's eastern\nManiema Province.\nThe disease has a high fatality rate, Merlin said in a statement released\non Fri 2 Sep 2005. Those infected suffer from high fever and acute\nshortness of breath as well as chest pains, headaches and swollen lymph glands.\nPneumonic plague is a bacterial infection of the lungs and can be easily\ntransmitted from human to human through infected air droplets, infected\nclothing or other contaminated articles, Merlin said.\nThe disease can be treated with antibiotics if identified early enough, but\nMerlin's head nurse, Prosper Tunda, at Libaku ya Suka, said that hospitals\nand health centers in the area were not equipped to deal with this kind of\nemergency. Patients are lying on the floor, as there are not enough beds or\nmattresses, and all the health facilities lack basic equipment and\nessentials drugs,\" Tunda said.\nThe Merlin team is working with other organizations in the area and local\nhealth staff to identify and treat new cases in the Punia, Lubutu and\nObokote districts of the province. Efforts to quarantine infected people is\ndifficult, Merlin said, because many of them are working at an open diamond\nmine in poor sanitary conditions in close proximity to some 8000 other miners.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Some cases may well be pneumonic plague, but it would seem extremely\nunlikely that the large outbreak involving more than 1300 individuals is\ndue to _Y. pestis_ pneumonia, primary or secondary, unless the strain is\nmuch less virulent than usual. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema) (07) 20050905.2620\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(06) 20050823.2482\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(05) 20050822.2466\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(04) 20050817.2410\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(03): bloody diarrhea 20050813.2375\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(02) 20050811.2341\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema): hem fever susp, RFI 20050805.2274\n...............ll/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Those infected suffer from high fever and acute\nshortness of breath as well as chest pains, headaches and swollen lymph glands.\nPneumonic plague is a bacterial infection of the lungs and can be easily\ntransmitted from human to human through infected air droplets, infected\nclothing or other contaminated articles, Merlin said.\nThe disease can be treated with antibiotics if identified early enough, but\nMerlin's head nurse, Prosper Tunda, at Libaku ya Suka, said that hospitals\nand health centers in the area were not equipped to deal with this kind of\nemergency. Patients are lying on the floor, as there are not enough beds or\nmattresses, and all the health facilities lack basic equipment and\nessentials drugs,\" Tunda said.\nThe Merlin team is working with other organizations in the area and local\nhealth staff to identify and treat new cases in the Punia, Lubutu and\nObokote districts of the province. Efforts to quarantine infected people is\ndifficult, Merlin said, because many of them are working at an open diamond\nmine in poor sanitary conditions in close proximity to some 8000 other miners.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Some cases may well be pneumonic plague, but it would seem extremely\nunlikely that the large outbreak involving more than 1300 individuals is\ndue to _Y. pestis_ pneumonia, primary or secondary, unless the strain is\nmuch less virulent than usual. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema) (07) 20050905.2620\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(06) 20050823.2482\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(05) 20050822.2466\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(04) 20050817.2410\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(03): bloody diarrhea 20050813.2375\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(02) 20050811.2341\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema): hem fever susp, RFI 20050805.2274\n...............ll/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
