For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2005-07-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Libaku", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1444", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, squirrel - USA (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1444", "date": "2005-09-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED DEATHS - CONGO DR (MANIEMA) (08): PNEUMONIC PLAGUE SUSPECTED\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Clinical Virology\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/jocv>\nDate: Mon 5 Sep 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: IRIN [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/274ed4a3686af8958a66a87dc8a8fa1e.htm>\n\nDRC: epidemic in diamond area identified as pneumonic plague\n------------------------------------------------------------\nAt least 38 people have died, and at least 1300 others are diagnosed with a\ndisease that the UK-based medical NGO Merlin calls a highly contagious form\nof pneumonic plague, which broke out in July 2005 in the remote diamond\nmining area of Libaku ya Suka in the Democratic Republic of Congo's eastern\nManiema Province.\nThe disease has a high fatality rate, Merlin said in a statement released\non Fri 2 Sep 2005. Those infected suffer from high fever and acute\nshortness of breath as well as chest pains, headaches and swollen lymph glands.\nPneumonic plague is a bacterial infection of the lungs and can be easily\ntransmitted from human to human through infected air droplets, infected\nclothing or other contaminated articles, Merlin said.\nThe disease can be treated with antibiotics if identified early enough, but\nMerlin's head nurse, Prosper Tunda, at Libaku ya Suka, said that hospitals\nand health centers in the area were not equipped to deal with this kind of\nemergency. Patients are lying on the floor, as there are not enough beds or\nmattresses, and all the health facilities lack basic equipment and\nessentials drugs,\" Tunda said.\nThe Merlin team is working with other organizations in the area and local\nhealth staff to identify and treat new cases in the Punia, Lubutu and\nObokote districts of the province. Efforts to quarantine infected people is\ndifficult, Merlin said, because many of them are working at an open diamond\nmine in poor sanitary conditions in close proximity to some 8000 other miners.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Some cases may well be pneumonic plague, but it would seem extremely\nunlikely that the large outbreak involving more than 1300 individuals is\ndue to _Y. pestis_ pneumonia, primary or secondary, unless the strain is\nmuch less virulent than usual. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema) (07) 20050905.2620\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(06) 20050823.2482\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(05) 20050822.2466\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(04) 20050817.2410\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(03): bloody diarrhea 20050813.2375\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(02) 20050811.2341\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema): hem fever susp, RFI 20050805.2274\n...............ll/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Those infected suffer from high fever and acute\nshortness of breath as well as chest pains, headaches and swollen lymph glands.\nPneumonic plague is a bacterial infection of the lungs and can be easily\ntransmitted from human to human through infected air droplets, infected\nclothing or other contaminated articles, Merlin said.\nThe disease can be treated with antibiotics if identified early enough, but\nMerlin's head nurse, Prosper Tunda, at Libaku ya Suka, said that hospitals\nand health centers in the area were not equipped to deal with this kind of\nemergency. Patients are lying on the floor, as there are not enough beds or\nmattresses, and all the health facilities lack basic equipment and\nessentials drugs,\" Tunda said.\nThe Merlin team is working with other organizations in the area and local\nhealth staff to identify and treat new cases in the Punia, Lubutu and\nObokote districts of the province. Efforts to quarantine infected people is\ndifficult, Merlin said, because many of them are working at an open diamond\nmine in poor sanitary conditions in close proximity to some 8000 other miners.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Some cases may well be pneumonic plague, but it would seem extremely\nunlikely that the large outbreak involving more than 1300 individuals is\ndue to _Y. pestis_ pneumonia, primary or secondary, unless the strain is\nmuch less virulent than usual. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema) (07) 20050905.2620\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(06) 20050823.2482\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(05) 20050822.2466\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(04) 20050817.2410\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(03): bloody diarrhea 20050813.2375\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema)(02) 20050811.2341\nUndiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema): hem fever susp, RFI 20050805.2274\n...............ll/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. These figures are based on the\ncurrent situation and a retrospective analysis of cases since 15 Dec 2004.\nLaboratory analysis of specimens is continuing. An isolation treatment\ncenter has been set up by the Ministry of Health with support from Medecins\nsans Frontieres, Belgium.\nContact tracing and follow up of 214 contacts is underway, and social\nmobilization activities are taking place in surrounding areas.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The last WHO update reported only 57 cases. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (05): (North East) 20050304.0660\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (04): (North East) 20050302.0641\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (03): (North East) 20050228.0623\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (02): (North East) 20050223.0575\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) 20050218.0537\n2004\n----\nPlague - Congo DR (Ituri): susp. 20040730.2083\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20040112.0128\n2003\n----\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) (02): background 20031013.2584\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20031012.2566\nPlague - Algeria (Oran) (04) 20030704.1643\nPlague, bubonic - Algeria (Oran) 20030622.1537\nPlague - Uganda (Arua) 20030331.0794\n2002\n----\nPlague - Uganda (Nebbi District): RFI 20021218.6090\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20021130.5938\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi (Nsanje) 20020601.4378\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi, Mozambique 20020510.4160\n2001\n----\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20011031.2689\nPlague - Uganda (Okoro County) (02) 20011016.2543\nPlague, suspected - Congo DR 20011011.2484\nPlague - Uganda (Okoro County) 20011009.2459\n...........................mpp/ll/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. These figures are based on the\ncurrent situation and a retrospective analysis of cases since 15 Dec 2004.\nLaboratory analysis of specimens is continuing. An isolation treatment\ncenter has been set up by the Ministry of Health with support from Medecins\nsans Frontieres, Belgium.\nContact tracing and follow up of 214 contacts is underway, and social\nmobilization activities are taking place in surrounding areas.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The last WHO update reported only 57 cases. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (05): (North East) 20050304.0660\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (04): (North East) 20050302.0641\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (03): (North East) 20050228.0623\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (02): (North East) 20050223.0575\nPlague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) 20050218.0537\n2004\n----\nPlague - Congo DR (Ituri): susp. 20040730.2083\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20040112.0128\n2003\n----\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) (02): background 20031013.2584\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20031012.2566\nPlague - Algeria (Oran) (04) 20030704.1643\nPlague, bubonic - Algeria (Oran) 20030622.1537\nPlague - Uganda (Arua) 20030331.0794\n2002\n----\nPlague - Uganda (Nebbi District): RFI 20021218.6090\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20021130.5938\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi (Nsanje) 20020601.4378\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi, Mozambique 20020510.4160\n2001\n----\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20011031.2689\nPlague - Uganda (Okoro County) (02) 20011016.2543\nPlague, suspected - Congo DR 20011011.2484\nPlague - Uganda (Okoro County) 20011009.2459\n...........................mpp/ll/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2004-12-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Okoro County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zobia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207465", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Congo DR (05): (North East)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207465", "date": "2004-11-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, TULAREMIA, RODENTS, HUMANS - USA (COLORADO)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 9 Nov 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Rocky Mountain Collegian 9 Nov 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.collegian.com/vnews/display.v/ART/2004/11/09/419067c0089df>\n\nHealth officials find dead animals infected with the plague\n-------------------------------------\nLocal health officials have found evidence that the plague and tularemia\nhave been found in dead animals and pets and are alerting the public to use\npreventative measures to avoid the diseases.\n2 pet cats have been diagnosed with the plague [caused by the\nbacterium _Yersinia pestis_] in the past 2 weeks, and a woman died from\nthe plague while visiting the Red Feather Lakes area in August 2004.\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have jointly been working\nwith the Larimer County Department of Health and Environment in monitoring\nthe plague and other infectious diseases.\n\"Plague has always been endemic to this area,\" said LeeAnn Kempton, an\nenvironmental specialist at the health and environment department.\nSo far, 4 feline plague cases have been reported this year. In 1999, a\nwoman died from the plague in the same area that this year's human case\noccurred.\nAnn Watson, public information specialist with the health and environment\ndepartment, said it is rare to find humans infected with the plague and\nsaid those people that are infected come from contact with their pets.\n\"Most of our human cases come from cats. We have had so few cases it is\nhard to make generalizations,\" Watson said.\nCats and other animals can be infected with the plague when they kill and\neat infected rodents that are riddled with infected fleas. From that point,\npets can transmit the disease to humans through bites, scratches or\ndroplets from their coughs. The bacteria can also be transmitted via the\ninfected fleas themselves, which pets can also bring into domesticated areas.\nBubonic plague, the more common form of the plague, occurs when extreme\npain and swelling of the lymph nodes strikes a victim. The groin and armpit\nregion are the most common fleabite locations in humans, according to a\npress release from the health and environment department. The bubonic\nplague is not transmitted person-to-person, but it can spread to the lungs\nto form pneumonic plague, and the victim's close contacts can be infected.\nThough the plague may be rare in humans, rodent populations carry it often,\nsuch as in mice or rats, Kempton said.\nRecently, another bacterium, [_Francisella tularensis, the cause of ]\ntularemia, has been traced in Larimer County in a dead beaver and mouse. A\nman from Loveland was struck with pneumonia caused by tularemia in August.\nTularemia is another rare occurrence in Larimer County and infects humans\nwho handle infected animals such as rodents or rabbits or humans who are\nbit by infected insects, especially ticks and deer flies. Tularemia is a\nbacterial disease that can affect humans or animals from insects that have\nthe disease.\nHealth officials say to take precautions to prevent infections from these\ndiseases. Using insect repellents, avoiding sick or dead rodents, keeping\npets leashed while camping or hiking, and keeping close attention to a\npet's health are all preventative measures.\nAdrienne LeBaily, the county's heath department director, said, \"Although\nthese bacteria are potential bioterror agents, we are convinced that these\nhuman cases were naturally occurring.\"\n[Byline: James Baetke]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org\n[Prairie dogs are often considered the most sensitive sentinel to plague.\nGenerally monitoring prairie dog activity can give one a clue as to when\nthe rodent cycle of plague may be spilling over into other\npopulations. Cats may be one of our most sensitive domestic sentinels.\nPlague generally has 2 forms: pneumonic and bubonic. Pneumonic form can\nspread between people if the contact is relatively close.\nWhile fleas carry plague, ticks carry tularemia.\nTularemia may be acquired from ticks, or from handling an infected carcass,\nfrom inhalation of the bacteria, and from consumption of contaminated food\nor water. Tularemia is not known to spread from person to person.\nBoth of these bacterial diseases can be treated, in pets as well as in\nhuman beings. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nPlague, fatal - China (Qinghai) 20041101.2948\nPlague, squirrels - USA (CO)(03) 20041022.2863\nPlague, squirrels - USA (CO) (02) 20041022.2858\nPlague, squirrels - USA (CO) 20041021.2851\nPlague, feline - USA (CO) 20040901.2440\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (CO)(02) 20040826.2380\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (CO) 20040825.2370\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (CO): alert 20040614.1600\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (TX) 20040520.1355\n..........tg/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\n* *\n* Please support the 2004 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2004.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-08-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Qinghai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Loveland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207457", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Congo DR (04): (North East)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207457", "date": "2004-11-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, TULAREMIA, RODENTS, HUMANS - USA (COLORADO)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 9 Nov 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Rocky Mountain Collegian 9 Nov 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.collegian.com/vnews/display.v/ART/2004/11/09/419067c0089df>\n\nHealth officials find dead animals infected with the plague\n-------------------------------------\nLocal health officials have found evidence that the plague and tularemia\nhave been found in dead animals and pets and are alerting the public to use\npreventative measures to avoid the diseases.\n2 pet cats have been diagnosed with the plague [caused by the\nbacterium _Yersinia pestis_] in the past 2 weeks, and a woman died from\nthe plague while visiting the Red Feather Lakes area in August 2004.\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have jointly been working\nwith the Larimer County Department of Health and Environment in monitoring\nthe plague and other infectious diseases.\n\"Plague has always been endemic to this area,\" said LeeAnn Kempton, an\nenvironmental specialist at the health and environment department.\nSo far, 4 feline plague cases have been reported this year. Tularemia is a\nbacterial disease that can affect humans or animals from insects that have\nthe disease.\nHealth officials say to take precautions to prevent infections from these\ndiseases. Using insect repellents, avoiding sick or dead rodents, keeping\npets leashed while camping or hiking, and keeping close attention to a\npet's health are all preventative measures.\nAdrienne LeBaily, the county's heath department director, said, \"Although\nthese bacteria are potential bioterror agents, we are convinced that these\nhuman cases were naturally occurring.\"\n[Byline: James Baetke]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org\n[Prairie dogs are often considered the most sensitive sentinel to plague.\nGenerally monitoring prairie dog activity can give one a clue as to when\nthe rodent cycle of plague may be spilling over into other\npopulations. Cats may be one of our most sensitive domestic sentinels.\nPlague generally has 2 forms: pneumonic and bubonic. Pneumonic form can\nspread between people if the contact is relatively close.\nWhile fleas carry plague, ticks carry tularemia.\nTularemia may be acquired from ticks, or from handling an infected carcass,\nfrom inhalation of the bacteria, and from consumption of contaminated food\nor water. Tularemia is not known to spread from person to person.\nBoth of these bacterial diseases can be treated, in pets as well as in\nhuman beings. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nPlague, fatal - China (Qinghai) 20041101.2948\nPlague, squirrels - USA (CO)(03) 20041022.2863\nPlague, squirrels - USA (CO) (02) 20041022.2858\nPlague, squirrels - USA (CO) 20041021.2851\nPlague, feline - USA (CO) 20040901.2440\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (CO)(02) 20040826.2380\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (CO) 20040825.2370\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (CO): alert 20040614.1600\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (TX) 20040520.1355\n..........tg/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\n* *\n* Please support the 2004 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2004.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Congo DR (03): (North East)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207451", "date": "2004-11-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, TULAREMIA, RODENTS, HUMANS - USA (COLORADO)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 9 Nov 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Rocky Mountain Collegian 9 Nov 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.collegian.com/vnews/display.v/ART/2004/11/09/419067c0089df>\n\nHealth officials find dead animals infected with the plague\n-------------------------------------\nLocal health officials have found evidence that the plague and tularemia\nhave been found in dead animals and pets and are alerting the public to use\npreventative measures to avoid the diseases.\n2 pet cats have been diagnosed with the plague [caused by the\nbacterium _Yersinia pestis_] in the past 2 weeks, and a woman died from\nthe plague while visiting the Red Feather Lakes area in August 2004.\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have jointly been working\nwith the Larimer County Department of Health and Environment in monitoring\nthe plague and other infectious diseases.\n\"Plague has always been endemic to this area,\" said LeeAnn Kempton, an\nenvironmental specialist at the health and environment department.\nSo far, 4 feline plague cases have been reported this year. In 1999, a\nwoman died from the plague in the same area that this year's human case\noccurred.\nAnn Watson, public information specialist with the health and environment\ndepartment, said it is rare to find humans infected with the plague and\nsaid those people that are infected come from contact with their pets.\n\"Most of our human cases come from cats. We have had so few cases it is\nhard to make generalizations,\" Watson said.\nCats and other animals can be infected with the plague when they kill and\neat infected rodents that are riddled with infected fleas. From that point,\npets can transmit the disease to humans through bites, scratches or\ndroplets from their coughs. The bacteria can also be transmitted via the\ninfected fleas themselves, which pets can also bring into domesticated areas.\nBubonic plague, the more common form of the plague, occurs when extreme\npain and swelling of the lymph nodes strikes a victim. The groin and armpit\nregion are the most common fleabite locations in humans, according to a\npress release from the health and environment department. The bubonic\nplague is not transmitted person-to-person, but it can spread to the lungs\nto form pneumonic plague, and the victim's close contacts can be infected.\nThough the plague may be rare in humans, rodent populations carry it often,\nsuch as in mice or rats, Kempton said.\nRecently, another bacterium, [_Francisella tularensis, the cause of ]\ntularemia, has been traced in Larimer County in a dead beaver and mouse. A\nman from Loveland was struck with pneumonia caused by tularemia in August.\nTularemia is another rare occurrence in Larimer County and infects humans\nwho handle infected animals such as rodents or rabbits or humans who are\nbit by infected insects, especially ticks and deer flies. Tularemia is a\nbacterial disease that can affect humans or animals from insects that have\nthe disease.\nHealth officials say to take precautions to prevent infections from these\ndiseases. Using insect repellents, avoiding sick or dead rodents, keeping\npets leashed while camping or hiking, and keeping close attention to a\npet's health are all preventative measures.\nAdrienne LeBaily, the county's heath department director, said, \"Although\nthese bacteria are potential bioterror agents, we are convinced that these\nhuman cases were naturally occurring.\"\n[Byline: James Baetke]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org\n[Prairie dogs are often considered the most sensitive sentinel to plague.\nGenerally monitoring prairie dog activity can give one a clue as to when\nthe rodent cycle of plague may be spilling over into other\npopulations. Cats may be one of our most sensitive domestic sentinels.\nPlague generally has 2 forms: pneumonic and bubonic. Pneumonic form can\nspread between people if the contact is relatively close.\nWhile fleas carry plague, ticks carry tularemia.\nTularemia may be acquired from ticks, or from handling an infected carcass,\nfrom inhalation of the bacteria, and from consumption of contaminated food\nor water. Tularemia is not known to spread from person to person.\nBoth of these bacterial diseases can be treated, in pets as well as in\nhuman beings. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nPlague, fatal - China (Qinghai) 20041101.2948\nPlague, squirrels - USA (CO)(03) 20041022.2863\nPlague, squirrels - USA (CO) (02) 20041022.2858\nPlague, squirrels - USA (CO) 20041021.2851\nPlague, feline - USA (CO) 20040901.2440\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (CO)(02) 20040826.2380\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (CO) 20040825.2370\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (CO): alert 20040614.1600\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (TX) 20040520.1355\n..........tg/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\n* *\n* Please support the 2004 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2004.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-08-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Qinghai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Loveland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207423", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Congo DR (02): (North East)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207423", "date": "2004-11-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, TULAREMIA, RODENTS, HUMANS - USA (COLORADO)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 9 Nov 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Rocky Mountain Collegian 9 Nov 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.collegian.com/vnews/display.v/ART/2004/11/09/419067c0089df>\n\nHealth officials find dead animals infected with the plague\n-------------------------------------\nLocal health officials have found evidence that the plague and tularemia\nhave been found in dead animals and pets and are alerting the public to use\npreventative measures to avoid the diseases.\n2 pet cats have been diagnosed with the plague [caused by the\nbacterium _Yersinia pestis_] in the past 2 weeks, and a woman died from\nthe plague while visiting the Red Feather Lakes area in August 2004.\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have jointly been working\nwith the Larimer County Department of Health and Environment in monitoring\nthe plague and other infectious diseases.\n\"Plague has always been endemic to this area,\" said LeeAnn Kempton, an\nenvironmental specialist at the health and environment department.\nSo far, 4 feline plague cases have been reported this year. In 1999, a\nwoman died from the plague in the same area that this year's human case\noccurred.\nAnn Watson, public information specialist with the health and environment\ndepartment, said it is rare to find humans infected with the plague and\nsaid those people that are infected come from contact with their pets.\n\"Most of our human cases come from cats. We have had so few cases it is\nhard to make generalizations,\" Watson said.\nCats and other animals can be infected with the plague when they kill and\neat infected rodents that are riddled with infected fleas. From that point,\npets can transmit the disease to humans through bites, scratches or\ndroplets from their coughs. The bacteria can also be transmitted via the\ninfected fleas themselves, which pets can also bring into domesticated areas.\nBubonic plague, the more common form of the plague, occurs when extreme\npain and swelling of the lymph nodes strikes a victim. The groin and armpit\nregion are the most common fleabite locations in humans, according to a\npress release from the health and environment department. The bubonic\nplague is not transmitted person-to-person, but it can spread to the lungs\nto form pneumonic plague, and the victim's close contacts can be infected.\nThough the plague may be rare in humans, rodent populations carry it often,\nsuch as in mice or rats, Kempton said.\nRecently, another bacterium, [_Francisella tularensis, the cause of ]\ntularemia, has been traced in Larimer County in a dead beaver and mouse. A\nman from Loveland was struck with pneumonia caused by tularemia in August.\nTularemia is another rare occurrence in Larimer County and infects humans\nwho handle infected animals such as rodents or rabbits or humans who are\nbit by infected insects, especially ticks and deer flies. Tularemia is a\nbacterial disease that can affect humans or animals from insects that have\nthe disease.\nHealth officials say to take precautions to prevent infections from these\ndiseases. Using insect repellents, avoiding sick or dead rodents, keeping\npets leashed while camping or hiking, and keeping close attention to a\npet's health are all preventative measures.\nAdrienne LeBaily, the county's heath department director, said, \"Although\nthese bacteria are potential bioterror agents, we are convinced that these\nhuman cases were naturally occurring.\"\n[Byline: James Baetke]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org\n[Prairie dogs are often considered the most sensitive sentinel to plague.\nGenerally monitoring prairie dog activity can give one a clue as to when\nthe rodent cycle of plague may be spilling over into other\npopulations. Cats may be one of our most sensitive domestic sentinels.\nPlague generally has 2 forms: pneumonic and bubonic. Pneumonic form can\nspread between people if the contact is relatively close.\nWhile fleas carry plague, ticks carry tularemia.\nTularemia may be acquired from ticks, or from handling an infected carcass,\nfrom inhalation of the bacteria, and from consumption of contaminated food\nor water. Tularemia is not known to spread from person to person.\nBoth of these bacterial diseases can be treated, in pets as well as in\nhuman beings. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nPlague, fatal - China (Qinghai) 20041101.2948\nPlague, squirrels - USA (CO)(03) 20041022.2863\nPlague, squirrels - USA (CO) (02) 20041022.2858\nPlague, squirrels - USA (CO) 20041021.2851\nPlague, feline - USA (CO) 20040901.2440\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (CO)(02) 20040826.2380\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (CO) 20040825.2370\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (CO): alert 20040614.1600\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (TX) 20040520.1355\n..........tg/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\n* *\n* Please support the 2004 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2004.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Tularemia is a\nbacterial disease that can affect humans or animals from insects that have\nthe disease.\nHealth officials say to take precautions to prevent infections from these\ndiseases. Tularemia is a\nbacterial disease that can affect humans or animals from insects that have\nthe disease.\nHealth officials say to take precautions to prevent infections from these\ndiseases. Tularemia is a\nbacterial disease that can affect humans or animals from insects that have\nthe disease.\nHealth officials say to take precautions to prevent infections from these\ndiseases. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-08-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Qinghai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Loveland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206848", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, tularemia, rodents, human - USA (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206848", "date": "2004-11-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, TULAREMIA, RODENTS, HUMANS - USA (COLORADO)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 9 Nov 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Rocky Mountain Collegian 9 Nov 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.collegian.com/vnews/display.v/ART/2004/11/09/419067c0089df>\n\nHealth officials find dead animals infected with the plague\n-------------------------------------\nLocal health officials have found evidence that the plague and tularemia\nhave been found in dead animals and pets and are alerting the public to use\npreventative measures to avoid the diseases.\n2 pet cats have been diagnosed with the plague [caused by the\nbacterium _Yersinia pestis_] in the past 2 weeks, and a woman died from\nthe plague while visiting the Red Feather Lakes area in August 2004.\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have jointly been working\nwith the Larimer County Department of Health and Environment in monitoring\nthe plague and other infectious diseases.\n\"Plague has always been endemic to this area,\" said LeeAnn Kempton, an\nenvironmental specialist at the health and environment department.\nSo far, 4 feline plague cases have been reported this year. In 1999, a\nwoman died from the plague in the same area that this year's human case\noccurred.\nAnn Watson, public information specialist with the health and environment\ndepartment, said it is rare to find humans infected with the plague and\nsaid those people that are infected come from contact with their pets.\n\"Most of our human cases come from cats. We have had so few cases it is\nhard to make generalizations,\" Watson said.\nCats and other animals can be infected with the plague when they kill and\neat infected rodents that are riddled with infected fleas. From that point,\npets can transmit the disease to humans through bites, scratches or\ndroplets from their coughs. The bacteria can also be transmitted via the\ninfected fleas themselves, which pets can also bring into domesticated areas.\nBubonic plague, the more common form of the plague, occurs when extreme\npain and swelling of the lymph nodes strikes a victim. The groin and armpit\nregion are the most common fleabite locations in humans, according to a\npress release from the health and environment department. The bubonic\nplague is not transmitted person-to-person, but it can spread to the lungs\nto form pneumonic plague, and the victim's close contacts can be infected.\nThough the plague may be rare in humans, rodent populations carry it often,\nsuch as in mice or rats, Kempton said.\nRecently, another bacterium, [_Francisella tularensis, the cause of ]\ntularemia, has been traced in Larimer County in a dead beaver and mouse. A\nman from Loveland was struck with pneumonia caused by tularemia in August.\nTularemia is another rare occurrence in Larimer County and infects humans\nwho handle infected animals such as rodents or rabbits or humans who are\nbit by infected insects, especially ticks and deer flies. Tularemia is a\nbacterial disease that can affect humans or animals from insects that have\nthe disease.\nHealth officials say to take precautions to prevent infections from these\ndiseases. Using insect repellents, avoiding sick or dead rodents, keeping\npets leashed while camping or hiking, and keeping close attention to a\npet's health are all preventative measures.\nAdrienne LeBaily, the county's heath department director, said, \"Although\nthese bacteria are potential bioterror agents, we are convinced that these\nhuman cases were naturally occurring.\"\n[Byline: James Baetke]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org\n[Prairie dogs are often considered the most sensitive sentinel to plague.\nGenerally monitoring prairie dog activity can give one a clue as to when\nthe rodent cycle of plague may be spilling over into other\npopulations. Cats may be one of our most sensitive domestic sentinels.\nPlague generally has 2 forms: pneumonic and bubonic. Pneumonic form can\nspread between people if the contact is relatively close.\nWhile fleas carry plague, ticks carry tularemia.\nTularemia may be acquired from ticks, or from handling an infected carcass,\nfrom inhalation of the bacteria, and from consumption of contaminated food\nor water. Tularemia is not known to spread from person to person.\nBoth of these bacterial diseases can be treated, in pets as well as in\nhuman beings. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nPlague, fatal - China (Qinghai) 20041101.2948\nPlague, squirrels - USA (CO)(03) 20041022.2863\nPlague, squirrels - USA (CO) (02) 20041022.2858\nPlague, squirrels - USA (CO) 20041021.2851\nPlague, feline - USA (CO) 20040901.2440\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (CO)(02) 20040826.2380\nPlague, bubonic, human - USA (CO) 20040825.2370\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (CO): alert 20040614.1600\nPlague, prairie dogs - USA (TX) 20040520.1355\n..........tg/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\n* *\n* Please support the 2004 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2004.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-08-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Qinghai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Loveland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206787", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, fatal - China (Qinghai)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206787", "date": "2004-07-07 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - TURKMENISTAN (DASHOGUZ): SUSPECTED (02)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Sun 6 Jun 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Gundogar, Turkmenistan forum, 6 Jun 2004 [translated by Mod.NR, edited]\n<http://www.gundogar.org/?topic_id=8&id=556>\n\n1st cases of bubonic plague in 20 years have been reported in Turkmenistan\n-----------------------------------------------\nAn epidemic of plague began in May 2004. There have already been more\nthan 20 deaths in Turkmenistan. News about the plague was delivered\nby a German humanitarian aid company that works at the Uzbek-Turkmen\nborder in the north Karakums in the Tashhovuz region. According to a\nspecialist, this is the most serious outbreak in the last 20-30 years.\nAccording to radio \"German wave\" (Nemezkaya volna), during a recent\nweek, 7 people died, in the Turkmen city Mari, from plague. There\nhave been fatal cases in Ashgabad (capital of Turkmenistan) as well.\nUnfortunately, there is no reliable information from Turkmenistan,\nfrom the Russia epidemiological surveillance center, or from WHO.\nAccording to the chief sanitary physician of Russia, Gennadiy\nOnishenko, everything associated with acute diseases in Turkmenistan\nis kept secret.\nTurkmenistan officials have made some efforts to prevent the spread\nof the epidemic. Quarantine was introduced in several of the\nhospitals of Ashgabad, and public pools are closed.\nAccording to Gennadiy Onishenko, carriers of plague in Central Asia\nare camels. If a camel dies, people usually eat the meat. However,\npeople will not be infected with plague if they cook the meat\nthoroughly [and avoid contamination with the uncooked meat - Mod. LL].\nUzbekistan has taken serious measures to prevent the spread of this\ndangerous infection. Transportation of domestic animals across the\nborder, including camels, is prohibited, and people living near the\nborders have been assessed. So far, according to official data, there\nhave been no human cases of plague registered in Uzbekistan.\nThere are no quarantine measures established in Russia. According to\nOnishenko, all elements of the transportation system of Central Asia,\nincluding airports and trains, have been notified.\nThe last case of plague in Turkmenistan was reported 25 years ago.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 6 Jul 2004\nFrom: Wendy Orent <orentw@mindspring.com> [edited]\n\nAccording to the moderator (LL), Kazakhstan is the only former Soviet\nrepublic reporting plague. This is, in part, because the Soviet Union\nactively suppressed all reports of plague outbreaks. In fact, in\n1949-50, there was a sizeable outbreak of pneumonic plague, which may\nhave killed upwards of 100 people, according to Dr. Lev A. Melnikov,\nwho was an eyewitness. Melnikov attributed the outbreak to the\ndangerous plague reservoir _Rhombomys optimus_ (the great gerbil.). I\nreported this in my recent book, Plague: The Mysterious Past and\nTerrifying Future of the World's Most Dangerous Disease, pp. 27-29.\n[The Free Press, New York, USA, 2004]\nPlague, and its reservoirs, are no respecters of borders, and the\nconditions prevailing in Kazhakstan (the presence of ancient\nreservoirs of gerbils and marmots) are also found in Turkmenistan.\nAtabekov is certainly correct that the territory of Turkmenistan is\nan endemic focus of plague, and there is no reason to discount\nreports of plague in Turkmenistan out of hand.\n--\nWendy Orent\n<orentw@mindspring.com>\nSee Also\nPlague - There have already been more\nthan 20 deaths in Turkmenistan. News about the plague was delivered\nby a German humanitarian aid company that works at the Uzbek-Turkmen\nborder in the north Karakums in the Tashhovuz region. According to a\nspecialist, this is the most serious outbreak in the last 20-30 years.\nAccording to radio \"German wave\" (Nemezkaya volna), during a recent\nweek, 7 people died, in the Turkmen city Mari, from plague. There\nhave been fatal cases in Ashgabad (capital of Turkmenistan) as well.\nUnfortunately, there is no reliable information from Turkmenistan,\nfrom the Russia epidemiological surveillance center, or from WHO.\nAccording to the chief sanitary physician of Russia, Gennadiy\nOnishenko, everything associated with acute diseases in Turkmenistan\nis kept secret.\nTurkmenistan officials have made some efforts to prevent the spread\nof the epidemic. Quarantine was introduced in several of the\nhospitals of Ashgabad, and public pools are closed.\nAccording to Gennadiy Onishenko, carriers of plague in Central Asia\nare camels. If a camel dies, people usually eat the meat. However,\npeople will not be infected with plague if they cook the meat\nthoroughly [and avoid contamination with the uncooked meat - Mod. LL].\nUzbekistan has taken serious measures to prevent the spread of this\ndangerous infection. Transportation of domestic animals across the\nborder, including camels, is prohibited, and people living near the\nborders have been assessed. So far, according to official data, there\nhave been no human cases of plague registered in Uzbekistan.\nThere are no quarantine measures established in Russia. According to\nOnishenko, all elements of the transportation system of Central Asia,\nincluding airports and trains, have been notified.\nThe last case of plague in Turkmenistan was reported 25 years ago.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 6 Jul 2004\nFrom: Wendy Orent <orentw@mindspring.com> [edited]\n\nAccording to the moderator (LL), Kazakhstan is the only former Soviet\nrepublic reporting plague. This is, in part, because the Soviet Union\nactively suppressed all reports of plague outbreaks. In fact, in\n1949-50, there was a sizeable outbreak of pneumonic plague, which may\nhave killed upwards of 100 people, according to Dr. Lev A. Melnikov,\nwho was an eyewitness. Melnikov attributed the outbreak to the\ndangerous plague reservoir _Rhombomys optimus_ (the great gerbil.). I\nreported this in my recent book, Plague: The Mysterious Past and\nTerrifying Future of the World's Most Dangerous Disease, pp. 27-29.\n[The Free Press, New York, USA, 2004]\nPlague, and its reservoirs, are no respecters of borders, and the\nconditions prevailing in Kazhakstan (the presence of ancient\nreservoirs of gerbils and marmots) are also found in Turkmenistan.\nAtabekov is certainly correct that the territory of Turkmenistan is\nan endemic focus of plague, and there is no reason to discount\nreports of plague in Turkmenistan out of hand.\n--\nWendy Orent\n<orentw@mindspring.com>\nSee Also\nPlague - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-06-06 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Okoro County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aktyubinsk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkmenistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ashgabad", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gennadiy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uzbekistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ecuador", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "kazakhstan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ecuador", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206749", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, squirrels - USA (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206749", "date": "2004-07-07 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - TURKMENISTAN (DASHOGUZ): SUSPECTED (02)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Sun 6 Jun 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Gundogar, Turkmenistan forum, 6 Jun 2004 [translated by Mod.NR, edited]\n<http://www.gundogar.org/?topic_id=8&id=556>\n\n1st cases of bubonic plague in 20 years have been reported in Turkmenistan\n-----------------------------------------------\nAn epidemic of plague began in May 2004. There have already been more\nthan 20 deaths in Turkmenistan. News about the plague was delivered\nby a German humanitarian aid company that works at the Uzbek-Turkmen\nborder in the north Karakums in the Tashhovuz region. According to a\nspecialist, this is the most serious outbreak in the last 20-30 years.\nAccording to radio \"German wave\" (Nemezkaya volna), during a recent\nweek, 7 people died, in the Turkmen city Mari, from plague. There\nhave been fatal cases in Ashgabad (capital of Turkmenistan) as well.\nUnfortunately, there is no reliable information from Turkmenistan,\nfrom the Russia epidemiological surveillance center, or from WHO.\nAccording to the chief sanitary physician of Russia, Gennadiy\nOnishenko, everything associated with acute diseases in Turkmenistan\nis kept secret.\nTurkmenistan officials have made some efforts to prevent the spread\nof the epidemic. Quarantine was introduced in several of the\nhospitals of Ashgabad, and public pools are closed.\nAccording to Gennadiy Onishenko, carriers of plague in Central Asia\nare camels. If a camel dies, people usually eat the meat. However,\npeople will not be infected with plague if they cook the meat\nthoroughly [and avoid contamination with the uncooked meat - Mod. LL].\nUzbekistan has taken serious measures to prevent the spread of this\ndangerous infection. Transportation of domestic animals across the\nborder, including camels, is prohibited, and people living near the\nborders have been assessed. So far, according to official data, there\nhave been no human cases of plague registered in Uzbekistan.\nThere are no quarantine measures established in Russia. According to\nOnishenko, all elements of the transportation system of Central Asia,\nincluding airports and trains, have been notified.\nThe last case of plague in Turkmenistan was reported 25 years ago.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 6 Jul 2004\nFrom: Wendy Orent <orentw@mindspring.com> [edited]\n\nAccording to the moderator (LL), Kazakhstan is the only former Soviet\nrepublic reporting plague. This is, in part, because the Soviet Union\nactively suppressed all reports of plague outbreaks. In fact, in\n1949-50, there was a sizeable outbreak of pneumonic plague, which may\nhave killed upwards of 100 people, according to Dr. Lev A. Melnikov,\nwho was an eyewitness. Melnikov attributed the outbreak to the\ndangerous plague reservoir _Rhombomys optimus_ (the great gerbil.). I\nreported this in my recent book, Plague: The Mysterious Past and\nTerrifying Future of the World's Most Dangerous Disease, pp. 27-29.\n[The Free Press, New York, USA, 2004]\nPlague, and its reservoirs, are no respecters of borders, and the\nconditions prevailing in Kazhakstan (the presence of ancient\nreservoirs of gerbils and marmots) are also found in Turkmenistan.\nAtabekov is certainly correct that the territory of Turkmenistan is\nan endemic focus of plague, and there is no reason to discount\nreports of plague in Turkmenistan out of hand.\n--\nWendy Orent\n<orentw@mindspring.com>\nSee Also\nPlague - There have already been more\nthan 20 deaths in Turkmenistan. News about the plague was delivered\nby a German humanitarian aid company that works at the Uzbek-Turkmen\nborder in the north Karakums in the Tashhovuz region. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-06-06 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Okoro County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aktyubinsk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkmenistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ashgabad", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gennadiy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uzbekistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ecuador", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "kazakhstan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ecuador", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206235", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR (Ituri): susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206235", "date": "2004-07-07 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - TURKMENISTAN (DASHOGUZ): SUSPECTED (02)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Sun 6 Jun 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Gundogar, Turkmenistan forum, 6 Jun 2004 [translated by Mod.NR, edited]\n<http://www.gundogar.org/?topic_id=8&id=556>\n\n1st cases of bubonic plague in 20 years have been reported in Turkmenistan\n-----------------------------------------------\nAn epidemic of plague began in May 2004. There have already been more\nthan 20 deaths in Turkmenistan. News about the plague was delivered\nby a German humanitarian aid company that works at the Uzbek-Turkmen\nborder in the north Karakums in the Tashhovuz region. According to a\nspecialist, this is the most serious outbreak in the last 20-30 years.\nAccording to radio \"German wave\" (Nemezkaya volna), during a recent\nweek, 7 people died, in the Turkmen city Mari, from plague. There\nhave been fatal cases in Ashgabad (capital of Turkmenistan) as well.\nUnfortunately, there is no reliable information from Turkmenistan,\nfrom the Russia epidemiological surveillance center, or from WHO.\nAccording to the chief sanitary physician of Russia, Gennadiy\nOnishenko, everything associated with acute diseases in Turkmenistan\nis kept secret.\nTurkmenistan officials have made some efforts to prevent the spread\nof the epidemic. Quarantine was introduced in several of the\nhospitals of Ashgabad, and public pools are closed.\nAccording to Gennadiy Onishenko, carriers of plague in Central Asia\nare camels. If a camel dies, people usually eat the meat. However,\npeople will not be infected with plague if they cook the meat\nthoroughly [and avoid contamination with the uncooked meat - Mod. LL].\nUzbekistan has taken serious measures to prevent the spread of this\ndangerous infection. Transportation of domestic animals across the\nborder, including camels, is prohibited, and people living near the\nborders have been assessed. So far, according to official data, there\nhave been no human cases of plague registered in Uzbekistan.\nThere are no quarantine measures established in Russia. According to\nOnishenko, all elements of the transportation system of Central Asia,\nincluding airports and trains, have been notified.\nThe last case of plague in Turkmenistan was reported 25 years ago.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 6 Jul 2004\nFrom: Wendy Orent <orentw@mindspring.com> [edited]\n\nAccording to the moderator (LL), Kazakhstan is the only former Soviet\nrepublic reporting plague. This is, in part, because the Soviet Union\nactively suppressed all reports of plague outbreaks. In fact, in\n1949-50, there was a sizeable outbreak of pneumonic plague, which may\nhave killed upwards of 100 people, according to Dr. Lev A. Melnikov,\nwho was an eyewitness. Melnikov attributed the outbreak to the\ndangerous plague reservoir _Rhombomys optimus_ (the great gerbil.). I\nreported this in my recent book, Plague: The Mysterious Past and\nTerrifying Future of the World's Most Dangerous Disease, pp. 27-29.\n[The Free Press, New York, USA, 2004]\nPlague, and its reservoirs, are no respecters of borders, and the\nconditions prevailing in Kazhakstan (the presence of ancient\nreservoirs of gerbils and marmots) are also found in Turkmenistan.\nAtabekov is certainly correct that the territory of Turkmenistan is\nan endemic focus of plague, and there is no reason to discount\nreports of plague in Turkmenistan out of hand.\n--\nWendy Orent\n<orentw@mindspring.com>\nSee Also\nPlague - Turkmenistan (Dashoguz): susp 20040706.1811\nPlague, fatal - Ecuador (Chimborazo) (02) 20040513.1288\nPlague, fatal - Ecuador: RFI 20040510.1264\nPlague warning - Russia: RFI 20040427.1178\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20040112.0128\n2003\n----\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) (02): background 20031013.2584\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20031012.2566\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) (02) 20030918.2360\nPlague - Algeria (Oran) (04) 20030704.1643\nPlague, bubonic - Algeria (Oran) 20030622.1537\nPlague - Uganda (Arua) 20030331.0794\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 20030822.2119\nPlague - Kazakhstan (Mangistausk): suspected 20030801.1881\n2002\n----\nPlague - Uganda (Nebbi District): RFI 20021218.6090\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20021130.5938\nPlague - Mongolia 20020919.5361\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi (Nsanje) 20020601.4378\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi, Mozambique 20020510.4160\nPlague - India (Chandigarh) (04): WHO conf... 20020220.3592\nPlague, suspected - India (Chandigarh) 20020215.3567\n2001\n----\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20011031.2689\nPlague - Uganda (Okoro County) (02) 20011016.2543\nPlague, suspected - Congo DR 20011011.2484\nPlague - Uganda (Okoro County) 20011009.2459\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia (Central): corr... 20010904.2115\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kyzyl-Orda) 20010805.1538\n1999\n----\nPlague, bubonic - Turkmenistan (Dashoguz): susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206056", "date": "2004-04-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE WARNING - RUSSIA: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri, 23 Apr 2004 20:29:54 -0300\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Mosnews.com [edited]\n<http://www.mosnews.com/news/2004/04/23/plague.shtml>\n\nChief sanitary inspector warns of plague threat\n-----------------------------------------------\nRussia's chief sanitary inspector, Gennadiy Onischenko, has called upon his\ncolleagues to be prepared for an outbreak of plague, the Rosbalt news\nagency reported, citing the press service of the State Sanitary and\nEpidemiology Monitoring Service.\nIn order to provide epidemiological security and to prevent the spread of\nthe dangerous disease among the population, the chief sanitary inspector\ntold the directors of anti-plague institutions located in the Russian\nregions bordering Kazakhstan, Mongolia, and China, to prepare for possible\ncases of plague, especially at border checkpoints. He also called for a\njoint effort of the State Sanitary and Epidemiology Monitoring Service and\ndepartments of the Health Ministry to carry out preventive measures within\nthe country.\nThe last case of plague was registered in Russia in 1979.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Given the absence of plague in Russia, it is important to know the reason\nfor this warning. As noted in some of the postings below, plague has been\nreported in the recent past in some of the adjacent states. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2003\n---\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) (02) 20030918.2360\nPlague - Mongolia 20030908.2255\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 20030822.2119\nPlague - Kazakhstan (Mangistausk): suspected 20030801.1881\n2002\n---\nPlague - Mongolia 20020919.5361\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi (Nsanje) 20020601.4378\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi, Mozambique 20020510.4160\nPlague - India (Chandigarh) (04): WHO confirmation 20020220.3592\n2001\n---\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20011031.2689\nPlague, suspected - Congo DR 20011011.2484\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia (Central): correction 20010904.2115\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kyzyl-Orda) 20010805.1538\n1999\n---\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (05) 19990817.1418\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (04) 19990810.1391\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (03) 19990809.1386\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (02) 19990804.1335\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan 19990802.1322\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Aktyubinsk) (02) 19990717.1200\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Aktyubinsk) 19990713.1172\n1998\n---\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan: NOT 19981211.2358\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan: background 19981206.2341\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan 19981205.2339\n.....................jw/ll/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA (CO): alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205922", "date": "2004-04-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE WARNING - RUSSIA: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri, 23 Apr 2004 20:29:54 -0300\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Mosnews.com [edited]\n<http://www.mosnews.com/news/2004/04/23/plague.shtml>\n\nChief sanitary inspector warns of plague threat\n-----------------------------------------------\nRussia's chief sanitary inspector, Gennadiy Onischenko, has called upon his\ncolleagues to be prepared for an outbreak of plague, the Rosbalt news\nagency reported, citing the press service of the State Sanitary and\nEpidemiology Monitoring Service.\nIn order to provide epidemiological security and to prevent the spread of\nthe dangerous disease among the population, the chief sanitary inspector\ntold the directors of anti-plague institutions located in the Russian\nregions bordering Kazakhstan, Mongolia, and China, to prepare for possible\ncases of plague, especially at border checkpoints. He also called for a\njoint effort of the State Sanitary and Epidemiology Monitoring Service and\ndepartments of the Health Ministry to carry out preventive measures within\nthe country.\nThe last case of plague was registered in Russia in 1979.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Given the absence of plague in Russia, it is important to know the reason\nfor this warning. As noted in some of the postings below, plague has been\nreported in the recent past in some of the adjacent states. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2003\n---\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) (02) 20030918.2360\nPlague - Mongolia 20030908.2255\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 20030822.2119\nPlague - Kazakhstan (Mangistausk): suspected 20030801.1881\n2002\n---\nPlague - Mongolia 20020919.5361\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi (Nsanje) 20020601.4378\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi, Mozambique 20020510.4160\nPlague - India (Chandigarh) (04): WHO confirmation 20020220.3592\n2001\n---\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20011031.2689\nPlague, suspected - Congo DR 20011011.2484\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia (Central): correction 20010904.2115\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kyzyl-Orda) 20010805.1538\n1999\n---\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (05) 19990817.1418\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (04) 19990810.1391\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (03) 19990809.1386\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (02) 19990804.1335\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan 19990802.1322\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Aktyubinsk) (02) 19990717.1200\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Aktyubinsk) 19990713.1172\n1998\n---\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan: NOT 19981211.2358\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan: background 19981206.2341\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan 19981205.2339\n.....................jw/ll/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. He also called for a\njoint effort of the State Sanitary and Epidemiology Monitoring Service and\ndepartments of the Health Ministry to carry out preventive measures within\nthe country.\nThe last case of plague was registered in Russia in 1979.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Given the absence of plague in Russia, it is important to know the reason\nfor this warning. As noted in some of the postings below, plague has been\nreported in the recent past in some of the adjacent states. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2003\n---\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) (02) 20030918.2360\nPlague - Mongolia 20030908.2255\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 20030822.2119\nPlague - Kazakhstan (Mangistausk): suspected 20030801.1881\n2002\n---\nPlague - Mongolia 20020919.5361\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi (Nsanje) 20020601.4378\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi, Mozambique 20020510.4160\nPlague - India (Chandigarh) (04): WHO confirmation 20020220.3592\n2001\n---\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20011031.2689\nPlague, suspected - Congo DR 20011011.2484\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia (Central): correction 20010904.2115\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kyzyl-Orda) 20010805.1538\n1999\n---\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (05) 19990817.1418\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (04) 19990810.1391\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (03) 19990809.1386\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (02) 19990804.1335\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan 19990802.1322\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Aktyubinsk) (02) 19990717.1200\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Aktyubinsk) 19990713.1172\n1998\n---\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan: NOT 19981211.2358\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan: background 19981206.2341\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan 19981205.2339\n.....................jw/ll/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Ecuador (Chimborazo) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205720", "date": "2004-04-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE WARNING - RUSSIA: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri, 23 Apr 2004 20:29:54 -0300\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Mosnews.com [edited]\n<http://www.mosnews.com/news/2004/04/23/plague.shtml>\n\nChief sanitary inspector warns of plague threat\n-----------------------------------------------\nRussia's chief sanitary inspector, Gennadiy Onischenko, has called upon his\ncolleagues to be prepared for an outbreak of plague, the Rosbalt news\nagency reported, citing the press service of the State Sanitary and\nEpidemiology Monitoring Service.\nIn order to provide epidemiological security and to prevent the spread of\nthe dangerous disease among the population, the chief sanitary inspector\ntold the directors of anti-plague institutions located in the Russian\nregions bordering Kazakhstan, Mongolia, and China, to prepare for possible\ncases of plague, especially at border checkpoints. He also called for a\njoint effort of the State Sanitary and Epidemiology Monitoring Service and\ndepartments of the Health Ministry to carry out preventive measures within\nthe country.\nThe last case of plague was registered in Russia in 1979.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Given the absence of plague in Russia, it is important to know the reason\nfor this warning. He also called for a\njoint effort of the State Sanitary and Epidemiology Monitoring Service and\ndepartments of the Health Ministry to carry out preventive measures within\nthe country.\nThe last case of plague was registered in Russia in 1979.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Given the absence of plague in Russia, it is important to know the reason\nfor this warning. As noted in some of the postings below, plague has been\nreported in the recent past in some of the adjacent states. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2003\n---\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) (02) 20030918.2360\nPlague - Mongolia 20030908.2255\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 20030822.2119\nPlague - Kazakhstan (Mangistausk): suspected 20030801.1881\n2002\n---\nPlague - Mongolia 20020919.5361\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi (Nsanje) 20020601.4378\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi, Mozambique 20020510.4160\nPlague - India (Chandigarh) (04): WHO confirmation 20020220.3592\n2001\n---\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20011031.2689\nPlague, suspected - Congo DR 20011011.2484\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia (Central): correction 20010904.2115\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kyzyl-Orda) 20010805.1538\n1999\n---\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (05) 19990817.1418\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (04) 19990810.1391\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (03) 19990809.1386\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (02) 19990804.1335\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan 19990802.1322\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Aktyubinsk) (02) 19990717.1200\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Aktyubinsk) 19990713.1172\n1998\n---\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan: NOT 19981211.2358\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan: background 19981206.2341\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan 19981205.2339\n.....................jw/ll/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. JW in the last ProMED-mail posting on plague in\nMongolia (Plague - Mongolia 20020919.5361), these cases have no\nimplications for international travel; they are reported by ProMED-mail as\na reminder that plague foci are still present in the world. Plague is\nendemic in Mongolia, and human cases of bubonic plague are reported every\nyear, mainly in country dwellers who have been hunting marmots for\ntheir fur. Marmots are large, burrowing rodents similar to groundhogs\n(woodchucks) in the USA. Most of the world's plague cases are reported\nfrom Africa - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2002\n-----\nPlague - Mongolia 20020919.5361\nPlague, squirrel, cat - USA (California): alert 20020829.5184\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi (Nsanje) 20020601.4378\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi, Mozambique 20020510.4160\nPlague, prairie dogs, suspected - USA (CO) (02) 20020507.4126\nPlague - India (Chandigarh) (04): WHO confirmation 20020220.3592\n2001\n----\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kyzyl-Orda) 20010805.1538\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20011031.2689\nPlague, suspected - Congo DR 20011011.2484\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia (Central): correction 20010904.2115\n...........................jw/ll/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Plague is\nendemic in Mongolia, and human cases of bubonic plague are reported every\nyear, mainly in country dwellers who have been hunting marmots for\ntheir fur. Marmots are large, burrowing rodents similar to groundhogs\n(woodchucks) in the USA. Most of the world's plague cases are reported\nfrom Africa - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2002\n-----\nPlague - Mongolia 20020919.5361\nPlague, squirrel, cat - USA (California): alert 20020829.5184\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi (Nsanje) 20020601.4378\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi, Mozambique 20020510.4160\nPlague, prairie dogs, suspected - USA (CO) (02) 20020507.4126\nPlague - India (Chandigarh) (04): WHO confirmation 20020220.3592\n2001\n----\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kyzyl-Orda) 20010805.1538\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20011031.2689\nPlague, suspected - Congo DR 20011011.2484\nPlague, bubonic - Mongolia (Central): correction 20010904.2115\n...........................jw/ll/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. JW in the last ProMED-mail posting on plague in\nMongolia (Plague - Mongolia 20020919.5361), these cases have no\nimplications for international travel; they are reported by ProMED-mail as\na reminder that plague foci are still present in the world. Plague is\nendemic in Mongolia, and human cases of bubonic plague are reported every\nyear, mainly in country dwellers who have been hunting marmots for\ntheir fur. Marmots are large, burrowing rodents similar to groundhogs\n(woodchucks) in the USA. To date, no new cases have been officially reported.\n\nWHO is working with the Ministry of Health to provide rapid diagnostic tests\nand technical support in liaison with WHO Collaborating Centers: Institut\nPasteur, Paris, France, also a partner in the Global Outbreak Alert and\nResponse Network <http://www.who.int/csr/outbreaknetwork/en/>, and Kazakh\nScientific Center for Quarantine and Zoonotic Diseases, Almaty, Kazakhstan.\n\nFor More Information\n\n- WHO Fact Sheet on Plague\n<http://www.who.int/inf-fs/en/fact267.html>\n- Plague Manual: Epidemiology, Distribution, Surveillance and Control\n<http://www.who.int/emc-documents/plague/whocdscsredc992c.html>\n---\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nPlague, bubonic - Algeria (Oran) 20030622.1537\n..............................ll/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. To date, no new cases have been officially reported.\n\nWHO is working with the Ministry of Health to provide rapid diagnostic tests\nand technical support in liaison with WHO Collaborating Centers: Institut\nPasteur, Paris, France, also a partner in the Global Outbreak Alert and\nResponse Network <http://www.who.int/csr/outbreaknetwork/en/>, and Kazakh\nScientific Center for Quarantine and Zoonotic Diseases, Almaty, Kazakhstan.\n\nFor More Information\n\n- WHO Fact Sheet on Plague\n<http://www.who.int/inf-fs/en/fact267.html>\n- Plague Manual: Epidemiology, Distribution, Surveillance and Control\n<http://www.who.int/emc-documents/plague/whocdscsredc992c.html>\n---\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nPlague, bubonic - Algeria (Oran) 20030622.1537\n..............................ll/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. To date, no new cases have been officially reported.\n\nWHO is working with the Ministry of Health to provide rapid diagnostic tests\nand technical support in liaison with WHO Collaborating Centers: Institut\nPasteur, Paris, France, also a partner in the Global Outbreak Alert and\nResponse Network <http://www.who.int/csr/outbreaknetwork/en/>, and Kazakh\nScientific Center for Quarantine and Zoonotic Diseases, Almaty, Kazakhstan.\n\nFor More Information\n\n- WHO Fact Sheet on Plague\n<http://www.who.int/inf-fs/en/fact267.html>\n- Plague Manual: Epidemiology, Distribution, Surveillance and Control\n<http://www.who.int/emc-documents/plague/whocdscsredc992c.html>\n---\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nPlague, bubonic - Algeria (Oran) 20030622.1537\n..............................ll/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
