For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-06-23 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Algeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Paris", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tafraoui", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204015", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic - Algeria (Oran)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204015", "date": "2002-06-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE , BUBONIC - MALAWI (NSANJE)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 31 May 2002 10:02 AM EST\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: AllAfrica.com (edited)\n\nBubonic plague adds to woes\n---------------------------\nLilongwe (UN Integrated Regional Information Networks/All Africa Global\nMedia): Malawi's existing health challenges of cholera, malnutrition,\nmalaria, and HIV/AIDS have been joined by another -- the bubonic plague.\nSince April 2002, 71 cases of the disease carried by fleas and rodents have\nbeen reported in the far south of the country, the World Health\nOrganization said on 30 May 2002. The first victim this year was a 9 year\nold girl from Zavedo village. Outbreaks of bubonic plague have occurred in\nNsanje district at the southern tip of the country since 1994, with the\nnumber of cases peaking at 304 in 1999. There were no reported cases for\nthe 2 years before April 2002.\nThe plague, which has a case fatality ratio of up to 60 per cent if left\nuntreated, has also been reported in Mozambique, leading to cross-border\ncollaboration between Mozambican and Malawian health teams. \"WHO is\nconcerned due to the fact that the current epidemic is combined with\nmalnutrition because of the food shortage in the country. It is a\nwell-known fact that prevalence and severity of all infectious diseases\nincrease where malnutrition is rampant,\" a statement said.\nA World Food Program (WFP) assessment released this week estimated that 3.2\nmillion Malawians face food shortages due to anticipated food shortages\nthis year. The country is only just recovering from a cholera epidemic that\nkilled over 900 people. Malawi's overstretched health services now share\nthe added burden of acquiring adequate medical staff and finding chemicals\nto spray against fleas and rodents. The UN children's agency, UNICEF, and\nWHO response includes providing cash to districts to buy insecticides for\nhousehold spraying and sending a consultant to give front-line health\nworkers refresher training.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The Nsanje district of Malawi has been the subject of ProMED-mail postings\nin the past (see below). The role of population disruption due to war,\nfamine, floods and other calamities cannot be overemphasized in the\nepidemiology of a variety of infectious diseases including plague. In such\nsituations involving plague, one must be concerned about the possibility of\npneumonic plague with the possibility of person to person spread and a very\nhigh mortality even with treatment. The bubonic form of _Yersinia pestis_\ninfection itself is spread to man from infected rodent fleas and without\nsecondary pneumonia is not infectious to others. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi, Mozambique 20020510.4160\nPlague - India (Chandigarh) (04):WHO confirmation 20020220.3592\nPlague - India, suspected - India (Chandigarh) 20020215.3567\n2001\n---\nPlague, confirmed - Congo Dr (Ituri) 20011219.3068\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20011031.2689\nPlague - Uganda (Okoro County) (02) 20011016.2543\nPlague, suspected - Congo DR 20011011.2484\nPlague - Uganda (Okoro County) 20011009.2459\nPlague, bubonic - Zambia (04) 20010418.0769\nPlague, bubonic - Zambia 20010315.0525\n2000\n---\nPlague? - India: 1994-2000 20000612.0951\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi (Nsanje): background 20000610.0942\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi (Nsanje) 20000609.0931\n.................mpp/ll/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The first victim this year was a 9 year\nold girl from Zavedo village. The country is only just recovering from a cholera epidemic that\nkilled over 900 people. Malawi's overstretched health services now share\nthe added burden of acquiring adequate medical staff and finding chemicals\nto spray against fleas and rodents. The UN children's agency, UNICEF, and\nWHO response includes providing cash to districts to buy insecticides for\nhousehold spraying and sending a consultant to give front-line health\nworkers refresher training.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The Nsanje district of Malawi has been the subject of ProMED-mail postings\nin the past (see below). The role of population disruption due to war,\nfamine, floods and other calamities cannot be overemphasized in the\nepidemiology of a variety of infectious diseases including plague. In such\nsituations involving plague, one must be concerned about the possibility of\npneumonic plague with the possibility of person to person spread and a very\nhigh mortality even with treatment. The first victim this year was a 9 year\nold girl from Zavedo village. Outbreaks of bubonic plague have occurred in\nNsanje district at the southern tip of the country since 1994, with the\nnumber of cases peaking at 304 in 1999. There were no reported cases for\nthe 2 years before April 2002.\nThe plague, which has a case fatality ratio of up to 60 per cent if left\nuntreated, has also been reported in Mozambique, leading to cross-border\ncollaboration between Mozambican and Malawian health teams. \"WHO is\nconcerned due to the fact that the current epidemic is combined with\nmalnutrition because of the food shortage in the country. It is a\nwell-known fact that prevalence and severity of all infectious diseases\nincrease where malnutrition is rampant,\" a statement said.\nA World Food Program (WFP) assessment released this week estimated that 3.2\nmillion Malawians face food shortages due to anticipated food shortages\nthis year. The country is only just recovering from a cholera epidemic that\nkilled over 900 people. Malawi's overstretched health services now share\nthe added burden of acquiring adequate medical staff and finding chemicals\nto spray against fleas and rodents. The UN children's agency, UNICEF, and\nWHO response includes providing cash to districts to buy insecticides for\nhousehold spraying and sending a consultant to give front-line health\nworkers refresher training.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The Nsanje district of Malawi has been the subject of ProMED-mail postings\nin the past (see below). The role of population disruption due to war,\nfamine, floods and other calamities cannot be overemphasized in the\nepidemiology of a variety of infectious diseases including plague. In such\nsituations involving plague, one must be concerned about the possibility of\npneumonic plague with the possibility of person to person spread and a very\nhigh mortality even with treatment. The bubonic form of _Yersinia pestis_\ninfection itself is spread to man from infected rodent fleas and without\nsecondary pneumonia is not infectious to others. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi, Mozambique 20020510.4160\nPlague - India (Chandigarh) (04):WHO confirmation 20020220.3592\nPlague - India, suspected - India (Chandigarh) 20020215.3567\n2001\n---\nPlague, confirmed - Congo Dr (Ituri) 20011219.3068\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20011031.2689\nPlague - Uganda (Okoro County) (02) 20011016.2543\nPlague, suspected - Congo DR 20011011.2484\nPlague - Uganda (Okoro County) 20011009.2459\nPlague, bubonic - Zambia (04) 20010418.0769\nPlague, bubonic - Zambia 20010315.0525\n2000\n---\nPlague? - India: 1994-2000 20000612.0951\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi (Nsanje): background 20000610.0942\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi (Nsanje) 20000609.0931\n.................mpp/ll/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The first victim this year was a 9 year\nold girl from Zavedo village. Outbreaks of bubonic plague have occurred in\nNsanje district at the southern tip of the country since 1994, with the\nnumber of cases peaking at 304 in 1999. There were no reported cases for\nthe 2 years before April 2002.\nThe plague, which has a case fatality ratio of up to 60 per cent if left\nuntreated, has also been reported in Mozambique, leading to cross-border\ncollaboration between Mozambican and Malawian health teams. \"WHO is\nconcerned due to the fact that the current epidemic is combined with\nmalnutrition because of the food shortage in the country. It is a\nwell-known fact that prevalence and severity of all infectious diseases\nincrease where malnutrition is rampant,\" a statement said.\nA World Food Program (WFP) assessment released this week estimated that 3.2\nmillion Malawians face food shortages due to anticipated food shortages\nthis year. The country is only just recovering from a cholera epidemic that\nkilled over 900 people. Malawi's overstretched health services now share\nthe added burden of acquiring adequate medical staff and finding chemicals\nto spray against fleas and rodents. The UN children's agency, UNICEF, and\nWHO response includes providing cash to districts to buy insecticides for\nhousehold spraying and sending a consultant to give front-line health\nworkers refresher training.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The Nsanje district of Malawi has been the subject of ProMED-mail postings\nin the past (see below). The role of population disruption due to war,\nfamine, floods and other calamities cannot be overemphasized in the\nepidemiology of a variety of infectious diseases including plague. In such\nsituations involving plague, one must be concerned about the possibility of\npneumonic plague with the possibility of person to person spread and a very\nhigh mortality even with treatment. The bubonic form of _Yersinia pestis_\ninfection itself is spread to man from infected rodent fleas and without\nsecondary pneumonia is not infectious to others. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi, Mozambique 20020510.4160\nPlague - India (Chandigarh) (04):WHO confirmation 20020220.3592\nPlague - India, suspected - India (Chandigarh) 20020215.3567\n2001\n---\nPlague, confirmed - Congo Dr (Ituri) 20011219.3068\nPlague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi) 20011031.2689\nPlague - Uganda (Okoro County) (02) 20011016.2543\nPlague, suspected - Congo DR 20011011.2484\nPlague - Uganda (Okoro County) 20011009.2459\nPlague, bubonic - Zambia (04) 20010418.0769\nPlague, bubonic - Zambia 20010315.0525\n2000\n---\nPlague? - India: 1994-2000 20000612.0951\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi (Nsanje): background 20000610.0942\nPlague, bubonic - Malawi (Nsanje) 20000609.0931\n.................mpp/ll/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The first victim this year was a 9 year\nold girl from Zavedo village. Outbreaks of bubonic plague have occurred in\nNsanje district at the southern tip of the country since 1994, with the\nnumber of cases peaking at 304 in 1999. There were no reported cases for\nthe 2 years before April 2002.\nThe plague, which has a case fatality ratio of up to 60 per cent if left\nuntreated, has also been reported in Mozambique, leading to cross-border\ncollaboration between Mozambican and Malawian health teams. \"WHO is\nconcerned due to the fact that the current epidemic is combined with\nmalnutrition because of the food shortage in the country. The country is only just recovering from a cholera epidemic that\nkilled over 900 people. Malawi's overstretched health services now share\nthe added burden of acquiring adequate medical staff and finding chemicals\nto spray against fleas and rodents. The UN children's agency, UNICEF, and\nWHO response includes providing cash to districts to buy insecticides for\nhousehold spraying and sending a consultant to give front-line health\nworkers refresher training.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The Nsanje district of Malawi has been the subject of ProMED-mail postings\nin the past (see below). In such\nsituations involving plague, one must be concerned about the possibility of\npneumonic plague with the possibility of person to person spread and a very\nhigh mortality even with treatment. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["cholera", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-12-16 00:00:00", "2001-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Okoro County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CONFIRMED - congo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2200920", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Uganda (Arua, Nebbi)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2200920", "date": "2001-07-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC, CHIPMUNK - USA (CALIFORNIA)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSee Also\n1999\n----\nPlague, squirrels, cats - USA (California) 19991022.1901\nPlague, squirrels - USA (California) 19990816.1413\n1998\n----\nPlague, bubonic, warning - USA (California) 19980611.1107\nPlague, bubonic - USA (California & New Mexico) (02) 19980612.1114\nPlague, wild rodents, warning - USA (California) 19980705.1261\n1997\n----\nPlague, bubonic - USA (California) 19970619.1312\nDate: 20 Jul 2001\nFrom: George Robertson <RobertG3@labs.wyeth.com>\nSource: Associated press\n\nDead chipmunk at Tahoe had bubonic plague\n-----------------------------------------\nSOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif. -- A dead chipmunk at Lake Tahoe has tested\npositive for bubonic plague. Authorities say it's important to alert area\nresidents and visitors, but no reason for alarm.\nSigns have been posted at area beaches, trailheads and campgrounds\nwarning people to avoid the rodents. The chipmunk was found last week\nnear the Lake Tahoe Forest Service Visitors Center.\nPlague is endemic in rodent populations in the West and has infected\nchipmunks and squirrels in all of the counties across Nevada. It's a\npotentially fatal disease that can be transferred to humans.\nFleas jump from one warm body to the next.\nThe last death recorded in the area was in 1980 when a South Lake Tahoe\nwoman contracted the disease from her cat, which had brought home a dead\nchipmunk. Her death was the first case of plague pneumonia reported in\nthe country since 1924, a California Department of Health Services report\nsaid.\nJim Hogan, supervisor for the Nevada Environmental Health Division, said\nwith today's modern medicine, the disease is not a death sentence. \"It\ncan be fatal, yes, but its very curable if treated early,\" Hogan said.\nHogan said the disease can take two pathways through the body. The most\ncommon way is infecting the lymph nodes, called bubonic plague. If left\nuntreated, the bacteria can travel through the blood stream to the\nlungs, progressing to the deadly pneumonic plague.\nEarly symptoms include high fever, chills, nausea, weakness and swollen\nglands. Health officials warn:\n-- Do not feed or handle rodents.\n-- Make sure your cat or dog has a flea collar.\n-- Do not rest, camp or sleep near a rodent burrow.\n-- Do not touch sick or dead animals.\n\u0096\u0096\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Cats may be the animal responsible for transmitting the disease to their\ncaretakers. Cats are very sensitive to the plague agent, both bubonic and\npneumonic forms of the disease. - Mod.TG\n...............................tg/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). Authorities say it's important to alert area\nresidents and visitors, but no reason for alarm.\nSigns have been posted at area beaches, trailheads and campgrounds\nwarning people to avoid the rodents. The chipmunk was found last week\nnear the Lake Tahoe Forest Service Visitors Center.\nPlague is endemic in rodent populations in the West and has infected\nchipmunks and squirrels in all of the counties across Nevada. The most\ncommon way is infecting the lymph nodes, called bubonic plague. If left\nuntreated, the bacteria can travel through the blood stream to the\nlungs, progressing to the deadly pneumonic plague.\nEarly symptoms include high fever, chills, nausea, weakness and swollen\nglands. Health officials warn:\n-- Do not feed or handle rodents.\n-- Make sure your cat or dog has a flea collar.\n-- Do not rest, camp or sleep near a rodent burrow.\n-- Do not touch sick or dead animals.\n\u0096\u0096\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Cats may be the animal responsible for transmitting the disease to their\ncaretakers. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1924-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nevada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Calif.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TAHOE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2200796", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, suspected - Congo DR", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2200796", "date": "2001-07-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC, CHIPMUNK - USA (CALIFORNIA)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSee Also\n1999\n----\nPlague, squirrels, cats - USA (California) 19991022.1901\nPlague, squirrels - USA (California) 19990816.1413\n1998\n----\nPlague, bubonic, warning - USA (California) 19980611.1107\nPlague, bubonic - USA (California & New Mexico) (02) 19980612.1114\nPlague, wild rodents, warning - USA (California) 19980705.1261\n1997\n----\nPlague, bubonic - USA (California) 19970619.1312\nDate: 20 Jul 2001\nFrom: George Robertson <RobertG3@labs.wyeth.com>\nSource: Associated press\n\nDead chipmunk at Tahoe had bubonic plague\n-----------------------------------------\nSOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif. -- A dead chipmunk at Lake Tahoe has tested\npositive for bubonic plague. Authorities say it's important to alert area\nresidents and visitors, but no reason for alarm.\nSigns have been posted at area beaches, trailheads and campgrounds\nwarning people to avoid the rodents. The chipmunk was found last week\nnear the Lake Tahoe Forest Service Visitors Center.\nPlague is endemic in rodent populations in the West and has infected\nchipmunks and squirrels in all of the counties across Nevada. It's a\npotentially fatal disease that can be transferred to humans.\nFleas jump from one warm body to the next.\nThe last death recorded in the area was in 1980 when a South Lake Tahoe\nwoman contracted the disease from her cat, which had brought home a dead\nchipmunk. Her death was the first case of plague pneumonia reported in\nthe country since 1924, a California Department of Health Services report\nsaid.\nJim Hogan, supervisor for the Nevada Environmental Health Division, said\nwith today's modern medicine, the disease is not a death sentence. \"It\ncan be fatal, yes, but its very curable if treated early,\" Hogan said.\nHogan said the disease can take two pathways through the body. The most\ncommon way is infecting the lymph nodes, called bubonic plague. If left\nuntreated, the bacteria can travel through the blood stream to the\nlungs, progressing to the deadly pneumonic plague.\nEarly symptoms include high fever, chills, nausea, weakness and swollen\nglands. Health officials warn:\n-- Do not feed or handle rodents.\n-- Make sure your cat or dog has a flea collar.\n-- Do not rest, camp or sleep near a rodent burrow.\n-- Do not touch sick or dead animals.\n\u0096\u0096\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Cats may be the animal responsible for transmitting the disease to their\ncaretakers. Cats are very sensitive to the plague agent, both bubonic and\npneumonic forms of the disease. - Mod.TG\n...............................tg/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. Pollack <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: The Glenwood Post and Associated Press, 31 Jul 2000 [edited\n\nPlague outbreak kills thousands of prairie dogs\n------------------------------------------------\nPUEBLO, Colo.-- Tens of thousands of prairie dogs may have died from a\nrecent outbreak of bubonic plague in Pueblo West.\nAnimal specimens sent to the Colorado State University laboratory have\nconfirmed bubonic plague is killing prairie dogs in the area.\n\"The last major outbreak we've had of this magnitude was in 1987 when there\nwere hundreds of thousands of prairie dogs dead,\" said Mando Torres,\nenvironmental health technician at the Pueblo City-County Health\nDepartment. \"There are easily tens of thousands of dogs having died during\nthis recent outbreak.\"\nBubonic plague is a bacterial infection caused by _Yersinia pestis_ and\ntreatable with antibiotics in humans and animals. Symptoms include high\nfever, chills, muscle aches and nausea as well as pain and swelling in\nlymph nodes. The disease is commonly spread through infected fleas.\nTorres cautioned people living near affected areas to take precautions and\nkeep children and pets away from the prairie dog area.\n\"Cats are very susceptible to the plague and while dogs aren't, they will\nbring the fleas back home,\" he said. Torres recommended using flea powder\non pets.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\n[There are a number of excellent flea control products available through\nveterinarians. Furthermore, pets should be examined by a veterinarian for\nany swollen lymph nodes and early signs of the disease. - Mod.TG\n......................tg/ds\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. Pollack <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: The Glenwood Post and Associated Press, 31 Jul 2000 [edited\n\nPlague outbreak kills thousands of prairie dogs\n------------------------------------------------\nPUEBLO, Colo.-- Tens of thousands of prairie dogs may have died from a\nrecent outbreak of bubonic plague in Pueblo West.\nAnimal specimens sent to the Colorado State University laboratory have\nconfirmed bubonic plague is killing prairie dogs in the area.\n\"The last major outbreak we've had of this magnitude was in 1987 when there\nwere hundreds of thousands of prairie dogs dead,\" said Mando Torres,\nenvironmental health technician at the Pueblo City-County Health\nDepartment. \"There are easily tens of thousands of dogs having died during\nthis recent outbreak.\"\nBubonic plague is a bacterial infection caused by _Yersinia pestis_ and\ntreatable with antibiotics in humans and animals. Symptoms include high\nfever, chills, muscle aches and nausea as well as pain and swelling in\nlymph nodes. The disease is commonly spread through infected fleas.\nTorres cautioned people living near affected areas to take precautions and\nkeep children and pets away from the prairie dog area.\n\"Cats are very susceptible to the plague and while dogs aren't, they will\nbring the fleas back home,\" he said. Torres recommended using flea powder\non pets.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\n[There are a number of excellent flea control products available through\nveterinarians. Furthermore, pets should be examined by a veterinarian for\nany swollen lymph nodes and early signs of the disease. - Mod.TG\n......................tg/ds\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The disease is commonly spread through infected fleas.\nTorres cautioned people living near affected areas to take precautions and\nkeep children and pets away from the prairie dog area.\n\"Cats are very susceptible to the plague and while dogs aren't, they will\nbring the fleas back home,\" he said. Torres recommended using flea powder\non pets.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\n[There are a number of excellent flea control products available through\nveterinarians. Furthermore, pets should be examined by a veterinarian for\nany swollen lymph nodes and early signs of the disease. - Mod.TG\n......................tg/ds\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-06-11 18:43:39", "1998-10-02 15:47:46", "1998-07-24 22:01:12", "1998-05-20 07:50:45", "2000-07-31 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Pueblo City - County Health \n Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2198344", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, bubonic, marmots - Mongolia: RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2198344", "date": "1999-10-22 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, SQUIRRELS, CATS - USA (CALIFORNIA)\n******************************************\nA ProMED post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nSee Also\nPlague, cats & dogs to humans 990619110831\nPlague, cats - USA (New Mexico) 990531221457\nPlague, cats - USA (New Mexico) (02) 990602121020\nPlague, cats and dogs to humans (02) 990627154921\nPlague, human - USA (Colorado) 990605095227\nPlague, human - USA (Colorado) (02) 990607223200\nPlague, human - USA (Colorado) (03) 990609213850\nPlague, squirrels - USA (California) 990816203653\nDate: Fri, 22 Oct 1999 04:43:43 -0400\nFrom: Marjorie P. Pollack <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: Los Angeles Times, 21 Oct 1999 (edited)\n<http://www.latimes.com/news/state/19991021/t000095157.html>\n\nPrompted by the discovery of 5 animals with sylvatic plague, Los Angeles\nCounty health officials temporarily closed a popular nature park near\nPasadena and stepped up efforts to find and destroy infected animals.\nThree infected squirrels were found in the Eaton Canyon Park north of\nPasadena and a fourth infected squirrel at Table Mountain, an Angeles\nNational Forest camping area near San Bernardino County.\nThe fifth animal, a 5-month-old kitten, was found roaming the Rancho Mirage\nmobile home park in Lancaster, where it was apparently fed by a resident\nbefore being turned over to a nearby animal shelter last month.The cat is\nbelieved to have been destroyed.\nSylvatic plague, when transmitted to humans, is commonly known as bubonic\nplague, a bacterial infection that can be fatal if not treated, said\nJonathan Fielding, director of public health and the county's health officer.\nBut he said such occurrences are extremely rare and the last case of\nanimal-to-human infection in Los Angeles County was reported in 1984.\nAs a precaution, county officials closed Eaton Canyon Park on Tuesday for\nat least 10 days. County workers will set up 40 to 50 dust stations to kill\nfleas, which carry the plague among animals, and will exterminate 90% of\nthe ground squirrels, which officials say are the most common carriers of\nthe plague in the Los Angeles area. Fielding said the measures were\nnecessary because the park is heavily used by picnickers and hikers. It\ncontains the Eaton Canyon Nature Center, which draws hundreds of children\nand adults on weekends and is home to dozens of nature organizations.\nAt Table Mountain, the discovery of the infected squirrel required no\nextraordinary measures because it coincided with the camping area's normal\nannual closure, county officials said.\nThe Lancaster cat, however, has prompted additional concern because there\nhave been no such cases among domesticated animals since the late 1980s,\nsaid Frank Hall, chief of the Department of Health Services' vector\nmanagement program. Vectors are animals or insects that can transmit\ndisease to humans.\n\"We're concerned about where this cat came from,\" Hall said. \"Did it have a\nprevious owner?\"\nCounty health officials said they are investigating areas near the\nLancaster trailer park to determine the extent of the plague infestation.\nThe woman who fed the cat showed no signs of bubonic plague, Hall said.\nTracy Bryant, Rancho Mirage trailer park's resident manager, said the\ncounty only informed her Wednesday afternoon about the infected tabby. \"The\ncounty is suppose to be coming out tomorrow. We'll be informing all our\nresidents about the cat.\"\nThe latest sylvatic plague cases were discovered during a routine sampling\nof animals in shelters and wilderness areas by county health officers.\nBubonic plague, once known as the \"Black Death,\" is believed to have wiped\nout as much as a third of Europe's population during the 14th century. But\nwith advances in preventive methods, only about 10 or 15 cases are now\nreported annually in the United States. Still, county health officials are\nurging the public to take precautions.\nPeople should stay away from wild or stray animals and use insect repellent\nagainst fleas, Hall said. Even healthy-looking animals can harbor the\ndisease, and pet owners should try to keep their animals flea-free and\nindoors.\n--\nProMED\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n......................................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It\ncontains the Eaton Canyon Nature Center, which draws hundreds of children\nand adults on weekends and is home to dozens of nature organizations.\nAt Table Mountain, the discovery of the infected squirrel required no\nextraordinary measures because it coincided with the camping area's normal\nannual closure, county officials said.\nThe Lancaster cat, however, has prompted additional concern because there\nhave been no such cases among domesticated animals since the late 1980s,\nsaid Frank Hall, chief of the Department of Health Services' vector\nmanagement program. But\nwith advances in preventive methods, only about 10 or 15 cases are now\nreported annually in the United States. Still, county health officials are\nurging the public to take precautions.\nPeople should stay away from wild or stray animals and use insect repellent\nagainst fleas, Hall said. Even healthy-looking animals can harbor the\ndisease, and pet owners should try to keep their animals flea-free and\nindoors.\n--\nProMED\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n......................................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Still, county health officials are\nurging the public to take precautions.\nPeople should stay away from wild or stray animals and use insect repellent\nagainst fleas, Hall said. Even healthy-looking animals can harbor the\ndisease, and pet owners should try to keep their animals flea-free and\nindoors.\n--\nProMED\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n......................................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Vectors are animals or insects that can transmit\ndisease to humans.\n\"We're concerned about where this cat came from,\" Hall said. \"Did it have a\nprevious owner?\"\nCounty health officials said they are investigating areas near the\nLancaster trailer park to determine the extent of the plague infestation.\nThe woman who fed the cat showed no signs of bubonic plague, Hall said.\nTracy Bryant, Rancho Mirage trailer park's resident manager, said the\ncounty only informed her Wednesday afternoon about the infected tabby. \"The\ncounty is suppose to be coming out tomorrow. But\nwith advances in preventive methods, only about 10 or 15 cases are now\nreported annually in the United States. Still, county health officials are\nurging the public to take precautions.\nPeople should stay away from wild or stray animals and use insect repellent\nagainst fleas, Hall said. It\ncontains the Eaton Canyon Nature Center, which draws hundreds of children\nand adults on weekends and is home to dozens of nature organizations.\nAt Table Mountain, the discovery of the infected squirrel required no\nextraordinary measures because it coincided with the camping area's normal\nannual closure, county officials said.\nThe Lancaster cat, however, has prompted additional concern because there\nhave been no such cases among domesticated animals since the late 1980s,\nsaid Frank Hall, chief of the Department of Health Services' vector\nmanagement program. Vectors are animals or insects that can transmit\ndisease to humans.\n\"We're concerned about where this cat came from,\" Hall said. \"Did it have a\nprevious owner?\"\nCounty health officials said they are investigating areas near the\nLancaster trailer park to determine the extent of the plague infestation.\nThe woman who fed the cat showed no signs of bubonic plague, Hall said.\nTracy Bryant, Rancho Mirage trailer park's resident manager, said the\ncounty only informed her Wednesday afternoon about the infected tabby. \"The\ncounty is suppose to be coming out tomorrow. We'll be informing all our\nresidents about the cat.\"\nThe latest sylvatic plague cases were discovered during a routine sampling\nof animals in shelters and wilderness areas by county health officers.\nBubonic plague, once known as the \"Black Death,\" is believed to have wiped\nout as much as a third of Europe's population during the 14th century. But\nwith advances in preventive methods, only about 10 or 15 cases are now\nreported annually in the United States. Still, county health officials are\nurging the public to take precautions.\nPeople should stay away from wild or stray animals and use insect repellent\nagainst fleas, Hall said. Even healthy-looking animals can harbor the\ndisease, and pet owners should try to keep their animals flea-free and\nindoors.\n--\nProMED\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n......................................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Pollack <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: Los Angeles Times, 21 Oct 1999 (edited)\n<http://www.latimes.com/news/state/19991021/t000095157.html>\n\nPrompted by the discovery of 5 animals with sylvatic plague, Los Angeles\nCounty health officials temporarily closed a popular nature park near\nPasadena and stepped up efforts to find and destroy infected animals.\nThree infected squirrels were found in the Eaton Canyon Park north of\nPasadena and a fourth infected squirrel at Table Mountain, an Angeles\nNational Forest camping area near San Bernardino County.\nThe fifth animal, a 5-month-old kitten, was found roaming the Rancho Mirage\nmobile home park in Lancaster, where it was apparently fed by a resident\nbefore being turned over to a nearby animal shelter last month.The cat is\nbelieved to have been destroyed.\nSylvatic plague, when transmitted to humans, is commonly known as bubonic\nplague, a bacterial infection that can be fatal if not treated, said\nJonathan Fielding, director of public health and the county's health officer.\nBut he said such occurrences are extremely rare and the last case of\nanimal-to-human infection in Los Angeles County was reported in 1984.\nAs a precaution, county officials closed Eaton Canyon Park on Tuesday for\nat least 10 days. County workers will set up 40 to 50 dust stations to kill\nfleas, which carry the plague among animals, and will exterminate 90% of\nthe ground squirrels, which officials say are the most common carriers of\nthe plague in the Los Angeles area. Fielding said the measures were\nnecessary because the park is heavily used by picnickers and hikers. It\ncontains the Eaton Canyon Nature Center, which draws hundreds of children\nand adults on weekends and is home to dozens of nature organizations.\nAt Table Mountain, the discovery of the infected squirrel required no\nextraordinary measures because it coincided with the camping area's normal\nannual closure, county officials said.\nThe Lancaster cat, however, has prompted additional concern because there\nhave been no such cases among domesticated animals since the late 1980s,\nsaid Frank Hall, chief of the Department of Health Services' vector\nmanagement program. Vectors are animals or insects that can transmit\ndisease to humans.\n\"We're concerned about where this cat came from,\" Hall said. \"Did it have a\nprevious owner?\"\nCounty health officials said they are investigating areas near the\nLancaster trailer park to determine the extent of the plague infestation.\nThe woman who fed the cat showed no signs of bubonic plague, Hall said.\nTracy Bryant, Rancho Mirage trailer park's resident manager, said the\ncounty only informed her Wednesday afternoon about the infected tabby. \"The\ncounty is suppose to be coming out tomorrow. We'll be informing all our\nresidents about the cat.\"\nThe latest sylvatic plague cases were discovered during a routine sampling\nof animals in shelters and wilderness areas by county health officers.\nBubonic plague, once known as the \"Black Death,\" is believed to have wiped\nout as much as a third of Europe's population during the 14th century. But\nwith advances in preventive methods, only about 10 or 15 cases are now\nreported annually in the United States. Still, county health officials are\nurging the public to take precautions.\nPeople should stay away from wild or stray animals and use insect repellent\nagainst fleas, Hall said. Even healthy-looking animals can harbor the\ndisease, and pet owners should try to keep their animals flea-free and\nindoors.\n--\nProMED\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n......................................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Pollack <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: Los Angeles Times, 21 Oct 1999 (edited)\n<http://www.latimes.com/news/state/19991021/t000095157.html>\n\nPrompted by the discovery of 5 animals with sylvatic plague, Los Angeles\nCounty health officials temporarily closed a popular nature park near\nPasadena and stepped up efforts to find and destroy infected animals.\nThree infected squirrels were found in the Eaton Canyon Park north of\nPasadena and a fourth infected squirrel at Table Mountain, an Angeles\nNational Forest camping area near San Bernardino County.\nThe fifth animal, a 5-month-old kitten, was found roaming the Rancho Mirage\nmobile home park in Lancaster, where it was apparently fed by a resident\nbefore being turned over to a nearby animal shelter last month.The cat is\nbelieved to have been destroyed.\nSylvatic plague, when transmitted to humans, is commonly known as bubonic\nplague, a bacterial infection that can be fatal if not treated, said\nJonathan Fielding, director of public health and the county's health officer.\nBut he said such occurrences are extremely rare and the last case of\nanimal-to-human infection in Los Angeles County was reported in 1984.\nAs a precaution, county officials closed Eaton Canyon Park on Tuesday for\nat least 10 days. County workers will set up 40 to 50 dust stations to kill\nfleas, which carry the plague among animals, and will exterminate 90% of\nthe ground squirrels, which officials say are the most common carriers of\nthe plague in the Los Angeles area. Fielding said the measures were\nnecessary because the park is heavily used by picnickers and hikers. It\ncontains the Eaton Canyon Nature Center, which draws hundreds of children\nand adults on weekends and is home to dozens of nature organizations.\nAt Table Mountain, the discovery of the infected squirrel required no\nextraordinary measures because it coincided with the camping area's normal\nannual closure, county officials said.\nThe Lancaster cat, however, has prompted additional concern because there\nhave been no such cases among domesticated animals since the late 1980s,\nsaid Frank Hall, chief of the Department of Health Services' vector\nmanagement program. Vectors are animals or insects that can transmit\ndisease to humans.\n\"We're concerned about where this cat came from,\" Hall said. \"Did it have a\nprevious owner?\"\nCounty health officials said they are investigating areas near the\nLancaster trailer park to determine the extent of the plague infestation.\nThe woman who fed the cat showed no signs of bubonic plague, Hall said.\nTracy Bryant, Rancho Mirage trailer park's resident manager, said the\ncounty only informed her Wednesday afternoon about the infected tabby. \"The\ncounty is suppose to be coming out tomorrow. We'll be informing all our\nresidents about the cat.\"\nThe latest sylvatic plague cases were discovered during a routine sampling\nof animals in shelters and wilderness areas by county health officers.\nBubonic plague, once known as the \"Black Death,\" is believed to have wiped\nout as much as a third of Europe's population during the 14th century. But\nwith advances in preventive methods, only about 10 or 15 cases are now\nreported annually in the United States. Still, county health officials are\nurging the public to take precautions.\nPeople should stay away from wild or stray animals and use insect repellent\nagainst fleas, Hall said. Even healthy-looking animals can harbor the\ndisease, and pet owners should try to keep their animals flea-free and\nindoors.\n--\nProMED\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n......................................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Pollack <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: Los Angeles Times, 21 Oct 1999 (edited)\n<http://www.latimes.com/news/state/19991021/t000095157.html>\n\nPrompted by the discovery of 5 animals with sylvatic plague, Los Angeles\nCounty health officials temporarily closed a popular nature park near\nPasadena and stepped up efforts to find and destroy infected animals.\nThree infected squirrels were found in the Eaton Canyon Park north of\nPasadena and a fourth infected squirrel at Table Mountain, an Angeles\nNational Forest camping area near San Bernardino County.\nThe fifth animal, a 5-month-old kitten, was found roaming the Rancho Mirage\nmobile home park in Lancaster, where it was apparently fed by a resident\nbefore being turned over to a nearby animal shelter last month.The cat is\nbelieved to have been destroyed.\nSylvatic plague, when transmitted to humans, is commonly known as bubonic\nplague, a bacterial infection that can be fatal if not treated, said\nJonathan Fielding, director of public health and the county's health officer.\nBut he said such occurrences are extremely rare and the last case of\nanimal-to-human infection in Los Angeles County was reported in 1984.\nAs a precaution, county officials closed Eaton Canyon Park on Tuesday for\nat least 10 days. County workers will set up 40 to 50 dust stations to kill\nfleas, which carry the plague among animals, and will exterminate 90% of\nthe ground squirrels, which officials say are the most common carriers of\nthe plague in the Los Angeles area. Fielding said the measures were\nnecessary because the park is heavily used by picnickers and hikers. It\ncontains the Eaton Canyon Nature Center, which draws hundreds of children\nand adults on weekends and is home to dozens of nature organizations.\nAt Table Mountain, the discovery of the infected squirrel required no\nextraordinary measures because it coincided with the camping area's normal\nannual closure, county officials said.\nThe Lancaster cat, however, has prompted additional concern because there\nhave been no such cases among domesticated animals since the late 1980s,\nsaid Frank Hall, chief of the Department of Health Services' vector\nmanagement program. Vectors are animals or insects that can transmit\ndisease to humans.\n\"We're concerned about where this cat came from,\" Hall said. \"Did it have a\nprevious owner?\"\nCounty health officials said they are investigating areas near the\nLancaster trailer park to determine the extent of the plague infestation.\nThe woman who fed the cat showed no signs of bubonic plague, Hall said.\nTracy Bryant, Rancho Mirage trailer park's resident manager, said the\ncounty only informed her Wednesday afternoon about the infected tabby. \"The\ncounty is suppose to be coming out tomorrow. We'll be informing all our\nresidents about the cat.\"\nThe latest sylvatic plague cases were discovered during a routine sampling\nof animals in shelters and wilderness areas by county health officers.\nBubonic plague, once known as the \"Black Death,\" is believed to have wiped\nout as much as a third of Europe's population during the 14th century. But\nwith advances in preventive methods, only about 10 or 15 cases are now\nreported annually in the United States. Still, county health officials are\nurging the public to take precautions.\nPeople should stay away from wild or stray animals and use insect repellent\nagainst fleas, Hall said. Even healthy-looking animals can harbor the\ndisease, and pet owners should try to keep their animals flea-free and\nindoors.\n--\nProMED\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n......................................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Pollack <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: Itar-Tass 03, Aug, 1999 (edited)\nSee Also\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Aktyubinsk) 990713103033\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Aktyubinsk) (02) 990717111432\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan 990802230845\nThree people, living in the Mangistauskaya Region, Western Kazakhstan,\ncontracted bubonic plague: a 13-year teenager, his mother and grandmother.\nThe patients are now at the hospital in the village of Beineu, situated 250\nkilometers from the regional administrative center Aktau.\nThe patients are now stable, although the teenager was in a critical\ncondition for several hours. Specialists of the local anti-plague center\nestablished the herdsman's family contracted the disease while cutting up\nthe carcass of a camel: only these animals can fall ill with this disease.\nA quarantine was put in placed at that locality. As many as 89 people\ncontacted the patients. Seven of them were hospitalized and are under\nmedical observation. They are mostly medics who inspected the patients for\nthe first time.\nEpidemiologists from the republican epidemiological center now work in the\nlocality. The regional administration appropriated 200,000 tenges (about\n1,500 U.S. dollars) for medicines. Measures were taken to localize the\nplague seat.\nThe Mangistauskaya Region is regarded as a higher risk zone for contracting\nplague, although the last case of plague was registered in the region 24\nyears ago. This is the third case of contracting plague in Kazakhstan this\nyear.\nThe Aktyubinsk and Kyzylorda regions registered one man each who fell ill\nwith plague in June.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia (formerly _Pasteurella_) pestis_ and affects\nprimarily the lymphatics and lungs. Plague is a historic scourge of man,\nwild rodents, and rabbits and cases associated with cats, dogs and camels\nare now recognized as hazards to man.\nThe primary means of spreading _Yersinia pestis_ is the flea. Contact with\ninfected carcasses has been a significant source of infection for man.\nEndemic foci of sylvatic plague exists in the western USA and in many areas\nworldwide. Throughout history, outbreaks of human plague involving rats in\ndensely populated agricultural or urban areas have occurred when rats\ncommingled with infected sylvatic rodents. - Mod.TG\n.................................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. Pollack <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: Itar-Tass 03, Aug, 1999 (edited)\nSee Also\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Aktyubinsk) 990713103033\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Aktyubinsk) (02) 990717111432\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan 990802230845\nThree people, living in the Mangistauskaya Region, Western Kazakhstan,\ncontracted bubonic plague: a 13-year teenager, his mother and grandmother.\nThe patients are now at the hospital in the village of Beineu, situated 250\nkilometers from the regional administrative center Aktau.\nThe patients are now stable, although the teenager was in a critical\ncondition for several hours. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Aktau", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aktyubinsk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2196283", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2196283", "date": "1999-08-04 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC- KAZAKHSTAN (02)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nDate: Tue, 03 Aug 1999 13:43:59 -0400\nFrom: Marjorie P. Pollack <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: Itar-Tass 03, Aug, 1999 (edited)\nSee Also\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Aktyubinsk) 990713103033\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Aktyubinsk) (02) 990717111432\nPlague, bubonic - Kazakhstan 990802230845\nThree people, living in the Mangistauskaya Region, Western Kazakhstan,\ncontracted bubonic plague: a 13-year teenager, his mother and grandmother.\nThe patients are now at the hospital in the village of Beineu, situated 250\nkilometers from the regional administrative center Aktau.\nThe patients are now stable, although the teenager was in a critical\ncondition for several hours. Specialists of the local anti-plague center\nestablished the herdsman's family contracted the disease while cutting up\nthe carcass of a camel: only these animals can fall ill with this disease.\nA quarantine was put in placed at that locality. As many as 89 people\ncontacted the patients. Seven of them were hospitalized and are under\nmedical observation. They are mostly medics who inspected the patients for\nthe first time.\nEpidemiologists from the republican epidemiological center now work in the\nlocality. The regional administration appropriated 200,000 tenges (about\n1,500 U.S. dollars) for medicines. Measures were taken to localize the\nplague seat.\nThe Mangistauskaya Region is regarded as a higher risk zone for contracting\nplague, although the last case of plague was registered in the region 24\nyears ago. This is the third case of contracting plague in Kazakhstan this\nyear.\nThe Aktyubinsk and Kyzylorda regions registered one man each who fell ill\nwith plague in June.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia (formerly _Pasteurella_) pestis_ and affects\nprimarily the lymphatics and lungs. Plague is a historic scourge of man,\nwild rodents, and rabbits and cases associated with cats, dogs and camels\nare now recognized as hazards to man.\nThe primary means of spreading _Yersinia pestis_ is the flea. Contact with\ninfected carcasses has been a significant source of infection for man.\nEndemic foci of sylvatic plague exists in the western USA and in many areas\nworldwide. Throughout history, outbreaks of human plague involving rats in\ndensely populated agricultural or urban areas have occurred when rats\ncommingled with infected sylvatic rodents. - Mod.TG\n.................................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Aktau", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aktyubinsk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2196188", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic - Kazakhstan", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2196188", "date": "1999-06-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, CATS AND DOGS TO HUMANS (02)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n[see also\nPlague, human - USA (Colorado) (03) 990609213850\nPlague, cats & dogs to humans 990619110831]\n[This is a comment re the second ref.above - Mod CHC]\nDate: Sat, 19 Jun 1999 15:47:14 -0400\nFrom: Raymond G. Whitham <rwhitha@emory.edu>\n\n\"[...Nevertheless, cats that explore rodent burrows, or kill and eat\nflea-infested rodents, could serve as temporary hosts for these\nectoparasites and bring them into human habitations, etc., where they could\njump off and bite people - Mod CHC]\"\nJudging from what Dr. Eidson has said, cats aren't very suitable hosts for\nrodent fleas (they apparently don't spend much time on them). The\npossibility would seem to be rather remote that they would wait on a cat's\nbody for it to come home, then to jump on an equally unsuitable host\n(human) to finally transmit the plaque. It is probably possible, but\nevidentially not the center of attention for a control program.\n--\nDr. Raymond G. Whitham\n<rwhitha@emory.edu>\n[Had I known anyone would read my comments, I would have said, \"fed on\npeople\", not \"bite people\". Nonetheless -- various workers have recovered\nrodent fleas from pets. There has been a cat-associated human plague case\nin northwestern New Mexico, where fleas were noted on the cat. Cat fleas\n(_Ctenocephalides felis_) are not present in this part of the U.S. (too\ndry) and the fleas almost undoubtedly were associated with the prairie\ndog/rock squirrel die-off that was going on in the same area. Rodent fleas\nmight not stay on pets for long periods of time but the fact that\ninvestigators have found them on these animals suggests that some rodent\nfleas stay on long enough to be carried into homes. While treating cats or\ndogs with flea powders that are insecticidal or repellent might not\ncompletely solve the problem, it is a relatively easy operation to perform\nand could result in some reduction of risks (of course, it would be best if\npeople confined their animals but they rarely do so). The entire\nprevention/control package would include community education, dusting\nrodent burrows, heightened surveillance, implementation of rodent\nsanitation measures, etc., as well as asking people to confine their\nanimals and to treat them for fleas. Treating pets is just a minor part of\nthe public health response and scarcely constitutes the \"center of\nattention\" of a control/prevention program. Let's cut this string. - Mod\nCHC]\n...................................................................chc/jw\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2196139", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic  - Malawi (southeast) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2196139", "date": "1999-06-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, CATS AND DOGS TO HUMANS (02)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n[see also\nPlague, human - USA (Colorado) (03) 990609213850\nPlague, cats & dogs to humans 990619110831]\n[This is a comment re the second ref.above - Mod CHC]\nDate: Sat, 19 Jun 1999 15:47:14 -0400\nFrom: Raymond G. Whitham <rwhitha@emory.edu>\n\n\"[...Nevertheless, cats that explore rodent burrows, or kill and eat\nflea-infested rodents, could serve as temporary hosts for these\nectoparasites and bring them into human habitations, etc., where they could\njump off and bite people - Mod CHC]\"\nJudging from what Dr. Eidson has said, cats aren't very suitable hosts for\nrodent fleas (they apparently don't spend much time on them). The\npossibility would seem to be rather remote that they would wait on a cat's\nbody for it to come home, then to jump on an equally unsuitable host\n(human) to finally transmit the plaque. It is probably possible, but\nevidentially not the center of attention for a control program.\n--\nDr. Raymond G. Whitham\n<rwhitha@emory.edu>\n[Had I known anyone would read my comments, I would have said, \"fed on\npeople\", not \"bite people\". Nonetheless -- various workers have recovered\nrodent fleas from pets. There has been a cat-associated human plague case\nin northwestern New Mexico, where fleas were noted on the cat. Cat fleas\n(_Ctenocephalides felis_) are not present in this part of the U.S. (too\ndry) and the fleas almost undoubtedly were associated with the prairie\ndog/rock squirrel die-off that was going on in the same area. Rodent fleas\nmight not stay on pets for long periods of time but the fact that\ninvestigators have found them on these animals suggests that some rodent\nfleas stay on long enough to be carried into homes. While treating cats or\ndogs with flea powders that are insecticidal or repellent might not\ncompletely solve the problem, it is a relatively easy operation to perform\nand could result in some reduction of risks (of course, it would be best if\npeople confined their animals but they rarely do so). The entire\nprevention/control package would include community education, dusting\nrodent burrows, heightened surveillance, implementation of rodent\nsanitation measures, etc., as well as asking people to confine their\nanimals and to treat them for fleas. Treating pets is just a minor part of\nthe public health response and scarcely constitutes the \"center of\nattention\" of a control/prevention program. Let's cut this string. - Mod\nCHC]\n...................................................................chc/jw\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Whitham <rwhitha@emory.edu>\n\n\"[...Nevertheless, cats that explore rodent burrows, or kill and eat\nflea-infested rodents, could serve as temporary hosts for these\nectoparasites and bring them into human habitations, etc., where they could\njump off and bite people - Mod CHC]\"\nJudging from what Dr. Eidson has said, cats aren't very suitable hosts for\nrodent fleas (they apparently don't spend much time on them). The\npossibility would seem to be rather remote that they would wait on a cat's\nbody for it to come home, then to jump on an equally unsuitable host\n(human) to finally transmit the plaque. It is probably possible, but\nevidentially not the center of attention for a control program.\n--\nDr. Raymond G. Whitham\n<rwhitha@emory.edu>\n[Had I known anyone would read my comments, I would have said, \"fed on\npeople\", not \"bite people\". Nonetheless -- various workers have recovered\nrodent fleas from pets. There has been a cat-associated human plague case\nin northwestern New Mexico, where fleas were noted on the cat. Cat fleas\n(_Ctenocephalides felis_) are not present in this part of the U.S. (too\ndry) and the fleas almost undoubtedly were associated with the prairie\ndog/rock squirrel die-off that was going on in the same area. Rodent fleas\nmight not stay on pets for long periods of time but the fact that\ninvestigators have found them on these animals suggests that some rodent\nfleas stay on long enough to be carried into homes. While treating cats or\ndogs with flea powders that are insecticidal or repellent might not\ncompletely solve the problem, it is a relatively easy operation to perform\nand could result in some reduction of risks (of course, it would be best if\npeople confined their animals but they rarely do so). The entire\nprevention/control package would include community education, dusting\nrodent burrows, heightened surveillance, implementation of rodent\nsanitation measures, etc., as well as asking people to confine their\nanimals and to treat them for fleas. Treating pets is just a minor part of\nthe public health response and scarcely constitutes the \"center of\nattention\" of a control/prevention program. It is probably possible, but\nevidentially not the center of attention for a control program.\n--\nDr. Raymond G. Whitham\n<rwhitha@emory.edu>\n[Had I known anyone would read my comments, I would have said, \"fed on\npeople\", not \"bite people\". Nonetheless -- various workers have recovered\nrodent fleas from pets. There has been a cat-associated human plague case\nin northwestern New Mexico, where fleas were noted on the cat. Cat fleas\n(_Ctenocephalides felis_) are not present in this part of the U.S. (too\ndry) and the fleas almost undoubtedly were associated with the prairie\ndog/rock squirrel die-off that was going on in the same area. Rodent fleas\nmight not stay on pets for long periods of time but the fact that\ninvestigators have found them on these animals suggests that some rodent\nfleas stay on long enough to be carried into homes. While treating cats or\ndogs with flea powders that are insecticidal or repellent might not\ncompletely solve the problem, it is a relatively easy operation to perform\nand could result in some reduction of risks (of course, it would be best if\npeople confined their animals but they rarely do so). The entire\nprevention/control package would include community education, dusting\nrodent burrows, heightened surveillance, implementation of rodent\nsanitation measures, etc., as well as asking people to confine their\nanimals and to treat them for fleas. Treating pets is just a minor part of\nthe public health response and scarcely constitutes the \"center of\nattention\" of a control/prevention program. Whitham <rwhitha@emory.edu>\n\n\"[...Nevertheless, cats that explore rodent burrows, or kill and eat\nflea-infested rodents, could serve as temporary hosts for these\nectoparasites and bring them into human habitations, etc., where they could\njump off and bite people - Mod CHC]\"\nJudging from what Dr. Eidson has said, cats aren't very suitable hosts for\nrodent fleas (they apparently don't spend much time on them). The\npossibility would seem to be rather remote that they would wait on a cat's\nbody for it to come home, then to jump on an equally unsuitable host\n(human) to finally transmit the plaque. It is probably possible, but\nevidentially not the center of attention for a control program.\n--\nDr. Raymond G. Whitham\n<rwhitha@emory.edu>\n[Had I known anyone would read my comments, I would have said, \"fed on\npeople\", not \"bite people\". Nonetheless -- various workers have recovered\nrodent fleas from pets. There has been a cat-associated human plague case\nin northwestern New Mexico, where fleas were noted on the cat. Cat fleas\n(_Ctenocephalides felis_) are not present in this part of the U.S. (too\ndry) and the fleas almost undoubtedly were associated with the prairie\ndog/rock squirrel die-off that was going on in the same area. Rodent fleas\nmight not stay on pets for long periods of time but the fact that\ninvestigators have found them on these animals suggests that some rodent\nfleas stay on long enough to be carried into homes. While treating cats or\ndogs with flea powders that are insecticidal or repellent might not\ncompletely solve the problem, it is a relatively easy operation to perform\nand could result in some reduction of risks (of course, it would be best if\npeople confined their animals but they rarely do so). The entire\nprevention/control package would include community education, dusting\nrodent burrows, heightened surveillance, implementation of rodent\nsanitation measures, etc., as well as asking people to confine their\nanimals and to treat them for fleas. Treating pets is just a minor part of\nthe public health response and scarcely constitutes the \"center of\nattention\" of a control/prevention program. Whitham <rwhitha@emory.edu>\n\n\"[...Nevertheless, cats that explore rodent burrows, or kill and eat\nflea-infested rodents, could serve as temporary hosts for these\nectoparasites and bring them into human habitations, etc., where they could\njump off and bite people - Mod CHC]\"\nJudging from what Dr. Eidson has said, cats aren't very suitable hosts for\nrodent fleas (they apparently don't spend much time on them). It is probably possible, but\nevidentially not the center of attention for a control program.\n--\nDr. Raymond G. Whitham\n<rwhitha@emory.edu>\n[Had I known anyone would read my comments, I would have said, \"fed on\npeople\", not \"bite people\". Nonetheless -- various workers have recovered\nrodent fleas from pets. There has been a cat-associated human plague case\nin northwestern New Mexico, where fleas were noted on the cat. Cat fleas\n(_Ctenocephalides felis_) are not present in this part of the U.S. (too\ndry) and the fleas almost undoubtedly were associated with the prairie\ndog/rock squirrel die-off that was going on in the same area. Rodent fleas\nmight not stay on pets for long periods of time but the fact that\ninvestigators have found them on these animals suggests that some rodent\nfleas stay on long enough to be carried into homes. While treating cats or\ndogs with flea powders that are insecticidal or repellent might not\ncompletely solve the problem, it is a relatively easy operation to perform\nand could result in some reduction of risks (of course, it would be best if\npeople confined their animals but they rarely do so). The entire\nprevention/control package would include community education, dusting\nrodent burrows, heightened surveillance, implementation of rodent\nsanitation measures, etc., as well as asking people to confine their\nanimals and to treat them for fleas. Treating pets is just a minor part of\nthe public health response and scarcely constitutes the \"center of\nattention\" of a control/prevention program. Let's cut this string. - Mod\nCHC]\n...................................................................chc/jw\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2195912", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, cats & dogs to humans", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2195912", "date": "1999-05-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC - NAMIBIA (05)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nSee Also\nPlague, bubonic - Namibia (04): confirmed 990510144515\n***************************\n... 39 cases have occurred up to 5 May 1999, 6 of which have been\nlaboratory confirmed. Eight patients have died of suspected plague.\n***************************\n[1\nDate: Tue, 11 May 1999 20:18:01 -0400\nFrom: \"Marjorie P. Pollack\" <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: WHO/CSR report, 11 May 1999\nhttp://www.who.int/emc/outbreak_news/n1999/may/n11may1999.html\n\nDisease outbreaks reported\n11 May 1999\nPlague in Namibia\n-----------------------\nThe Ministry of Health and Social Services has reported plague cases in\nOhangwena Region in the north western part of the country. The first\nsuspected case was reported on 6 Apr 1999 and 39 cases have occurred\nup to 5 May 1999, 6 of which have been laboratory confirmed.\nEight patients have died of suspected plague.\nThe North West regional directorate team, which has had experience in\ndealing with plague, has undertaken control activities, including training\ncourses for health workers, community mobilization for preventive measures,\nadditional nurses placed at local hospitals and dusting of homesteads.\nThe Ministry of Health report also states that, although plague has been\nendemic in this part of the country, it was successfully controlled in\nrecent years, the last known cases having occurred in January 1994.\n***\n[2\n21:53:54 -0400 (EDT)\nDate: Tue, 11 May 1999 21:53:01 -0400\nFrom: \"Marjorie P. Pollack\" <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: The Namibian, 11 May 1999 [edited\nPlague on increase: At least 21 villages affected\n------------------------------------------------------\nThe bubonic plague in the Ohangwena region is spreading from village\nto village and has already struck down people in two health areas.\nPreviously cases were only reported in Ohangwena's Eenhana health\ndistrict now the disease is reported to have broken out in the Engela\nhealth district in Ohangwena.\nFears are also rife that it has reached the Oshana region, where a resident\nof a village between Ondangwa and Oshakati is said to have been\nadmitted to hospital with bubonic plague. The worst-affected village in\nthe Engela district is Oshatotwa, where one resident is reported to have\ndied from the feared disease.\nSeven plague patients, who were admitted to Eenhana hospital three\nweeks ago, have all been discharged, and the hospital is only treating\none patient for the plague at the moment. It is also believed that\nOnandjokwe hospital has admitted a patient who could be suffering\nfrom the plague. The patient is from Onakatambilili-Eheke, a village\nbetween Ondangwa and Oshakati in the Oshana Region. This means\nthat the plague (Okatumba) could be spreading to other regions and that\ninfected residents may not yet have been diagnosed with having the\ndisease, some health workers told The Namibian yesterday.\nAccording to information given to The Namibian, the first three people\nwho died from bubonic plague, died in Onandjokwe Hospital on March\n25 and April 4.\nAdded to the eight villages already reported to have been affected by the\ndisease in the Ohangwena region are 13 more villages in the Engela\nhealth district. Early last week, Dr Hamata and his team took blood\nsample from patients and sent them to the South African Institute for\nMedical Research which found six of the 11 samples to be positive.\nYesterday Hamata said a team of health inspectors from Oshakati\nHospital went out last Sunday and yesterday to villages such as\nOshatotwa and Onandova to put up traps to catch rats. It is hoped that\nthe fleas that are carrying the disease can be extracted and sent to South\nAfrica for further testing.\nBubonic plague is caused by a bacterium which can be transmitted to\nhumans by flea bites. The fleas often live on rodents such as rats.\n[Byline: Oswald Shivute At Oshakati\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n[To those readers who picked up the error in the original article of\nconfirmation from The Namibian, where _Yersinia pestis_ was referred\nto as a virus, rather than a bacterium, thank you - MPP\n................................................jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
