The first\nsuspected case was reported on 6 Apr 1999 and 39 cases have occurred\nup to 5 May 1999, 6 of which have been laboratory confirmed.\nEight patients have died of suspected plague.\nThe North West regional directorate team, which has had experience in\ndealing with plague, has undertaken control activities, including training\ncourses for health workers, community mobilization for preventive measures,\nadditional nurses placed at local hospitals and dusting of homesteads.\nThe Ministry of Health report also states that, although plague has been\nendemic in this part of the country, it was successfully controlled in\nrecent years, the last known cases having occurred in January 1994.\n***\n[2\n21:53:54 -0400 (EDT)\nDate: Tue, 11 May 1999 21:53:01 -0400\nFrom: \"Marjorie P. Pollack\" <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: The Namibian, 11 May 1999 [edited\nPlague on increase: At least 21 villages affected\n------------------------------------------------------\nThe bubonic plague in the Ohangwena region is spreading from village\nto village and has already struck down people in two health areas.\nPreviously cases were only reported in Ohangwena's Eenhana health\ndistrict now the disease is reported to have broken out in the Engela\nhealth district in Ohangwena.\nFears are also rife that it has reached the Oshana region, where a resident\nof a village between Ondangwa and Oshakati is said to have been\nadmitted to hospital with bubonic plague. The worst-affected village in\nthe Engela district is Oshatotwa, where one resident is reported to have\ndied from the feared disease.\nSeven plague patients, who were admitted to Eenhana hospital three\nweeks ago, have all been discharged, and the hospital is only treating\none patient for the plague at the moment. It is also believed that\nOnandjokwe hospital has admitted a patient who could be suffering\nfrom the plague. The patient is from Onakatambilili-Eheke, a village\nbetween Ondangwa and Oshakati in the Oshana Region. This means\nthat the plague (Okatumba) could be spreading to other regions and that\ninfected residents may not yet have been diagnosed with having the\ndisease, some health workers told The Namibian yesterday.\nAccording to information given to The Namibian, the first three people\nwho died from bubonic plague, died in Onandjokwe Hospital on March\n25 and April 4.\nAdded to the eight villages already reported to have been affected by the\ndisease in the Ohangwena region are 13 more villages in the Engela\nhealth district. Early last week, Dr Hamata and his team took blood\nsample from patients and sent them to the South African Institute for\nMedical Research which found six of the 11 samples to be positive.\nYesterday Hamata said a team of health inspectors from Oshakati\nHospital went out last Sunday and yesterday to villages such as\nOshatotwa and Onandova to put up traps to catch rats. It is hoped that\nthe fleas that are carrying the disease can be extracted and sent to South\nAfrica for further testing.\nBubonic plague is caused by a bacterium which can be transmitted to\nhumans by flea bites. The first\nsuspected case was reported on 6 Apr 1999 and 39 cases have occurred\nup to 5 May 1999, 6 of which have been laboratory confirmed.\nEight patients have died of suspected plague.\nThe North West regional directorate team, which has had experience in\ndealing with plague, has undertaken control activities, including training\ncourses for health workers, community mobilization for preventive measures,\nadditional nurses placed at local hospitals and dusting of homesteads.\nThe Ministry of Health report also states that, although plague has been\nendemic in this part of the country, it was successfully controlled in\nrecent years, the last known cases having occurred in January 1994.\n***\n[2\n21:53:54 -0400 (EDT)\nDate: Tue, 11 May 1999 21:53:01 -0400\nFrom: \"Marjorie P. Pollack\" <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: The Namibian, 11 May 1999 [edited\nPlague on increase: At least 21 villages affected\n------------------------------------------------------\nThe bubonic plague in the Ohangwena region is spreading from village\nto village and has already struck down people in two health areas.\nPreviously cases were only reported in Ohangwena's Eenhana health\ndistrict now the disease is reported to have broken out in the Engela\nhealth district in Ohangwena.\nFears are also rife that it has reached the Oshana region, where a resident\nof a village between Ondangwa and Oshakati is said to have been\nadmitted to hospital with bubonic plague. The worst-affected village in\nthe Engela district is Oshatotwa, where one resident is reported to have\ndied from the feared disease.\nSeven plague patients, who were admitted to Eenhana hospital three\nweeks ago, have all been discharged, and the hospital is only treating\none patient for the plague at the moment. It is also believed that\nOnandjokwe hospital has admitted a patient who could be suffering\nfrom the plague. The patient is from Onakatambilili-Eheke, a village\nbetween Ondangwa and Oshakati in the Oshana Region. This means\nthat the plague (Okatumba) could be spreading to other regions and that\ninfected residents may not yet have been diagnosed with having the\ndisease, some health workers told The Namibian yesterday.\nAccording to information given to The Namibian, the first three people\nwho died from bubonic plague, died in Onandjokwe Hospital on March\n25 and April 4.\nAdded to the eight villages already reported to have been affected by the\ndisease in the Ohangwena region are 13 more villages in the Engela\nhealth district. Early last week, Dr Hamata and his team took blood\nsample from patients and sent them to the South African Institute for\nMedical Research which found six of the 11 samples to be positive.\nYesterday Hamata said a team of health inspectors from Oshakati\nHospital went out last Sunday and yesterday to villages such as\nOshatotwa and Onandova to put up traps to catch rats. It is hoped that\nthe fleas that are carrying the disease can be extracted and sent to South\nAfrica for further testing.\nBubonic plague is caused by a bacterium which can be transmitted to\nhumans by flea bites. The fleas often live on rodents such as rats.\n[Byline: Oswald Shivute At Oshakati\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n[To those readers who picked up the error in the original article of\nconfirmation from The Namibian, where _Yersinia pestis_ was referred\nto as a virus, rather than a bacterium, thank you - MPP\n................................................jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The first\nsuspected case was reported on 6 Apr 1999 and 39 cases have occurred\nup to 5 May 1999, 6 of which have been laboratory confirmed.\nEight patients have died of suspected plague.\nThe North West regional directorate team, which has had experience in\ndealing with plague, has undertaken control activities, including training\ncourses for health workers, community mobilization for preventive measures,\nadditional nurses placed at local hospitals and dusting of homesteads.\nThe Ministry of Health report also states that, although plague has been\nendemic in this part of the country, it was successfully controlled in\nrecent years, the last known cases having occurred in January 1994.\n***\n[2\n21:53:54 -0400 (EDT)\nDate: Tue, 11 May 1999 21:53:01 -0400\nFrom: \"Marjorie P. Pollack\" <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: WHO/CSR report, 11 May 1999\nhttp://www.who.int/emc/outbreak_news/n1999/may/n11may1999.html\n\nDisease outbreaks reported\n11 May 1999\nPlague in Namibia\n-----------------------\nThe Ministry of Health and Social Services has reported plague cases in\nOhangwena Region in the north western part of the country. The first\nsuspected case was reported on 6 Apr 1999 and 39 cases have occurred\nup to 5 May 1999, 6 of which have been laboratory confirmed.\nEight patients have died of suspected plague.\nThe North West regional directorate team, which has had experience in\ndealing with plague, has undertaken control activities, including training\ncourses for health workers, community mobilization for preventive measures,\nadditional nurses placed at local hospitals and dusting of homesteads.\nThe Ministry of Health report also states that, although plague has been\nendemic in this part of the country, it was successfully controlled in\nrecent years, the last known cases having occurred in January 1994.\n***\n[2\n21:53:54 -0400 (EDT)\nDate: Tue, 11 May 1999 21:53:01 -0400\nFrom: \"Marjorie P. Pollack\" <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: The Namibian, 11 May 1999 [edited\nPlague on increase: At least 21 villages affected\n------------------------------------------------------\nThe bubonic plague in the Ohangwena region is spreading from village\nto village and has already struck down people in two health areas.\nPreviously cases were only reported in Ohangwena's Eenhana health\ndistrict now the disease is reported to have broken out in the Engela\nhealth district in Ohangwena.\nFears are also rife that it has reached the Oshana region, where a resident\nof a village between Ondangwa and Oshakati is said to have been\nadmitted to hospital with bubonic plague. The worst-affected village in\nthe Engela district is Oshatotwa, where one resident is reported to have\ndied from the feared disease.\nSeven plague patients, who were admitted to Eenhana hospital three\nweeks ago, have all been discharged, and the hospital is only treating\none patient for the plague at the moment. It is also believed that\nOnandjokwe hospital has admitted a patient who could be suffering\nfrom the plague. The patient is from Onakatambilili-Eheke, a village\nbetween Ondangwa and Oshakati in the Oshana Region. This means\nthat the plague (Okatumba) could be spreading to other regions and that\ninfected residents may not yet have been diagnosed with having the\ndisease, some health workers told The Namibian yesterday.\nAccording to information given to The Namibian, the first three people\nwho died from bubonic plague, died in Onandjokwe Hospital on March\n25 and April 4.\nAdded to the eight villages already reported to have been affected by the\ndisease in the Ohangwena region are 13 more villages in the Engela\nhealth district. It is hoped that\nthe fleas that are carrying the disease can be extracted and sent to South\nAfrica for further testing.\nBubonic plague is caused by a bacterium which can be transmitted to\nhumans by flea bites. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "1999-05-16 00:00:00", "1999-05-16 00:00:00", "1999-05-11 00:00:00", "1999-05-11 00:00:00", "1999-04-06 00:00:00", "1994-01-16 00:00:00", "1999-05-16 00:00:00", "1999-05-11 00:00:00", "2021-04-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Onandova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Namibia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eenhana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ondangwa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohangwena", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oshakati", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Engela", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2195633", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic - Namibia (04): confirmed", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2195633", "date": "1998-10-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA: REPORTING\n*************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n<http://www.fas.org/promed>\nSee Also\nPlague - USA (California & New Mexico) 980518232356\nPlague, bubonic - USA (California & New Mexico) (02) 980612194123\nPlague, wild rodents, warning - USA (California) 980705231736\nPlague, bubonic - USA (New Mexico) 980805221400\nPlague, human - USA (Arizona) 981002154746\nPlague, human - USA (Arizona) (02) 981011001623\nPlague, human - USA (Arizona) (03) 981018225103\nPlague, human - USA (Arizona) (04) 981020202037\nPlague, human - USA (Colorado, New Mexico) 980724220112\nPlague, human - USA (Colorado, New Mexico) (02) 980728214322\nPlague, pet prairie dogs - USA (Texas) 980710224535\nPlague epidemiology\n980520075045\nPlague epidemiology (02)\n980525072547\nPlague epidemiology (03)\n980526221852\n[1\nDate: Fri, 23 Oct 1998 15:32:08 -0400\nFrom: Ron_St.John@hc-sc.gc.ca\n\nI would like to take this opportunity to clarify some of the points\nraised\nby Dr. Jon Rosenberg in his 20 Oct 1998 comments on plague reporting.\n[Plague, human - USA (Arizona) (04) 981020202037\nRegarding the disease, as the Moderator rightly pointed out, the WHO\ndecision regarding the notification of sporadic cases is based on input\nfrom internationally recognized health experts. Obviously such\nnotification can only be conducted with the full cooperation of local\nhealth departments.\nDr. Rosenberg asks what advice on plague Health Canada provides to\ntravellers to the Rockies. Our response to this question is that in\nmany\ninstances we do not provide specific advice regarding endemic pathogens,\nunless there is some change to indicate that the level of risk for the\ntraveller has increased. Thus, we would not routinely advise travellers\nto\nthe Rockies regarding their risk for Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever unless\nthere was some change in risk, e.g., a change from endemic to epidemic.\nBased on the evidence to date, we do not feel it is necessary to provide\nsuch travellers with specific information on plague in the Rockies at\nthe\npresent time. However, should the situation change, say in a way\ncomparable to the William Heise County Park situation [see below,\nthen we would respond accordingly.\nOur approach would be to identify the risk, assess\nit, and then provide travellers with the appropriate advice. In a\nnutshell, the identification of the risk and the assessment of that risk\nwould be the cornerstone of our response.\nAs Dr. Rosenberg rightly points out, sporadic cases of a specific\ndisease\nmay be expected to occur from time to time in known endemic areas. But\nI\nthink he will agree that a change in the endemic pattern of disease\nmight\nwarrant a timely public health response. In fact, this is how we\ninterpreted the actions of the public health officials in the County of\nSan\nDiego, Department of Health Services, San Diego, California, when in\nJune\n1998 they thought it necessary to warn campers and visitors to the\nWilliam\nHeise County Park that routine monitoring suggested that chipmunks,\nground\nsquirrels or other wild rodents in this area might be infected with\nplague.\nThey identified a potential public health risk, assessed it and\nimplemented\nthe necessary measures, including warning signs in the Park.\n[Plague, wild rodents, warning - USA (California) 980705231736\n>From our\nperspective these actions justified an appropriate advisory notice to\nCanadian travellers who might be visiting the above area, especially\nsince\nCanadians travelling and camping in the US are not aware of, nor do they\nexpect to encounter, serious infectious diseases. I can assure Dr.\nRosenberg that if a similar situation developed in Canada, then our\nresponse would be similar.\nAlthough human plague is still sporadic in North America, I do not\nbelieve\nthat we can ignore changing trends and patterns in the wild rodent\nreservoir. In turn, this means timely dissemination of information and\nappropriate responses by the public health authorities in question.\n--\nDr. R. St. John\nDirector\nOffice of Special Health Initiatives\nLaboratory Centre for Disease Control\nHealth Canada\nRon_St.John@hc-sc.gc.ca\n***\n[2\nDate: Wed, 21 Oct 1998 09:15:25 -0700\nFrom: \"Rosenberg, Jon\" <JRosenbe@dhs.ca.gov>\n\nSubscribers should make an effort to read accurately notes prior to\nresponding. Dr. Taylor and I never took a position against reporting of\nplague cases; we only took exception to criticism for failing to rapidly\nreport cases.\nLocal health departments should be afforded some professional\njudgement to distinguish between cases of little immediate public health\nimport beyond the locality, e.g., a sporadic case of plague in an area\nwell\nknown to be endemic for plague, and an outbreak of a mosquito-borne\nvirus.\nAll reportable diseases should not have to be immediately broadcast\nglobally\nover ProMED-mail.\nIn California, with a population of over 33 million people, we\nhave reported annually at least 6000 cases of hepatitis A with numerous\nfoodborne and community-wide outbreaks, 4000 cases of tuberculosis, 1000\ncases of foodborne illness associated with 100 outbreaks, 1000-3000\ncases of\nviral meningitis, 500 cases of pertussis, 300 cases of invasive\nmeningococcal infections, 200 cases of malaria, 50 cases of\nlegionellosis,\n30 cases of brucellosis, 30-40 cases of infant botulism, 10-20 cases of\nwound botulism, 3-5 cases of foodborne botulism, 3-5 cases of relapsing\nfever, and 1-2 cases of human plague, human rabies, hantavirus pulmonary\nsyndrome, and tularemia, just to highlight some of the 71 categories of\nreportable diseases that might be of some interest to ProMED\nsubscribers.\nWe would have to dedicate a position to reporting to ProMED just to keep\nup\nwith these. We and our 56 local health jurisdictions try to be\nresponsible\nin our reporting, so forgive us if we are sensitive to criticism that\nsome\nweeks might elapse before we report a case of sporadic human plague to\nCDC\nor ProMED-mail.\n--\nJon Rosenberg, M.D.\nCalifornia Department of Health Services\nDivision of Communicable Disease Control\nInfection Control and Healthcare Epidemiology\n2151 Berkeley Way\nBerkeley CA 84704\nPhone (510) 540-3233 Fax (510) 540-2570\n<jrosenbe@dhs.ca.gov>\n[The comments *were* read carefully. We certainly agree that \"All\nreportable diseases should not have to be immediately broadcast globally\nover ProMED-mail.\" As for \"We would have to dedicate a position to\nreporting to ProMED[-mail just to keep up with these,\" if California\ncould just report those reportable diseases rapidly to CDC, that would\nbe good enough for us. We are mainly interested in outbreaks of emerging\ninfectious diseases and toxins, and therefore the majority of the\nimpressive list of diseases reported above are not of interest to this\nlist.\nThe issue is why individual states do not help the USA fulfil its\nobligation under the International Health Regulations (IHR) to report\nsporadic cases of plague to WHO within 24 hours.\nA subsidiary issue is whether delayed reporting might result in delayed\nrecognition of a terrorist trial run with plague (the sarin attack in\nTokyo was preceded by at least one trial, and the typhoid incident in\nOregon years ago appeared to be a trial run).\nIf there is a strong feeling in the USA that there is no hurry to report\nsuch cases, in spite of concerns such as Health Canada\u00b4s (above) and\nabout bioterrorism, then the US authorities concerned should lobby WHO\nto drop the requirement for immediate notification, rather than letting\nindividual states decide for themselves when they are ready to report.\nThe proposed revision of the IHR will apparently leave it up to\ncountries -- but not to their component states or provinces -- to decide\nwhether or not to report such cases if they unilaterally deem they are\nof no international importance. Whether that is a good idea will be\ndebated at WHO during the coming months - Mod.JW\n.............................jw\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism", "brucellosis", "hantavirus", "hepatitis a", "malaria", "pertussis", "plague", "rabies", "tuberculosis", "tularemia", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-06-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tokyo", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the County of \n San \n Diego , Department of Health Services", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "San Diego", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Heise County Park", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2194781", "headline": "PRO/ALL> The Eleventh Plague", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194781", "date": "1998-10-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA: REPORTING\n*************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n<http://www.fas.org/promed>\nSee Also\nPlague - USA (California & New Mexico) 980518232356\nPlague, bubonic - USA (California & New Mexico) (02) 980612194123\nPlague, wild rodents, warning - USA (California) 980705231736\nPlague, bubonic - USA (New Mexico) 980805221400\nPlague, human - USA (Arizona) 981002154746\nPlague, human - USA (Arizona) (02) 981011001623\nPlague, human - USA (Arizona) (03) 981018225103\nPlague, human - USA (Arizona) (04) 981020202037\nPlague, human - USA (Colorado, New Mexico) 980724220112\nPlague, human - USA (Colorado, New Mexico) (02) 980728214322\nPlague, pet prairie dogs - USA (Texas) 980710224535\nPlague epidemiology\n980520075045\nPlague epidemiology (02)\n980525072547\nPlague epidemiology (03)\n980526221852\n[1\nDate: Fri, 23 Oct 1998 15:32:08 -0400\nFrom: Ron_St.John@hc-sc.gc.ca\n\nI would like to take this opportunity to clarify some of the points\nraised\nby Dr. Jon Rosenberg in his 20 Oct 1998 comments on plague reporting.\n[Plague, human - USA (Arizona) (04) 981020202037\nRegarding the disease, as the Moderator rightly pointed out, the WHO\ndecision regarding the notification of sporadic cases is based on input\nfrom internationally recognized health experts. Obviously such\nnotification can only be conducted with the full cooperation of local\nhealth departments.\nDr. Rosenberg asks what advice on plague Health Canada provides to\ntravellers to the Rockies. Our response to this question is that in\nmany\ninstances we do not provide specific advice regarding endemic pathogens,\nunless there is some change to indicate that the level of risk for the\ntraveller has increased. Thus, we would not routinely advise travellers\nto\nthe Rockies regarding their risk for Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever unless\nthere was some change in risk, e.g., a change from endemic to epidemic.\nBased on the evidence to date, we do not feel it is necessary to provide\nsuch travellers with specific information on plague in the Rockies at\nthe\npresent time. However, should the situation change, say in a way\ncomparable to the William Heise County Park situation [see below,\nthen we would respond accordingly.\nOur approach would be to identify the risk, assess\nit, and then provide travellers with the appropriate advice. In a\nnutshell, the identification of the risk and the assessment of that risk\nwould be the cornerstone of our response.\nAs Dr. Rosenberg rightly points out, sporadic cases of a specific\ndisease\nmay be expected to occur from time to time in known endemic areas. But\nI\nthink he will agree that a change in the endemic pattern of disease\nmight\nwarrant a timely public health response. In fact, this is how we\ninterpreted the actions of the public health officials in the County of\nSan\nDiego, Department of Health Services, San Diego, California, when in\nJune\n1998 they thought it necessary to warn campers and visitors to the\nWilliam\nHeise County Park that routine monitoring suggested that chipmunks,\nground\nsquirrels or other wild rodents in this area might be infected with\nplague.\nThey identified a potential public health risk, assessed it and\nimplemented\nthe necessary measures, including warning signs in the Park.\n[Plague, wild rodents, warning - USA (California) 980705231736\n>From our\nperspective these actions justified an appropriate advisory notice to\nCanadian travellers who might be visiting the above area, especially\nsince\nCanadians travelling and camping in the US are not aware of, nor do they\nexpect to encounter, serious infectious diseases. I can assure Dr.\nRosenberg that if a similar situation developed in Canada, then our\nresponse would be similar.\nAlthough human plague is still sporadic in North America, I do not\nbelieve\nthat we can ignore changing trends and patterns in the wild rodent\nreservoir. In turn, this means timely dissemination of information and\nappropriate responses by the public health authorities in question.\n--\nDr. R. St. John\nDirector\nOffice of Special Health Initiatives\nLaboratory Centre for Disease Control\nHealth Canada\nRon_St.John@hc-sc.gc.ca\n***\n[2\nDate: Wed, 21 Oct 1998 09:15:25 -0700\nFrom: \"Rosenberg, Jon\" <JRosenbe@dhs.ca.gov>\n\nSubscribers should make an effort to read accurately notes prior to\nresponding. In a\nnutshell, the identification of the risk and the assessment of that risk\nwould be the cornerstone of our response.\nAs Dr. Rosenberg rightly points out, sporadic cases of a specific\ndisease\nmay be expected to occur from time to time in known endemic areas. But\nI\nthink he will agree that a change in the endemic pattern of disease\nmight\nwarrant a timely public health response. In fact, this is how we\ninterpreted the actions of the public health officials in the County of\nSan\nDiego, Department of Health Services, San Diego, California, when in\nJune\n1998 they thought it necessary to warn campers and visitors to the\nWilliam\nHeise County Park that routine monitoring suggested that chipmunks,\nground\nsquirrels or other wild rodents in this area might be infected with\nplague.\nThey identified a potential public health risk, assessed it and\nimplemented\nthe necessary measures, including warning signs in the Park.\n[Plague, wild rodents, warning - USA (California) 980705231736\n>From our\nperspective these actions justified an appropriate advisory notice to\nCanadian travellers who might be visiting the above area, especially\nsince\nCanadians travelling and camping in the US are not aware of, nor do they\nexpect to encounter, serious infectious diseases. I can assure Dr.\nRosenberg that if a similar situation developed in Canada, then our\nresponse would be similar.\nAlthough human plague is still sporadic in North America, I do not\nbelieve\nthat we can ignore changing trends and patterns in the wild rodent\nreservoir. In turn, this means timely dissemination of information and\nappropriate responses by the public health authorities in question.\n--\nDr. R. St. John\nDirector\nOffice of Special Health Initiatives\nLaboratory Centre for Disease Control\nHealth Canada\nRon_St.John@hc-sc.gc.ca\n***\n[2\nDate: Wed, 21 Oct 1998 09:15:25 -0700\nFrom: \"Rosenberg, Jon\" <JRosenbe@dhs.ca.gov>\n\nSubscribers should make an effort to read accurately notes prior to\nresponding. Dr. Taylor and I never took a position against reporting of\nplague cases; we only took exception to criticism for failing to rapidly\nreport cases.\nLocal health departments should be afforded some professional\njudgement to distinguish between cases of little immediate public health\nimport beyond the locality, e.g., a sporadic case of plague in an area\nwell\nknown to be endemic for plague, and an outbreak of a mosquito-borne\nvirus.\nAll reportable diseases should not have to be immediately broadcast\nglobally\nover ProMED-mail.\nIn California, with a population of over 33 million people, we\nhave reported annually at least 6000 cases of hepatitis A with numerous\nfoodborne and community-wide outbreaks, 4000 cases of tuberculosis, 1000\ncases of foodborne illness associated with 100 outbreaks, 1000-3000\ncases of\nviral meningitis, 500 cases of pertussis, 300 cases of invasive\nmeningococcal infections, 200 cases of malaria, 50 cases of\nlegionellosis,\n30 cases of brucellosis, 30-40 cases of infant botulism, 10-20 cases of\nwound botulism, 3-5 cases of foodborne botulism, 3-5 cases of relapsing\nfever, and 1-2 cases of human plague, human rabies, hantavirus pulmonary\nsyndrome, and tularemia, just to highlight some of the 71 categories of\nreportable diseases that might be of some interest to ProMED\nsubscribers.\nWe would have to dedicate a position to reporting to ProMED just to keep\nup\nwith these. We and our 56 local health jurisdictions try to be\nresponsible\nin our reporting, so forgive us if we are sensitive to criticism that\nsome\nweeks might elapse before we report a case of sporadic human plague to\nCDC\nor ProMED-mail.\n--\nJon Rosenberg, M.D.\nCalifornia Department of Health Services\nDivision of Communicable Disease Control\nInfection Control and Healthcare Epidemiology\n2151 Berkeley Way\nBerkeley CA 84704\nPhone (510) 540-3233 Fax (510) 540-2570\n<jrosenbe@dhs.ca.gov>\n[The comments *were* read carefully. We certainly agree that \"All\nreportable diseases should not have to be immediately broadcast globally\nover ProMED-mail.\" As for \"We would have to dedicate a position to\nreporting to ProMED[-mail just to keep up with these,\" if California\ncould just report those reportable diseases rapidly to CDC, that would\nbe good enough for us. We are mainly interested in outbreaks of emerging\ninfectious diseases and toxins, and therefore the majority of the\nimpressive list of diseases reported above are not of interest to this\nlist.\nThe issue is why individual states do not help the USA fulfil its\nobligation under the International Health Regulations (IHR) to report\nsporadic cases of plague to WHO within 24 hours.\nA subsidiary issue is whether delayed reporting might result in delayed\nrecognition of a terrorist trial run with plague (the sarin attack in\nTokyo was preceded by at least one trial, and the typhoid incident in\nOregon years ago appeared to be a trial run).\nIf there is a strong feeling in the USA that there is no hurry to report\nsuch cases, in spite of concerns such as Health Canada\u00b4s (above) and\nabout bioterrorism, then the US authorities concerned should lobby WHO\nto drop the requirement for immediate notification, rather than letting\nindividual states decide for themselves when they are ready to report.\nThe proposed revision of the IHR will apparently leave it up to\ncountries -- but not to their component states or provinces -- to decide\nwhether or not to report such cases if they unilaterally deem they are\nof no international importance. Whether that is a good idea will be\ndebated at WHO during the coming months - Mod.JW\n.............................jw\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA (California & New Mexico) 980518232356\nPlague, bubonic - USA (California & New Mexico) (02) 980612194123\nPlague, wild rodents, warning - USA (California) 980705231736\nPlague, bubonic - USA (New Mexico) 980805221400\nPlague, human - USA (Colorado, New Mexico) (02) 980728214322\nPlague, pet prairie dogs - USA (Texas) 980710224535\nPlague epidemiology\n980520075045\nPlague epidemiology (02)\n980525072547\nPlague epidemiology (03)\n980526221852\n[1\nDate: Fri, 23 Oct 1998 15:32:08 -0400\nFrom: Ron_St.John@hc-sc.gc.ca\n\nI would like to take this opportunity to clarify some of the points\nraised\nby Dr. Jon Rosenberg in his 20 Oct 1998 comments on plague reporting.\n[Plague, human - USA (Arizona) (04) 981020202037\nRegarding the disease, as the Moderator rightly pointed out, the WHO\ndecision regarding the notification of sporadic cases is based on input\nfrom internationally recognized health experts. Obviously such\nnotification can only be conducted with the full cooperation of local\nhealth departments.\nDr. Rosenberg asks what advice on plague Health Canada provides to\ntravellers to the Rockies. Our response to this question is that in\nmany\ninstances we do not provide specific advice regarding endemic pathogens,\nunless there is some change to indicate that the level of risk for the\ntraveller has increased. Thus, we would not routinely advise travellers\nto\nthe Rockies regarding their risk for Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever unless\nthere was some change in risk, e.g., a change from endemic to epidemic.\nBased on the evidence to date, we do not feel it is necessary to provide\nsuch travellers with specific information on plague in the Rockies at\nthe\npresent time. However, should the situation change, say in a way\ncomparable to the William Heise County Park situation [see below,\nthen we would respond accordingly.\nOur approach would be to identify the risk, assess\nit, and then provide travellers with the appropriate advice. In a\nnutshell, the identification of the risk and the assessment of that risk\nwould be the cornerstone of our response.\nAs Dr. Rosenberg rightly points out, sporadic cases of a specific\ndisease\nmay be expected to occur from time to time in known endemic areas. But\nI\nthink he will agree that a change in the endemic pattern of disease\nmight\nwarrant a timely public health response. I can assure Dr.\nRosenberg that if a similar situation developed in Canada, then our\nresponse would be similar.\nAlthough human plague is still sporadic in North America, I do not\nbelieve\nthat we can ignore changing trends and patterns in the wild rodent\nreservoir. In turn, this means timely dissemination of information and\nappropriate responses by the public health authorities in question.\n--\nDr. R. USA (Colorado, New Mexico) (02) 980728214322\nPlague, pet prairie dogs - USA (Texas) 980710224535\nPlague epidemiology\n980520075045\nPlague epidemiology (02)\n980525072547\nPlague epidemiology (03)\n980526221852\n[1\nDate: Fri, 23 Oct 1998 15:32:08 -0400\nFrom: Ron_St.John@hc-sc.gc.ca\n\nI would like to take this opportunity to clarify some of the points\nraised\nby Dr. Jon Rosenberg in his 20 Oct 1998 comments on plague reporting.\n[Plague, human - USA (Arizona) (04) 981020202037\nRegarding the disease, as the Moderator rightly pointed out, the WHO\ndecision regarding the notification of sporadic cases is based on input\nfrom internationally recognized health experts. Obviously such\nnotification can only be conducted with the full cooperation of local\nhealth departments.\nDr. Rosenberg asks what advice on plague Health Canada provides to\ntravellers to the Rockies. Our response to this question is that in\nmany\ninstances we do not provide specific advice regarding endemic pathogens,\nunless there is some change to indicate that the level of risk for the\ntraveller has increased. Thus, we would not routinely advise travellers\nto\nthe Rockies regarding their risk for Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever unless\nthere was some change in risk, e.g., a change from endemic to epidemic.\nBased on the evidence to date, we do not feel it is necessary to provide\nsuch travellers with specific information on plague in the Rockies at\nthe\npresent time. However, should the situation change, say in a way\ncomparable to the William Heise County Park situation [see below,\nthen we would respond accordingly.\nOur approach would be to identify the risk, assess\nit, and then provide travellers with the appropriate advice. In a\nnutshell, the identification of the risk and the assessment of that risk\nwould be the cornerstone of our response.\nAs Dr. Rosenberg rightly points out, sporadic cases of a specific\ndisease\nmay be expected to occur from time to time in known endemic areas. But\nI\nthink he will agree that a change in the endemic pattern of disease\nmight\nwarrant a timely public health response. In fact, this is how we\ninterpreted the actions of the public health officials in the County of\nSan\nDiego, Department of Health Services, San Diego, California, when in\nJune\n1998 they thought it necessary to warn campers and visitors to the\nWilliam\nHeise County Park that routine monitoring suggested that chipmunks,\nground\nsquirrels or other wild rodents in this area might be infected with\nplague.\nThey identified a potential public health risk, assessed it and\nimplemented\nthe necessary measures, including warning signs in the Park.\n[Plague, wild rodents, warning - USA (California) 980705231736\n>From our\nperspective these actions justified an appropriate advisory notice to\nCanadian travellers who might be visiting the above area, especially\nsince\nCanadians travelling and camping in the US are not aware of, nor do they\nexpect to encounter, serious infectious diseases. I can assure Dr.\nRosenberg that if a similar situation developed in Canada, then our\nresponse would be similar.\nAlthough human plague is still sporadic in North America, I do not\nbelieve\nthat we can ignore changing trends and patterns in the wild rodent\nreservoir. In turn, this means timely dissemination of information and\nappropriate responses by the public health authorities in question.\n--\nDr. R. St. John\nDirector\nOffice of Special Health Initiatives\nLaboratory Centre for Disease Control\nHealth Canada\nRon_St.John@hc-sc.gc.ca\n***\n[2\nDate: Wed, 21 Oct 1998 09:15:25 -0700\nFrom: \"Rosenberg, Jon\" <JRosenbe@dhs.ca.gov>\n\nSubscribers should make an effort to read accurately notes prior to\nresponding. Dr. Taylor and I never took a position against reporting of\nplague cases; we only took exception to criticism for failing to rapidly\nreport cases.\nLocal health departments should be afforded some professional\njudgement to distinguish between cases of little immediate public health\nimport beyond the locality, e.g., a sporadic case of plague in an area\nwell\nknown to be endemic for plague, and an outbreak of a mosquito-borne\nvirus.\nAll reportable diseases should not have to be immediately broadcast\nglobally\nover ProMED-mail.\nIn California, with a population of over 33 million people, we\nhave reported annually at least 6000 cases of hepatitis A with numerous\nfoodborne and community-wide outbreaks, 4000 cases of tuberculosis, 1000\ncases of foodborne illness associated with 100 outbreaks, 1000-3000\ncases of\nviral meningitis, 500 cases of pertussis, 300 cases of invasive\nmeningococcal infections, 200 cases of malaria, 50 cases of\nlegionellosis,\n30 cases of brucellosis, 30-40 cases of infant botulism, 10-20 cases of\nwound botulism, 3-5 cases of foodborne botulism, 3-5 cases of relapsing\nfever, and 1-2 cases of human plague, human rabies, hantavirus pulmonary\nsyndrome, and tularemia, just to highlight some of the 71 categories of\nreportable diseases that might be of some interest to ProMED\nsubscribers.\nWe would have to dedicate a position to reporting to ProMED just to keep\nup\nwith these. We and our 56 local health jurisdictions try to be\nresponsible\nin our reporting, so forgive us if we are sensitive to criticism that\nsome\nweeks might elapse before we report a case of sporadic human plague to\nCDC\nor ProMED-mail.\n--\nJon Rosenberg, M.D.\nCalifornia Department of Health Services\nDivision of Communicable Disease Control\nInfection Control and Healthcare Epidemiology\n2151 Berkeley Way\nBerkeley CA 84704\nPhone (510) 540-3233 Fax (510) 540-2570\n<jrosenbe@dhs.ca.gov>\n[The comments *were* read carefully. We certainly agree that \"All\nreportable diseases should not have to be immediately broadcast globally\nover ProMED-mail.\" As for \"We would have to dedicate a position to\nreporting to ProMED[-mail just to keep up with these,\" if California\ncould just report those reportable diseases rapidly to CDC, that would\nbe good enough for us. We are mainly interested in outbreaks of emerging\ninfectious diseases and toxins, and therefore the majority of the\nimpressive list of diseases reported above are not of interest to this\nlist.\nThe issue is why individual states do not help the USA fulfil its\nobligation under the International Health Regulations (IHR) to report\nsporadic cases of plague to WHO within 24 hours.\nA subsidiary issue is whether delayed reporting might result in delayed\nrecognition of a terrorist trial run with plague (the sarin attack in\nTokyo was preceded by at least one trial, and the typhoid incident in\nOregon years ago appeared to be a trial run).\nIf there is a strong feeling in the USA that there is no hurry to report\nsuch cases, in spite of concerns such as Health Canada\u00b4s (above) and\nabout bioterrorism, then the US authorities concerned should lobby WHO\nto drop the requirement for immediate notification, rather than letting\nindividual states decide for themselves when they are ready to report.\nThe proposed revision of the IHR will apparently leave it up to\ncountries -- but not to their component states or provinces -- to decide\nwhether or not to report such cases if they unilaterally deem they are\nof no international importance. Whether that is a good idea will be\ndebated at WHO during the coming months - Mod.JW\n.............................jw\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA (Arizona) (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194484", "date": "1998-08-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nSee Also\nPlague, human - USA (Colorado, New Mexico) 980724220112\nPlague, human - USA (Colorado, New Mexico) (02) 980728214322\nDate: Wed, 5 Aug 1998 12:13:30 GMT-3\nSource: News media, Mon 03 Aug 1998\nFrom: ProMED-mail\n\n[This gives backgound on a case contracted from a cat that was already\nreported to WHO & posted on ProMED-mail - Mod.JW\nThe veterinarian didn't think much about it when the sweet, sick cat she\nwas treating for an infection bit her on the thumb. Four days later, a high\nfever and intense pain in her arm sent her to the hospital. The diagnosis:\nbubonic plague.\nIn the United States, 10 to 15 cases are reported in humans each year,\nmostly in the West.\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents that generally is transmitted\nthrough flea bites. The culprits are most likely to be rock squirrels,\nground squirrels, prairie dogs or pack rats living roughly in the western\nhalf of the United States. Most of the human cases occur in the Southwest\n-- New Mexico accounts for more than half--and along the Sierra Nevada in\nCalifornia. There have been human cases reported in at least 13 Western\nstates.\nA roaming cat can bring plague to a suburban living room. Although flea\npowder and other precautions can reduce the risk, and prompt treatment with\nantibiotics can cure it, plague kills about 16% of its human victims,\naccording to the CDC.\nThere were 394 human plague cases in the nation from 1949 through 1997, 63\nof them fatal. New Mexico logged 218 of those, including 30 fatalities,\nsaid Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian with the state Department of\nHealth. \"It's a disease that can be fatal if not recognized and treated\nearly enough,\" Ettestad said.\nBubonic plague, which accounts for 80% of cases, is marked by swollen lymph\nglands, called buboes. It's harder to diagnose septicemic plague, which\ncirculates in the bloodstream, and pneumonic plague, which infects the\nlungs and is particularly dangerous because it can be transmitted through\ncoughing. Generally, those in contact with a pneumonic plague victim are\nalso treated with antibiotics.\n\"In the United States, we actually haven't had person-to-person\ntransmission since the 1920s--not that it couldn't occur,\" said the CDC's\nKen Gage.\nMost people become sick two to seven days after infection. Other symptoms\nare fever, chills, headache, muscle pain, nausea, vomiting and diarrhea.\nThe incidence of plague appears to be cyclical, apparently linked to the\nhigh-moisture, milder winters typical of El Nino years that cause rodents\nto thrive, Ettestad said. This is a big year, with the rodent population in\nNew Mexico estimated at 10 to 20 times higher than last year -- when no one\nin the state caught plague.\nBelieved to have evolved in central Asia, plague is new to the United\nStates. It arrived about 1900 in San Francisco aboard trading ships from\nChina and spread from urban rats into the wild rodent population of the\n[American West. There were outbreaks in ports along the Gulf of Mexico,\nbut it never got established in the native rodents there, according to the\nCDC.\nCats are more susceptible to plague than dogs, and get sicker.\nListlessness and not eating are clues that a cat is ill. \"If you become\nsick and there's a sick cat in the house, go see your doctor,\" [a\nveterinarian advised.\nPlague also can be contracted by handling infected animals. Hunters, for\nexample, are at risk if they don't wear gloves while skinning animals.\n[Written by: Deborah Baker [Excerpted\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n...............................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "San Francisco", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2194477", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, human - USA (Arizona) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194477", "date": "1998-08-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nSee Also\nPlague, human - USA (Colorado, New Mexico) 980724220112\nPlague, human - USA (Colorado, New Mexico) (02) 980728214322\nDate: Wed, 5 Aug 1998 12:13:30 GMT-3\nSource: News media, Mon 03 Aug 1998\nFrom: ProMED-mail\n\n[This gives backgound on a case contracted from a cat that was already\nreported to WHO & posted on ProMED-mail - Mod.JW\nThe veterinarian didn't think much about it when the sweet, sick cat she\nwas treating for an infection bit her on the thumb. Four days later, a high\nfever and intense pain in her arm sent her to the hospital. The diagnosis:\nbubonic plague.\nIn the United States, 10 to 15 cases are reported in humans each year,\nmostly in the West.\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents that generally is transmitted\nthrough flea bites. The culprits are most likely to be rock squirrels,\nground squirrels, prairie dogs or pack rats living roughly in the western\nhalf of the United States. Most of the human cases occur in the Southwest\n-- New Mexico accounts for more than half--and along the Sierra Nevada in\nCalifornia. There have been human cases reported in at least 13 Western\nstates.\nA roaming cat can bring plague to a suburban living room. Although flea\npowder and other precautions can reduce the risk, and prompt treatment with\nantibiotics can cure it, plague kills about 16% of its human victims,\naccording to the CDC.\nThere were 394 human plague cases in the nation from 1949 through 1997, 63\nof them fatal. New Mexico logged 218 of those, including 30 fatalities,\nsaid Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian with the state Department of\nHealth. \"It's a disease that can be fatal if not recognized and treated\nearly enough,\" Ettestad said.\nBubonic plague, which accounts for 80% of cases, is marked by swollen lymph\nglands, called buboes. It's harder to diagnose septicemic plague, which\ncirculates in the bloodstream, and pneumonic plague, which infects the\nlungs and is particularly dangerous because it can be transmitted through\ncoughing. Generally, those in contact with a pneumonic plague victim are\nalso treated with antibiotics.\n\"In the United States, we actually haven't had person-to-person\ntransmission since the 1920s--not that it couldn't occur,\" said the CDC's\nKen Gage.\nMost people become sick two to seven days after infection. Other symptoms\nare fever, chills, headache, muscle pain, nausea, vomiting and diarrhea.\nThe incidence of plague appears to be cyclical, apparently linked to the\nhigh-moisture, milder winters typical of El Nino years that cause rodents\nto thrive, Ettestad said. This is a big year, with the rodent population in\nNew Mexico estimated at 10 to 20 times higher than last year -- when no one\nin the state caught plague.\nBelieved to have evolved in central Asia, plague is new to the United\nStates. It arrived about 1900 in San Francisco aboard trading ships from\nChina and spread from urban rats into the wild rodent population of the\n[American West. There were outbreaks in ports along the Gulf of Mexico,\nbut it never got established in the native rodents there, according to the\nCDC.\nCats are more susceptible to plague than dogs, and get sicker.\nListlessness and not eating are clues that a cat is ill. \"If you become\nsick and there's a sick cat in the house, go see your doctor,\" [a\nveterinarian advised.\nPlague also can be contracted by handling infected animals. Hunters, for\nexample, are at risk if they don't wear gloves while skinning animals.\n[Written by: Deborah Baker [Excerpted\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n...............................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "San Francisco", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2194416", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, human - USA (Arizona) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194416", "date": "1998-08-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nSee Also\nPlague, human - USA (Colorado, New Mexico) 980724220112\nPlague, human - USA (Colorado, New Mexico) (02) 980728214322\nDate: Wed, 5 Aug 1998 12:13:30 GMT-3\nSource: News media, Mon 03 Aug 1998\nFrom: ProMED-mail\n\n[This gives backgound on a case contracted from a cat that was already\nreported to WHO & posted on ProMED-mail - Mod.JW\nThe veterinarian didn't think much about it when the sweet, sick cat she\nwas treating for an infection bit her on the thumb. Four days later, a high\nfever and intense pain in her arm sent her to the hospital. The diagnosis:\nbubonic plague.\nIn the United States, 10 to 15 cases are reported in humans each year,\nmostly in the West.\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents that generally is transmitted\nthrough flea bites. The culprits are most likely to be rock squirrels,\nground squirrels, prairie dogs or pack rats living roughly in the western\nhalf of the United States. Most of the human cases occur in the Southwest\n-- New Mexico accounts for more than half--and along the Sierra Nevada in\nCalifornia. There have been human cases reported in at least 13 Western\nstates.\nA roaming cat can bring plague to a suburban living room. Although flea\npowder and other precautions can reduce the risk, and prompt treatment with\nantibiotics can cure it, plague kills about 16% of its human victims,\naccording to the CDC.\nThere were 394 human plague cases in the nation from 1949 through 1997, 63\nof them fatal. New Mexico logged 218 of those, including 30 fatalities,\nsaid Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian with the state Department of\nHealth. \"It's a disease that can be fatal if not recognized and treated\nearly enough,\" Ettestad said.\nBubonic plague, which accounts for 80% of cases, is marked by swollen lymph\nglands, called buboes. It's harder to diagnose septicemic plague, which\ncirculates in the bloodstream, and pneumonic plague, which infects the\nlungs and is particularly dangerous because it can be transmitted through\ncoughing. Generally, those in contact with a pneumonic plague victim are\nalso treated with antibiotics.\n\"In the United States, we actually haven't had person-to-person\ntransmission since the 1920s--not that it couldn't occur,\" said the CDC's\nKen Gage.\nMost people become sick two to seven days after infection. Other symptoms\nare fever, chills, headache, muscle pain, nausea, vomiting and diarrhea.\nThe incidence of plague appears to be cyclical, apparently linked to the\nhigh-moisture, milder winters typical of El Nino years that cause rodents\nto thrive, Ettestad said. This is a big year, with the rodent population in\nNew Mexico estimated at 10 to 20 times higher than last year -- when no one\nin the state caught plague.\nBelieved to have evolved in central Asia, plague is new to the United\nStates. It arrived about 1900 in San Francisco aboard trading ships from\nChina and spread from urban rats into the wild rodent population of the\n[American West. There were outbreaks in ports along the Gulf of Mexico,\nbut it never got established in the native rodents there, according to the\nCDC.\nCats are more susceptible to plague than dogs, and get sicker.\nListlessness and not eating are clues that a cat is ill. \"If you become\nsick and there's a sick cat in the house, go see your doctor,\" [a\nveterinarian advised.\nPlague also can be contracted by handling infected animals. Hunters, for\nexample, are at risk if they don't wear gloves while skinning animals.\n[Written by: Deborah Baker [Excerpted\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n...............................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Four days later, a high\nfever and intense pain in her arm sent her to the hospital. The diagnosis:\nbubonic plague.\nIn the United States, 10 to 15 cases are reported in humans each year,\nmostly in the West.\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents that generally is transmitted\nthrough flea bites. The culprits are most likely to be rock squirrels,\nground squirrels, prairie dogs or pack rats living roughly in the western\nhalf of the United States. Most of the human cases occur in the Southwest\n-- New Mexico accounts for more than half--and along the Sierra Nevada in\nCalifornia. There have been human cases reported in at least 13 Western\nstates.\nA roaming cat can bring plague to a suburban living room. Although flea\npowder and other precautions can reduce the risk, and prompt treatment with\nantibiotics can cure it, plague kills about 16% of its human victims,\naccording to the CDC.\nThere were 394 human plague cases in the nation from 1949 through 1997, 63\nof them fatal. New Mexico logged 218 of those, including 30 fatalities,\nsaid Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian with the state Department of\nHealth. \"It's a disease that can be fatal if not recognized and treated\nearly enough,\" Ettestad said.\nBubonic plague, which accounts for 80% of cases, is marked by swollen lymph\nglands, called buboes. It's harder to diagnose septicemic plague, which\ncirculates in the bloodstream, and pneumonic plague, which infects the\nlungs and is particularly dangerous because it can be transmitted through\ncoughing. Generally, those in contact with a pneumonic plague victim are\nalso treated with antibiotics.\n\"In the United States, we actually haven't had person-to-person\ntransmission since the 1920s--not that it couldn't occur,\" said the CDC's\nKen Gage.\nMost people become sick two to seven days after infection. Other symptoms\nare fever, chills, headache, muscle pain, nausea, vomiting and diarrhea.\nThe incidence of plague appears to be cyclical, apparently linked to the\nhigh-moisture, milder winters typical of El Nino years that cause rodents\nto thrive, Ettestad said. This is a big year, with the rodent population in\nNew Mexico estimated at 10 to 20 times higher than last year -- when no one\nin the state caught plague.\nBelieved to have evolved in central Asia, plague is new to the United\nStates. It arrived about 1900 in San Francisco aboard trading ships from\nChina and spread from urban rats into the wild rodent population of the\n[American West. There were outbreaks in ports along the Gulf of Mexico,\nbut it never got established in the native rodents there, according to the\nCDC.\nCats are more susceptible to plague than dogs, and get sicker.\nListlessness and not eating are clues that a cat is ill. \"If you become\nsick and there's a sick cat in the house, go see your doctor,\" [a\nveterinarian advised.\nPlague also can be contracted by handling infected animals. Hunters, for\nexample, are at risk if they don't wear gloves while skinning animals.\n[Written by: Deborah Baker [Excerpted\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n...............................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Most of the human cases occur in the Southwest\n-- New Mexico accounts for more than half--and along the Sierra Nevada in\nCalifornia. There have been human cases reported in at least 13 Western\nstates.\nA roaming cat can bring plague to a suburban living room. Although flea\npowder and other precautions can reduce the risk, and prompt treatment with\nantibiotics can cure it, plague kills about 16% of its human victims,\naccording to the CDC.\nThere were 394 human plague cases in the nation from 1949 through 1997, 63\nof them fatal. New Mexico logged 218 of those, including 30 fatalities,\nsaid Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian with the state Department of\nHealth. \"It's a disease that can be fatal if not recognized and treated\nearly enough,\" Ettestad said.\nBubonic plague, which accounts for 80% of cases, is marked by swollen lymph\nglands, called buboes. It's harder to diagnose septicemic plague, which\ncirculates in the bloodstream, and pneumonic plague, which infects the\nlungs and is particularly dangerous because it can be transmitted through\ncoughing. Generally, those in contact with a pneumonic plague victim are\nalso treated with antibiotics.\n\"In the United States, we actually haven't had person-to-person\ntransmission since the 1920s--not that it couldn't occur,\" said the CDC's\nKen Gage.\nMost people become sick two to seven days after infection. Other symptoms\nare fever, chills, headache, muscle pain, nausea, vomiting and diarrhea.\nThe incidence of plague appears to be cyclical, apparently linked to the\nhigh-moisture, milder winters typical of El Nino years that cause rodents\nto thrive, Ettestad said. This is a big year, with the rodent population in\nNew Mexico estimated at 10 to 20 times higher than last year -- when no one\nin the state caught plague.\nBelieved to have evolved in central Asia, plague is new to the United\nStates. It arrived about 1900 in San Francisco aboard trading ships from\nChina and spread from urban rats into the wild rodent population of the\n[American West. There were outbreaks in ports along the Gulf of Mexico,\nbut it never got established in the native rodents there, according to the\nCDC.\nCats are more susceptible to plague than dogs, and get sicker.\nListlessness and not eating are clues that a cat is ill. \"If you become\nsick and there's a sick cat in the house, go see your doctor,\" [a\nveterinarian advised.\nPlague also can be contracted by handling infected animals. Hunters, for\nexample, are at risk if they don't wear gloves while skinning animals.\n[Written by: Deborah Baker [Excerpted\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n...............................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The provinces of Franz Tamayo and Sud\nYungas are wet tropical valleys near, or at the [southern Peruvian border,\nwhile Valle Grande is a dry semi-tropical Valley near the middle of the\ncountry. These provinces have weather and geographic conditions very\nsimilar to north and northeastern Peru and southern Ecuador. That's\nprobably a reason for not noticing similar infections in the northern\nArgentina and Chile, where these conditions are radically different.\n--\nRodrigo Rosa L.\nSYSTEM OPERATOR\nHealthNet-Bolivia\nPROGRAMA DE COORDINACION EN SALUD INTEGRAL\nPROYECTO HEALTHNET-BOLIVIA\nAv. 20 de Octubre 2164, La Paz\nPhone +591 (2) 416061\nFax +591 (2) 314188\ne-mail: SYSOP@bol.healthnet.org\n[This might argue that there may be a second affected area in southern Peru,\nadjoining the affected northern Bolivian tropical/semitropical territories.\nIf I remember correctly this area was severely afflicted by Shining Path\nactivities. - Mod.MHJ\n........................................mhj/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The provinces of Franz Tamayo and Sud\nYungas are wet tropical valleys near, or at the [southern Peruvian border,\nwhile Valle Grande is a dry semi-tropical Valley near the middle of the\ncountry. These provinces have weather and geographic conditions very\nsimilar to north and northeastern Peru and southern Ecuador. That's\nprobably a reason for not noticing similar infections in the northern\nArgentina and Chile, where these conditions are radically different.\n--\nRodrigo Rosa L.\nSYSTEM OPERATOR\nHealthNet-Bolivia\nPROGRAMA DE COORDINACION EN SALUD INTEGRAL\nPROYECTO HEALTHNET-BOLIVIA\nAv. 20 de Octubre 2164, La Paz\nPhone +591 (2) 416061\nFax +591 (2) 314188\ne-mail: SYSOP@bol.healthnet.org\n[This might argue that there may be a second affected area in southern Peru,\nadjoining the affected northern Bolivian tropical/semitropical territories.\nIf I remember correctly this area was severely afflicted by Shining Path\nactivities. - Mod.MHJ\n........................................mhj/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. That is, to view an American\nor Canadian programme taped directly to videotape, I think one will need a TV\nmade for that market. I don't remember if that is also true of the videotape\nmachine. I believe that it is possible to convert between formats, but that\nthis in essence requires making a new tape. Subscribers outside the US or\nCanada may wish to verify this before purchasing videotapes intended for sale\nhere. Perhaps someone with more technical expertise can clarify, as my\nexperience is somewhat dated.\n---\nJohn Gawoski, M.D.\nDepartment of Laboratory Medicine\nLahey Hitchcock Clinic\n41 Mall Road\nBurlington, MA 01805 USA\n617.273.8935\ne-mail: <jgawoski@warren.med.harvard.edu>\n[Absolutely correct. -- Mod CHC]\n................................\n[4]\nDate: Wed, 23 Apr 1997 02:35:25 +1000\nFrom: Ken and Meryl dorey <van@mypostbox.com>\nGood idea! That is, to view an American\nor Canadian programme taped directly to videotape, I think one will need a TV\nmade for that market. I don't remember if that is also true of the videotape\nmachine. I believe that it is possible to convert between formats, but that\nthis in essence requires making a new tape. Subscribers outside the US or\nCanada may wish to verify this before purchasing videotapes intended for sale\nhere. That is, to view an American\nor Canadian programme taped directly to videotape, I think one will need a TV\nmade for that market. I don't remember if that is also true of the videotape\nmachine. I believe that it is possible to convert between formats, but that\nthis in essence requires making a new tape. Subscribers outside the US or\nCanada may wish to verify this before purchasing videotapes intended for sale\nhere. Perhaps someone with more technical expertise can clarify, as my\nexperience is somewhat dated.\n---\nJohn Gawoski, M.D.\nDepartment of Laboratory Medicine\nLahey Hitchcock Clinic\n41 Mall Road\nBurlington, MA 01805 USA\n617.273.8935\ne-mail: <jgawoski@warren.med.harvard.edu>\n[Absolutely correct. -- Mod CHC]\n................................\n[4]\nDate: Wed, 23 Apr 1997 02:35:25 +1000\nFrom: Ken and Meryl dorey <van@mypostbox.com>\nGood idea! That is, to view an American\nor Canadian programme taped directly to videotape, I think one will need a TV\nmade for that market. I don't remember if that is also true of the videotape\nmachine. I believe that it is possible to convert between formats, but that\nthis in essence requires making a new tape. Subscribers outside the US or\nCanada may wish to verify this before purchasing videotapes intended for sale\nhere. Perhaps someone with more technical expertise can clarify, as my\nexperience is somewhat dated.\n---\nJohn Gawoski, M.D.\nDepartment of Laboratory Medicine\nLahey Hitchcock Clinic\n41 Mall Road\nBurlington, MA 01805 USA\n617.273.8935\ne-mail: <jgawoski@warren.med.harvard.edu>\n[Absolutely correct. -- Mod CHC]\n................................\n[4]\nDate: Wed, 23 Apr 1997 02:35:25 +1000\nFrom: Ken and Meryl dorey <van@mypostbox.com>\nGood idea! Newton, Ph.D.\" <Nolan_Newton@deh.ehnr.state.nc.us>\n\nCDC has posted a notice at http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/tbsplague.htm\nregarding the April 20 and April 27 showings of parts 1 and 2 of a\nTBS special based on \"The Coming Plague\".\n[The CDC notice runs as follows - Mod.JW]\n\nOverview of \"The Coming Plague\"\nTurner Broadcasting Superstation has put two years of work into a 4 hour\ndocumentary based on the research from Laurie Garrett's book of the same name.\n***Part 1 (two hours long) will show Sunday, April 20, 1997 at 9pm (ET). It\nwill show again Monday, April 21 at 12:05 am (ET).\n***Part II (also two hours long) will show Sunday, April 27 at 9pm (ET).\nPart II will show again Monday, April 28 at 12:05 am (ET).\nHour one: \"Virus Hunters\" follows disease cowboys around the world in an\neffort to solve epidemic mysteries and discover ways to prevent future\noutbreaks.\nHour two: \"The Price of Passion\" focus on the AIDS epidemic and its global\nimplications.\nHour three: \"Revenge of the Microbes\" documents the pathogens' ability to\nfight back against our technology.\nHour four: \"A World Out of Balance\" details how many aspects of 'modern'\nlife must change if we are to avoid -- the coming plague.\n.............................................................jw\n\n--\nJack Woodall, Ph.D., Director, FAS ProMED-mail\nNew York State Dept.of Health, Albany NY, USA\ne-mail: woodall@wadsworth.org\nhttp://www.fas.org/promed/\nhttp://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html\nhttp://www.outbreak.org/cgi-outbreak-unreg/credits.html#jack\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-04-27 00:00:00", "1997-04-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "1997-04-20 00:00:00", "2021-04-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-04-27 00:00:00", "2021-04-28 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New York State Dept.of Health", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Albany", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2190526", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague - India 1994: economic loss", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2190526", "date": "1996-01-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "Date: Fri, 5 Jan 1996 14:13:20 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: \"David W. Swim\" <dwswim@cais.com>\nvia: Brasil Net <bras-net@psg.com>\nCATERPILLAR PLAGUE - BRAZIL\n===========================\nSubject: \"Killer caterpillars return to southern Brazil\"\nSAO PAULO, Jan 5 (ex Reuter) - Apparently, caterpillars are spreading\nfear in southern Brazil, where 20 people have been taken to hospital\nrecently after touching them, authorities said on Friday.\nThe caterpillars, which secrete a potent venom through their skin,\nhave killed nine people over the past two years, Celso Bernardon,\na public health official, informed Reuters. A public awareness\nprogramme has been initiated in Santa Catarina.\nContact with the venom causes a burning sensation and spotting on the\nskin. If left untreated, it can lead to high fever, bleeding from the\nnose and ears, kidney failure and death, said Luis Dalla Costa, a doctor\nin the Santa Catarina city of Chapeco. Since December, 20 people have\nbeen treated in hospital after contact with the caterpillars, Costa said.\nIn most cases, unsuspecting victims grab a tree trunk or another\nobject where the caterpillar rests. But authorities are concerned that\nchildren, attracted by the greenish worm-like creature, might become\ncurious and want to feel it. It grows to a length of two inches (5 cms).\nIt is appears every year from December to March. The pupal and adult\nforms are harmless.\nOnce just a rural phenomenon, the caterpillars this year are migrating\ninto urban centres, turning up on porches and in the fruit trees of\nsuburban gardens. This apparent increase is being blamed on the excessive\nuse of toxic fertiliser killing the caterpillars' normal predators.\nDavid W. SWIM\n<dwswim@cais.com>\nWestgate - McLean - Fairfax - Virginia - United States of America\nhttp://members.aol.com/dwswim/index.html\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1996-01-05 00:00:00", "2021-01-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-12-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Santa Catarina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fairfax", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2187703", "headline": "PROMED-AHEAD: Caterpillar plague - Brazil (2)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2187703", "date": "1996-01-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "Date: Fri, 5 Jan 1996 14:13:20 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: \"David W. Swim\" <dwswim@cais.com>\nvia: Brasil Net <bras-net@psg.com>\nCATERPILLAR PLAGUE - BRAZIL\n===========================\nSubject: \"Killer caterpillars return to southern Brazil\"\nSAO PAULO, Jan 5 (ex Reuter) - Apparently, caterpillars are spreading\nfear in southern Brazil, where 20 people have been taken to hospital\nrecently after touching them, authorities said on Friday.\nThe caterpillars, which secrete a potent venom through their skin,\nhave killed nine people over the past two years, Celso Bernardon,\na public health official, informed Reuters. A public awareness\nprogramme has been initiated in Santa Catarina.\nContact with the venom causes a burning sensation and spotting on the\nskin. If left untreated, it can lead to high fever, bleeding from the\nnose and ears, kidney failure and death, said Luis Dalla Costa, a doctor\nin the Santa Catarina city of Chapeco. Since December, 20 people have\nbeen treated in hospital after contact with the caterpillars, Costa said.\nIn most cases, unsuspecting victims grab a tree trunk or another\nobject where the caterpillar rests. But authorities are concerned that\nchildren, attracted by the greenish worm-like creature, might become\ncurious and want to feel it. It grows to a length of two inches (5 cms).\nIt is appears every year from December to March. The pupal and adult\nforms are harmless.\nOnce just a rural phenomenon, the caterpillars this year are migrating\ninto urban centres, turning up on porches and in the fruit trees of\nsuburban gardens. This apparent increase is being blamed on the excessive\nuse of toxic fertiliser killing the caterpillars' normal predators.\nDavid W. SWIM\n<dwswim@cais.com>\nWestgate - McLean - Fairfax - Virginia - United States of America\nhttp://members.aol.com/dwswim/index.html\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
